         <tei:p>M</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BRITISH MUSEUM<tei:lb/>(NATURAL HiSi</tei:p>
         <tei:p>26 JU</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PRESENTED<tei:lb/>GENERAL UC.-lARY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bulletin of the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The ichneumon-fly genus Banchus<tei:lb/>(Hymenoptera) in the Old World</tei:p>
         <tei:p>M. G. Fitton</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Entomology series</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vol51 Nol 25 July 1985</tei:p>
         <tei:p/>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>The Bulletin of the British Museum (Natural History), instituted in 1949, is issued in four<tei:lb/>scientific series, Botany, Entomology, Geology (incorporating Mineralogy) and Zoology,<tei:lb/>and an Historical series.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Papers in the Bulletin are primarily the results of research carried out on the unique and<tei:lb/>ever-growing collections of the Museum, both by the scientific staff of the Museum and by<tei:lb/>specialists from elsewhere who make use of the Museum's resources. Many of the papers are<tei:lb/>works of reference that will remain indispensable for years to come.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Parts are published at irregular intervals as they become ready, each is complete in itself,<tei:lb/>available separately, and individually priced. Volumes contain about 300 pages and several<tei:lb/>volumes may appear within a calendar year. Subscriptions may be placed for one or more of<tei:lb/>the series on either an Annual or Per Volume basis. Prices vary according to the contents of<tei:lb/>the individual parts. Orders and enquiries should be sent to:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Publications Sales,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History),<tei:lb/>Cromwell Road,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>London SW75BD,<tei:lb/>England.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>'<tei:lb/>World List abbreviation: Bull. Br. Mus. nat. Hist. (Ent.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trustees of the British Museum (Natural History), 1985</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Entomology series is produced under the general editorship of the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Keeper of Entomology: Laurence A. Mound</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Assistant Editor: W. Gerald Tremewan</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ISBN 565 06011 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ISSN 0524-6431 Entomology series</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vol 51 No 1 pp 1-60<tei:lb/>British Museum (Natural History)<tei:lb/>Cromwell Road<tei:lb/>London SW7 5BD Issued 25 July 1985</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>BRITISH MU:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The ichneumon-fly genus Banchus (Hymenoptera) in<tei:lb/>the Old World -^1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>M. G. Fitton</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Department of Entomology, British Museum (Natural History), Cromwell Road, London<tei:lb/>SW7 5BD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Contents</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synopsis 1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction 1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banchus Fabricius 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Taxonomy 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Biology and hosts 5</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Systematic list of hosts 6</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nomenclatural summary 7</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Format, material examined and depositories 8</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Keys to species 11</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Males 11</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Females 12</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Systematic section 14</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Species excluded from Banchus 43</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acknowledgements 45</tei:p>
         <tei:p>References 45</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Index 59</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synopsis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This paper provides the first comprehensive account of the genus Banchus (Ichneumonidae, Banchinae) in<tei:lb/>the Old World. Twenty-three species are recognized, described and keyed. Seven of the species are new.<tei:lb/>Geographical distributions and data on biology and hosts are summarized. Known hosts are Lepidoptera<tei:lb/>(mainly of the family Noctuidae) and Banchus species are known to play an important role in the control of<tei:lb/>some pest species in Europe and North America. The taxonomic treatment includes 11 new synonymies,<tei:lb/>one provisional synonymy, three new combinations, one revised combination, two revised statuses, three<tei:lb/>lectotype designations and four nomina dubia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banchus has had a chequered history. Taxonomists found it difficult to assign to one of the five<tei:lb/>traditional subfamilies of the Ichneumonidae, sometimes placing it in the Ophioninae and<tei:lb/>sometimes in the Pimplinae. As originally defined by Fabricius (1798; 1804) the genus included<tei:lb/>members of the families Braconidae, Cephidae, Pompilidae, Proctotrupidae and Ibaliidae, as<tei:lb/>well as the Ichneumonidae. This exotic assortment was reduced by Gravenhorst (1829) to a<tei:lb/>grouping resembling the genus as understood at present. The main error in his treatment was the<tei:lb/>transposition of the sexes. Developments in the following 150 years were mainly concerned with<tei:lb/>description of new species, splitting the genus and faunistic studies. Much of this work was of<tei:lb/>poor quality; no one made a comprehensive study and those describing and keying species failed<tei:lb/>to appreciate all but the most superficial characters. A real advance in our understanding of the<tei:lb/>taxonomy of Banchus came only with publication of the revision of the Nearctic species by<tei:lb/>Townes &amp; Townes in 1978.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bull. Br. Mus. nat. Hist. (Ent.) 51 (1): 1-60 Issued 25 July 1985</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>M. G. FITTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I<tei:lb/>8</tei:p>
         <tei:p>E</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ICHNEUMON-FLY GENUS BANCHUS 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BANCHUSFabridus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banchus Fabricius, 1798: 209, 233. Type-species: Banchus pictus Fabricius, by subsequent designation<tei:lb/>(Curtis, 1836: 588).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Corynephanus Wesmael, 1849: 631. Type-species: Banchus monileatus Gravenhorst, by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cidaphurus Foerster, 1869: 159. Type-species: Ichneumon volutatorius Linnaeus, by subsequent mono-<tei:lb/>typy (Woldstedt, 1877: 439).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nawaia Ashmead, 1906: 184. Type-species: Nawaia japoni ca Ashmead, by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. Moderately-built ichneumonids (Fig. 1), fore wing length 7-7-14-3 mm. Frons simple. Margin<tei:lb/>of clypeus with a median notch. Genal carina joining hypostomal carina above base of mandible. Upper<tei:lb/>tooth of mandible much wider than lower tooth and longer, its apex truncate and weakly subdivided.<tei:lb/>Lower tooth pointed. Maxillary palp with segment 4 more or less widened and flattened distally, especially<tei:lb/>in males. Labium not elongate. Antennal flagellum long, tapered to a slender apex. In males, flagellum<tei:lb/>with poorly- to well-developed specialized setae (flag setae), 2 to 4 per segment, often arising from a<tei:lb/>poorly- to well-marked, shallow trough on the dorsal surface. Epicnemial carina absent. Scutellum<tei:lb/>produced posteriorly into a spine, although it is sometimes reduced to a very weak tubercle or even absent.<tei:lb/>Propodeum short, its posterior transverse carina strong laterally, weak or obsolete medially. Pleural carina<tei:lb/>present, at least in part. Tarsal claws pectinate. Laterotergites of segments 2 and 3 of gaster about 0-7 times<tei:lb/>as deep as long. Gaster more or less compressed, relatively strongly so in most females. Ovipositor very<tei:lb/>short, its sheath about 0-1 times as long as hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The genus comprises 47 valid, described species. One is Holarctic in distribution, a<tei:lb/>further 24 occur in the Nearctic (Townes &amp; Townes, 1978) and another 22 are found in the<tei:lb/>Palaearctic and the mountains of the Oriental region.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banchus is the largest of a group of five genera united by the structure of the mandible. The<tei:lb/>mandible is of an unusual, almost tridentate form unlikely to have arisen more than once within<tei:lb/>the Banchinae. A mandible similar in structure is found only in the Diplazontinae (in which<tei:lb/>subfamily it occurs in all species). The other genera in the Banchus-group are: Rhynchoban-<tei:lb/>chus (with 3, possibly 4, Palaearctic species); Banchopsis (1 Palaearctic and 1 Oriental species);<tei:lb/>Ceratogastra (1 Palaearctic and 1 Nearctic species) and; Philogalleria (7 Australian species and 1<tei:lb/>species in Argentina which possibly deserves a separate genus). Within this group the most<tei:lb/>important discriminant characters are the form of the claws, the presence or absence of the<tei:lb/>epicnemial carina, the extent of the propodeal carinae, the form of the frons, the position of<tei:lb/>cross- vein 2m-cu in the fore wing, and the relative sizes of the coxae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The tribe Banchini, as currently recognized (Townes, 1970: 45; Townes &amp; Townes, 1978:<tei:lb/>378), includes two disparate elements- the Banchus-group of genera and Exetastes and its allies.<tei:lb/>Cushman (1937), Perkins (in Beirne, 1941) and Beirne (1941) all supported separation of the<tei:lb/>two groups on the basis of adult and larval characters. Cushman and Perkins associated the<tei:lb/>Exetastes-gioup more closely with the tribe Lissonotini. Townes (1944) on the other hand linked<tei:lb/>the two groups as the Banchini, separate from the Lissonotini, mainly on the basis of a rather<tei:lb/>weak character in the hind wing venation. Townes has consistently maintained this position.<tei:lb/>Viktorov (1967) supported Cushman's (1937) conclusion, citing several characters of Exetastes<tei:lb/>which distinguish it from the Banchus-group. Aubert (1978) has gone further, placing Exetastes<tei:lb/>in a tribe of its own, Exetastini. As with many ichneumonid subfamilies the generic and tribal<tei:lb/>classification of the Banchinae, although workable, is in need of closer study. Townes' (1970)<tei:lb/>treatment and key fail to take account of the structure of the mandible in Philogalleria (of which<tei:lb/>Townes may have then seen only one specimen).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Taxonomy</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Despite its long period of gestation this study, based on the examination of 3421 specimens of<tei:lb/>Old World Banchus, cannot be regarded as definitive. It has raised as many taxonomic questions<tei:lb/>as it has answered. The lack of specimens from some problem areas (taxonomic as well as<tei:lb/>geographic), coupled with an inadequate knowledge of most aspects of the biology of the genus,<tei:lb/>has effectively prevented discrimination of all of the species. A conservative approach was<tei:lb/>adopted and some of the morphospecies recognized undoubtedly comprise complexes of two or</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>4 M. G. FITTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>more 'biological' species. With the material and resources available further splitting could not be<tei:lb/>justified on scientific grounds.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Apart from obvious species-pairs or very small groups it is difficult to deduce anything of the<tei:lb/>phylogenetic relationships of the species within the genus. As noted by Townes &amp; Townes<tei:lb/>(1978) in their revision of North American Banchus, the characters which distinguish species do<tei:lb/>not correlate in ways which indicate clear-cut species-groups. Specialization by reduction (an<tei:lb/>obvious example is in the length of the scutellar spine) is probably one of the complicating<tei:lb/>factors. The best that can be done is to suggest trends of specialization for individual characters.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Many species show considerable sexual dimorphism (including colour patterns). The most<tei:lb/>obvious morphological differences are in the shape of the gaster , the antennae and the maxillary<tei:lb/>palps. The specializations in the female seem to be associated with oviposition and in the male<tei:lb/>with mate-finding and courtship. In some species the overall colour pattern is the same in male<tei:lb/>and female, in others it is completely different, for example, in B. falcatorius and B. volutatorius<tei:lb/>the females are largely black with reddish legs while the males are conspicuously marked with<tei:lb/>yellow. This female colour pattern, although still aposematic, probably renders her less<tei:lb/>conspicuous while searching for hosts (which, in B. falcatorius, probably occurs very low in the<tei:lb/>vegetation at soil level). As a general rule males have a yellowish face with a median black stripe<tei:lb/>and females a black face, sometimes with yellowish orbital marks, and there are often also<tei:lb/>differences in the colour of the antennae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The characters which have been used in this study are discussed below. The formal<tei:lb/>descriptions of species in the systematic section of the paper are restricted largely to the<tei:lb/>characters used in the keys. When comparing specimens with figures allowance should be made<tei:lb/>for some variation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head. The overall shape of the head is important in distinguishing species. The characters<tei:lb/>most easily used are the relative width of the face and the size of the malar space. These are<tei:lb/>measured as indicated in Figs 2 and 3. The shape of the head behind the eyes varies between<tei:lb/>species but is much more difficult to use as a distinguishing character. The maxillary palps are<tei:lb/>specialized in many species (Figs 11-32, 103-123). The relative lengths of the two terminal<tei:lb/>segments are important and in males the way in which the fourth segment is widened and<tei:lb/>flattened is characteristic. The antennae vary in length and in the shape of the terminal<tei:lb/>segments, both characters being difficult to use in keys.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the male the distal half of the antenna bears specialized setae ('flag setae') on its dorsal<tei:lb/>surface (Figs 124-129). The development of these varies greatly between species. In the most<tei:lb/>primitive cases the setae are not easily distinguished from others on the antenna. In the most<tei:lb/>specialized forms the setae (two, three or four per segment) are erect, widened and flattened and<tei:lb/>arise from a shallow polished trough. All segments do not bear these setae, there is a zone (which<tei:lb/>varies in position between species) in which they are best developed and proximally and distally<tei:lb/>to this the setae become progressively less modified. The descriptions given for each species<tei:lb/>apply only to the zone bearing the most modified setae. The shape and number per segment are<tei:lb/>subject to some variation, but together with the form of the male maxillary palps these setae give<tei:lb/>the best 'key' characters for a species. Both are probably important in courtship.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thorax and propodeum. The scutellum bears a spine on its posterior apex (Figs 33-58). The<tei:lb/>primitive condition, it is supposed, is to have a well-developed spine. The length of the spine is<tei:lb/>impossible to measure accurately because of the lack of reference points, and there is variation<tei:lb/>within species. Nonetheless it is still useful taxonomically. The lower postero-lateral corners of<tei:lb/>the mesothorax in some species are formed into weak tubercles which, although relatively<tei:lb/>constant in their development, are difficult to use comparatively. In the descriptions the<tei:lb/>'posterior part of the propodeum' refers to the posterior transverse carina and the area behind<tei:lb/>and enclosed by it. The posterior transverse carina itself is often obsolete or absent medially.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The measured proportions of the hind femur (as shown in Fig. 5) are used to represent the<tei:lb/>general proportions of the legs as a whole. The length of the fore wing (measured from the tip of<tei:lb/>the tegula to the tip of the wing) is used as a measure of overall size.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gaster. The form of the gaster in the female offers a number of very useful characters.<tei:lb/>However, their practical value is much reduced by the very variable amounts of distortion found</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ICHNEUMON-FLY GENUS BANCHUS 5</tei:p>
         <tei:p>in dry specimens. Allowance must be made for this in comparing specimens with descriptions<tei:lb/>and figures, particularly those of the apex of the gaster (Figs 82-102). The distortion most affects<tei:lb/>the amount of compression of the posterior half of the gaster, the telescoping of segments and<tei:lb/>the compression and profile of sternite 6 (the subgenital plate) which in some species has a<tei:lb/>weaker, less sclerotised portion on its posterior margin. The form of tergite 1 is not subject to<tei:lb/>distortion and it offers useful characters in males and females (Figs 59-81), although subject to<tei:lb/>some variation (compare Figs 65 and 66 of male and female gudrunae). The proportions of<tei:lb/>tergite 1 are measured as indicated in Fig. 4.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sculpture and colour. The development of microsculpture and puncturation on the thorax,<tei:lb/>coxae and gaster varies between species but variation within species and difficulties of descrip-<tei:lb/>tion limit its value. Colour patterns are subject to variation but are easily observed. Care was<tei:lb/>taken to ensure that such variation was taken into account in construction of those parts of the<tei:lb/>keys relying on colour.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Biology and hosts</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Townes &amp; Townes (1978) state that Banchus is a genus of open shrubby country and that females<tei:lb/>fly rather low and males higher and faster. However, there are few published observations on the<tei:lb/>habits and habitats of individual species. Adults have been collected from flowers. The black and<tei:lb/>yellow and/or reddish colour patterns may be aposematic (Townes &amp; Townes note that<tei:lb/>specimens give off a strong pungent odour when captured). B. falcatorius has been recorded as<tei:lb/>the prey of an asilid fly.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Most species probably are univoltine and adults are on the wing for some period during late<tei:lb/>spring or early summer. A few species (e.g. B. dilatatorius) occur in early spring. These probably<tei:lb/>pass the winter as adults or pharate adults within the cocoon. In Europe three species (B.<tei:lb/>zonatus, B. gudrunae and B. moppiti) have been taken in late autumn, winter and early spring.<tei:lb/>Of these three, B. zonatus and B. gudrunae are Mediterranean in distribution whilst the few<tei:lb/>known specimens of B. moppiti come from localities as scattered as Great Britain, Switzerland<tei:lb/>and Spain. There appears to be a similar pattern in the species in the eastern Palaearctic and<tei:lb/>mountains of the Oriental region, with some specimens of the more southern species occurring<tei:lb/>in the period from October to May. However, some of these species might not be univoltine.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Courtship behaviour in B. hastator is described by van Veen (1982): when the male<tei:lb/>encounters a female he orientates himself face to face and starts fanning with his wings, probably<tei:lb/>creating an airstream along the female and himself. The gaster of the male is also raised and at<tei:lb/>intervals these actions are interrupted by an attempt to mount the female. Using the tips of the<tei:lb/>antennae the male gently strokes the legs and sides of the thorax of the female. If the female is<tei:lb/>receptive copulation takes place.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The hosts of Banchus are Lepidoptera. All of the reliable observations relate to species of<tei:lb/>Noctuidae, though species of seven other lepidopterous families are also recorded. Whether or<tei:lb/>not any or all of the non-noctuid records should be rejected is difficult to assess. In the Nearctic<tei:lb/>species B. flavescens it has been shown that females oviposited readily in the larvae of its usual<tei:lb/>host Mamestra configurata Walker and also in Scotogramma trifolii (Rottemburg) and Tricho-<tei:lb/>plusia ni (Hiibner) , but had to be induced to attack A utographa calif ornica (Speyer) , A . falcifera<tei:lb/>(Kirby) and Heliothis ononis (Denis &amp; Schiffermuller) by an immediately preceding exposure to<tei:lb/>M. configurata larvae (Arthur &amp; Ewen, 1975; Ewen &amp; Arthur, 1976). All these hosts are<tei:lb/>noctuids and in addition to the reluctance of the females to oviposit in some species the parasite<tei:lb/>failed to develop in any except M. configurata, because of successful host defence reactions. Van<tei:lb/>Veen (1982), working with B. hastator in the Netherlands, found 'that an antennal contact of a<tei:lb/>few strokes with the cuticle of the host's skin was sufficient to reject a strange host by walking<tei:lb/>away or to a susceptible instar of Pfanolis] flammea [the usual host] immediately by an acute<tei:lb/>sting reaction'. He unfortunately does not identify the 'strange host'. All these results could be<tei:lb/>used to support a contention that Banchus species are probably monophagous on species of<tei:lb/>Noctuidae, but for one species, B. volutatorius , there are reliable rearings from at least three<tei:lb/>noctuid species (Anarta myrtilli (Linnaeus), Lacanobia oleracea (Linnaeus) and Xestia xanth-</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>6 M. G. FITTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ographa (Denis &amp; Schiffermiiller)), so judgement must be reserved. The host records from two<tei:lb/>Hymenoptera (Maneval, 1935) can probably be dismissed out of hand.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The larvae normally develop as solitary internal parasites and it is usually suggested that<tei:lb/>oviposition is into an early instar host larva. In experiments, van Veen (1982) has demonstrated<tei:lb/>a preference for early instar larvae in B. hastator, although females will attack all larval instars<tei:lb/>except the last (the fifth) (van Veen, 1982; Bledowski &amp; Krainska, 1926). The larval develop-<tei:lb/>ment of B. hastator was studied in detail by Bledowski &amp; Krainska (1926). The head sclerites of<tei:lb/>the final larval instar of four species are illustrated by Short (1978). Short's work should be used<tei:lb/>with caution: his figures of Banchus show why. The illustrations of B. femoralis and B. hastator<tei:lb/>show differences which might be thought significant; however, both specimens are of the same<tei:lb/>species (B. hastator, of which femoralis is a synonym) and one figure shows the view from outside<tei:lb/>the head capsule while the other shows the view from within! Other figures are given by Beirne<tei:lb/>(1941) and Barron (1976).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The full-grown Banchus larva kills and leaves the host larva after it has left its foodplant and<tei:lb/>entered the soil to pupate (this has been reported in several species). Cocoons of Banchus are<tei:lb/>elongate-ovoid, the silk dense and almost black. The adult emerges through a hole cut next to<tei:lb/>one end.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Barron (1976) records a species of Banchus (from Maryland) parasitized by Euceros medialis<tei:lb/>Cresson (Hymenoptera: Ichneumonidae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Systematic list of hosts</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The list below includes all the hosts of Banchus detailed elsewhere in this paper. Those details<tei:lb/>can be accessed via the index.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>LEPIDOPTERA</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Format, material examined and depositories</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the systematic section the species are arranged in alphabetical order. For each (except<tei:lb/>altaiensis) information is under the following headings.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synonymy. When types have not been available for study (because of loss or destruction or<tei:lb/>because they could not be obtained on loan) the inclusion of a nominal species in a synonymy is<tei:lb/>based on consideration of the original description and/or it is substantiated by reference to a<tei:lb/>published treatment or is considered more fully under 'Nomenclature'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nomenclature. This includes discussion of synonymies, type-restrictions, etc. It takes up a<tei:lb/>considerable amount of space (and it took up a lot of time) because the nomenclatural problems</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ICHNEUMON-FLY GENUS BANCHUS 9</tei:p>
         <tei:p>associated with work on European species are related to human historical and sociological<tei:lb/>factors rather than biological ones.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Description. The descriptions for females and males are separate. The characters included are<tei:lb/>mainly those used in the keys, the ones which apply equally to both sexes are given for the female<tei:lb/>only (except where the female is not known). The characters, including details of measure-<tei:lb/>ments, are discussed in the 'Taxonomy' section above.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Remarks. These include brief notes on recognition and relationships of the species and<tei:lb/>discussion of its taxonomy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Biology and hosts. This is a brief summary based on data associated with material examined<tei:lb/>and information gleaned from the literature. Names of hosts have been up-dated to conform<tei:lb/>with current usage.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Distribution. As given this is based entirely on data taken from specimens examined, as are<tei:lb/>the distribution maps. Map 1 shows the distribution of the genus (that is, the combined<tei:lb/>distributions of all the species) in the Old World for comparison with the distributions of<tei:lb/>individual species (Maps 2-11). The records in the literature are not reliable and only a few<tei:lb/>references are made to them (Aubert (1978) should be consulted for more details of these).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Material examined. Except for new species and those known from only a few specimens, the<tei:lb/>data under 'material examined' are restricted to totals of specimens, the names of countries (and</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Map 1 Distribution of Banchus in the Old World.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>10 M. G. FITTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>larger islands) from which they come and the depositories in which they are to be found. All<tei:lb/>specimens on which this revision is based bear my determination labels. Some detail of collecting<tei:lb/>localities is presented in the distribution maps for each species. However, a feature of much<tei:lb/>European material is inadequate locality data on labels and there are no points on the maps for<tei:lb/>perhaps a third of all the specimens examined. Dates of collection are also often lacking; for<tei:lb/>instance, in an attempt to relate morphological to seasonal variation in Banchus pictus only 90 of<tei:lb/>the 184 specimens to hand could be utilized because the rest had no date of collection.<tei:lb/>The names of depositories are abbreviated as in the list below.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>ICHNEUMON-FLY GENUS BANCHUS 11</tei:p>
         <tei:p>UZM Universitetets Zoologisk Museum, Copenhagen, Denmark</tei:p>
         <tei:p>VRC Collection of G. van Rossem, Ede, Netherlands</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Keys to species</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The keys to females and males are separate. Sexing specimens of Banchus is not always<tei:lb/>straightforward. The short, broad ovipositor sheaths are sometimes mistaken for the male<tei:lb/>genitalia. The most reliable way to sex specimens is to examine the last visible tergites and<tei:lb/>sternites of the gaster: in females they are relatively long (Figs 6-10) and in males they are short<tei:lb/>(Fig. 1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Males (the males of cerinus and insulanus are unknown)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Maxillary palp (Figs 104, 114) with segment 5 less than 0-2 as long as segment 4; segment 4 long</tei:p>
         <tei:p>and cylindrical , with only its extreme apex sharply expanded and flattened 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Maxillary palp (Figs 103, 105-113, 115-123) with segment 5 more than 0-4 as long as segment 4;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>segment 4 gradually and evenly widened and flattened from base to apex or more sharply<tei:lb/>expanded from near base 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Hind femur less than 6-2 times as long as deep; entirely reddish yellow in colour. Gaster usually</tei:p>
         <tei:p>entirely black, the segments sometimes brownish or yellowish on their posterior margins,<tei:lb/>very rarely as conspicuous yellow bands on tergites 1, 2 and 3. Scutellar spine usually long<tei:lb/>(more than 0-8 as long as scutellum) (Fig. 47) palpalis Ruthe (p. 30)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Hind femur more than 6-5 times as long as deep; black, yellow proximally and distally and</tei:p>
         <tei:p>sometimes dorsally. Gaster with each segment black anteriorly and yellow posteriorly.<tei:lb/>Scutellar spine short (about 0-3 as long as scutellum) (Fig. 34) crefeldensis Ulbricht (p. 15)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Antennal flag setae well developed (Figs 126-129): upright, flattened, 2 or 3 (rarely 4) per</tei:p>
         <tei:p>segment, arising from a more or less well-defined and polished trough 4</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Antennal flag setae not or only poorly differentiated (as in Fig. 124, or at most as in Fig. 125 but</tei:p>
         <tei:p>shorter): at 60 degrees or less to the segment surface, not flattened, 2 per segment, never<tei:lb/>arising from a trough 17</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4 Antennal flag setae 3 (occasionally 4) per segment (Fig. 129)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Antennal flag setae 2 per segment (Figs 126-128) (very rarely a few segments with 3 setae)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5 Scutellar spine long (about 0-8 as long as scutellum) (Fig. 44) mauricettae sp. n. (p. 28)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Scutellar spine short (about 0-3 as long as scutellum) to absent (Figs 33, 37, 38) 6</tei:p>
         <tei:p>6 Hind femur less than 5-3 times as long as deep, usually entirely reddish yellow in colour but can</tei:p>
         <tei:p>be darkened medially. Malar space more than 0-6 times basal width of mandible</tei:p>
         <tei:p>falcatorius (Fabricius) (p. 19)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Hind femur about 6 1 times as long as deep , yellow in colour with the median part black . Malar</tei:p>
         <tei:p>space about 0-5 times basal width of mandible agathae sp. n. (p. 14)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>7 Tergite 1 of gaster at least 2-1 times as long as broad</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tergite 1 of gaster at most 2-0 times as long as broad 11</tei:p>
         <tei:p>8 Hind femur at least 7-0 times as long as deep. Tergite 3 of gaster with a crease separating</tei:p>
         <tei:p>laterotergite along its whole length gudrunaesp. n. (p. 23)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hind femur less than 6-5 times as long as deep. Tergite 3 of gaster with a crease separating<tei:lb/>laterotergite on only about its anterior 0-5</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9 Meoscutum shining , with only weak microsculpture between punctures . Scutellar spine at most</tei:p>
         <tei:p>about 0-5 as long as scutellum (Fig. 39) ffavomaculatus (Cameron) (p. 23)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Mesoscutum not shining, with well-developed microsculpture between punctures. Scutellar</tei:p>
         <tei:p>spine at least about 0-7 as long as scutellum (Figs 46, 52)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>10 Hind femur about 6-0 times as long as deep. Antennal flagellum black with underside of<tei:lb/>segment 1 and distal section reddish yellow. Segments of gaster each black anteriorly and<tei:lb/>yellow posteriorly , with j unction of the two areas reddish nox Morley (p . 30)</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>12 M. G. FITTON</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Systematic section</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hunch us agathae sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 11, 33, 59, 82, 103)<tei:lb/>[Banchus pictus Fabricius; Bischoff, 1930: 225. Misidentification (and wrong sex).]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Female. Width of lower face 0-90 times vertical length of eye. Malar space 0-60 times basal<tei:lb/>width of mandible. Maxillary palp as in Fig. 11. Antenna with apical segments as long as broad. Scutellar<tei:lb/>spine (Fig. 33) about 0-3 as long as scutellum. Mesopleuron and mesoscutum shining, only very weakly<tei:lb/>sculptured, with strong punctures, on the mesopleuron separated by much less than their diameter. Hind<tei:lb/>femur 5-40 times as long as deep. Fore wing length 10-1 mm. Tergite 1 of gaster 2-00 times as long as broad,<tei:lb/>its dorsal profile as in Fig. 59. Gaster compressed from the posterior of segment 3, reaching just beyond the<tei:lb/>tips of the fore wings (when folded back). Tergite 3 with a crease along its anterior 0-5 separating<tei:lb/>laterotergite. Tergite 7 and sternite 6 as in Fig. 82.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour: black and yellow. Face yellow with a median black stripe. Antenna black with scape and pedicel<tei:lb/>yellow ventrally. Maxillary palp yellowish with dark marks, including distal 0-7 of segment 4 and all of<tei:lb/>segment 5. Posterior part of propodeum yellow, narrowly black posteriorly. Hind coxa black with a yellow<tei:lb/>dorsal patch and distal margin narrowly yellow. Hind femur black, yellow proximally and distally.<tei:lb/>Segments of gaster each black anteriorly, very narrowly yellow posteriorly.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Width of lower face 0-90 times vertical length of eye. Malar space 0-45 times basal width of<tei:lb/>mandible. Maxillary palp as in Fig. 103; segment 4 flattened and considerably widened; segment 5 about<tei:lb/>0-7 as long as 4. Antennal flag setae (similar to Fig. 129, but the setae only about half as long) upright, short,<tei:lb/>flattened, 3 per segment, arising from a polished trough. Hind femur 6-10 times as long as deep. Fore wing</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ICHNEUMON-FLY GENUS BANCHUS 15</tei:p>
         <tei:p>length 8-5 mm. Tergite 1 of gaster 1-80 times as long as broad. Tergite 3 with a crease along its anterior 0-5<tei:lb/>separating the laterotergite.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour: black and yellow. Antenna black with scape, pedicel and proximal and distal parts of flagellum<tei:lb/>yellow ventrally. Maxillary palp with segments 1 yellowish, 2 and 3 reddish, 4 and 5 blackish. Posterior part<tei:lb/>of propodeum yellow, narrowly black posteriorly. Hind coxa black with a yellow dorsal spot and narrow<tei:lb/>postero-ventral margin. Hind femur yellow, black medially. Segments of gaster each black anteriorly,<tei:lb/>yellow posteriorly.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The male should be readily recognized by the form of the antennal flag setae. The female is<tei:lb/>keyed to a large extent on colour characters but the form of the posterior part of the gaster is also<tei:lb/>important.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY AND HOSTS. Unknown. The specimens were taken in July and August.<tei:lb/>DISTRIBUTION (Map 2, p. 16). Known from only two specimens collected in the Pamir.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , U.S.S.R.: Pamir, Umss-Tugai, 25.vii.1928 (Rickmers) (ZSBS).<tei:lb/>Paratype $, U.S.S.R.: Pamir, Maz, 3580 m, 15.viii.1928 (Reinig) (MNHU).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banchus altaiensis Meyer nomen dubium<tei:lb/>Banchus altaiensis Meyer, 19276: 295. Type(s) cf , U.S.S.R. (destroyed).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This species was described from material, probably only one specimen, collected in the Altai mountains.<tei:lb/>The description does not fit adequately any of the species from Central Asia known to me and I hesitate to<tei:lb/>identify it with any species not proven to occur there. Its identification will have to wait until more extensive<tei:lb/>collections have been made in the area.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banchus cerinus Chandra &amp; Gupta</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 6, 12)<tei:lb/>Banchus cerinus Chandra &amp; Gupta, 1977: 185. Holotype $, INDIA (GC) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Female. Width of lower face 0-85 times vertical length of eye. Maxillary palp as in Fig. 12.<tei:lb/>Antenna with apical segments longer than broad. Scutellar spine of moderate length. Mesopleuron and<tei:lb/>mesoscutum weakly coriaceous, with dense, fairly small punctures. Hind femur 6-25 times as long as deep.<tei:lb/>Fore wing length 14-3 mm. Tergite 1 of gaster 2-75 times as long as broad, its dorsal profile as in Fig. 6.<tei:lb/>Gaster subcylindrical, only weakly compressed posteriorly, not reaching to tips of fore wings (when folded<tei:lb/>back). Tergite 3 with a crease along its anterior 0-6 separating laterotergite. Tergite 7 and sternite 6 as in<tei:lb/>Fig. 6.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour: mainly yellow, with black marks. Face yellow with a black mark between and just below<tei:lb/>antennal sockets. Antenna yellow with distal half of flagellum and an externo-lateral mark on pedicel<tei:lb/>blackish. Maxillary palp yellowish. Posterior part of propodeum yellow. Hind coxa yellow, blackish<tei:lb/>distally. Hind femur yellow. Segments of gaster yellow, with basal third of tergites 1,2 and 3 and of sternite<tei:lb/>2 black.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. A pale-coloured species with relatively long appendages. Its closest relatives seem to be tholus<tei:lb/>and tumidus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION (Map 4, p. 20), BIOLOGY AND HOSTS. The species is known only from the holotype, which was<tei:lb/>collected amongst mixed bushes in coniferous forest in the NW. Himalayas (Gupta, 1975: (appendix) 50).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED (1 $)<tei:lb/>India: 1 $ (holotype), Himachal Pradesh, Ahla, 2286 m, 18.vii.1971 (Gulati) (GC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banchus crefeldensis Ulbricht<tei:lb/>(Figs 4, 13,34,60,83,104, 125)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banchus crefeldensis Ulbricht, 1916: 12. Holotype cf, WEST GERMANY (A. Ulbricht coll., Krefeld)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[examined].<tei:lb/>Banchus croaticus Hensch, 1928: 99. Lectotype $, YUGOSLAVIA (ZPZ), designated by Horstmann, 1982a:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>82 [examined].</tei:p>

         <tei:p>M. G. FITTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Map 2 Distribution of Banchus agathae, B. japonicus, B. mauricettae, B. nox, B. sanjozanus, B. tholus<tei:lb/>and B. tumidus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Female. Width of lower face 0-90-1-00 times vertical length of eye. Malar space 0-60-0-75<tei:lb/>times basal width of mandible. Maxillary palp as in Fig. 13. Antenna with apical segments longer than<tei:lb/>broad. Scutellar spine (Fig. 34) about 0-3 as long as scutellum.       </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ICHNEUMON-FLY GENUS BANCHUS 17</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour: black and yellow. Face black with broad yellow orbital stripes and a vertical yellow mark below<tei:lb/>each antennal socket. Antenna entirely black except for a yellow patch on underside of scape, and rarely<tei:lb/>also on pedicel. Maxillary palp blackish with part or all of segment 2 and proximal 0-7 of segments 3 and 4<tei:lb/>reddish yellow. Posterior part of propodeum yellow anteriorly, black posteriorly. Hind coxa black with a<tei:lb/>yellow dorsal patch. Hind femur black, yellow proximally and distally and sometimes dorsally. Segments of<tei:lb/>gaster each black anteriorly and broadly yellow posteriorly.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Width of lower face 0-90-1-00 times vertical length of eye. Malar space 0-55-0-70 times basal<tei:lb/>width of mandible. Maxillary palp as in Fig. 104; segment 4 narrow and cylindrical, flattened and widened<tei:lb/>only at its extreme distal apex; segment 5 less than 0-2 as long as 4. Antennal flag setae (Fig. 125) at about 50<tei:lb/>degrees, not flattened, 2 or 3 per segment, not arising from a trough. Hind femur 6-60-7-65 times as long as<tei:lb/>deep. Fore wing length 9-1-10-8 mm. Tergite 1 of gaster 1-80-2-10 times as long as broad (Fig. 4). Tergite 3<tei:lb/>with a crease along its entire length separating laterotergite.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour: black and yellow. Antenna black, with scape and pedicel yellow ventrally. Maxillary palp<tei:lb/>blackish with segments 2 wholly and 3 and 4 proximally reddish yellow. Posterior part of propodeum black<tei:lb/>with a variable amount of yellow anteriorly, ranging from a very broad band along posterior transverse<tei:lb/>carina to a small median spot to absent entirely. Hind coxa black, usually with a yellow dorsal patch. Hind<tei:lb/>femur black, yellow proximally and distally and sometimes dorsally. Segments of gaster each black<tei:lb/>anteriorly, yellow posteriorly (on at least tergites 2 and 3 relatively broadly so).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Like the related B. palpalis, this is a very distinctive species; it is readily recognized by the<tei:lb/>structure of the maxillary palps and its coloration.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY AND HOSTS. Dates of collection range from mid-February (in Spain and Portugal) to mid-May (in<tei:lb/>Scotland and Ireland). Stelfox (1936: 63) records males flying in numbers round ivy (Hedera helix) and<tei:lb/>gorse (Ulex europaeus) in Ireland. Specimen labels indicate capture of males on Betula and around Buxus<tei:lb/>and females from pine.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I have seen 11 reared specimens, 3 without a satisfactory host identification, the remaining 8 (including<tei:lb/>both sexes) fromAporophyla lutulenta (Denis &amp; Schiffermuller) or A. lutulenta 'subspecies' lueneburgensis<tei:lb/>(Freyer) (Noctuidae). The named hosts were collected at Bussum, Netherlands; Aviemore, Great Britain;<tei:lb/>and Bremen and near Hamburg, West Germany.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION (Map 3, p. 18). Widely distributed in Europe but not found in Scandinavia or the U.S.S.R.<tei:lb/>In Great Britain it is restricted to the Scottish Highlands.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED (40 $ , 79 cf )</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Austria, Belgium, France, Great Britain, Hungary, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Portugal, Spain,<tei:lb/>Switzerland, Tunisia, Turkey, West Germany, Yugoslavia (BMNH, FSA, IEE, IRSNB, LELW, MHN,<tei:lb/>MNHN, NM, NMB, NR, RNH, UM, USNM, ZC, ZSBS).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banchus dilatatorius (Thunberg) stat. rev.<tei:lb/>(Figs 2, 14, 35, 36, 61, 84, 105)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ichneumon acuminator Fabricius, 1787: 268. Type(s) cf , EAST GERMANY (lost). [Junior primary homonym</tei:p>
         <tei:p>of Ichneumon acuminator Miiller, 1776: 157.] Syn. n.<tei:lb/>Ichneumon compressus Fabricius, 1787: 381. Holotype $, SWEDEN (UZM) [examined]. [Junior primary</tei:p>
         <tei:p>homonym of Ichneumon compressus Sulzer, 1776: 190.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ichneumon dilatatorius Thunberg, 1822: 279; 1824: 360. Holotype $, GERMANY (UU) [not examined].<tei:lb/>Banchus sibiricus Meyer, 19276: 294. Syntypes $, cf , U.S.S.R. (destroyed). Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>NOMENCLATURE. In most of the literature this species is referred to by the invalid name compressus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although Ichneumon acuminator has been placed previously in Banchus it has never been identified.<tei:lb/>The description fits certain males of dilatatorius if one allows that Fabricius failed to observe the pale colour<tei:lb/>of the underside of the antennae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The description of Banchus sibiricus fits well specimens from Kamchatka (which include those identified<tei:lb/>by Roman (1931: 29) as lavrovi var.) which are considered conspecific with dilatatorius but are discussed<tei:lb/>under 'Remarks' below. The identity of the female from Rumania determined as sibiricus by Constan-<tei:lb/>tineanu &amp; Pisica (1959: 190) is not known.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Female. Width of lower face 1-15-1-25 times vertical length of eye. Malar space 0-80-1-00<tei:lb/>times basal width of mandible (Fig. 2). Maxillary palp as in Fig. 14. Antenna with apical segments about as<tei:lb/>broad as long. Scutellar spine (Figs 35, 36) very small or virtually absent. Mesopleuron and mesoscutum<tei:lb/>coriaceous, with strong punctures, on mesopleuron separated by less than diameter. Hind femur 4-35-4-85</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>M. G. FITTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>o *</tei:p>
         <tei:p>crefeldensis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Map 3 Distribution of Banchus crefeldensis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>times as long as deep. Fore wing length 8-7-11-5 mm. Tergite 1 of gaster 1-30-1-40 times as long as broad,<tei:lb/>its dorsal profile as in Fig. 61. Gaster strongly compressed from posterior of tergite 3, reaching beyond tips<tei:lb/>of fore wings (when folded back). Tergite 3 with a crease along its anterior 0-3 separating laterotergite.<tei:lb/>Tergite 7 and sternite 6 as in Fig. 84.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour: black and yellow (the yellow often rather creamy). Face black with yellow orbital marks.<tei:lb/>Antenna with scape and pedicel black, scape, and usually pedicel, yellowish or reddish ventrally.<tei:lb/>Flagellum yellowish orange, with base of segment 1 and distal segments dark. Maxillary palp blackish,<tei:lb/>entirely or with segments 2 and 3 brownish. Posterior part of propodeum black, entirely or, more usually,<tei:lb/>with a yellow band along posterior transverse carina, the band usually not extensive and narrowly absent<tei:lb/>medially. Hind coxa black. Hind femur black, narrowly yellowish proximally and usually widely yellowish<tei:lb/>distally. Segments of gaster each black anteriorly, yellow posteriorly, the yellow bands usually less than 0-3<tei:lb/>of length of segments.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Width of lower face 1-10-1-25 times vertical length of eye. Malar space 0-85-0-95 times basal<tei:lb/>width of mandible. Maxillary palp as in Fig. 105; segment 4 only slightly flattened and widened distally;<tei:lb/>segment 5 about 0-9 as long as 4. Antennal flag setae (similar to Fig. 126) upright, flattened, relatively<tei:lb/>narrow, 2 per segment, arising from a polished trough. Hind femur 4-35-5-00 times as long as deep. Fore<tei:lb/>wing length 8-6-10-7 mm. Tergite 1 of gaster 1-25-1-55 times as long as broad. Tergite 3 with a crease along<tei:lb/>its anterior 0-3 separating laterotergite.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour: black and yellow. Antenna blackish or brownish dorsally, yellow or yellowish ventrally (except<tei:lb/>for apex of flagellum which is dark). Maxillary palp blackish or brownish. Posterior part of propodeum<tei:lb/>black, entirely or with a yellow band (sometimes broken medially) along posterior transverse carina. Hind<tei:lb/>coxa black. Hind femur yellow with a black mark on interne-lateral and ventral surface, and sometimes<tei:lb/>also dorsally near base. Segments of gaster each black anteriorly, yellow posteriorly, the yellow bands<tei:lb/>usually less than 0-3 of length of segment.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ICHNEUMON-FLY GENUS BANCHUS 19</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species is distinctive and easily identified. The very wide face is a conspicuous feature.<tei:lb/>However, the poor characters used in earlier keys led to confusion with other species in several of the<tei:lb/>collections examined.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The details of colour given in the description above do not apply fully to all of the material examined.<tei:lb/>One female from Iran (AC) has the yellow coloration much more extensive than in any other specimens<tei:lb/>seen. All the specimens from Kamchatka (1 $ (MLSU) and 4 $ , 2 0" (NR)) have yellow absent but with<tei:lb/>reddish in place of the yellow on the legs and on the face of the male, and with the margins of some or all of<tei:lb/>tergites 1, 2 and 3 of the gaster narrowly to broadly reddish brown. Other than in these colour characters<tei:lb/>the Iranian and Kamchatka specimens do not differ much from 'typical' dilatatorius . It is impossible to<tei:lb/>decide whether or not they represent extremes of colour variation or distinct species. Unfortunately the<tei:lb/>character which might enable a decision to be reached, the male flag setae, cannot be investigated. Of the<tei:lb/>two male specimens one lacks the head completely and the other lacks both antennae. The Kamchatka<tei:lb/>specimens match the description of B. sibiricus which was described from Irkutsk (see 'Nomenclature'<tei:lb/>above). The material from Mongolia identified by Momoi (1973: 242-243) as lavrovi might also be this dark<tei:lb/>form of dilatatorius. I could not examine these Mongolian specimens because Momoi has so far failed to<tei:lb/>return them to Budapest (Zombori, pers. comm.). The six specimens in Stockholm (NR) had been<tei:lb/>identified by Roman (1931: 29) as lavrovi var.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY AND HOSTS. This is an early spring species with most records relating to the period from late March<tei:lb/>to late April. The earliest dates of collection (7 and 13 March) come from sand dune areas in the<tei:lb/>Netherlands. The label on one female records that it was found on catkins of Salix caprea. I have seen no<tei:lb/>reared specimens of this species, although the following hosts are recorded in the literature: Blepharita<tei:lb/>adusta (Esper) (Noctuidae) (Bajari, 1960: 260); Euxoa nigricans (Linnaeus) (Noctuidae) (Schmiedek-<tei:lb/>necht, 1910: 1926; Meyer, 1934: 228); Phlogophora meticulosa (Linnaeus) (Noctuidae) (Gyorfi, 1944:<tei:lb/>106); Euproctis similis (Fuessly) (Lymantriidae) (de Gaulle, 1907: 19); and Leucoma salicis (Linnaeus)<tei:lb/>(Lymantriidae) (Leonardi, 1928: 83).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION (Map 4, p. 20). Western and central Europe, mainly north of 50 degrees N. (but with very<tei:lb/>few records from the area bordering the Atlantic (France, the British Isles and Norway) and only a few<tei:lb/>from Denmark and Sweden); the European Alps; and with some scattered records in the western<tei:lb/>U.S.S.R. , north-west Iran and the Soviet Far East (see 'Remarks' above).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED (86 9 , 96 cf)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Austria, Belgium, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, East Germany, Finland, France, Great Britain, Hungary,<tei:lb/>Iran, Italy, Netherlands, Sweden, Switzerland, U.S.S.R., West Germany (AC, BMNH, BRI, HC, IP,<tei:lb/>IRSNB, ITZ, LELW, MNHN, MHN, MIZS, NMB, NR, RNH, SMT, USNM, UZI, UZM, ZC, ZIL,<tei:lb/>ZMU, ZSBS).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banchus falcatorius (Fabricius)<tei:lb/>(Figs 5, 9, 10, 15, 37, 38, 62, 85, 106, 129)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ichneumon falcatorius Fabricius, 1775: 332. Holotype d", DENMARK (UZM) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ichneumon variegator Fabricius, 1775: 339. LECTOTYPE d", SWEDEN (UZM), here designated</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[examined] .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ichneumon intersectus Geoffroy, 1785: 414. Type(s) cf , FRANCE (lost) (Horstmann, 19826: 243).<tei:lb/>Ichneumon aries Christ, 1791: 339. Type(s) $, no type-locality (lost).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ichneumon labiatus Schrank, 1802: 264. Syntypes $ [not cf as stated by Schrank], WEST GERMANY (lost).<tei:lb/>Ichneumon histrio Schrank, 1802: 265. Syntypes cf , WEST GERMANY and FRANCE (lost) (Horstmann,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>19826: 243). [Junior primary homonym of Ichneumon histrio Christ, 1791: 356.]<tei:lb/>Ichneumon tricolor Schrank, 1802: 286. Syntypes cf , WEST GERMANY (lost).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banchus falcator Fabricius, 1804: 128. [Unjustified emendation of Ichneumon falcatorius Fabricius, 1775.]<tei:lb/>CorynephanessachalinensisMatsumura, 1911: 92. Lectotype d" [not $ as stated by Matsumura] , U.S.S.R.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(EIHU), designated by Townes, Momoi &amp; Townes, 1965: 236 [examined].<tei:lb/>Banchus falcatorius var. luteofasciatus Ulbricht, 1911: 151. Type(s) , HUNGARY (?lost).<tei:lb/>Banchus nobilitator Morley, 1915: 138. Holotype $, U.S.S.R. (BMNH) [examined].<tei:lb/>Banchus falcatorius var. sanguinator Meyer, 1922: 139. Holotype d", U.S.S.R. (destroyed).<tei:lb/>Banchus lavrovi Meyer, 19276: 294. Syntypes $, cf, U.S.S.R. (destroyed).<tei:lb/>Banchus falcatorius var. nigromarginatus Constantineanu &amp; Pisica, 1960: 710. Syntypes 3 $, RUMANIA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(?Constantineanu coll.) [not examined].<tei:lb/>Banchus propitius Kuslitzky, 1979: 351. Holotype d", MONGOLIA (ZIL) [not examined]. [Provisional</tei:p>
         <tei:p>synonymy.]</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>M. G. FITTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Map 4 Distribution of Banchus cerinus, B. dilatatorius and B. turcator.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>NOMENCLATURE. Ichneumon labiatus was listed by Dalla Torre (1901: 63) in the synonymy of compressus<tei:lb/>(= dilatatorius). However, as noted by Gravenhorst (1829: 390) the description applies to B. falcatorius.<tei:lb/>Schrank misdetermined the sex of his species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ichneumon tricolor has been synonymised usually with compressus (= dilatatorius) (e.g. Aubert, 1978:<tei:lb/>153). The description and the figure to which Schrank refers (Schaeffer, 1768: pi. 116, fig. 5), differ from<tei:lb/>that species in the coloration of the gaster. However, they fit the male of B. falcatorius and there can be<tei:lb/>little doubt about the identity of the two species. This synonymy was first proposed by Gravenhorst (1829:<tei:lb/>396).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The synonymy of sanguinator might be questioned. I have seen no male of B. falcatorius as red as<tei:lb/>described by Meyer; the most reasonable explanation of the colour is that the specimen had suffered from<tei:lb/>overlong exposure to cyanide in a killing jar.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The description of lavrovi fits specimens from the northern part of the eastern Palaearctic and here<tei:lb/>included in falcatorius . One such specimen determined as lavrovi by Meyer himself has been examined.<tei:lb/>The oldest name applying to this form of falcatorius is nobilitator Morley.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In terms of falcatorius as recognized in this revision (see 'Remarks' below) I have thought it best<tei:lb/>provisionally to synonymize the species, propitius, recently described by Kuslitzky (1979).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Female. Width of lower face 0-95-1-00 times vertical length of eye. Malar space 0-60-0-70<tei:lb/>times basal width of mandible. Maxillary palp as in Fig. 15. Antenna with apical segments just longer than<tei:lb/>broad. Scutellar spine (Fig. 37) minute or absent (but see 'Remarks'). Mesopleuron and mesoscutum</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ICHNEUMON-FLY GENUS BANCHUS 21</tei:p>
         <tei:p>coriaceous, with moderately strong punctures, on mesopleuron separated by less than their diameter. Hind<tei:lb/>femur 4-25^4-70 times as long as deep. Fore wing length 10-1-11-2 mm. Tergite 1 of gaster 1-45-1-70 times<tei:lb/>as long as broad, its dorsal profile as in Fig. 62. Gaster (Figs 9, 10) strongly compressed, reaching beyond<tei:lb/>tips of fore wings (when folded back). Tergite 3 with a crease along its anterior 0-3 separating laterotergite.<tei:lb/>Tergite 7 and sternite 6 as in Fig. 85.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour: mainly black, with legs largely reddish and usually some reddish and very rarely yellow on the<tei:lb/>gaster. Face black, often with very small reddish or yellowish orbital spots. Antenna dark brown or<tei:lb/>blackish dorsally, brown or reddish ventrally. Maxillary palp reddish with segments 4 apically and 5 wholly<tei:lb/>dark. Posterior part of propodeum entirely black. Hind coxa black, very rarely with a postero-ventral<tei:lb/>reddish spot. Hind femur reddish yellow, entirely or, in a few specimens, blackish medially. Segments of<tei:lb/>gaster black, rarely entirely so, usually with variable reddish marks on segments 1,2 and 3 and more rarely<tei:lb/>on other segments. Very rarely reddish areas grade to yellow posteriorly.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Width of lower face 0-95-1-10 times vertical length of eye. Malar space 0-65-0-75 times basal<tei:lb/>width of mandible. Maxillary palp as in Fig. 106; segment 4 considerably widened and flattened; segment 5<tei:lb/>about 0-5 as long as 4. Antennal flag setae (Fig. 129) upright, long, flattened and considerably widened, 3<tei:lb/>(sometimes 4) per segment, arising from a polished trough. Hind femur (Fig. 5) 4-45-5-25 times as long as<tei:lb/>deep. Fore wing length 9-2-11-7 mm. Tergite 1 of gaster 1-40-1-70 times as long as broad. Tergite 3 with a<tei:lb/>crease along its anterior 0-3 separating the laterotergite.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour: black, yellow and reddish. Antenna black dorsally (and ventrally at distal apex of flagellum),<tei:lb/>yellow ventrally. Maxillary palp with segment 1 yellow, segments 2 and 3 wholly and 4 proximally reddish<tei:lb/>yellow, segment 4 distally and 5 wholly brown or blackish. Posterior part of propodeum yellow anteriorly,<tei:lb/>black posteriorly, the yellow sometimes reduced to a pair of latero-median spots or entirely absent. Hind<tei:lb/>coxa black, usually with a yellowish or reddish patch postero-ventrally and sometimes also dorsally. Hind<tei:lb/>femur reddish yellow, almost always entirely but in a few specimens blackish medially. Gaster with tergite 1<tei:lb/>black anteriorly, reddish and then yellow posteriorly; tergites 2 and 3 each reddish anteriorly, yellow<tei:lb/>posteriorly (with some blackish laterally); remaining tergites black, 4, 5 and 6 each with a postero-median<tei:lb/>yellow spot.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. B. falcatorius has several specialized features and it is the species in which sexual dimorphism is<tei:lb/>most marked. There is also some geographical variation in characters; for instance, specimens from the<tei:lb/>eastern part of the range have the hind femur darkened medially and a few specimens from Turkey have a<tei:lb/>well-developed spine on the scutellum. More than one species might be included in the taxon here<tei:lb/>recognized, but in the limited material from the eastern Palaearctic available for study no clear-cut<tei:lb/>segregates could be recognized.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although the sex association in this species is not in doubt, interesting confirmation comes from the<tei:lb/>discovery of four gynandromorph specimens in the extensive material examined. These were the only<tei:lb/>gynandromorphs found (or at least recognized) during the present study. Details of the specimens are as<tei:lb/>follows.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Italy: Piemonte, Susa, 24. vi. 1872 (Gribodo) (MCSN). Head male (unfortunately the antennal flagella<tei:lb/>are missing), thorax and abdomen female. Italy: Cadore, Valle del Boite (IEUB). Head female, thorax<tei:lb/>and propodeum apparently mainly female but with yellow marks on the left of the mesoscutum and<tei:lb/>scutellum (male characters), gaster apparently male (including the genitalia) but with some bilateral<tei:lb/>asymmetry in colour anteriorly. ?locality [illegible] (Giraud coll.) (MNHN). Head (including antennae<tei:lb/>and palps) male on the left and female on the right, prothorax and anterior of mesothorax mainly female<tei:lb/>but partly male on left, posterior of mesothorax and remainder of body female. Interestingly this specimen<tei:lb/>had been labelled (anonymously) as a hybrid between falcatorius and monileatus [= palpalis}. Denmark:<tei:lb/>Ordrup, 19.viii. 1877 (Drewsen) (UZM). Head (including appendages) female, remainder male except that<tei:lb/>the dark colour of the left fore and mid coxae suggests some female influence.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY AND HOSTS. This species is on the wing from early June to mid August (with a few records for late<tei:lb/>May and late August). The adults have often been collected from umbellifer flowers. One female is<tei:lb/>labelled as being the prey of Dasypogon teutonics (Diptera; Asilidae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Despite the abundance of specimens in collections there are very few reared examples, and not all of<tei:lb/>those have an attached host name or host remains. The most reliable host data relate to Agrotis segetum<tei:lb/>(Denis &amp; Schiffermiiller) (Noctuidae) and this is certainly an important host species. It is (or was) a major<tei:lb/>pest of root crops (particularly various beets and carrots) and its association with B. falcatorius was the<tei:lb/>subject of research in the U.S.S.R. in the 1920s and 30s (Kosobutzkii, 1928; Meyer, 1927a, 1928; Pospelov,<tei:lb/>1924; Samoilova, 1936). The long, knife-like gaster of the female is undoubtedly adapted to enable it to<tei:lb/>reach the host larvae, which feed at soil level. Other hosts recorded on specimen labels are: Deilephila<tei:lb/>porcellus (Linnaeus) and D. elpenor (Linnaeus) (Sphingidae), Dasychira fascelina (Linnaeus) (Lyman-</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>22</tei:p>
         <tei:p>M. G. FITTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>triidae), Acronicta megacephala (Denis &amp; Schiffermiiller) (Noctuidae) and Melitaea didyma (Esper)<tei:lb/>(Nymphalidae). The last named host record seems unlikely to be accurate, but it is difficult to judge the<tei:lb/>others (all the specimens are without locality or date !). Other hosts recorded in the literature are: Agrotis<tei:lb/>exclamationis (Linnaeus) (Noctuidae) (Meyer, 1927a: 81) and, erroneously, two Hymenoptera (Diprion<tei:lb/>pini (Linnaeus) (Diprionidae) and Ophion luteus (Linnaeus) (Ichneumonidae) (Maneval, 1935: 74)).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION (Map 5, p. 22). Most of the Palaearctic, but few specimens seen from large areas of the<tei:lb/>U.S.S.R. and further east than the Caucasus none from south of 50 degrees N. In the more southern parts<tei:lb/>of its range in the western Palaearctic it is apparently restricted to higher altitudes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED (652 $ , 806 cf )</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Austria, Belgium, Bulgaria, Corsica, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, East Germany, Finland, France, Great<tei:lb/>Britain, Greece, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Rumania, Sakhalin, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland,<tei:lb/>Turkey, U.S.S.R., West Germany, Yugoslavia (AC, BC, BMNH, BRI, CM, EIHU, FSA, HC, IEE,<tei:lb/>IEUB, IP, IRSNB, ITZ, IZPAN, JC, JKC, KHC, LELW, MCSN, MHN, MNHN, MNHU, MUM, NMB,<tei:lb/>NR, PC, RNH, SC, SMT, UM, USNM, UZI, UZM, VRC, ZIL, ZIM, ZMU, ZC, ZSBS).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>falcatorius</tei:p>
         <tei:p>T flavomaculatus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Map 5 Distribution of Banchus falcatorius and B. flavomaculatus.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ICHNEUMON-FLY GENUS BANCHUS 23</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banchus ffavomaculatus (Cameron)<tei:lb/>(Figs 16, 39, 63, 86, 107)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cidaphurusflavomaculatus Cameron, 1904: 346. Lectotype $ [not cf as stated by Cameron and by Morley,<tei:lb/>1913], INDIA (BMNH), fixed by Morley, 1913: 255.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>NOMENCLATURE. The lectotype and one paralectotype female (BMNH) are the only known syntype<tei:lb/>specimens. Both bear labels 'Cidaphurus flavomaculatus Cam. Simla' in Cameron's handwriting. The<tei:lb/>lectotype has, in addition, Nurse's typewritten data label 'Simla 5.97.'. It is unfortunate that Cameron's<tei:lb/>original description applies better to the paralectotype because it is not conspecific with the lectotype and is<tei:lb/>B. punkettai.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Female. Width of lower face 0-75-0-80 times vertical length of eye. Malar space 0-50-0-55<tei:lb/>times basal width of mandible. Maxillary palp as in Fig. 16. Antenna with apical segments about as broad as<tei:lb/>long. Scutellar spine (Fig. 39) varying from very short to about 0-5 as long as scutellum. Mesopleuron and<tei:lb/>mesoscutum shining, weakly coriaceous, with moderate punctures, on mesopleuron separated by about or<tei:lb/>a little more than their diameter. Hind femur 5-60-5-65 times as long as deep. Fore wing length 8-8-9-2<tei:lb/>mm. Tergite 1 of gaster 2-25-2-35 times as long as broad, its dorsal profile as in Fig. 63. Gaster strongly<tei:lb/>compressed from posterior of segment 3, reaching to about tips of fore wings (when folded back). Tergite 3<tei:lb/>with a crease along its anterior 0-4 separating laterotergite. Tergite 7 and sternite 6 as in Fig. 86.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour: black and reddish, with some yellow marks. Face reddish, yellowish laterally and with a black<tei:lb/>median stripe. Antenna blackish dorsally, scape and pedicel yellowish ventrally, flagellum brown<tei:lb/>ventrally. Maxillary palp reddish yellow, segments 4 distally and 5 wholly dark. Posterior part of<tei:lb/>propodeum entirely reddish. Hind coxa black with large dorsal and postero-ventral reddish patches. Hind<tei:lb/>femur reddish with a black stripe ventrally. Segments of gaster black anteriorly, very broadly reddish<tei:lb/>posteriorly.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Width of lower face 0-80 times vertical length of eye. Malar space 0-60 times basal width of<tei:lb/>mandible. Maxillary palp as in Fig. 107; segment 4 considerably widened and flattened; segment 5 about<tei:lb/>0-5 as long as 4. Antennal flag setae (similar to Fig. 126, but setae slightly longer) upright, long, flattened, 2<tei:lb/>per segment, arising from a polished trough. Hind femur 5-25 times as long as deep. Fore wing length 8-3<tei:lb/>mm. Tergite 1 of gaster 2-30 times as long as broad. Tergite 3 with a crease along its anterior 0-5 separating<tei:lb/>laterotergite.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour: black and yellow, with some reddish, especially on legs. Antenna black dorsally, scape and<tei:lb/>pedicel yellow ventrally, underside of flagellum reddish yellow proximally and distally, black medially.<tei:lb/>Maxillary palp with segments 1 brownish, 2 reddish yellow, 3 brownish and 4 and 5 blackish. Posterior part<tei:lb/>of propodeum entirely yellow. Hind coxa black, with a yellow dorsal spot contiguous interno-laterally with<tei:lb/>a postero-ventral spot. Hind femur reddish yellow with a black mark ventrally. Segments of gaster each<tei:lb/>black anteriorly, yellow posteriorly, the yellow tending to reddish, especially on sternites.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. See 'Remarks' under nox.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY AND HOSTS. Virtually unknown. Adults have been collected in May and October. The specimens<tei:lb/>collected at Simla by Gupta and Joseph were from coniferous and deodar forest (Gupta, 1971: (appendix)<tei:lb/>2, 3, 54).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION (Map 5, p. 22). Along the southern flank of the Himalayas at about 2000 m.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED (11 $, 2 cT).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>India: 1 $, Himachal Pradesh, Simla, v.1897 (Nurse) (BMNH) (lectotype); 4 $, 1 cf, Himachal<tei:lb/>Pradesh, Simla, 2133 m, 1 &amp; lO.x.1962, 3.X.1966 (Gupta, Joseph) (GC); 1 $, Uttar Pradesh, Khurpatal,<tei:lb/>ll.x.1978 (Gupta) (GC); 1 $, 1 cT, Uttar Pradesh, Mussoorie, 2100 m, l.x.1962, 21.x. 1972 (Gupta,<tei:lb/>Khana) (GC); 3 $ , Uttar Pradesh, Nainital, 1938 m, 2-10 &amp; 12.X.1978 (Gupta) (GC). Nepal: 1 $ , 3-2 km<tei:lb/>SE. of Sikha, 2100-2400 m, 23.V.1954 (Quinlan) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banchus gudrunae sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 17, 40, 65, 66, 87, 108)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Female. Width of lower face 0-75-0-85 times vertical length of eye. Malar space 0-45-0-55<tei:lb/>times basal width of mandible. Maxillary palp as in Fig. 17. Antenna with apical segments longer than<tei:lb/>broad. Scutellar spine (Fig. 40) about 0-7 as long as scutellum. Mesopleuron and mesoscutum coriaceous,<tei:lb/>with moderately strong punctures, on mesopleuron separated by about their diameter. Hind femur<tei:lb/>6-75-7-20 times as long as deep. Fore wing length 9-7-10-7 mm. Tergite 1 of gaster 2-00-2-50 times as long</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>24 M. G. FITTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>as broad, its dorsal profile as in Figs 65 (male), 66 (female). Gaster compressed from tergite 4, reaching<tei:lb/>about to tips of fore wings (when folded back). Tergite 3 with a crease along its whole length separating<tei:lb/>laterotergite. Tergite 7 and sternite 6 as in Fig. 87.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour: black and yellow. Face yellow with a black median stripe. Antenna black (sometimes slightly<tei:lb/>brownish distally), scape, and sometimes pedicel, with a yellow patch beneath. Maxillary palp reddish<tei:lb/>yellow with segment 1 and distal parts of 4 and 5 blackish. Posterior part of propodeum yellow, narrowly<tei:lb/>black posteriorly. Hind coxa black with a yellow dorsal patch. Hind femur yellowish with proximal half<tei:lb/>largely black. Segments of gaster each black anteriorly, yellow posteriorly, the yellow bands relatively<tei:lb/>wide.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Width of lower face 0-80-0-90 times vertical length of eye. Malar space 0-45-0-65 times basal<tei:lb/>width of mandible. Maxillary palp as in Fig. 108; segment 4 flattened and widened distally; segment 5 about<tei:lb/>0-5 as long as 4. Antennal flag setae (similar to Fig. 127, but with setae slightly shorter and very much<tei:lb/>broader) upright, relatively short, flattened and very broad, 2 (occasionally 3) per segment, arising from a<tei:lb/>polished trough. Hind femur 7-00-7-45 times as long as deep. Fore wing length 8-8-10-0 mm. Tergite 1 of<tei:lb/>gaster 2-10-2-40 times as long as broad. Tergite 3 with a crease along its whole length separating<tei:lb/>laterotergite.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour: black and yellow. Antenna black dorsally, scape and pedicel yellow ventrally, flagellum<tei:lb/>brownish ventrally. Maxillary palp reddish yellow, segment 1 dorsally narrowly black, segment 4 distally<tei:lb/>and 5 wholly blackish. Posterior part of propodeum yellow, very narrowly black posteriorly. Hind coxa<tei:lb/>black with a large yellow dorsal patch. Hind femur yellow, blackish on its proximal 0-3, especially ventrally<tei:lb/>and laterally. Segments of gaster each black anteriorly, very broadly yellow posteriorly.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species has a number of characters which make relating it to any others in the Palaearctic<tei:lb/>difficult. The form of the male palp suggests a relationship withpalpalis and crefeldensis but the flag setae<tei:lb/>are of a very much more specialized kind and the female palp is not specialized in the same way.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY AND HOSTS. Unknown. Dates of collection of adults range from the middle of November to the<tei:lb/>middle of January.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION (Map 6, p. 27). Known only from the island of Cyprus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Cyprus: Polemedia Hills, 14.xii.1948 (Mavromoustakis) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes 10 $ , 9 cf .
