         <tei:p>Banchus hastator (Fahricius )</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 18, 41, 64, 88, 109, 124)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ichneumon hastator Fabricius, 1793: 167. Holotype $, EUROPE (UZM) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ichneumon pungitor Thunberg, 1822: 265; 1824: 320. [Replacement name for Ichneumon hastator</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fabricius.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ichneumon reticulatorThunberg, 1822: 265; 1824: 321. Type(s) cf , SWEDEN (lost). Syn. n.<tei:lb/>Banchus femoralis Thomson, 1897: 2411. Lectotype 9, SWEDEN (UZI), designated by Townes, Momoi &amp;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Townes, 1965: 237 [examined].<tei:lb/>Banchus kolosovi Meyer, 1925: 10. Syntypes3 &lt;J&gt;, U.S.S.R. (destroyed). Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>NOMENCLATURE. This species until recently has been referred to by the junior synonym femoralis. It is dealt<tei:lb/>with in a relatively large number of non-taxonomic papers so the name change is particularly unfortunate.<tei:lb/>A further source of confusion is the incorrect use of the name hastator by Townes &amp; Townes (1978) (see<tei:lb/>nomenclatural notes under palpalis).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ichneumon pungitor is a junior objective synonym of hastator. It was proposed apparently because of the<tei:lb/>secondary homonymy in Ichneumon, in Thunberg's work, with Foenus hastator Fabricius, 1804 [which,<tei:lb/>incidentally, was miss-spelled as vastator by Thunberg (1822: 262; 1824: 315)]. The status of pungitor as a<tei:lb/>replacement name has not been recognized previously and it had been placed incorrectly in the synonymy<tei:lb/>of B. volutatorius (Linnaeus) (e.g. Aubert, 1978: 158).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ichneumon reticulator has not been identified since its description. Roman (1912: 277) reported that<tei:lb/>there were no specimens in Thunberg's collection and suggested that the species was a Banchus. The<tei:lb/>description fits some males of hastator, with which it is here synonymised.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>After its description, except for an entry in the Zoological Record, B. kolosovi was not referred to (even</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ICHNEUMON-FLY GENUS BANCHUS 25</tei:p>
         <tei:p>by Meyer) until Aubert (1978: 166) noted its existence. Aubert miss-spelled the name as kozlovi. The<tei:lb/>description fits particularly dark specimens ofhastator, with which it is here synonymised. Notwithstanding<tei:lb/>Meyer's comments on kolosovi andfemoralis, it seems that he realised his mistake because in his treatment<tei:lb/>of the genus (1934: 229) he mentions, under femoralis, material from Sverdlovsk (the type-locality of<tei:lb/>kolosovi) collected by Kolosov. This is presumably the type-material of kolosovi. No material collected by<tei:lb/>Kolosov is noted under other Banchus species by Meyer.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Female. Width of lower face 0-85-0-90 times vertical length of eye. Malar space 0-50-0-65<tei:lb/>times basal width of mandible. Maxillary palp as in Fig. 18. Antenna with apical segments longer than<tei:lb/>broad. Scutellar spine (Fig. 41) about 0-2 as long as scutellum. Mesopleuron and mesoscutum coriaceous,<tei:lb/>usually fairly weakly so, with moderate punctures, on mesopleuron separated by about their diameter.<tei:lb/>Hind femur 4-50-5-15 times as long as deep. Fore wing length 8-8-10-9 mm. Tergite 1 of gaster 1-50-1-70<tei:lb/>times as long as broad, its dorsal profile as in Fig. 64. Gaster weakly compressed, reaching about to tips of<tei:lb/>fore wings (when folded back). Tergite 3 with a crease along its anterior 0-3 separating laterotergite.<tei:lb/>Tergite 7 and sternite 6 as in Fig. 88.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour: mainly black, with yellow and reddish, particularly on legs. Face black with yellow orbital<tei:lb/>marks, which are usually small but are sometimes large and with a pair of very small reddish marks in centre<tei:lb/>of face. Antenna with scape and pedicel black, scape, and usually pedicel, yellow ventrally. Flagellum<tei:lb/>brown dorsally, reddish ventrally, darker at extreme base and apex. Maxillary palp reddish with segment 1<tei:lb/>black and segments 2 proximally, 4 distally and 5 wholly darker. Posterior part of propodeum entirely<tei:lb/>black. Hind coxa black. Hind femur reddish or yellowish proximally and distally, medially varying from<tei:lb/>reddish dorsally and blackish ventrally to all blackish. Segments of gaster black, sometimes almost entirely<tei:lb/>except for brownish posterior margin of sternites 1 and 6 and tergite 7, but usually with posterior margins of<tei:lb/>further segments narrowly yellowish and with the yellow grading into a wider brownish band.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Width of lower face 0-90-1-00 times vertical length of eye. Malar space 0-50-0-65 times basal<tei:lb/>width of mandible. Maxillary palp as in Fig. 109; segment 4 only slightly widened and flattened; segment 5<tei:lb/>almost as long as 4. Antennal flag setae (Fig. 124) relatively poorly differentiated, small, not flattened, 2<tei:lb/>per segment, not arising from a trough. Hind femur 4-60-5-50 times as long as deep. Fore wing length<tei:lb/>7-2-10-7 mm. Tergite 1 of gaster 1-45-1-80 times as long as broad. Tergite 3 with a crease along its anterior<tei:lb/>0-3 separating laterotergite.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour: mainly black, with some reddish and yellow, particularly on legs. Antenna black dorsally, scape<tei:lb/>and pedicel yellow ventrally, flagellum reddish ventrally. Maxillary palp with segment 1 blackish or<tei:lb/>blackish and yellow, 2 and 3 reddish, 4 and 5 blackish or brownish. Posterior part of propodeum entirely<tei:lb/>black. Hind coxa black (in a single specimen with a small yellowish dorsal spot and the postero- ventral<tei:lb/>margin reddish). Hind femur reddish or yellowish proximally and distally, medially varying from reddish<tei:lb/>dorsally and blackish ventrally to all blackish. Gaster sometimes almost entirely black except for brownish<tei:lb/>posterior margins of some segments, but usually with posterior margins of segments narrowly yellowish<tei:lb/>with adjacent brownish bands.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This is an isolated species, with few obvious specializations. The primitive condition of the<tei:lb/>antennal flag setae in the male is particularly notable.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY AND HOSTS. The species is an important parasite of Panolis flammea (Denis &amp; Schiffermiiller)<tei:lb/>(Noctuidae), which is sometimes a serious pest in pine forests. B. hastator is univoltine and adults occur in<tei:lb/>May, June and early July. Reared specimens have emergence dates in March and April also. Some details<tei:lb/>of the biology and ecology of the species have been investigated as a result of the association with an<tei:lb/>economically important host. Most of the work has been connected with its effect as a natural control agent<tei:lb/>(Friederichs, 1936; Habermehl, 1922, 1924; Pfeffer, 1933; Scheidter, 1934; Schwerdtfeger, 1952; Smits van<tei:lb/>Burgst, 1927) but has included studies of embryonic and larval development and morphology (Beirne,<tei:lb/>1941; Biedowski &amp; Krainska, 1926; Shevyrev, 1913), courtship, host identification and host-stage<tei:lb/>preferences, egg-laying and the reproductive system (van Veen, 1982).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There are many specimens reared from P. flammea in collections. Apart from that species, the following<tei:lb/>species are recorded as hosts on specimen labels: Blepharita adusta (Esper) (Noctuidae) (1 $, 2 cf,<tei:lb/>Germany (Smits van Burgst coll.) LELW); Deilephila porcellus (Linnaeus) (Sphingidae) (1 cf , no locality<tei:lb/>(Adkin) BMNH); Hyloicus pinastri (Linnaeus) (Sphingidae) (1 $, Poland (Mazur) IZPAN) and ?Achlya<tei:lb/>flavicornis (Linnaeus) (Thyatiridae) (1 $, Great Britain (Lyle) BMNH). While one might cast doubt on<tei:lb/>these records it is difficult to investigate them critically. Kolubajiv (1934: 114, 116) records Lymantria<tei:lb/>dispar (Linnaeus) (Lymantriidae) as a host.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION (Map 6, p. 27). Widely distributed in northern Europe as far east as Leningrad, perhaps<tei:lb/>extending further east to the Urals (if my synonymy of kolosovi is correct (see 'Nomenclature' above)). It<tei:lb/>also occurs in the European Alps and I have seen single individuals collected in Corsica and Yugoslavia.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>26 M. G. FITTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED (113 $, 151 cf)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Belgium, Corsica, Denmark, East Germany, Finland, France, Great Britain, Ireland, Netherlands,<tei:lb/>Poland, Sweden, Switzerland, U.S.S.R., West Germany, Yugoslavia (AC, BC, BMNH, BRI, HC, IP,<tei:lb/>IRSNB, ITZ, IZPAN, LELW, KC, MNHN, MUM, NMB, NR, RNH, RSM, SC, SMT, UM, USNM,<tei:lb/>UZI, UZM, VRC, ZC, ZIL, ZMU, ZSBS).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banchus insulanus Roman</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 19, 42, 67, 89)<tei:lb/>Banchus insulanus Roman, 1937: 18. Holotype $, MADEIRA (NR) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Female. Width of lower face 0-85 times vertical length of eye. Malar space 0-55 times basal<tei:lb/>width of mandible. Maxillary palp as in Fig. 19. Antenna with apical segments longer than broad. Scutellar<tei:lb/>spine (Fig. 42) indistinct. Mesopleuron and mesoscutum coriaceous, with moderate punctures, on<tei:lb/>mesopleuron separated by more than their diameter. Hind femur 6-55 times as long as deep. Fore wing<tei:lb/>length 9-3-9-5 mm. Tergite 1 of gaster 1-65 times as long as broad, its dorsal profile as in Fig. 67. Gaster<tei:lb/>only weakly compressed, not reaching to tips of fore wings (when folded back). Tergite 3 with a crease<tei:lb/>along its entire length separating laterotergite. Tergite 7 and sternite 6 as in Fig. 89.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour: mainly black, with yellow and reddish marks. Face black with irregular, yellow orbital marks.<tei:lb/>Antenna black. Maxillary palp blackish. Posterior part of propodeum black. Hind coxa black with a small<tei:lb/>yellow dorsal patch. Hind femur yellowish, blackish ventrally and posteriorly on its proximal 0-5. Segments<tei:lb/>of gaster blackish, in one specimen with only posterior 0-5 of tergite 3 and posterior 0-3 of tergite 7 reddish;<tei:lb/>in the other specimen with posterior 0-7 of tergite 2, almost all of tergite 3, posterior 0-5 of tergite 4, and<tei:lb/>tergites 5 and 6 laterally, reddish.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Unknown (but see 'Remarks').</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The specimen described as the male by Hellen (1949: 13) proved, on examination, to be a<tei:lb/>female. The material collected in 1959 and supposedly including both sexes (Hellen, 1961: 37) cannot be<tei:lb/>found in Hellen's collection (A. Albrecht, pers. comm.).<tei:lb/>The relationships of the species are not at all obvious from the characters of the female.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY AND HOSTS. Unknown. Adults have been collected in May and July-August.<tei:lb/>DISTRIBUTION (Map 6, p. 27). Known only from the island of Madeira.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED (2 9)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Madeira: 1 $, 25 Fontes, Rabacal, 17.vrM.viii.1935 (Lunblad) (NR) (holotype); 1 $, Ribeiro Frio,<tei:lb/>3.v.l938(Fre&gt;0(ZMU).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banchus japonicus (Ashmead)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 20, 43, 68, 90, 110)<tei:lb/>Nawoia japonica Ashmead, 1906: 185. LECTOTYPE 9, JAPAN (USNM), here designated [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>NOMENCLATURE. Ashmead described this species from two specimens, also stating 'Type. - Cat. No. 7259,<tei:lb/>U.S.N.M.', thus giving the impression that one was the holotype. However, both specimens are labelled<tei:lb/>Type No. 7259 U.S.N.M.' and must be considered as syntypes. Other labels include 'Nawaia japonica<tei:lb/>Ashm' on one specimen and 'Nawaia japonica Ash. Paratype' on the other, the latter on a similar label but<tei:lb/>in a different hand and obviously more modern than the former. The specimen labelled as paratype also<tei:lb/>bears a label '47' and is in much better condition than the other. I have labelled and hereby designate it as<tei:lb/>lectotype.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Female. Width of lower face 0-80-0-90 times vertical length of eye. Malar space 0-35-0-45<tei:lb/>times basal width of mandible. Maxillary palp as in Fig. 20. Antenna with apical segments about as long as<tei:lb/>broad. Scutellar spine (Fig. 43) about 0-3 as long as scutellum. Mesopleuron and mesoscutum shining and<tei:lb/>only weakly coriaceous, with moderate punctures, on mesopleuron separated by about their diameter.<tei:lb/>Hind femur 5-55-6-50 times as long as deep. Fore wing length 9-2-12-1 mm. Tergite 1 of gaster 1-45-1-85<tei:lb/>times as long as broad, its dorsal profile as in Fig. 68. Gaster only weakly compressed, reaching to tips of<tei:lb/>fore wings (when folded back). Tergite 3 with a crease along its anterior 0-5 separating laterotergite.<tei:lb/>Tergite 7 and sternite 6 as in Fig. 90.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour: black and yellow. Face yellow with a broad median black stripe and sometimes a black mark<tei:lb/>below each antennal socket. Antenna black, with a small yellow mark on scape. Maxillary palp blackish,<tei:lb/>with a longitudinal yellow stripe ventrally on segments 1 and 2. Posterior part of propodeum yellow,</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ICHNEUMON-FLY GENUS BANCHUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>27</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Map 6</tei:p>
         <tei:p>^ gudruni<tei:lb/>hastator<tei:lb/>V insulanus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Map 6 Distribution of Banchus gudrunae, B. hastator and B. insulanus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>entirely or with a black area postero-medially. Hind coxa black with a yellow dorsal patch. Hind femur<tei:lb/>blackish, yellow proximally and distally. Segments of gaster black with posterior margins broadly yellow<tei:lb/>and with a pair of yellow spots on tergite 2 and usually also on 1 and 3.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Width of lower face 0-90 times vertical length of eye. Malar space 0-35-0-45 times basal width of<tei:lb/>mandible. Maxillary palp as in Fig. 110; segment 4 flattened and considerably widened; segment 5 about<tei:lb/>0-5 as long as 4. Tergite 3 with a<tei:lb/>crease along almost its entire length separating laterotergite.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour: black and yellow. Antenna black with scape, pedicel and proximal end of flagellar segment 1<tei:lb/>yellow ventrally. Maxillary palp with segment 1 yellow, 2 and 3 brownish yellow to blackish, 4 and 5 black.<tei:lb/>Posterior part of propodeum yellow, entirely or with small black marks posteriorly. Hind coxa black and<tei:lb/>yellow. Hind femur yellow with a black mark ventrally and interno-laterally, usually extending also to<tei:lb/>dorsal surface. Segments of gaster black with posterior margins broadly yellow and with a pair of yellow<tei:lb/>spots on tergite 2 and usually also on 1 and 3.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Although japonicus has been confused withpoppiti the two species are easily separated.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY AND HOSTS. Unknown. Adults have been collected in May and June.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION (Map 2, p. 16). Japan. Recorded also from Korea (Kim, 1955: 493), from which country the<tei:lb/>only species of Banchus examined is B. palpalis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED (6 $ , 6 c?)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Japan: 1 $, Gifu, Fujishiro (Nawa) (USNM) (lectotype); 1 $, Gifu, Gifu-yama (Nawa) (USNM)<tei:lb/>(paralectotype); 1 $, Hokkaido (Uchidd) (TC); 1 $, 3 cf, Hokkaido, Mt Soranuma, 26.vi.1965 and</tei:p>

         <tei:p>15.vi.1968 (Kusigemati) (KC); 1 cf, Hokkaido, Toya-ko, 14.vi.1967 (Miyazaki) (KC); 1 $, Honshu,<tei:lb/>Tokyo, Komaba, 9.V.1916 (Hirayama) (EIHU); 1 cf , Honshu, Hyogo Pref., Ryuzoji, Sasayama, 5. v. 1965<tei:lb/>(Nakanishi) (NC); 1 $, Honshu, Tottori Pref., Mt Daisen, 12.vi.1963 (Nakanishi) (NC); 1 cf , Honshu,<tei:lb/>Yatsugatake, 2.vi.l967 (Kocha) (KC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banchus mauricettae sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 21, 44, 69, 91, 111)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Female. Width of lower face 0-90-0-95 times vertical length of eye. Malar space 0-55 times<tei:lb/>basal width of mandible. Maxillary palp as in Fig. 21. Antenna with apical segments longer than broad.<tei:lb/>Scutellar spine (Fig. 44) about as long as scutellum. Mesopleuron and mesoscutum coriaceous, with<tei:lb/>moderate to strong punctures, on mesopleuron separated by a little more than their diameter. Hind femur<tei:lb/>5-20-5-30 times as long as deep. Fore wing length 10-5-10-6 mm. Tergite 1 of gaster 1-90-2-35 times as long<tei:lb/>as broad, its dorsal profile as in Fig. 69 (male). Gaster moderately compressed, not quite reaching tips of<tei:lb/>fore wings (when folded back). Tergite 3 with a crease along its anterior 0-6 separating laterotergite.<tei:lb/>Tergite 7 and sternite 6 as in Fig. 91.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour: yellowish red with black and yellow marks. Face yellowish red with orbits yellow and sometimes<tei:lb/>with a blackish median stripe. Antenna entirely reddish yellow except for extreme apex of flagellum and<tei:lb/>scape and pedicel dorsally, which are blackish. Maxillary palp reddish yellow with segments 4 distally and 5<tei:lb/>wholly dark. Posterior part of propodeum reddish, entirely or with black marks posteriorly. Hind coxa<tei:lb/>varying from reddish with black patches to almost entirely black. Hind femur entirely reddish. Segments of<tei:lb/>gaster entirely reddish or with some black anteriorly.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Width of lower face 0-85-0-90 times vertical length of eye. Malar space 0-60-0-65 times basal<tei:lb/>width of mandible. Maxillary palp as in Fig. Ill; segment 4 flattened and widened; segment 5 about 0-8 as<tei:lb/>long as 4. Antennal flag setae (similar in appearance to Fig. 129, but with setae only two-thirds as long)<tei:lb/>upright, fairly short and broad, 3 (occasionally 4) per segment, arising from a polished trough. Hind femur<tei:lb/>5 95-6 20 times as long as deep . Fore wing length 11-2-12-3 mm . Tergite 1 of gaster 2 20-2 35 times as long<tei:lb/>as broad. Tergite 3 with a crease along its anterior 0-6 separating laterotergite.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour: yellow, reddish and black. Antenna blackish dorsally, scape and pedicel yellow ventrally,<tei:lb/>flagellum reddish yellow ventrally. Maxillary palp reddish yellow with segments 4 distally and 5 wholly<tei:lb/>blackish. Posterior part of propodeum entirely yellow. Hind coxa largely reddish yellow, blackish or<tei:lb/>brownish antero-ventrally and dorso-posteriorly. Hind femur reddish, sometimes with a blackish mark<tei:lb/>ventrally. Segments of gaster each black, reddish and yellow (from anterior to posterior), the area of black<tei:lb/>reduced or absent on posterior segments.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This is a distinctive species; its relationships are difficult to discern.<tei:lb/>BIOLOGY AND HOSTS. Unknown. Dates of collection are in June and July.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION (Map 2, p. 16). The Szechuen province of China. Altitudes given on data labels range from<tei:lb/>300-4500 m.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , China: Szechuen, Yao-Gi, 1200-2400 m, 3.vii.l929 (Graham) (USNM).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes 4 $, 10 cf. China: 1 9, 2 cf, Szechuen, Yao-Gi, 1200-2400 m, 3 &amp; 16.vii.1929 (Graham)<tei:lb/>(USNM); 2 cf, Szechuen, near Mupin, 600-2400 m, 28.vi &amp; 22.vii.1929 (Graham) (USNM); 1 cf,<tei:lb/>Szechuen, Ningyuenfu, 1800-3240 m, 24-26. vii. 1928 (Graham) (USNM); 1 cf , Szechuen, Mt Omei, 840<tei:lb/>m, vi.1937 (Graham) (USNM); 1 cf , Szechuen, Suifu, 300-450 m, l-21.vi.1928 (Graham) (USNM); 2 cf ,<tei:lb/>Szechuen, 14-5 km SW. of Tatsienlu, 2550-3900 m, 25-27.vi.1923 (Graham) (USNM); 1 cf , Szechuen, U<tei:lb/>Long Kong, near Tatsienlu, 3000-4500 m, 25-30.vi.1923 (Graham) (USNM); 2 9, Szechuen, Yachow,<tei:lb/>v-vi.1928 (Graham) (USNM); 1 $, Szechuen, Yachow to Mupin, 600-1500 m, 23-27.vi.1929 (Graham)<tei:lb/>(USNM).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banchus moppitisp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 22, 45, 70, 92, 113, 127)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Female. Width of lower face 1-10-1-20 times vertical length of eye. Malar space 0-85-1-00<tei:lb/>times basal width of mandible. Maxillary palp as in Fig. 22. Antenna with apical segments about as broad as<tei:lb/>long. Scutellar spine (Fig. 45) about 0-6 as long as scutellum, usually downcurved at the tip. Mesopleuron<tei:lb/>and mesoscutum coriaceous, usually strongly so, with strong punctures, on mesopleuron separated by<tei:lb/>much less than their diameter. Hind femur 4-75-5-20 times as long as deep. Fore wing length 8-2-10-8 mm.<tei:lb/>Tergite 1 of gaster 1-60-1-80 times as long as broad, its dorsal profile as in Fig. 70. Gaster compressed from</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ICHNEUMON-FLY GENUS BANCHUS 29</tei:p>
         <tei:p>segment 4, reaching just beyond tips of fore wings (when folded back). Tergite 3 with a crease along its<tei:lb/>anterior 0-3 separating laterotergite. Tergite 7 and sternite 6 as in Fig. 92.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour: black and yellow. Face black with yellow orbital stripes, usually broad but varying considerably<tei:lb/>in width. Antenna black, usually with a small yellow patch on underside of scape. Maxillary palp blackish.<tei:lb/>Posterior part of propodeum black with a broad yellow stripe along posterior transverse carina. Hind coxa<tei:lb/>black, usually with a small yellow dorsal patch. Hind femur black, yellow proximally and distally and<tei:lb/>usually dorsally. Segments of gaster each black anteriorly, broadly yellow posteriorly.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Width of lower face 1-10-1 -20 times vertical length of eye. Malar space 0-75-0-95 times basal<tei:lb/>width of mandible. Maxillary palp as in Fig. 113; segment 4 flattened and widened; segment 5 not quite as<tei:lb/>long as 4. Antennal flag setae (Fig. 127) upright, relatively short, flattened and widened, 2 per segment,<tei:lb/>arising from a polished trough. Hind femur 4-80-5-50 times as long as deep. Fore wing length 8-5-10-9 mm.<tei:lb/>Tergite 1 of gaster 1-45-1-60 times as long as broad. Tergite 3 with a crease along its anterior 0-3 separating<tei:lb/>laterotergite.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour: black and yellow. Antenna black with scape and pedicel yellow ventrally. Maxillary palp<tei:lb/>blackish. Posterior part of propodeum yellow anteriorly, black posteriorly. Hind coxa black, usually with a<tei:lb/>yellow dorsal spot and sometimes also a postero-lateral one. Hind femur yellow with an extensive black<tei:lb/>mark, extending ventrally and laterally. Segments of gaster each black anteriorly, yellow posteriorly.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species seems closely related to zonatus. Its generally much smaller size and relatively<tei:lb/>shorter appendages (and gaster in females) readily differentiate it.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY AND HOSTS. Unknown. The specimens were collected early in the year (in February, March and<tei:lb/>April) with the exception of a female taken in October.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION (Map 7, p. 29). The few known specimens come from widely scattered localities in western<tei:lb/>Europe.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Banchus nox Morley<tei:lb/>(Figs 23, 46, 71, 93, 112)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banchus nox Morley, 1913: 255. Holotype cf , INDIA (BMNH) [examined].<tei:lb/>NOMENCLATURE. The species misidentified as nox by Chandra &amp; Gupta (1977: 182) is B. punkettai.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION, female. Width of lower face 0-80 times vertical length of eye. Malar space 0-55 times basal<tei:lb/>width of mandible. Maxillary palp as in Fig. 23. Antenna with apical segments longer than broad. Scutellar<tei:lb/>spine (Fig. 46) about 0-7 as long as scutellum. Mesopleuron and mesoscutum coriaceous, with moderate<tei:lb/>punctures, on mesopleuron separated by a little more than their diameter. Hind femur 6-40 times as long as<tei:lb/>deep. Fore wing length 11-2 mm. Tergite 1 of gaster 2-70 times as long as broad, its dorsal profile as in Fig.<tei:lb/>71 (male). Gaster strongly compressed from posterior of segment 3, not reaching to tips of fore wings<tei:lb/>(when folded back). Tergite 3 with a crease along its anterior 0-4 separating laterotergite. Tergite 7 and<tei:lb/>sternite 6 as in Fig. 93.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour: black and reddish, with some yellow marks. Face black with very broad yellow orbital marks<tei:lb/>which also extend beneath antennal sockets. Antenna dark brown, blackish dorsally, scape and pedicel<tei:lb/>yellowish ventralty. Maxillary palp reddish yellow, with segment 1 dorsally and segment 4 distally blackish.<tei:lb/>Posterior part of propodeum blackish with an irregular reddish yellow band along posterior transverse<tei:lb/>carina. Hind coxa black with a large reddish dorsal patch. Hind femur reddish with a black stripe ventrally.<tei:lb/>Segments of gaster reddish, tergites 1, 2 and 3 black anteriorly.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Width of lower face 0-85 times vertical length of eye. Malar space 0-50 times basal width of<tei:lb/>mandible. Maxillary palp as in Fig. 112; segment 4 flattened and considerably widened; segment 5 about<tei:lb/>0-6 as long as 4. Antennal flag setae (similar to Fig. 126, but setae slightly longer) upright, long, flattened, 2<tei:lb/>per segment, arising from a polished trough. Hind femur 6-05 times as long as deep. Fore wing length 9-7<tei:lb/>mm. Tergite 1 of gaster 2-15 times as long as broad. Tergite 3 with a crease along its anterior 0-5 separating<tei:lb/>laterotergite.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour: black and yellow, with some reddish, especially on legs. Antenna black dorsally, scape and<tei:lb/>pedicel yellow ventrally, underside of flagellum with segment 1 and distal part reddish yellow, remainder<tei:lb/>black. Maxillary palp with segment 1 yellowish, 2 and 3 wholly and 4 proximally reddish yellow, 4 distally<tei:lb/>and 5 wholly brownish. Posterior part of propodeum yellow, narrowly black postero-medially. Hind coxa<tei:lb/>black, with a yellow dorsal spot contiguous interno-laterally with a postero- ventral spot. Hind femur<tei:lb/>reddish with a black mark ventrally. Segments of gaster each black anteriorly, yellow posteriorly, with<tei:lb/>junction of the two areas reddish.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Closely related toflavomaculatus. The aggregate differences between these taxa warrant their<tei:lb/>separation, but this will need to be reassessed when more material becomes available for study.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY AND HOSTS. The only two known specimens were collected in October and November, the male on<tei:lb/>flowers of Spiraea (Morley, 1913: 255).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION (Map 2, p. 16). Assam, between 1800 and 2400 m.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED (1 $, 1 cf)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>India: 1 cf, Assam, Shillong, Khasi Hills, 1800 m, x.1903 (Turner) (BMNH) (holotype); 1 $, Assam,<tei:lb/>Mishmi Hills, Delai Valley, Cha Che, 2200-2400 m, 21.xi.1936 (Steele) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banchus palpalis Ruthe</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 1,24, 47, 72, 94, 114)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[Banchus monileatus Gravenhorst, 1829: 393; in part. Misidentification.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banchus palpalis Ruthe, 1859: 377. Syntypes 2 cf , ICELAND (lost).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banchus spinosus Cresson, 1865: 274. Holotype 9 [not cf as stated by Cresson], U.S.A. (ANS) [not</tei:p>
         <tei:p>examined]. Syn. n.<tei:lb/>Banchus formidabilis Provancher, 1874: 61. Holotype $, CANADA (UL) [not examined]. Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ICHNEUMON-FLY GENUS BANCHUS 31</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banchus (Corynephanus) groenlandicus Aurivillius, 1890: 30. Lectotype cf , GREENLAND (NR), designated</tei:p>
         <tei:p>by Townes, 1961: 104 [examined]. Syn. n.<tei:lb/>Cidaphurus alticola Ashmead, 1901 : 148. Holotype $ [not cf as stated by Ashmead], U.S. A. (USNM) [not</tei:p>
         <tei:p>examined]. Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>NOMENCLATURE. For almost 150 years the name monileatus was applied consistently to this species.<tei:lb/>However, two species were mixed in Gravenhorst's original material and a series of unfortunate events<tei:lb/>culminated in Townes &amp; Townes (1978: 532) designating as lectotype of monileatus a female which was<tei:lb/>volutatorius , rather than the species as it had been identified previously. In addition, as a result of<tei:lb/>misinformation about my examination of the holotype of hastator, Townes &amp; Townes incorrectly<tei:lb/>synonymized monileatus with that species. Female volutatorius and palpalis superficially are strikingly<tei:lb/>similar, so much so that Aubert (1978: 156), without realising that he was examining volutatorius,<tei:lb/>commented that Townes' lectotype differed from volutatorius only in certain details! When he originally<tei:lb/>examined Gravenhorst's syntypes (in 1964) Townes probably checked the identity of the species and then<tei:lb/>made the mistake of selecting the specimen in best condition for designation as lectotype without<tei:lb/>re-checking it. Under the International Code the lectotype designation has priority over the previous<tei:lb/>restriction of the taxonomic species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thus monileatus becomes a junior synonym of volutatorius while the species previously known as<tei:lb/>monileatus must take the next available name -palpalis. The name hastator correctly applies to the species<tei:lb/>previously known by the junior synonym femoralis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The identity of palpalis was established by Roman (1928: 24; 1930: 285) and Fitton (1978a: 76).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banchus spinosus, B. formidabilis and Cidaphurus alticola are included in the synonymy of palpalis on<tei:lb/>the basis of their treatment in Townes &amp; Townes (1978).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Female. Width of lower face 0-80-0-90 times vertical length of eye. Malar space 0-65-0-75<tei:lb/>times basal width of mandible. Maxillary palp as in Fig. 24. Antenna with apical segments longer than<tei:lb/>broad. Scutellar spine (Fig. 47) long, more than 0-8 as long as scutellum (in a very few specimens only 0-3 as<tei:lb/>long as scutellum). Mesopleuron and mesoscutum coriaceous, with fine to moderate punctures, on<tei:lb/>mesopleuron separated by a little more than their diameter. Hind femur 5-00-5-95 times as long as deep.<tei:lb/>Fore wing length 9-8-11-5 mm. Tergite 1 of gaster 1-65-2-15 times as long as broad, its dorsal profile as in<tei:lb/>Fig. 72 (male). Gaster compressed from posterior of segment 3, not quite reaching to tips of fore wings<tei:lb/>(when folded back). Tergite 3 with a crease along its anterior 0-4 separating laterotergite. Tergite 7 and<tei:lb/>sternite 6 as in Fig. 94.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour: almost entirely black except for mainly reddish legs and a few small yellowish marks. Face black<tei:lb/>with yellow orbital marks, usually very small and sometimes absent. Antenna black, entirely or with<tei:lb/>yellowish marks ventrally on scape and pedicel. Maxillary palp yellowish or brownish with segments 1 and 5<tei:lb/>wholly and 3 and 4 distally blackish. Posterior part of propodeum entirely black. Hind coxa black. Hind<tei:lb/>femur reddish yellow, usually entirely, rarely darkened ventrally. Segments of gaster black, sternites and<tei:lb/>posterior edges of tergites 6 and 7 sometimes brownish.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male (Fig. 1). Width of lower face 0-90-0-95 times vertical length of eye. Malar space 0-60-0-70 times<tei:lb/>basal width of mandible. Maxillary palp as in Fig. 114; segment 4 narrow and cylindrical, flattened and<tei:lb/>widened only at its extreme distal apex; segment 5 less than 0-2 as long as 4. Antennal flag setae (similar to<tei:lb/>Fig. 125, but setae slightly longer and showing signs of flattening) at about 50 degrees, very weakly<tei:lb/>flattened, 3 per segment, not arising from a trough. Hind femur 5-35-6- 10 times as long as deep. Fore wing<tei:lb/>length 9-8-11-4 mm. Tergite 1 of gaster 1-90-2-25 times as long as broad. Tergite 3 with a crease along its<tei:lb/>anterior 0-5 separating laterotergite.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour: black, with some yellow and with legs mainly reddish yellow. Antenna black, scape and pedicel<tei:lb/>yellow ventrally, proximal and distal parts of flagellum often brownish yellow ventrally. Maxillary palp<tei:lb/>with segments 1 and 2 wholly and 3 and 4 proximally reddish yellow, 3 and 4 distally and 5 wholly blackish.<tei:lb/>Posterior part of propodeum usually entirely black, sometimes with a transverse yellow mark (or marks)<tei:lb/>immediately behind posterior transverse carina. Hind coxa sometimes entirely black, usually with an<tei:lb/>externo-lateral reddish yellow mark and sometimes also dorsal and/or ventral yellowish spots. Hind femur<tei:lb/>entirely reddish yellow. Segments of gaster black, sometimes brownish or yellowish on their posterior<tei:lb/>margins, very rarely with conspicuous yellow bands on tergites 1, 2 and 3.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Easily identified from the structure of the maxillary palps. Nonetheless, it is confused with<tei:lb/>female volutatorius by incompetent or overconfident identifiers. Its presumed sister-species is crefeldensis.<tei:lb/>The males with well-developed yellow marking and conspicuous yellow bands on the gaster come<tei:lb/>mainly, but not exclusively, from the southern parts of the range. In North America, where the<tei:lb/>geographical variation in colour may be more consistent and also applies to females, this form has been<tei:lb/>recognized as a separate 'subspecies' (Townes &amp; Townes, 1978: 533).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>32</tei:p>
         <tei:p>M. G. FITTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY AND HOSTS. Adults normally occur from mid-June to mid-August, with one record from<tei:lb/>Switzerland as early as 22 May and one from Yugoslavia as late as September. In Europe the usual host<tei:lb/>seems to be Blepharita adusta (Esper) (Noctuidae), from which I have seen 39 reared specimens. Of these,<tei:lb/>34, possibly 35, come from a single mass rearing (with the only data: Germany (Smits van Burgs t coll.)<tei:lb/>(LELW)). In Great Britain Blepharita adusta is more common in the north (Bretherton, Goater &amp;<tei:lb/>Lorimer, 1983) and the records ofpalpalis show a similar pattern.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hosts recorded in the literature are: Panolis flammea (Denis &amp; Schiffermuller) (Noctuidae) (Smits van<tei:lb/>Burgst, 1927: 239), Lacanobia oleracea (Linnaeus) (Noctuidae) (Meyer, 1934: 231) and Deilephila<tei:lb/>porcellus (Linnaeus) (Sphingidae) (Leonardi, 1928: 87). The record from L. oleracea, at least, can<tei:lb/>probably be dismissed as having resulted from the misidentification of female volutatorius.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION (Map 8, p. 32). The only Holarctic species of Banchus. Very widely distributed; in the more<tei:lb/>southern parts of its range it occurs at higher altitudes (for example, altitudes of 1800 to 2100 m are<tei:lb/>recorded for the specimens from Austria, Yugoslavia, Bulgaria, Greece and Turkey).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Map 8</tei:p>
         <tei:p>tt.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>palpal is</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Map 8 Distribution of Banchus palpalis (the North American records are taken from Townes &amp; Townes ,<tei:lb/>1978).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ICHNEUMON-FLY GENUS BANCHUS 33</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED (103 $ , 88 cf )</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Belgium, Bulgaria, Canada, Denmark, East Germany, Finland, France, Great Britain, Greece, Iceland,<tei:lb/>Ireland, Italy, Japan, Korea, Netherlands, Poland, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey, West Germany, U.S.A.,<tei:lb/>U.S.S.R., Yugoslavia (BC, BMNH, BRI, EIHU, FSA, HC, IEUB, IRSNB, IZPAN, JC, JKC, KC<tei:lb/>LELW, MHN, MNHN, MNHU, MUM, NC, NR, RNH, USNM, UZM, VRC, ZC, ZI, ZMU, ZSBS).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banchus pictus Fab rid us<tei:lb/>(Figs 25, 49, 50, 73, 95, 115)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ichneumon cultratus Gmelin, 1790: 2708. Type(s) [?sex], EUROPE (destroyed). [Junior (by first reviser<tei:lb/>choice of Gravenhorst, 1829: 382, 1006) primary homonym of Ichneumon cultratus Gmelin, 1790: 2699.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ichneumon mutillatus Christ, 1791: 358. Type(s) cf , no type-locality (lost). [Junior primary homonym of<tei:lb/>Ichneumon mutillatus Gmelin, 1790: 2716.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banchus pictus Fabricius, 1798: 234. Lectotype $, GERMANY (UZM), designated by Townes, Momoi &amp;<tei:lb/>Townes, 1965: 238 [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banchus zagoriensis Hensch, 1928: 100. ?Syntypes 2 &lt;J&gt;, 1 cf , YUGOSLAVIA (ZSBS) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banchus bipunctatus Hensch, 1928: 101. Holotype cf , YUGOSLAVIA (ZPZ) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banchus russiator Aubert, 1978: 157. [Unavailable name published conditionally (Article 15 of the Code).]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banchus russiator Aubert, 1981: 18. Holotype $, U.S.S.R. (AC) [examined]. Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>NOMENCLATURE. The synonymy of/, cultratus with pictus was queried by Aubert (1978: 157) but he gave no<tei:lb/>reasons for so doing and I can find none.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The description of Ichneumon mutillatus Christ fits well the male of pictus and the synonymy, proposed<tei:lb/>by Gravenhorst (1829: 383) but queried by Aubert (1978: 157), is accepted. The Christ name is unavailable<tei:lb/>because of its homonymy with /. mutillatus Gmelin, which is a replacement name for /. mutillarius<tei:lb/>Fabricius, 1787: 271 (a junior homonym of/, multillarius Fabricius, 1775: 342).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I did not succeed in obtaining on loan material from the Hensch collection. However, Dr K. Horstmann<tei:lb/>was able to visit Zagreb in 1980 and in the course of his work on the species of Ichneumonidae described by<tei:lb/>Hensch he made the types of the Banchus species available to me. Unfortunately the specimen tentatively<tei:lb/>selected for designation as lectotype of B. zagoriensis had the date of collection 28 August 1928 and could<tei:lb/>not therefore have been a syntype as the description was published on 1 September 1928 (Horstmann,<tei:lb/>1982a: 82). Three specimens labelled as cotypes (= syntypes) of B. zagoriensis are present in the Bauer<tei:lb/>collection (ZSBS). Because they bear no dates of collection and because the cotype labels were almost<tei:lb/>certainly added by Bauer and not Hensch (Horstmann, pers. comm.) they are only tentatively regarded as<tei:lb/>syntypes. Selection and designation of a lectotype for B. zagoriensis is best deferred until the other material<tei:lb/>in the Hensch collection can be examined. The identity of the species is not in doubt.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Female. Width of lower face 0-80-0-95 times vertical length of eye. Malar space 0-40-0-50<tei:lb/>times basal width of mandible. Maxillary palp as in Fig. 25. Antenna with apical segments slightly longer<tei:lb/>than broad. Scutellar spine (Figs 49, 50) ranging from very small to about 0-6 as long as scutellum.<tei:lb/>Mesopleuron and mesoscutum coriaceous, with strong punctures, on mesopleuron separated by less than<tei:lb/>their diameter. Hind femur 5-00-5-50 times as long as deep. Fore wing length 8-1-10-6 mm. Tergite 1 of<tei:lb/>gaster 1-45-1-65 times as long as broad, its dorsal profile as in Fig. 73. Gaster compressed, reaching just<tei:lb/>beyond tips of fore wings (when folded back). Tergite 3 with a crease along its anterior 0-2 to 0-3 separating<tei:lb/>later otergite. Tergite 7 and sternite 6 as in Fig. 95.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour: black and yellow. Face yellow, with a black median stripe (rarely rather wide). Antenna with<tei:lb/>scape and pedicel black dorsally, yellow ventrally. Flagellum orange, sometimes slightly darker dorsally,<tei:lb/>almost always with segment 1 proximally blackish and distal segments dark. Maxillary palp reddish yellow,<tei:lb/>with segment 1 black and sometimes segments 2 proximally and 4 distally darkened. Posterior part of<tei:lb/>propodeum yellow anteriorly, black posteriorly; the yellow area varying considerably in extent, from<tei:lb/>covering almost all of the area to being divided by the black area medially, reduced to a pair of spots, or<tei:lb/>(very rarely) entirely absent. Hind coxa black, entirely or with a yellow dorsal patch. Hind femur medially<tei:lb/>black (sometimes brownish red, especially dorsally), yellow proximally and distally. Segments of gaster<tei:lb/>each black anteriorly, broadly yellow posteriorly.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Width of lower face 0-85-1-00 times vertical length of eye. Malar space 0-45-0-55 times basal<tei:lb/>width of mandible. Maxillary palp as in Fig. 115; segment 4 moderately widened and flattened; segment 5<tei:lb/>about 0-9 as long as 4. Antennal flag setae (similar to Fig. 125, but setae shorter) at about 60 degrees, short,<tei:lb/>not flattened, 2 per segment, not arising from a trough. Hind femur 5-05-5-65 times as long as deep. Fore<tei:lb/>wing length 8-1-10-3 mm. Tergite 1 of gaster 1-45-1-70 times as long as broad. Tergite 3 with a crease along<tei:lb/>its anterior 0-3 separating laterotergite.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>34 M. G. FITTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour: black and yellow. Antenna with scape and pedicel black dorsally, yellow ventrally. Flagellum<tei:lb/>reddish orange, dorsally darker (blackish at base and apex). Maxillary palp blackish, sometimes entirely,<tei:lb/>but usually with segments 2 and 3 wholly and 4 and 5 proximally yellowish brown. Posterior part of<tei:lb/>propodeum black, entirely or with a pair of antero-lateral yellow patches (rarely the yellow more<tei:lb/>extensive, very rarely posterior part of propodeum entirely yellow). Hind coxa black, often with a dorsal<tei:lb/>yellow patch. Hind femur medially black (sometimes brownish red, especially dorsally), yellow proximally<tei:lb/>and distally. Segments of gaster each black anteriorly, broadly yellow posteriorly.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Specimens of turcator have been confused with pictus. The two species can be distinguished<tei:lb/>using the characters given in the key.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The morphospecies/7/ctaj, as here defined, has variations in time of occurrence of adults, length of the<tei:lb/>scutellar spine, and sex ratios which need further investigation and explanation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There are two distinct periods of occurrence of adults. When this was noted 184 specimens were to hand.<tei:lb/>Of these 90 had a date of collection, 48 were captured between 10 April and 3 June and 42 between 1 July<tei:lb/>and 2 October (most of the latter batch after 10 August). The length of the scutellar spine varies from very<tei:lb/>small to about 0-6 as long as the scutellum. Although there is continuous variation in the length of the spine<tei:lb/>most of the specimens with a short spine were collected in the first period and most of those with a longer<tei:lb/>spine in the second. The sex ratio of the 48 specimens collected in the first period was 1 18 $ : 1 cf and of the<tei:lb/>42 in the second period 4-25 $ : Icf .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Three possible biological explanations of these observations are that (1) pictus is bivoltine, with the<tei:lb/>generations varying slightly in morphology and more distinctly in sex ratio; (2) the early and late summer<tei:lb/>groups represent separate species; or (3) that one species has a partial second generation and a second<tei:lb/>species (possibly parthenogenetic) occurs in late summer.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>If two species were involved diligent study should have revealed variation in some morphological<tei:lb/>characters, colour, geographical distribution, or host or other biological data correlated with date of<tei:lb/>capture or length of scutellar spine. None was found. Assignment of the 94 specimens without a date of<tei:lb/>capture to two subjective classes - with short or long scutellar spine - gave groups which varied in sex ratio<tei:lb/>in the same way as the early and late summer groups (short spine, 58 specimens, 1-55 $ : 1 cf ; long spine, 36<tei:lb/>specimens, 5 $: 1 cf). The only other relevant evidence comes from two reared specimens: two larvae of<tei:lb/>the noctuid Agrochola helvola (Linnaeus) collected near Sheffield, Great Britain (Ford) (UM) on 13 June<tei:lb/>1969 proved to be parasitized. The parasite larvae emerged in August 1969 and spun cocoons. The resulting<tei:lb/>adults (1 $ Id") did not emerge until early May 1970.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>None of this evidence gives unambiguous support to any of the three suggested explanations of the<tei:lb/>observations. Even the one year life-cycle of the specimens reared in Sheffield could be explained by<tei:lb/>postulating univoltinism in the northern part of the range of the species and bivoltinism in the south<tei:lb/>(although no evidence of this was found). However, the balance is perhaps in favour of the involvement of<tei:lb/>more than one species, if only because there is no undisputed evidence of bivoltinism in any other species of<tei:lb/>Banchus. The poor quality and quantity of the available data and the possible complexity of the situation<tei:lb/>mean that the problem remains unresolved - a fruitful field for future study.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY AND HOSTS. For information on phenology see 'Remarks' above. I have seen only three reared<tei:lb/>specimens of pictus, from Agrochola helvola (Linnaeus) (Noctuidae) (all from Great Britain (Lyle and<tei:lb/>Ford) BMNH and UM). There are several hosts noted in the literature, but as black-and-yellow Banchus<tei:lb/>are frequently misidentified as pictus they should be treated with caution. The recorded hosts are:<tei:lb/>Agrochola circellaris (Hufnagel) (Noctuidae) (Habermehl, 1922: 269), Agrotis segetum (Denis &amp; Schiffer-<tei:lb/>muller) (Noctuidae) (Bajari, 1960: 261), Atethmia ambusta (Denis &amp; Schifferrmiller) (Noctuidae)<tei:lb/>(Schmiedeknecht, 1910: 1928), Lycophotia porphyrea (Denis &amp; Schiffermiiller) (Noctuidae) (de Gaulle,<tei:lb/>1907: 119), Hadena rivularis (Fabricius) (Noctuidae) (Wagner, 1929: 11), Phalera bucephala (Linnaeus)<tei:lb/>(Notodontidae) (Leonardi, 1928: 83) and Smerinthus ocellata (Linnaeus) (Sphingidae) (Meyer, 1934: 228).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION (Map 9, p. 35). Widely distributed in the western Palaearctic as far north as 56N in the west,<tei:lb/>and extending south-east as far as the Pamirs.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED (162 $ , 75 cf ).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Austria, Belgium, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, East Germany, France, Great Britain, Greece, Hungary,<tei:lb/>Italy, Morocco, Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Rumania, Sardinia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey,<tei:lb/>U.S.S.R., West Germany, Yugoslavia (AC, BMNH, BRI, CM, FSA, HC, IBMPP, IEAU, IEE, IP,<tei:lb/>IRSNB, KHC, LELW, MCSN, MHN, MIZS, MLSU, MNHN, MUM, NM, NMB, NR, PC, RNH, RSM,<tei:lb/>TM, UM, USNM, UZI, UZM, VRC, ZC, ZIL, ZMU, ZSBS).</tei:p>

      </tei:div>

         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Female. Width of lower face 0-90 times vertical length of eye. Malar space 0-55-0-65 times<tei:lb/>basal width of mandible. Maxillary palp as in Fig. 26. Gaster very weakly compressed, not reaching to tips of fore wings (when folded<tei:lb/>back). Tergite 3 with a crease along its anterior 0-4 separating laterotergite. Tergite 7 and sternite 6 as in<tei:lb/>Fig. 96.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour: black and yellow, the margins of some yellow areas slightly reddish. Face black with yellow<tei:lb/>orbital stripes. Maxillary palp yellowish with segments 1 dorsally, 4 distally, and 5 wholly dark.<tei:lb/>Posterior part of propodeum yellow, entirely or with posterior margin black. Hind coxa black with a large<tei:lb/>yellow dorsal patch. Hind femur black, narrowly reddish yellow proximally and distally. Segments of<tei:lb/>gaster black, narrowly yellow posteriorly.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>36 M. G. FITTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Antennal flag setae (similar to Fig. 127, but with setae narrower) upright, flattened, 2 per segment, arising<tei:lb/>from a polished trough.          <tei:p>Colour: black and yellow, the margins of some yellow areas slightly reddish. Antenna black dorsally,<tei:lb/>yellow ventrally.          <tei:p>Banchus punkettai sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 27, 51, 75, 97, 117)<tei:lb/>[Banchus nox Morley; Chandra &amp; Gupta, 1977: 182. Misidentification.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Female. Width of lower face 0-75-0-80 times vertical length of eye. Malar space 0-45-0-60<tei:lb/>times basal width of mandible. Maxillary palp as in Fig. 27. Antenna with apical segments just broader than<tei:lb/>long. Scutellar spine (Fig. 51) about 0-5 as long as scutellum. Tergite 7 and sternite 6 as in Fig. 97.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour: black and yellow, with some reddish, especially on legs. Face yellow with a black median stripe,<tei:lb/>the stripe sometimes rather wide but with reddish yellow patches remaining below antennal sockets.<tei:lb/>Antenna brown, often rather darker dorsally and distally, with scape and pedicel blackish dorsally and<tei:lb/>yellowish ventrally. Posterior part<tei:lb/>of propodeum yellowish with a black patch medio-posteriorly, the yellow area sometimes reduced to a<tei:lb/>band along posterior transverse carina. Hind coxa black with a yellow dorsal patch and a red postero-<tei:lb/>ventral patch. Hind femur reddish with a blackish ventral stripe. Segments of gaster each black anteriorly,<tei:lb/>yellow posteriorly, with junction between two colours reddish. Tergite 1 also with posterior margin black<tei:lb/>and yellow area reduced to two lateral and/or one median spot(s).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male. Width of lower face 0-90 times vertical length of eye. Malar space 0-65 times basal width of<tei:lb/>mandible. Maxillary palp as in Fig. 117; segment 4 flattened and considerably widened; segment 5 about<tei:lb/>0-6 as long as 4. Antennal flag setae (similar to Fig. 124) relatively poorly differentiated, at about 50<tei:lb/>degrees, very short, not flattened, 2 per segment, without a polished trough. Hind femur 6-05 times as long<tei:lb/>as deep. Fore wing length 8-6 mm. Tergite 1 of gaster 1-90 times as long as broad. Tergite 3 with a crease<tei:lb/>along its anterior 0-5 separating laterotergite.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour: black and yellow, with some reddish, especially on legs. Antenna black dorsally, scape, pedicel<tei:lb/>and proximal flagellar segments yellow ventrally, remainder of flagellum brownish yellow ventrally.<tei:lb/>Maxillary palp with segment 1 yellow, 2 and 3 reddish yellow, 4 and 5 blackish. Posterior part of<tei:lb/>propodeum yellow, black postero-medially. Hind coxa black, with a dorsal yellow spot which is contiguous<tei:lb/>interno-laterally with a postero-ventral spot. Hind femur reddish, black ventrally and with a separate<tei:lb/>dorsal blackish area. Segments of gaster each black anteriorly, yellow posteriorly, the junction between the<tei:lb/>two colours very narrowly reddish.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The colour pattern of this species is very similar to two other species, flavomaculatus and nox,<tei:lb/>found in the same area. The males are easily identified using the flag setae but the females are more difficult<tei:lb/>to separate.</tei:p>

      </tei:div>

         <tei:p>ICHNEUMON-FLY GENUS BANCHUS 37</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BIOLOGY AND HOSTS. Virtually unknown. Adults have been collected in April and May. The specimens<tei:lb/>collected by Kamath and Gupta came from mixed vegetation in coniferous forest (Gupta, 1975: (appendix)<tei:lb/>20,22).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION (Map 9, p. 35). Along the southern flank of the Himalayas and south-east into Burma,<tei:lb/>between about 2000 and 3000 m.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Banchus sanjozanus Uchida</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Banchus tholussp. n.</tei:p>
