In addition both these taxa share a number of<tei:lb/>developmental trends (underlying synapomorphies of Saether, 1979), most notably, the de-<tei:lb/>velopment of a sinuous ovipositor apex and the presence of dorsally convergent eyes in males.<tei:lb/>The second group, Ophioninae + Campopleginae, is supported by a larval specialization, the<tei:lb/>possession of an expanded labial sclerite. The petioles of these two taxa are similarly modified,<tei:lb/>although this development appears to have been paralleled in some tersilochines (primitive<tei:lb/>tersilochines have a more 'cremastine-like' petiole). Most ophionines and campoplegines<tei:lb/>possess an apomorphic short, straight ovipositor; even when it is long it is very similar in the two<tei:lb/>groups, being robust and up-curved.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>For the purposes of this study the Ophioninae is considered to be the sister-group of the<tei:lb/>Campopleginae, and the Campopleginae + Ophioninae is treated as the sister-group of the<tei:lb/>Cremastinae + Tersilochinae (Fig. 2).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Polarity determination and character coding</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The polarity of the majority of characters has largely been determined by the method of<tei:lb/>out-group comparison (Watrous &amp; Wheeler, 1981) using as out-groups the taxa mentioned<tei:lb/>above. Unfortunately this method does not work for all characters, usually because both states<tei:lb/>occur in both the group under study and the out-groups. In these cases the polarity assignment is<tei:lb/>based on unsatisfactory criteria such as common equals primitive, but this is stated in the<tei:lb/>discussion.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In many cases in the Ichneumonidae, character-states are progressive steps in the loss of<tei:lb/>ancestral features such as the occipital carina, propodeal carinae or segments of the palp. Such<tei:lb/>characters can be arranged in simple transformation series, from plesiomorphic to the most<tei:lb/>derived state. For example, -for maxillary palps - 5-segments to 4-segments to 3-segments. Such<tei:lb/>transformation series may simply be scored in binary form as two characters -</tei:p>
         <tei:p>8-1 8-2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>maxillary palp 5-segmented</tei:p>
         <tei:p>maxillary palp 4-segmented 1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>maxillary palp 3-segmented 1 1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>where = plesiomorphic and 1 = apomorphic. Hence 8-1 represents reduction from 5 to 4<tei:lb/>segments and 8-2 further reduction to 3. Such characters are obviously not independent for it is<tei:lb/>impossible to have a 0,1 coding as, if extreme reduction is observed, it is assumed that an<tei:lb/>intermediate stage has been passed through.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In other cases a particular structure may have been modified in one of several ways. For<tei:lb/>example, in the Ichneumonidae generally the mandible is bidentate equally, so in the Ophio-<tei:lb/>ninae teeth of the same length must be considered a plesiomorphic feature. Although the lower<tei:lb/>tooth is fairly constant in size, the upper may either be lengthened or shortened. Such a bifurcate<tei:lb/>series can be scored as two binary characters -</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4-1 4-2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>mandible equally bidentate</tei:p>
         <tei:p>upper tooth enlarged 1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>upper tooth reduced 1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thus character 4-1 represents enlargement of the upper tooth, whilst 4-2 represents reduction.<tei:lb/>Clearly a 1,1 coding cannot exist for such character pairs. All transformation series in the<tei:lb/>characters dealt with below have been treated in similar fashion.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>From the very large number of characters exhibited by the Ophioninae a number have been<tei:lb/>selected which show the greatest range of variation between the different genera. Included are<tei:lb/>all characters previously considered to be diagnostic of genera, and a number of additional<tei:lb/>features that have been found to be useful in delineating species-groups (e.g. in Gauld &amp;</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>74 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mitchell, 1978). Many other characters, features in which a single species differs from others in a<tei:lb/>species-complex, were excluded from this analysis. These characters, such as the shape of the<tei:lb/>alar sclerites, form of the microsculpture of the alitrunk, density of hairs on the wing surface,<tei:lb/>general colour pattern, relative length of the mid tibial spurs etc. , show a considerable range of<tei:lb/>variation within the species of any single genus and, in most cases, this range of variation is<tei:lb/>repeated in many genera. Such characters were considered to be unlikely to make significant<tei:lb/>contribution to resolving the phylogeny of the genera.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Characters used in the study</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the following section considerable space has been allocated to explaining the rationale<tei:lb/>involved in character scoring and polarity determination. Although this practice is not usual in<tei:lb/>all cladistic studies (characters are frequently relegated to an appendix) it is considered to be<tei:lb/>important in the present work. It is upon these scores that the results of any numerical analysis<tei:lb/>depend; consequently, this section is seminal to the entire work.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The characters and their polarity</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1-1, 1-2 Occipital carina. A complete occipital carina is plesiomorphic (0,0). It may be centrally<tei:lb/>interrupted (1,0) or absent (1,1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Mandibular axis. The plesiomorphic condition is for the axis of articulation of the mandible to be at 90 to</tei:p>
         <tei:p>the longest axis of the head. In a few ophionines the head is narrowed and the mandibular axis tilted<tei:lb/>almost into the vertical plane (1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Mandibular swelling. A flat outer mandibular surface is plesiomorphic for ichneumonids; the swelling</tei:p>
         <tei:p>present near the mandibular base of some ophionines is apparently a derived feature (1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4-1, 4-2 Mandibular teeth. The relative lengths of the teeth vary considerably in ichneumonids, but equally<tei:lb/>bidentate appears to be the plesiomorphic state (0). In ophionines the alternative specializations are -<tei:lb/>upper tooth elongate (1,0) and upper tooth reduced (0,1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5-1,5-2 Torsion of the mandibles. The plesiomorphic condition for ichneumonids is to have the teeth of the<tei:lb/>mandible aligned in the same plane as the mandibular axis (Figs 38, 39). Many ophionines have the<tei:lb/>mandible twisted from 5-50 so that the lower tooth is directed forwards (Fig. 40). In a few species the<tei:lb/>mandible is exceptional in being twisted more than 70 so that, when closed, the lower tooth occludes<tei:lb/>the internal, upper one. This torsion is here considered a serial development, from untwisted (0,0)<tei:lb/>through slightly twisted (1,0) to exceptionally twisted (1,1). The selective advantage of this torsion is<tei:lb/>not clearly understood, but it is suggested that it is important in facilitating egress from certain types of<tei:lb/>cocoon. It is noteworthy that not only do all species of the huge and successful genus Enicospilus have<tei:lb/>such mandibles, but the totally unrelated tryphonine genus Netelia (which is also nocturnal and has a<tei:lb/>similar host range) also has twisted mandibles.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>6-1, 6-2 Shape of the clypeal margin in anterior aspect. The shape of the clypeus is often characteristic of a<tei:lb/>group of ichneumonids. For example, in the pimplines it is usually bilobate, in the anomalonines<tei:lb/>convex with a central tooth, whilst in the ichneumonines it is usually flat and truncated. The weakly<tei:lb/>convex condition found in many ophionines, campoplegines and cremas tines is considered plesio-<tei:lb/>morphic. In the Ophioninae the clypeus may be modified one of two ways - either being strongly<tei:lb/>concave (1,0), or centrally produced and pointed (0,1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>7-1, 7-2 Clypeal profile. It is difficult to assign polarity to this character, but the widespread condition in the<tei:lb/>subfamily and in the closely related out-groups was assumed to be plesiomorphic. This is the<tei:lb/>possession of a virtually flat clypeus (0,0) (Fig. 39). The clypeus may be modified in one of two ways -<tei:lb/>either flared outwards (1 ,0) (Fig. 44) or with a groove present parallel to the margin, so that the actual<tei:lb/>margin is sharp (0,1) (Fig. 38).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>8-1, 8-2 Number of maxillary palp segments. The plesiomorphic condition for the Hymenoptera is<tei:lb/>6-segmented palps, but in the Ichneumonidae the number is reduced to 5. Fusion may occur between<tei:lb/>the distal two or three segments leading to a reduction in apparent segment number to 4 or 3. This<tei:lb/>character is scored as a transformation series, 5-segmented being 0,0, 4 being 1,0 and 3 being 1,1.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9 Shape of central segments of maxillary palp. In most primitive ichneumonids, virtually all members of the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>out-groups and many ophionines, the maxillary palp segments are slender and elongate. This is<tei:lb/>considered to be plesiomorphic. In a few ophionines the central segments are specialized, being<tei:lb/>globose.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>10 Maxillae. The maxillae of most ichneumonids resemble those of the more primitive mandibulate</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE 75</tei:p>
         <tei:p>hexapods (Richards, 1956). A few ophionines have the maxillae specialized, unusually elongated so<tei:lb/>that the galea projects below the mandibles. This apomorphic condition is found in species inhabiting<tei:lb/>dry areas and is presumed to be an adaptation to feeding from certain flowers.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>11 Labium. Like the maxillae, the labium is remarkably unspecialized in most ichneumonids. A few</tei:p>
         <tei:p>eremic ophionines possess greatly elongated glossae, an apomorphy that presumably has a similar<tei:lb/>function to character 10.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>12 Ocelli. The majority of ophionines exhibit a set of features, the so-called ophionoid facies (Gauld &amp;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Huddleston, 1976), common to nocturnal Hymenoptera. These features are here regarded as<tei:lb/>apomorphies of the entire Ophioninae. They include possession of greatly enlarged ocelli. The<tei:lb/>majority of species in the out-groups, being diurnally active, lack this specialization. Consequently the<tei:lb/>possession of enlarged ocelli must, within the Ophioninae, be regarded as a plesiomorphy. In a few<tei:lb/>areas where competition from other ichneumonids is low, e.g., remote islands, deserts, tops of high<tei:lb/>mountains, several ophionines have adopted a diurnal habit. This is presumed to be a secondary<tei:lb/>feature as several species retain some nocturnal features. However, these diurnal species have small<tei:lb/>ocelli, and in these cases small ocelli are considered apomorphic. Polarity determination of this<tei:lb/>character can be questioned as it is based on an a posteriori inference.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>13 Frontal grooves. Most ichneumonids, including almost all members of the out-groups, have the lateral</tei:p>
         <tei:p>part of the frons flat. In some ophionines a groove is present on either side, parallel to the inner orbit.<tei:lb/>Possession of this groove is regarded as a specialization.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>14-1, 14-2 Flagellum length. In most ichneumonids the flagellum is setaceous and consists of a large<tei:lb/>number of more or less identical segments (flagellomeres). In the majority of ophionines there are<tei:lb/>between 45 and 65 such segments, and the flagellum is about as long as the fore wing. This is<tei:lb/>considered, because of its common occurrence within the group, to be the plesiomorphic condition.<tei:lb/>The flagellum appears to be modified in one of two ways. Either the segments may be very short and<tei:lb/>transverse (scored 1 ,0) or the number may be greatly increased (to between 75 and 95) so the flagellum<tei:lb/>is very much longer than the fore wing (0,1). A short flagellum is found in many species inhabiting hot,<tei:lb/>dry areas, and is perhaps an attempt at reducing an evaporative surface. A very long flagellum is found<tei:lb/>in species inhabiting humid areas, particularly rain forest canopies. Similarly shortened or elongated<tei:lb/>antennae can be observed in other groups, e.g. the Anomaloninae (Gauld, 1976).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>15-1, 15-2 Spiracular sclerite. In most ichneumonids, including the majority of species in the closely related<tei:lb/>out-groups, the spiracular sclerite is exposed and is clearly visible near the upper hind corner of the<tei:lb/>pronotum (Fig. 42). This is considered to be plesiomorphic. A large number of ophionines have the<tei:lb/>upper corner of the pronotum somewhat broadened and notched to partially occlude the spiracular<tei:lb/>sclerite (1,0), whilst in a few species this flap completely covers the sclerite (1,1) (Fig. 43).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>16-1, 16-2 Notauli. The notauli are grooves in the mesoscutum that appear to extend backwards from the<tei:lb/>anterior margin, and at their most extreme, reach the scuto-scutellar groove. The presence of these<tei:lb/>grooves seems to be a plesiomorphic feature (0,0), as they are well developed in many sawflies and are<tei:lb/>visible in many fossil apocritans. However, notauli are not present in all members of the out-groups so<tei:lb/>some doubt remains about the correct polarity of this character. The majority of ophionines only have<tei:lb/>vestigial notauli impressed at the extreme anterior margin of the mesoscutum (1,0), whilst in several<tei:lb/>they are absent entirely (1,1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>17 Pronotal crest. The plesiomorphic condition for ichneumonids is possession of a more or less flat<tei:lb/>pronotum dorsally. In several ophionines a crest is present to protect the neck region, possibly against<tei:lb/>attacks by asilids which habitually kill Hymenoptera by piercing the cervical region. The presence of<tei:lb/>this crest is regarded as an apomorphy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>18-1, 18-2 Mesopleural furrow. The plesiomorphic condition of the ichneumonid mesopleuron is for it to<tei:lb/>be relatively flat with a small pit (the episternal scrobe) near to the middle of the mesopleural suture<tei:lb/>(Townes, 1969). Amongst ophionines two specializations have apparently arisen - the presence of a<tei:lb/>diagonal groove from the pit to just below the subalar prominence (1 ,0) or possession of a groove from<tei:lb/>the pit to the upper end of the epicnemial carina (0,1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>19 Epicnemial carina. It is a plesiomorphic feature for ichneumonids to have this carina complete,<tei:lb/>extending laterally from the medioventral line to near the subalar prominence. In a number of taxa the<tei:lb/>lateral portion of this carina is lost (1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>20-1, 20-2 Scutellar carinae. These carinae are of sporadic occurrence throughout the Ichneumonidae but<tei:lb/>in many of the more primitive groups such as Pimplinae they are not developed. In the majority of<tei:lb/>species in the out-groups these carinae are absent, suggesting that their absence in ophionines may be<tei:lb/>a plesiomorphic feature. When present these carinae may be short, reaching to or not quite to the<tei:lb/>centre (1,0), or they may be virtually complete, reaching 0-8 or more of the length of the scutellum<tei:lb/>(1,1).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>76 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>27-7, 27-2 Metanotal protuberances. The hind rim of the metanotum of most ophionines, as well as most<tei:lb/>campoplegines and cremastines, is unspecialized. In a few ophionines a small lateral tooth is<tei:lb/>discernible (1,0), whilst in some taxa this tooth is apparently enlarged to form a protuberance that<tei:lb/>extends back almost to the propodeal spiracle (1,1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>22-7, 22-2 Propodeal anterior area. The anterior part of the propodeum (Fig. 50), immediately behind the<tei:lb/>metanotum, is, in ichneumonids, characteristically depressed to form a transverse groove which is<tei:lb/>often somewhat broadened medially behind the postscutellum. This presumably plesiomorphic state<tei:lb/>is found widely in Ophioninae and in virtually all members of the out-groups. Two modifications from<tei:lb/>this pattern have been observed. In some species the groove is broadened (lengthened) and striate,<tei:lb/>and thus forms a broad shallow concavity, almost as if the insect had been stretched (Fig. 51) (1,0).<tei:lb/>The other adaptation is for the groove to be much deeper and present as a U-shaped furrow (Fig. 52)<tei:lb/>(0,1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>23 Propodeal spiracle. In the majority of ophionines and members of the out-groups the propodeal<tei:lb/>spiracle is oval or even subcircular, with the longest axis 4 or less times as long as the shortest. A few<tei:lb/>ophionines have very large, very elongate spiracles which are 8 or more times as long as broad. This is<tei:lb/>considered to be an apomorphic development.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>24-1, 24-2 Anterior transverse carina of the propodeum. The presence of this carina, like the other<tei:lb/>propodeal carinae, is a plesiomorphic feature of ichneumonids as they are complete in fossils<tei:lb/>(Townes, I913b). The reduction of this carina is a progressive feature and has been coded as follows -<tei:lb/>complete (0,0), present only centrally (1,0), absent (1,1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>25-7, 25-2 Posterior transverse carina of the propodeum. Coded as for character 24 for the same reasons.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>26 Longitudinal propodeal impression. The plesiomorphic condition for ichneumonids is to have the<tei:lb/>dorsum of the propodeum more or less flat. In a few ophionines a deep longitudinal impression is<tei:lb/>present and this is considered to be an apomorphic feature.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>27-7, 27-2, 27-3 Posterior transverse carina of the mesosternum. This carina is usually complete in<tei:lb/>campoplegines and cremastines and thus a complete carina is here considered plesiomorphic for the<tei:lb/>Ophioninae. The carina is usually lost at two points on either side of the midline, before the mid coxae,<tei:lb/>so that central and lateral vestiges remain (1,0,0). Sometimes the central vestige is completely lost so<tei:lb/>only lateral traces remain (1,1,0). In a few species reduction seems to have occurred by loss of only the<tei:lb/>central part so two broad lateral portions remain (0,0,1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>28-1, 28-2 Lateromedian longitudinal carina of the propodeum. Coded as for character 24 for the same<tei:lb/>reasons.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>29-7, 29-2 The thyridium. This is a moderately large indentation found on the second gastral tergite. In its<tei:lb/>plesiomorphic condition it is close to the anterior margin of the tergite (0,0), but in a number of<tei:lb/>ophionines it can be seen to have been displaced posteriorly, leaving a scar between itself and the<tei:lb/>tergal margin (0,1). In a few taxa the thyridium is absent (1,0).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>30 Epipleuron of tergite 2. This is a difficult feature to determine the polarity of as within the out-groups</tei:p>
         <tei:p>both conditions occur widely. In most ophionines it is upturned, and in a few otherwise specialized<tei:lb/>taxa it is pendant. The latter condition is tentatively considered to be apomorphic.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>31 Profile of tergite 2. Tergite 2 is laterally compressed in ophionines and members of the closer out-groups</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 2). In profile it is much longer than posteriorly deep. In a few ophionines it is quadrate and this is<tei:lb/>considered to be an apomorphic development.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>32 Position of spiracles on tergite 1. The plesiomorphic condition for ophionines and members of the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>out-groups is for the spiracles to be at or behind the level of the margin of the sternite. In a few taxa the<tei:lb/>spiracles are situated before the sternite margin, a presumed apomorphic condition (1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>33 Presence of an umbo on tergite 2. The umbo is a convex area on the midline at the anterior margin of</tei:p>
         <tei:p>tergite 2. It is typically present in many ophionines and members of the out-groups. The apomorphic<tei:lb/>state (1) is where this structure has been lost.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>34 Ovipositor length. The length of the ovipositor varies a great deal between ichneumonid taxa. Probably</tei:p>
         <tei:p>the ancestral condition for the family was long, but almost every evolutionary lineage shows<tei:lb/>reduction. Virtually all ophionines have short straight ovipositors resembling those of many campo-<tei:lb/>plegines (Townes, 1970), and thus this condition is considered to be plesiomorphic. The long<tei:lb/>ovipositors found in a few taxa are considered to be apomorphic features (1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>35 Ovipositor sheath. The ovipositor sheaths (valvulae 3) of ichneumonids are almost always slender, just</tei:p>
         <tei:p>wide enough to enclose the ovipositor. In a few ophionines the sheaths are very stout. This is<tei:lb/>considered to be an apomorphic development (1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>36-7, 36-2, 36-3 Position oflm-cu in relation to Cu la in the fore wing. In most ichneumonids these two veins<tei:lb/>are quite widely separated and are often at least as far apart as 0-75 of the length of Cu lb . With some<tei:lb/>reservation this is considered to be the plesiomorphic state (0,0,0). In many ophionines these veins are</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>77</tei:p>
         <tei:p>separated by about 0-5 times the length of C lb (1,0,0), in a number of species by about 0-25 times<tei:lb/>(1,1,0), whilst in a very few instances the veins are practically contiguous (1,1,1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>37 Length of second discal cell. The plesiomorphic condition for ichneumonids generally, including</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ophionines, is for the length of the second discal cell (measured along C la ) to exceed 1-10 times the<tei:lb/>length of the first subdiscal cell (measured along Cui). In a number of ophionines the second discal cell<tei:lb/>is unusually short, being less than the length of the first subdiscal cell. This is considered to be an<tei:lb/>apomorphic feature (1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>38 Presence of a ramellus. The ramellus on Im-cu in the fore wing is apparently a remnant of the vein that</tei:p>
         <tei:p>divided the first discal from the submarginal cell (the two are confluent in all extant ichneumonids<tei:lb/>though present in fossil forms (Townes, 19736)). The retention of this stub is tentatively considered to<tei:lb/>be a plesiomorphic feature, but I have some doubts about the polarity assignment for similar reasons<tei:lb/>to those stated in 47-1 below.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>39 Base o&gt;/Rs+2r in fore wing. In the majority of ophionines and members of the out-groups this vein is</tei:p>
         <tei:p>emitted from the pterostigma at about 30 to the fore margin of the wing; the base of the vein is straight<tei:lb/>(Fig. 3). In some ophionines the angle of emission is greater (40+) and the vein is rather sharply bent<tei:lb/>basally (Fig. 4). This is considered to be an apomorphic feature (1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>40 Shaft o/Rs+2r in fore wing. The plesiomorphic condition for Hymenoptera generally is for this vein to</tei:p>
         <tei:p>be centrally straight; this condition is found widely in out-groups and many ophionines (Fig. 3). In<tei:lb/>some ophionines the vein is markedly sinuous just before the centre and this (Fig. 6) is considered to<tei:lb/>be an apomorphic development (1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>41 Position of confluence o/Rs and R! in fore wing. In virtually all ophionines and many members of the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>out-groups these veins meet at the extreme distal apex of the wing so the marginal cell is very long. In a<tei:lb/>few ophionines the confluence of these veins is more proximal on the fore margin of the wing, away<tei:lb/>from the tip, so the marginal cell is correspondingly shorter (Fig. 4). This is considered to be an<tei:lb/>apomorphic feature (1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>42-1, 42-2 Shape of pterostigma. In most ichneumonids the pterostigma is quite broadly triangular and this<tei:lb/>plesiomorphic condition prevails in most species in the out-groups. In some ophionines the ptero-<tei:lb/>stigma is still broad (0,0) but in many it is not abruptly narrowed distally but evenly tapered (1 ,0) (Figs<tei:lb/>4, 6). In a few the pterostigma is much more slender and elongately tapered (1,1) (Fig. 5).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>43-1, 43-2 Position of distal abscissa of Cu } in hind wing. It is very difficult to assign polarity to this<tei:lb/>character as all stages from Ci close to M to Cui close to L4 can be found in members of the<tei:lb/>out-groups. Furthermore, in most Campopleginae this vein is lost. However, in some of the more<tei:lb/>primitive ichneumonids the usual condition is for this vein to be closer to M than to L4 . This is<tei:lb/>tentatively assumed to be the plesiomorphic condition (0,0). The derived states, treated as a<tei:lb/>transformation series are: intermediate between M and \A (1,0) and closer to IA than to M (1,1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>44-1, 44-2 Shape o/Rs in hind wing. The plesiomorphic condition of this vein in ichneumonids generally,<tei:lb/>including many ophionines, is for it to be straight (0,0). In many ophionines it is quite distinctly</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 3-6 Fore wings: 3, Ophion; 4, Simophion; 5, Stauropoctonus; 6, Enicospilus.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>78 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>concave whilst in a few taxa it is exceptionally curved so that the distal portion is parallel to the fore<tei:lb/>margin of the wing. These two derivations are treated as a transformation series and coded 1,0 and 1,1<tei:lb/>respectively.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>45-1, 45-2 Glabrous area in fore wing. All primitive ichneumonids, most taxa in the out-groups, and<tei:lb/>virtually all lower Hymenoptera have the membrane of the fore wing uniformly hirsute close to vein<tei:lb/>Rs+2r. This is treated as the plesiomorphic condition (0,0). In most ophionines a small glabrous area<tei:lb/>is present in the discosubmarginal cell near where the pterostigma emits Rs+2r. This is considered<tei:lb/>apomorphic (1,0). A further specialization is for this area to be very extensive, reaching at least 0-3 of<tei:lb/>the way along Rs+2r (1,1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>46 Alarsclerites. The possession of alar sclerites is an unusual apomorphic feature of certain ophionines.<tei:lb/>Other than in this subfamily these sclerites are only found in two species of ichneumonid (and then in<tei:lb/>different positions). Elsewhere in the Hymenoptera alar sclerites are apparently only found in some<tei:lb/>pepsine pompilids (M. C. Day, pers. comm.).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>47-1, 47-2 Shape of 7m-cu in fore wing. In the lower Hymenoptera this vein (which in fact is almost<tei:lb/>certainly not just \m-cu but a composite of this and other vein parts) is angled centrally so the<tei:lb/>antero-proximal side of the 2nd discal cell is angulate at about 90. In many ophionines this angulation<tei:lb/>is present (Fig. 3) and often accompanied by a ramellus (see character 38). This is here tentatively<tei:lb/>considered to be the plesiomorphic condition (0,0). In many species this vein is evenly curved (1,0),<tei:lb/>whilst in some it is further modified by being sinuous (1,1). I have certain reservations about<tei:lb/>the polarity of 47-1 as the evenly curved condition is the widespread condition amongst the out-<tei:lb/>groups.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>48-1, 48-2 Length of3r-m in the fore wing. In the majority of more primitive ichneumonids 3r-m is longer<tei:lb/>than the abscissa of M between 2m-cu and 3r-m. In many ophionines this is also the case and it is here<tei:lb/>considered to be the plesiomorphic state (0,0). In some ophionines 3r-m is shorter, 0-75-0-50 times as<tei:lb/>long as M (1,0), whilst in a very few it is extremely reduced, 0-35 or less times the length of M (1,1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>49 Position of abscissa ofCuj between 7m-cu and Cu la . This vein is positioned at about 90 to the axis of the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>fore wing in most ichneumonids and virtually all lower Hymenoptera. In some ophionines it is<tei:lb/>specialized in being turned so that it is almost parallel to the wing axis (1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>50 Position of cu-a in fore wing. The plesiomorphic cdndition of this vein in ichneumonids is for it to</tei:p>
         <tei:p>subtend an angle of about 90 to Cu^. In a few ophionines it is strongly oblique, subtending an angle of</tei:p>
         <tei:p>50-60 (1).<tei:lb/>51-1, 51-2 Flange on fore tibial spur. The plesiomorphic state for ichneumonids is the possession of a</tei:p>
         <tei:p>membranous flange on almost the entire length of the fore tibial spur, immediately behind the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>microtrichial 'comb' (Fig. 48) (0,0). In some ophionines this is reduced to about 0-3 of the length of the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>spur (1,0), whilst in others it is entirely lost (Fig. 49) (1,1).<tei:lb/>52-7, 52-2 Form of hind trochanter. The possession of a simple margin to the trochanter is plesiomorphic</tei:p>
         <tei:p>for ichneumonids (0,0). In a few ophionines a small marginal tubercle is present (1,0), whilst in some</tei:p>
         <tei:p>cases this may be long, curved and pointed (1,1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>53 Dorsal margin of hind trochanter. This is also unspecialized in most ichneumonids, but some ophionines</tei:p>
         <tei:p>are unusual in having a specialization - the margin extended as a flange over the articulation of the<tei:lb/>trochantellus (1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>54 Hind tibial spurs. In many ophionines and members of the out-groups these spurs are flattened</tei:p>
         <tei:p>internally and bear a long fringe of close hairs. In some ophionines they are specialized in being<tei:lb/>cylindrical and bearing only scattered hairs (1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>55 Penultimate distal hamulus. The unspecialized condition in Hymenoptera is for the hamuli to be of</tei:p>
         <tei:p>similar size and shape. In some ophionines the penultimate hamulus is specialized in being very much<tei:lb/>longer and more coiled than its fellows (1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>56 Grouping of distal hamuli. The plesiomorphic condition for Hymenoptera is for the row of hamuli to be</tei:p>
         <tei:p>fairly evenly spaced. In a few ophionines they are arranged in two groups, an apparently specialized<tei:lb/>condition (1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>57 Number of hamuli distally. Most primitive Hymenoptera have from 9 to about 15 distal hamuli and, as</tei:p>
         <tei:p>this condition is widespread in primitive ichneumonids and many ophionines, it is considered<tei:lb/>plesiomorphic in context of this study. Some ophionines have only 4 or 5 distal hamuli and this<tei:lb/>reduction is considered to be an apomorphic condition (1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>58-1, 58-2 Shape of hind tarsal claw. In most members of the out-groups and many primitive ichneumonids<tei:lb/>the tarsal claws are fairly evenly curved (Fig. 45) and this condition, where it occurs in ophionines is<tei:lb/>considered to be plesiomorphic (0,0). In Ophioninae the claw may be modified in one of two ways -<tei:lb/>either by being longer and straighter (1,0) or by being almost geniculate (0,1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>59 Colour of inter ocellar area. In most Hymenoptera this area is concolorous with the vertex. In a few</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE 79</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ophionines it is sharply chromatically contrasted, and this is tentatively considered an apomorphic</tei:p>
         <tei:p>feature (1).<tei:lb/>60 Distal pectinal tooth of hind tarsal claw. The claws of ophionines possess a sinuous row of pectinal teeth</tei:p>
         <tei:p>or pectinae (Gauld &amp; Mitchell, 1978) forming a comb-like internal surface. This is apparently an</tei:p>
         <tei:p>apomorphy of the subfamily, so in the present context such a claw may be considered a plesiomorphy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In some ophionines the claw is specialized in having the distal pectinal tooth on the outer surface of the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>main tooth (Fig. 46) (1).<tei:lb/>61-1, 61-2 Taper of mandibular teeth. In most primitive ichneumonids the mandible is weakly tapered so</tei:p>
         <tei:p>that the distal apex is more than 0-5 times as broad as the base. This is considered to be the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>plesiomorphic condition where it occurs in ophionines (0,0). Some species have the mandible more</tei:p>
         <tei:p>strongly tapered so the apex is 0-4-0-5 times as wide as the base (1,0) whilst a few are exceptional in</tei:p>
         <tei:p>having the apex &lt;0-3 times as wide as the base (1,1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>62 Thickness of base of Rs+2r. The plesiomorphic condition for Ichneumonidae is for this vein to be</tei:p>
         <tei:p>slender at its junction with the pterostigma. In some ophionines it is specialized in being broadened so<tei:lb/>that close to the pterostigma it is more than twice its central thickness (1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>63 Presence of laterotergite 1 of gaster. In primitive ichneumonids a distinct laterotergite is present</tei:p>
         <tei:p>associated with tergite 1 ; vestiges of this may be found by partial dissection in many ophionines. Some<tei:lb/>are specialized in having lost this structure (1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>64 Presence of a pectinal comb on both sides of male claw. The plesiomorphic condition for ophionines is</tei:p>
         <tei:p>for a single sinuous pectinal comb to be present on the tarsal claws; some males are specialized in<tei:lb/>having this comb present as a double row of teeth, surrounding a flattened central area (1) (Fig. 47).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Preliminary remarks on the relative values of the characters</tei:p>
         <tei:p>For analytical purposes all characters have been treated initially as having equal numerical<tei:lb/>weight. However, a practising taxonomist does not value characters equally. Intuitively he is<tei:lb/>more likely to consider some to be more important than others. 'Good' characters are likely to<tei:lb/>include many of the more bizarre morphological adaptations (Gauld &amp; Mound, 1982). At the<tei:lb/>other extreme, characters may be considered to have very little value as indicators of phylo-<tei:lb/>genetic affinity. This is often for one of three reasons.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(a) The apomorphic state of the character may involve the disappearance of a structure and, as<tei:lb/>it is obvious that certain structures are frequently lost in parallel in many distantly related<tei:lb/>lineages (e.g. the occipital carina has been lost in some taxa independently in virtually all<tei:lb/>ichneumonid subfamilies), one suspects that an absence in two closely related taxa could also be<tei:lb/>the result of parallel reduction.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(b) There may be some doubt concerning polarity. This is particularly true in cases where one<tei:lb/>postulates that a particular state is an apomorphy for the subfamily, but advocates reversal in a<tei:lb/>few exceptional taxa (e.g. character 12, ocellar size).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(c) Even if the apomorphic condition involves the development of a particular structure, the<tei:lb/>character may be judged to be unstable, as examination of out-groups suggests it has been<tei:lb/>derived independently in numerous evolutionary lineages, or is correlated with a particular size<tei:lb/>range or extreme habitat occupied by a particular species. For example, very large ichneu-<tei:lb/>monids often have similarly coarse reticulate propodeal sculpture, whilst eremic species have<tei:lb/>short, stout antennae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The third of these reservations is discussed for individual characters in a subsequent section,<tei:lb/>but it is appropriate to mention a and b here. Those of the characters used in this study which<tei:lb/>involve an apomorphic 'loss' are listed below with an asterisk(*), whilst those in which the<tei:lb/>polarity assignment is suspect are denoted by a prime mark('). This convention is used<tei:lb/>extensively in the cladograms presented in the following sections. For comparative purposes a<tei:lb/>list is given below.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1-1*, 1-2*, 2, 3, 4-1, 4-2*, 5-1, 5-2, 6-1, 6-2, 7-1', 7-2', 8-1*, 8-2*, 9, 10, 11, 12*, 13, 144', 14-2',<tei:lb/>15-1, 15-2, 16-1*', 16-2*', 17, 18-1, 18-2, 19*, 20-1, 20-2, 21-1, 21-2, 22-1, 22-2, 23, 24-1*, 24-2*,<tei:lb/>25-1*, 25-2*, 26, 27-1*, 27-2*, 27-3*, 28-1*, 28-2*, 29-1, 29-2*, 30', 31, 32, 33*, 34', 35, 36-1',<tei:lb/>36-2', 36-3, 37, 38*', 39, 40, 41, 42-1, 42-2, 43-1', 43-2', 44-1, 44-2, 45-1, 45-2, 46, 47-1', 47-2,</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>80</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>48-1, 48-2, 49, 50, 51-1*, 51-2*, 52-1, 52-2, 53, 54, 55, 56, 57*, 58-1, 58-2, 59', 60, 61-1, 61-2, 62,<tei:lb/>63*, 64.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The phylogenetic analysis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>An initial attempt was made to construct a Wagner tree, but with repeated runs it became<tei:lb/>obvious that there exists a large number of equally or almost equally (less than 1% difference in<tei:lb/>overall length) short trees, many of which exhibit quite different topologies. As there is no basis<tei:lb/>on which to prefer one of these, and there is no way of knowing whether all the shortest trees<tei:lb/>have been computed, Wagner analysis was initially rejected in favour of a more detailed study of<tei:lb/>characters and taxa using the programs LEQU.BAS and FOURS. From these it was possible to<tei:lb/>gain some indication of the 'shape' of the primary data set. Tentative groups of taxa recognized<tei:lb/>initially were reanalysed using Wagner and compatibility methods.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Preliminary analysis of data</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Analysis using LeQuesne test program, LEQU.BAS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Using the program LEQU.BAS the primary data matrix (Appendix 2) of 51 selected ophionine</tei:p>
         <tei:p>taxa was analysed (see Table 6). Of the 95 characters used, six, 8-2, 11, 28-1, 34, 49 and 53,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 6 Results of LeQuesne test on the primary data matrix (Appendix 2). Conventions follow table 2.<tei:lb/>Note that a character with a single incidence of one or other state logically cannot fail the test and is<tei:lb/>represented by .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Character number: incompatibilities observed expected 0/E ratio</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Grand total- 2598 observed. 3007.1 expected. Overall 0/E ratio = 0.86<tei:lb/>Ranking ratio of scoring characters</tei:p>
         <tei:p>64 8.1 21.2 27.3 16.1 6.2 25.1 55 2 3 40 60 52.2 52.1 46 7.2<tei:lb/>13 42.2 21.1 22.2 22.1 15.2 14.2 45.2 9 36.3 5.1 7.1 51.2 48.2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>58.1 14.1 24.1 51.1 48.1 15.1 63 45.1 30 12 17 42.1 57 6.1 18</tei:p>
         <tei:p>28.2 24.2 1.2 37 25.2 27.1 59 18.2 47.2 43.2 58.2 27.2 36.2 29<tei:lb/>29.1 43.1 16.2 31 44.1 41 44.2 56 50 36.1 10 4.2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5.2 47.1 35 54 23<tei:lb/>20.2 26 38 33 61.1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 4.1 61.2 62 32</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 20.1 1.1 19 39</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>81</tei:p>
         <tei:p>showed only a single discordant state. In the case of 28-1 and 49 the majority state was the<tei:lb/>derived condition, whilst in the remainder it was the plesiomorphic condition that predomi-<tei:lb/>nated. As a minimum of two discordant character-states is logically required for a failure, it<tei:lb/>follows none of these eight can fail; they are shown as .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The remaining 89 characters have two or more discordant states and therefore can potentially<tei:lb/>fail the test. Each character was paired with every other one (except for the alternatives n. 1 with<tei:lb/>.2) and of the 7,855 comparisons made 2,598 resulted in failures. A total of 3,007 failures was<tei:lb/>expected, so although slightly better than random (O/E value = 0-86), the results suggest a very<tei:lb/>high incidence of homoplasy. For individual characters a considerable variation in O/E ratio was<tei:lb/>observed. Characters 6-2, 84, 16-1, 21-2, 25-1, 27-3 and 64 all scored better than 0-55, whilst at<tei:lb/>the other extreme eight characters, 4-2, 10, 36-1, 41, 44-1, 44-2, 50 and 56 all scored worse than<tei:lb/>1-00.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Examination of the labels matrix (Appendix 4) showed that two taxa, 909 and 922, had been<tei:lb/>labelled exceptionally frequently (scoring 89 and 85 labels respectively). Six further species, 906,<tei:lb/>908, 921, 923, 942 and 951, were labelled between 45 and 67 times, whilst the rest were labelled<tei:lb/>less than 42 times. Sixteen taxa were labelled less than ten times and three, 912, 913 and 933 were<tei:lb/>not labelled at all.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As would be expected, the elimination of bad characters (i.e. those with an exceptionally high<tei:lb/>O/E score) produced, in general, a progressive improvement in the O/E ratios of the surviving<tei:lb/>characters. However, the average ratio improved very slowly. With 20 informative characters<tei:lb/>remaining it was still 0-34. This clearly shows that not all the failures of the 'better' characters<tei:lb/>were due to clashes with the worst characters; the majority of characters seem to be somewhat<tei:lb/>homoplastic! Complete elimination of homoplasy (as advocated by LeQuesne, 1972) results in<tei:lb/>the removal of virtually all characters. The largest cliques contain only ten compatible<tei:lb/>characters. Several of these have only a very low information value (i.e. have only two or three<tei:lb/>derived states), but five more informative characters (2, 6-2, 15-1, 15-2 and 22-2) were found to<tei:lb/>be universal to all the larger cliques. All of these are features that have been used previously in<tei:lb/>ichneumonid higher classification (Cushman, 1947; Townes, 1971). These characters support<tei:lb/>the cladogram shown in Fig. 7. Only the group supported by character 2 corresponds with any<tei:lb/>previously recognized grouping of taxa, the Thyreodon group of Cushman (1947).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>905 909<tei:lb/>910-911<tei:lb/>916-918<tei:lb/>923 948<tei:lb/>938 939<tei:lb/>941</tei:p>
         <tei:p>906 927</tei:p>
         <tei:p>935 937</tei:p>
         <tei:p>901 904</tei:p>
         <tei:p>907 908</tei:p>
         <tei:p>921</tei:p>
         <tei:p>912 915</tei:p>
         <tei:p>919 920</tei:p>
         <tei:p>928 934</tei:p>
         <tei:p>940 945</tei:p>
         <tei:p>"</tei:p>
         <tei:p>922</tei:p>
         <tei:p>924 926</tei:p>
         <tei:p>932 934</tei:p>
         <tei:p>942 944</tei:p>
         <tei:p>946 947</tei:p>
         <tei:p>15.2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>15.1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>22.2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 7 Cladogram supported by largest clique of compatible characters.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>82 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The rate at which the O/E values of individual characters improved (after removal of bad<tei:lb/>characters) varied tremendously. For example, after removal of the eight worst characters<tei:lb/>(Table 7), character 29-1, initially the seventy-eighth placed (and the twelfth one scheduled for<tei:lb/>elimination) progressively improved (with the elimination of each worse character) to sixty-<tei:lb/>seventh. Character 59, initially placed as sixty-sixth, steadily worsened its position to eighty-<tei:lb/>third ; it would in fact be the tenth character eliminated . If the ten worst characters were removed<tei:lb/>en bloc they would have been 4-2, 10, 36-1, 50, 56, 44-2, 41, 44-1, 31 and 16-2. By stepwise<tei:lb/>removal of the worst character they would be 4-2, 10, 50, 36-1, 44-1, 41, 39 and 59. All further<tei:lb/>'cleaning-up' of data was done by stepwise removal of characters.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 7 Results of a LeQuesne test on the primary data matrix after the progressive removal of the<tei:lb/>highest scoring characters (4-2, 10, 50, 36-1, 44-2, 56, 44-1, 41). Conventions follow table 2; non-<tei:lb/>informative characters omitted.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Character number: incompatibilities observed expected O/E ratio</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Grand total- 2179 observed, 2613.3 expected. Overall O/E ratio = 0.83<tei:lb/>Ranking ratios of scoring characters</tei:p>
         <tei:p>64 8.1 21.2 27.3 16.1 6.2 2 25.1 55 3 60 40 52.1 52.2 54 42.2 5.2 47.1 23 46 7.2<tei:lb/>35 22.2 13 21.1 14.2 15.2 22.1 45.2 51.2 7.1 5.1 36.3 9 58.1 48.2 20.2 51.1 4.1 26<tei:lb/>6.1 33 14.1 61.1 15.1 38 12 45.1 42.1 48.1 63 30 61.2 24.1 57 1.2 62 32 17 18.2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>29.1 24.1 18.1 1.1 37 25.2 28.2 20.1 19 27.1 43.1 47.2 43.2 27.2 29.2 36.2 59 31</tei:p>
         <tei:p>58.2 39 16.2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It is apparent from the generally high O/E values that homoplasy is a common feature in the<tei:lb/>Ophioninae. Any attempt to produce a character set without homoplasy (a clique) necessitates<tei:lb/>excluding the great majority of characters, including some of the most informative ones. This is<tei:lb/>unacceptable for two reasons.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(1) A large amount of information would have to be discarded leaving many unresolvable<tei:lb/>situations. As 2N t 2 apomorphies are necessary to fully resolve N t taxa, a minimum of 100<tei:lb/>compatible characters would be needed to fully resolve the ophionine data. Consequently,<tei:lb/>without homoplasy, even the full set of 95 characters is insufficient for full resolution. Excluding<tei:lb/>autapomorphies for definition of terminal taxa, a minimum of 49 characters is necessary for</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE 83</tei:p>
         <tei:p>resolution, but in the present case it can be seen that even discarding half the characters, the<tei:lb/>resultant data set would still be extremely homoplastic.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(2) It is important to realize that just because a character is homoplastic and has been derived<tei:lb/>independently in two (or more) lineages, this does not mean that it is not of phylogenetic value.<tei:lb/>Such a character can still be a genuine synapomorphy for species in two different groups of taxa,<tei:lb/>and many minimally homoplastic characters are still highly regarded by traditional taxonomists.<tei:lb/>For example, Mason (1981) states that one of the major synapomorphies of the Braconidae (the<tei:lb/>probable sister-group of the Ichneumonidae) is the fusion of the second and third gastral<tei:lb/>tergites. Approximately six of the 60,000 species of Ichneumonidae also have tergites 2 and 3<tei:lb/>fused. This parallelism in a few specialized ichneumonids does not eliminate the character as a<tei:lb/>useful apomorphy for defining Braconidae in a phylogenetic sense, it merely reduces the value of<tei:lb/>the character as an infallible means of identifying braconids. If it were possible to consider all<tei:lb/>species of the two taxa Ichneumonidae and Braconidae, it is likely that the O/E value of this<tei:lb/>character would be very low, but if the analysis were of all Parasitica, and a few taxa from each<tei:lb/>family were selected as examples of the range of morphological variation, it is quite possible that<tei:lb/>one of the six anomalous ichneumonids would be included, giving the character a much larger<tei:lb/>O/E value, and consequently risking its exclusion. In the present study certain species of<tei:lb/>Enicospilus, Leptophion and Laticoleus were deliberately selected to show the range of<tei:lb/>morphological variation in the genus, so it is highly likely that these will contribute to the high<tei:lb/>level of homoplasy in the way outlined above.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the LeQuesne analysis eight characters were eliminated stepwise until none of the remainder<tei:lb/>scored worse than 1-00. The particularly high O/E value of these characters strongly suggests<tei:lb/>they are particularly homoplastic, and consequently of no real value in phylogenetic reconstruc-<tei:lb/>tion. Considered from a biological point of view it certainly seems these features are homo-<tei:lb/>plastic, but even so several seem to be of use in defining possible holophyletic groups.<tei:lb/>Considered in order of 'worst' first these characters are as follows.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4-2*: reduction of upper tooth of mandible. The occurrence of the derived state of this feature is<tei:lb/>limited in the matrix to three species, Rhynchophion flamipennis (908), Sicophion pleuralis<tei:lb/>(922) and Enicospilus unidens (946). Amongst the Ophioninae in general, this feature is found in<tei:lb/>the apomorphic state in a group of Madagascan and southern Indian species of Enicospilus<tei:lb/>(Gauld &amp; Mitchell, 1978; 1981) that seem to be related to E. unidens, an apparently unrelated<tei:lb/>Melanesian species (E. interruptus Szepligeti) and in an Indian Ophion species. Thus although<tei:lb/>the character has phylogenetic value in some cases (the definition of the unidens group) in others<tei:lb/>it has none. Presumably the apomorphic condition found in three taxa in the matrix is the result<tei:lb/>of parallel derivation, a conclusion that is strongly suggested by the very high label values<tei:lb/>(Appendix 4). Amongst out-groups this character is of similar sporadic occurrence (cf. Townes,<tei:lb/>1970), sometimes defining an apparent clade and other times being characteristic of a single<tei:lb/>species. Structurally it is a simple adaptation for biting through fibrous cocoons and as such it is<tei:lb/>not surprising that it has apparently arisen independently in many different evolutionary<tei:lb/>lineages.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>10: elongation of maxillae. This too is a low information value character as the apomorphic<tei:lb/>condition occurs in just two taxa in the matrix, Rhynchophion flamipennis (908) and Sicophion<tei:lb/>pleuralis (922). Amongst other ophionines it is limited in occurrence to some Neotropical<tei:lb/>species of Eremotylus. All of these taxa are restricted to the drier areas of Central and South<tei:lb/>America and the structural development seems to be an adaptation to drinking from certain<tei:lb/>flowers. Similar structural modification can be observed in many other ichneumonids in similar<tei:lb/>habitats, including many Tersilochinae, Cremastinae and Anomaloninae. In arid areas of<tei:lb/>south-western Australia species of three closely related cremastine genera, Trathala, Temelucha<tei:lb/>and Pristomerus, all have identically modified maxillae. Only familiarity with the world<tei:lb/>cremastine fauna enables one to recognize this as evolutionary convergence rather than<tei:lb/>considering it indicative of a holophyletic group. These observations strongly suggest that<tei:lb/>particularly intense selection pressures in a particular area may elicit the development in</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>84 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>parallel, of apparently identical apomorphic features in closely related lineages. This may<tei:lb/>explain the similarity between the taxa in the matrix.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>50: oblique position of cu-a in fore wing. Like the preceding two characters this is of low<tei:lb/>information content as the derived condition occurs in just two taxa in the matrix, Lepiscelus<tei:lb/>distans (909) and Barytatocephalus mocsaryi (927). Amongst other ophionines it is limited to<tei:lb/>occurring in one or two species of Ophion. In the sister-group to the Ophioninae, the<tei:lb/>Campopleginae, the derived condition apparently is useful for defining some genera (e.g.<tei:lb/>Cymodusa, see Townes, 1970) but the character has little apparent phylogenetic significance in<tei:lb/>the Ophioninae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>36-1': vein Im-cu separated from Cu la by less than 0-75, but more than 0-5 of the length ofCu lb .<tei:lb/>The majority of taxa have this character present in the presumed derived state. Only Lepiscelus<tei:lb/>distans (909), Stauropoctonus occipitalis (917), Riekophion emandibulator (920), Ophionopsis<tei:lb/>nigrocyaneus (921), Sicophion pleuralis (922), Rictophion nebulifer (937) and Enicospilus<tei:lb/>nephele (944) are plesiomorphic for this feature. It is not found in the plesiomorphic state in any<tei:lb/>other Stauropoctonus species, in most other Enicospilus species nor any other Riekophion<tei:lb/>species. If the state were a genuine symplesiomorphic feature of these taxa the 1 state must<tei:lb/>have been derived in parallel in at least species of Riekophion, Enicospilus and Stauropoctonus<tei:lb/>(assuming they are natural genera) and therefore the 1 state is not synapomorphic for all species<tei:lb/>so scored. Alternatively, if the 1 state is a genuine synapomorphy for all 'other taxa', the state<tei:lb/>must represent independent reversals in some taxa. Either way the character is homoplastic.<tei:lb/>The same argument can be applied even if the polarity is reversed, unless one were to accept the<tei:lb/>otherwise unsupported clade of 909+917+920+921+922+937+944.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>44-2: strongly curved Rs in hind wing. In the matrix the apomorphic state of this character is<tei:lb/>found in Simophion calvus (905), Lepiscelus distans (909), Laticoleus curvatus (915), Abancho-<tei:lb/>gastra hawaiiensis (925), Leptophion maculipennis (928), Euryophion adustus (936), Rictophion<tei:lb/>nebulifer (937) and Ophion luteus (939). Elsewhere in the subfamily all species of Ophion (ca 150<tei:lb/>species) have Rs strongly curved. The genus Abanchogastra is monotypic, but only some species<tei:lb/>of Leptophion, Enicospilus, Euryophion and Laticoleus possess the apomorphic state as do<tei:lb/>some species of Eremotylus and Ophiogastrella. In both Leptophion and Laticoleus this feature<tei:lb/>seems to define holophyletic species-groups, but there is no evidence to support the idea that it<tei:lb/>could be a synapomorphy of all the taxa listed above. Clearly it must have been derived<tei:lb/>independently in many ophionine lineages, but although a homoplastic feature, it is interesting<tei:lb/>to note that it still is quite characteristic of certain species-groups and even genera, suggesting<tei:lb/>that once the apomorphic state has been derived, it is unlikely to undergo reversal.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>56: separation of hamuli into two groups. This feature occurs in the matrix only in two<tei:lb/>Afrotropical species, Lepiscelus distans (909) and Laticoleus curvatus (915). The latter is the<tei:lb/>only species in its genus with this particular modification and Lepiscelus is monobasic (Gauld &amp;<tei:lb/>Mitchell, 1978). The apomorphic condition is also found in some central Asian Ophion species.<tei:lb/>The only feature these taxa seem to have in common is that they inhabit rather dry areas. The<tei:lb/>character appears to have little phylogenetic value.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>41: fore wing with R^ not reaching to tip. The apomorphic condition is found in Thyreodon<tei:lb/>atricolor (901), Simophion calvus (905), Orientospilus melasma (906), Ophionopsis nigro-<tei:lb/>cyaneus (921) and Sicophion pleuralis (922). It is not present in many other Thyreodon species so<tei:lb/>it is unlikely that the derived condition in 901 is synapomorphic with that of other species. The<tei:lb/>exclusion of 901 from the analysis actually resulted in a worsening of the O/E value of this<tei:lb/>character from 1-02 to 1-12, suggesting it is homoplastic in other taxa. The apomorphic state of<tei:lb/>this character is found in all species of the genera Simophion, Orientospilus and Ophionopsis,<tei:lb/>suggesting this feature, once derived, is not likely to undergo reversal.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>44-1: bowed vein Rs in hind wing. The apomorphic state of this character is found in all taxa<tei:lb/>listed under 44-2 above and additionally in 14 other taxa, all from different genera. Elsewhere<tei:lb/>the feature is of sporadic occurrence in Ophiogastrella, Aulophion, Leptophion, Laticoleus and</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE 85</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Enicospilus, as well as being present in all species of Dictyonotus, Hellwigiella, Sclerophion,<tei:lb/>Eremotylus, Xylophion and Rhopalophion. This suggests parallel development in many dif-<tei:lb/>ferent evolutionary lines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The high O/E values of several of these characters were surprising as almost all represent<tei:lb/>structural specializations (not 'loss' apomorphies or dubious polarity assignments). Several (4-2,<tei:lb/>41 and 44-2) do apparently have considerable phylogenetic value at certain hierarchical levels<tei:lb/>and really only two (36-1 and 44-1) are likely to be considered by a traditional taxonomist as<tei:lb/>category 3 'bad' characters. Character 10 almost certainly would intuitively be regarded as a<tei:lb/>'good' character (vide Cushman, 1947). It is interesting to note that two taxa (909 and 922) were<tei:lb/>cited for at least half of the eight worst characters, as having contributed to the high level of<tei:lb/>homoplasy . These taxa, also recognizable by their high label scores, were subsequently shown to<tei:lb/>be amongst the more difficult to place, and small differences in their position in the order of taxa<tei:lb/>submitted to the WAGNER program, produced large changes in the resulting cladogram.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Another estimate of incidences of homoplasy in the primary data may be obtained from<tei:lb/>perusal of the labels matrix (Appendix 4). Notably high scores, indicative of homoplastic<tei:lb/>derivation of the apomorphic state in two or more taxa, can be observed for character 1-2 (taxa<tei:lb/>909, 923 and 949), 4-1 (906, 909), 4-2 (908, 922, 946), 10 (908, 922), 26 (906, 923), 29-1 (922,<tei:lb/>937), 50 (909, 927), 56 (909, 915), 58-2 (942, 951) and 60 (928, 942). The shared plesiomorphic<tei:lb/>condition for character 38 in taxa 941 and 943 was also highly labelled, suggesting one or other<tei:lb/>has undergone reversal. Of these 11 characters, six (4-2, 10, 50, 56, 58-2 and 60) are highly<tei:lb/>labelled for all apomorphic states (two or three in each case), suggesting these are not useful<tei:lb/>characters for phylogenetic reconstruction. Rather suprisingly all are 'gain' apomorphies. Four<tei:lb/>(4-2, 10, 50 and 56) are amongst the eight characters eliminated in cleaning up the LeQuesne<tei:lb/>matrix; one other (58-2) has a higher than average O/E score, but surprisingly one (60) has a<tei:lb/>reasonably low O/E value.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Analysis using FOURS program</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Using the FOURS program a shared derived character matrix (Appendix 3) was computed. This<tei:lb/>shows the number of derived characters common to each pair of taxa and has values in the range<tei:lb/>of 3-37. Multiple linkage clusters drawn for taxa with 29+ shared derived characters are shown<tei:lb/>in Fig. 8. Four groups are apparent. The largest includes 17 species (912-5, 919, 924, 928-30,<tei:lb/>932-4, 942-3, 945-7), the last eight of which form a particularly closely knit group. Taxon 925<tei:lb/>and the reciprocal nearest neighbours 911 and 910 are less strongly associated with this group.<tei:lb/>This complex contains most of the species of Enicospilus and Leptophion, all Dicamptus,<tei:lb/>Laticoleus and Pamophion, together with Ophiogastrella and representatives of two of the three<tei:lb/>endemic Hawaiian genera, Pycnophion and Abanchogastra. It is noteworthy that Enicospilus<tei:lb/>nephele (944) and Leptophion tetus (931) are not associated. Each of these taxa share less<tei:lb/>derived characters with their supposed congeners than their congeners share with other taxa,<tei:lb/>although in each case the species' nearest neighbours are its congeners (Table 13).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Taxa 916, 917 and 918 (the Stauropoctonus group) form a cluster with 30-34 derived<tei:lb/>characters in common. This group seems to be associated with the Enicospilus group quite<tei:lb/>closely as 918 shares 28 derived characters with 947, 943, 942 and 919.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Taxa 935, 936 and 937 (the Euryophion group) cluster with 30-32 shared derived characters.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Taxa 901-4 (the Thyreodon group) form a cluster sharing 28-32 derived characters. Also<tei:lb/>associated with this cluster are the reciprocal nearest neighbours 907 and 921 (Dictyonotus I<tei:lb/>Ophionopsis).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>When linkages of more than 22 shared derived characters are considered (Fig. 9), the majority<tei:lb/>serve to consolidate the clusters already formed. The Stauropoctonus group and Ophiogastrella<tei:lb/>are repeatedly linked to the Enicospilus cluster (both having in excess of 60% of possible<tei:lb/>linkages to the latter) as does taxon 931. Taxa 926 and 944 are less strongly but uniquely<tei:lb/>associated with this group and taxon 949 also links to this group. The Thyreodon, Euryophion<tei:lb/>and Dictyonotus/ Ophionopsis groups, together with taxon 908, form a second robust cluster<tei:lb/>with only Euryophion showing any linkage to non-group taxa. Taxon 909 is somewhat</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>86</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>o</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I</tei:p>
         <tei:p>&lt;0<tei:lb/>TD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>O</tei:p>

      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>87</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 9 Multiple linkage clusters drawn for all taxa with 22 or more derived characters in common. As<tei:lb/>virtually complete linkages occur between taxa enclosed within the boxes, these linkages are not shown<tei:lb/>so as to avoid confusion.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>intermediate linking to both the Enicospilus and Euryophion groups but shares most derived<tei:lb/>features with taxa in the Stauropoctonus group.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Other taxa occupy a more ambivalent position. Taxon 906 is intermediate between Enico-<tei:lb/>spilus and Euryophion, whilst 905 appears to be fairly closely associated with Euryophion<tei:lb/>although its nearest neighbour is taxon 906. Taxon 927 is also intermediate. The remaining<tei:lb/>species, 920, 922, 923, 938-41, 948 and 950-51, are not closely associated with other taxa. To<tei:lb/>summarize therefore, two major groups are discernible, the Enicospilus/ Stauropoctonus com-<tei:lb/>plex containing taxa 909-919, 924-926, 928-934, 942-947 and 949, and the Thyreodonl<tei:lb/>Euryophion complex with taxa 901-904, 907-908, 921 and 935-937. Taxa 920, 922, 923,<tei:lb/>938^941, 948 and 950-951 are not associated at all whilst 905, 906 and 927 are intermediates<tei:lb/>between the major clusters. It is interesting to note that, excluding the last three taxa, the<tei:lb/>remainder could be classified phenetically (if one counted shared plesiomorphies of which 920,<tei:lb/>922, 938-941, 948 and 950-951 have a considerable number in common) into three groups<tei:lb/>approximately corresponding to the Ophion (plesiomorphic group) , Thyreodon and Enicospilus<tei:lb/>groups of Cushman (1947).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phylogenetic analyses of groups of ophionine taxa</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Euryophion group (taxa 935, 936, 937)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It can be seen from Appendix 3 that these taxa form a group with 30+ shared derived characters,<tei:lb/>and no more than 26 derived characters in common with any other taxon. Using these three as<tei:lb/>the fixed taxa (3F option) of FOURS, and trying them against all other taxa, nothing broke them<tei:lb/>up. The three taxa were found to share 29 apomorphies (2, 6-1, 7-1, 16-1, 16-2, 22-2, 24-1, 24-2,<tei:lb/>25-1, 25-2, 27-1, 28-1, 28-2, 31, 32, 38, 39, 42-1, 42-2, 43-1, 44-1, 454, 47-1, 49, 51-1, 51-2, 58-1,<tei:lb/>61-1 and 62). Five of these apomorphies (2, 7-1, 22-2, 42-2 and 58-1) have average or lower O/E<tei:lb/>values (0-60, 0-84, 0-80, 0-79 and 0-87 respectively) and are shared by relatively few other taxa in<tei:lb/>the matrix. Of these five apomorphies only one (7-1) has questionable polarity. No character is a</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>88</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>unique apomorphy of the group, but the four apomorphies accepted above suggest this group is<tei:lb/>monophyletic.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There are three possible arrangements of these taxa (Fig. 10). Taxa 935 and 936 have been<tei:lb/>considered to be congeneric (in Euryophion) whilst 937 is usually placed in a separate genus,<tei:lb/>Rictophion (Townes, 1971; Gauld &amp; Mitchell, 1978). Rictophion has been separated from<tei:lb/>Euryophion by two unique apomorphies, loss of thyridia and possession of 3-segmented palps.<tei:lb/>Cladogram A supporting this arrangement is the weakest of the three as it involves only a single<tei:lb/>informative character, 36-1 which has both a dubious polarity assignment and a very high O/E<tei:lb/>score. Both B and C also involve some poor scoring characters (19 and 44-2 both have O/E<tei:lb/>values of more than 0-95). Arrangement B is only supported by 'loss' apomorphies, though one<tei:lb/>(8-1) has a low O/E value (0-39). However, it has a rather high label score. The characters<tei:lb/>supporting C are all fairly high scoring (O/E values 0-76+) but do not involve either apomorphic<tei:lb/>loss or dubious polarity assignment. On balance therefore, C seems to be the preferable<tei:lb/>arrangement, suggesting that Euryophion, as currently recognized, is paraphyletic with respect<tei:lb/>to Rictophion. This conclusion is not surprising as originally Rictophion was separated from<tei:lb/>Euryophion on the basis of two autapomorphies. Rictophion ikuthana (937), the only species in<tei:lb/>the genus, can be regarded as a specialized species of Euryophion. These species, and all the<tei:lb/>remainder in the genus, are further analysed below (p. 136).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>935 936 937</tei:p>
         <tei:p>935 937 936</tei:p>
         <tei:p>936 937 935</tei:p>
         <tei:p>8.1*</tei:p>
         <tei:p>44. 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>54</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A B</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 10 The three possible dichotomous arrangements of Euryophion latipennis (935), E. adustus (936)<tei:lb/>and Rictophion ikuthana (937).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Thyreodon group (taxa 901, 902, 903, 904)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>These four taxa, all species currently placed in the genus Thyreodon (Townes &amp; Townes, 1966),<tei:lb/>form a closely knit group. Using the FOURS 3F option any combination of these species<tei:lb/>remained as a group when tested against any fourth taxon. The Thyreodon species share 27<tei:lb/>apomorphies (2, 6-2, 7-1, 14-1, 17, 22-2, 23, 24-1, 24-2, 25-1, 25-2, 27-1, 28-1, 28-2, 29-2, 30, 33,<tei:lb/>36-1, 38, 424, 42-2, 47-1, 49, 51-1, 51-2, 54 and 61-1). Seven of these apomorphies (2, 6-2, 7-1,<tei:lb/>22-2, 23, 42-2 and 54) have both lower than average O/E scores (0-60, 0-47, 0-84, 0-80, 0-78, 0-79<tei:lb/>and 76 respectively) and are shared by relatively few other taxa. Only one, 7-1, involves<tei:lb/>dubious polarity assignment; the remainder are gain apomorphies suggesting the group is</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>89</tei:p>
         <tei:p>monophyletic. Considering the possible phylogenetic relationships of these taxa to each other,<tei:lb/>the following result was obtained using the FOURS program (Underwood, 1982).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TAXA NOS.- 901<tei:lb/>X<tei:lb/>X'<tei:lb/>Y</tei:p>
         <tei:p>XYZ'<tei:lb/>XY'Z<tei:lb/>X'Y'Z'</tei:p>
         <tei:p>902</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The most favoured arrangement X,XYZ' is shown in Fig. 11. This involves three forward<tei:lb/>parallelisms 21-2 (in 901 and 903), 37 (in 901/2 and 904) and 36-2 (in 903 and 904) and one<tei:lb/>reversal (9 in 901). If the dubious polarity of 36-2 were to be reversed this character would fit the<tei:lb/>cladogram. It is noteworthy that some authors (e.g. Ashmead, 1900; Cushman, 1947) have<tei:lb/>placed taxon 904 and its relatives in a separate genus, Athyreodon.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>904</tei:p>
         <tei:p>12*, 13</tei:p>
         <tei:p>26, 58.1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 11 The arrangement of Thyreodon species as supported by the largest number of compatible<tei:lb/>characters.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The DictyonotuslOphionopsis group (taxa 907, 921)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>These two taxa are reciprocal nearest neighbours. They share 30 apomorphies (2, 6-2, 7-1, 12,<tei:lb/>13, 14-1, 16-2, 18-2, 21-1, 21-2, 22-2, 23, 24-1, 24-2, 25-1, 25-2, 28-1, 28-2, 30, 33, 38, 424, 42-2,<tei:lb/>44-1, 47-1, 49, 51-1, 51-2, 54 and 58-1). Ten of these (2, 6-2, 7-1, 21-1, 21-2, 22-2, 23, 42-2, 54 and<tei:lb/>58-1) have both average or lower O/E values (0-60, 047, 0-84, 0-79, 0-39, 0-80, 0-78, 0-79, 0-76<tei:lb/>and 0-87 respectively) and are shared by relatively few other taxa in the matrix. One character,</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>90 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>21 '2, is a unique apomorphy of this group. The primary label matrix (Appendix 4) suggests<tei:lb/>characters 16-1, 36-1 and 61-1 (0 scores in taxon 921) may have undergone reversal, whilst<tei:lb/>character 41-2(1 score in 921) may have been derived in parallel in 921 and other taxa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Thyreodon + Euryophion + Dictyonotus complex (the above three groups)<tei:lb/>These three groups of taxa appear to be associated (see shared derived character matrix,<tei:lb/>Appendix 3). Phylogenetically they also seem to form a distinctive clade, sharing 16 apomorphic<tei:lb/>features (2, 7-1, 22-2, 24-1, 24-2, 25-1, 25-2, 28-1, 28-2, 38, 42-1, 42-2, 47-1, 49, 51-1 and 51-2).<tei:lb/>Four of these apomorphies (2, 7-1, 22-2 and 42-2) have both lower than average O/E values<tei:lb/>(0-60, 0-84, 0-80 and 0-79 respectively) and are shared by very few other taxa. Character 2 is<tei:lb/>elsewhere only found in the apomorphic state in taxon 908, character 7-1 is apomorphic for taxa<tei:lb/>908, 940 and 946, character 22-2 is apomorphic for taxa 906, 908, 927 and 950, whilst character<tei:lb/>42-2 is otherwise only apomorphic for taxa 908, 909, 916, 917 and 918. Examination of the labels<tei:lb/>matrix (Appendix 4) shows that for character 7-1, species 940 and 946 are labelled more than<tei:lb/>twice as frequently as any other taxon. Similarly for character 22-2, species 906 and 950 are fairly<tei:lb/>highly labelled. These data suggest parallel derivation of the apomorphic condition of these<tei:lb/>characters in taxa 906, 940, 946 and 950.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Three other characters are found in the apomorphic condition in all except one taxon in the<tei:lb/>group . Of these ,61-1 has a high label score for taxon 921 , suggesting the apparent plesiomorphic<tei:lb/>condition in this taxon may be a reversal. Character 54 is present in the apomorphic condition in<tei:lb/>all taxa in this group except 935; elsewhere it is only found, in the data matrix, in the derived<tei:lb/>state in three taxa, 908, 941 and 950. The higher values of these last two species suggest the<tei:lb/>apomorphic state may have been derived in parallel in them. The third of the three characters,<tei:lb/>58-1, is usually found in the derived state in Thyreodon, so may be presumed to have undergone<tei:lb/>reversal in 904. Elsewhere it is only found in the apomorphic state in taxa 908, 909, 927, 941 and<tei:lb/>950. Taxon 909 has a high label score for this character, suggesting homoplasy. It seems<tei:lb/>reasonable to treat tentatively all these three characters as apomorphies of the group. This<tei:lb/>interpretation is certainly the most parsimonious, for in each case the alternative to single<tei:lb/>postulated reversals must be the advocacy of multiple forward parallelisms.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>One other taxon, 908, seems to be consistently associated with this group. Its nearest<tei:lb/>neighbours all lie within the group (Table 8), and in cluster analysis it readily associated with the<tei:lb/>group. It shares 18 of the 19 apomorphies of the group and is discordant only in having character</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 8 The Thyreodonl Euryophion complex showing nearest neighbours with numbers of shared<tei:lb/>derived characters. The rows give the five (or more if several are equal fifth) nearest neighbours of each<tei:lb/>taxon listed in the left-hand column. The columns show the number of times a species is cited as a near<tei:lb/>neighbour. It can be seen that taxon 908 occupies an intermediate position between Thyreodon (901-4)<tei:lb/>and Euryophion (935-7), having nearest neighbours in both. The Thyreodon and Euryophion groups<tei:lb/>have only one near neighbour in common (904-936). Only species in the latter group share large<tei:lb/>numbers of derived characters in common with non-group taxa (the 'others' column). It is interesting to<tei:lb/>note that taxon 907, the least autapomorphic in this group (see p. 89), is cited as a near neighbour by all<tei:lb/>other taxa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>901<tei:lb/>902<tei:lb/>903<tei:lb/>904<tei:lb/>907<tei:lb/>921<tei:lb/>908<tei:lb/>935<tei:lb/>936<tei:lb/>937</tei:p>

         <tei:p>28-2 plesiomorphic. However, this character is highly labelled for this taxon suggesting a<tei:lb/>reversal. In FOURS analyses taxon 908 repeatedly broke into the group. For example -</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TAXANOS.-901 921 936 908</tei:p>
         <tei:p>33</tei:p>
         <tei:p>33</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In both these cases exclusion of taxon 908 from the group, the XYZ' option, is not the most<tei:lb/>parsimonious solution. Accordingly, taxon 908, Rhynchophion flammipennis , is included for<tei:lb/>analysis in this group.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Considering only the ten taxa of this group, 35 characters are informative for examining<tei:lb/>intra-group relationships. A LeQuesne test on this subset of data yielded the results shown in<tei:lb/>Table 9. Progressive removal of the five worst characters (59, 36-1, 27-2, 9 and 39) markedly<tei:lb/>altered the ranking of the 'best' scoring characters (i.e. those with an O/E value of 0-6+) ; the<tei:lb/>overall O/E ratio improved from 0-69 to 0-52 (Table 10). The data matrix was re-ordered with<tei:lb/>characters arranged in increasing value of O/E ratio (Tables 11, 12) before and after removal of<tei:lb/>the worst characters. Considering only the characters with an O/E value greater than 0-55 shows<tei:lb/>that there are two competing patterns. Characters 16-2, 44-1, 31 and 32 unite the Euryophion<tei:lb/>group (935-7) with the Dictyonotus group (907, 921) and 908. This arrangement is contradicted<tei:lb/>by characters 14-1, 23, 33 and 6-2, which all favour uniting the Dictyonotus group with</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Thyreodon (901^). Characters 6-1, 8-1, 17, 26, 45-1 and 62 clash with neither of these<tei:lb/>combinations and so, in this context, are uninformative. The very best characters in the original<tei:lb/>35 character set (Table 11) favour the former grouping whilst in the 'cleaned-up' 30 character set<tei:lb/>(Table 12) the best characters favour Thyreodon + Dictyonotus. Of the eight characters in the<tei:lb/>two contradictory groups, two, 16-2 and 33, are 'loss' apomorphies and perhaps therefore the<tei:lb/>apomorphic state is particularly likely to be subject to parallel development. Even disregarding<tei:lb/>these one is still left with a tie with three characters supporting each arrangement, so it is<tei:lb/>necessary to consider further characters. Of the characters having an initial O/E value of average<tei:lb/>or better (16-2-16-1 in Table ll)two, 12 and 21-1, suggest uniting Thyreodon with Dictyonotus if<tei:lb/>one postulates minimal reversal in Thyreodon. Character 27-1 suggests uniting Thyreodon with<tei:lb/>Euryophion and taxon 908, whilst 21-2 is an autapomorphy of taxa 907 and 921. Character 39<tei:lb/>suggests linking a single Thyreodon species with Euryophion. Character 20-1 is apomorphic in<tei:lb/>only two taxa, 901 and 907.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Considering all characters the most parsimonious arrangement appears to be to treat<tei:lb/>Euryophion as the first branch. By postulating minimal homoplasy (i.e. single reversals or<tei:lb/>parallelisms) 12 characters can be made to support this arrangement. Only three, 30, 43-1 and<tei:lb/>44-2, have an O/E value below average, and only one, 33, is a 'loss' apomorphy. This<tei:lb/>arrangement involves the following homoplasy (and these are considered to be predictable from<tei:lb/>the Thyreodon labels matrix (Appendix 5) if, for a particular character, the score obtained by<tei:lb/>the presumed discordant species is higher than that obtained by other species in the group) - 12,<tei:lb/>reversal in 903/4 (not predictable); 30, reversal in 908, parallelism in 935 (predictable); 39,</tei:p>

         <tei:p>In attempting to resolve the sister-lineage of Euryophion, the Thyreodonl Dictyonotusl<tei:lb/>Rhynchophion branch, it is apparent that no character is a unique apomorphy of either<tei:lb/>Rhynchophion + Dictyonotus, Rhynchophion + Thyreodon or Dictyonotus + Thyreodon.<tei:lb/>Character 30 suggesting the latter is paralleled in taxon 935, 16-2 and 44-1 suggesting Rhyn-<tei:lb/>chophion + Dictyonotus are paralleled in Euryophion as is character 27-1 which favours uniting<tei:lb/>Rhynchophion + Thyreodon. In any compatibility cladogram (e.g. Fig. 12) these three taxa<tei:lb/>must remain as an unresolved trichotomy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>935/7</tei:p>
         <tei:p>17</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2, 7.1, 22.2, 24.1*, 24.2*. 25.1*, 25.2*. 28.1*.<tei:lb/>38*. 42.1, 42.2, 47.1, 49, 51.1*. 51.2*</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 12 Cladogram showing inter-relationships of taxa in the Thyreodon/ Euryophion complex as<tei:lb/>supported by the largest compatible clique.</tei:p>
