         <tei:p>94</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>To resolve these data further it was necessary to use the WAGNER option of PHYLIP. The<tei:lb/>shortest rooted tree obtained involved 83 transformation steps for the 45 characters showing<tei:lb/>both and 1 states for this group of taxa (that is the 35 characters shown in the LeQuesne matrix<tei:lb/>(Table 11) plus 1-1,4-2, 8-2, 10, 18-1, 29-1, 36-3, 43-2, 47-2 and 57 which are autapomorphies of<tei:lb/>various individual taxa). To obtain this tree (Fig. 13) 21 characters (1-1, 4-2, 6-1, 6-2, 8-2, 10,<tei:lb/>14-1, 17, 184, 21-2, 23, 26, 29-1, 33, 36-3, 43-2, 44-2, 45-1, 47-2, 57 and 62) are presumed to have<tei:lb/>been uniquely derived, 11 characters (8-1, 12, 16-2, 18-2, 20-1, 27-1, 39, 41, 43-1, 44-1 and 59)<tei:lb/>have undergone two transformations (i.e. have either been derived in parallel or have</tei:p>
         <tei:p>903 904</tei:p>
         <tei:p>936 937 907 921</tei:p>
         <tei:p>36.2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>16.1, 30, 36.1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 13 Most parsimonious cladogram for taxa in the Thyreodonl Euryophion complex. Black squares<tei:lb/>represent uniquely derived characters; circles, apomorphic features derived independently in two<tei:lb/>lineages; diamonds, in three lineages; squares, in four lineages, or involving four transformations.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE 95</tei:p>
         <tei:p>undergone reversal), 12 characters (13, 16-1, 19, 21-1, 27-2, 29-2, 30, 31, 32, 36-1, 36-2 and 37)<tei:lb/>have undergone three transformations, whilst one (9) underwent four. It is noteworthy that the<tei:lb/>cladogram shows only one of a number of competing cladograms with the same arrangement of<tei:lb/>taxa and the same number of transformation steps, but different positioning of the homoplastic<tei:lb/>characters. For example, character 30 is shown as a group apomorphy and is postulated as<tei:lb/>undergoing reversal in the stem 936/7, and in taxon 908, but it would be equally parsimonious to<tei:lb/>have suggested that 30 was derived in parallel in stems 901/4, 907/21 and taxon 935. Biologically<tei:lb/>neither is implausible.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Stauropoctonus group (Taxa 916, 917, 918)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>These three taxa share 29 apomorphies (1-1, 5-1, 5-2, 14-2, 16-1, 16-2, 18-2, 21-1, 22-1, 25-1,<tei:lb/>28-1, 28-2, 29-2, 33, 37, 38, 39, 42-1, 42-2, 45-1, 47-1, 49, 51-1, 51-2, 52-1, 52-2, 61-1, 61-2 and<tei:lb/>62). Six of these apomorphies (5-1, 5-2, 14-2, 21-1, 42-2 and 52-2) have both lower than average<tei:lb/>O/E values (0-84, 0-75, 0-83, 0-79, 0-79 and 0-71 respectively) and are shared by relatively few<tei:lb/>other taxa in the matrix.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Within this group all three possible arrangements of taxa are supported: 916 + 917 by 25-2*<tei:lb/>and 47-2; 916 + 918 by 1-2*, 36-1', 36-2', 43-1' and 63; 917 + 918 by 57*. All of these eight<tei:lb/>informative characters have high LeQuesne test failure rates (0-9+) and most are either loss<tei:lb/>characters or have dubiously assigned polarity, making the choice between arrangements<tei:lb/>difficult. The most parsimonious would obviously be 916 + 918. Currently 916 and 917 are<tei:lb/>placed together in Stauropoctonus whilst 918 is placed in a separate taxon, Aulophion (Cush-<tei:lb/>man, 1947; Townes, 1971). Aulophion has traditionally been separated from Stauropoctonus by<tei:lb/>the possession of two autapomorphies, loss of the posterior transverse carina of the meso-<tei:lb/>sternum and absence of the epicnemial carina. This suggests Stauropoctonus may be a<tei:lb/>paraphyletic assemblage. For the present these taxa are treated as an unresolved trichotomy,<tei:lb/>but their inter-relationship is discussed further below (p. 146). It is sufficient now to state that<tei:lb/>these three taxa seem to form a closely knit and apparently holophyletic group.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Enicospilus + Stauropoctonus complex (Taxa 909-919, 924-926, 928-934, 942-947)<tei:lb/>This, the largest apparent group of ophionine taxa in the matrix, contains 28 species. (N.B.<tei:lb/>Taxon 949 which associates with this group in the cluster analysis is exceptional in having the<tei:lb/>plesiomorphic state of a number of characters usually found in the apomorphic condition in this<tei:lb/>group (e.g. 25-2, 28-2, 42-1, 51-1, 51-2 and 63). For the present this taxon is excluded from the<tei:lb/>complex and its position discussed later in the work.) Their nearest neighbours are shown in<tei:lb/>Table 13. These taxa share four apomorphic features (16-1, 25-1, 28-1 and 51-1). A further 13<tei:lb/>characters (22-1, 25-2, 28-2, 33, 36-1, 38, 42-1, 43-1, 45-1, 47-1, 49, 51-2 and 63) are present in the<tei:lb/>apomorphic state in all except one, two or three taxa. Most of these characters are labelled,<tei:lb/>often highly, for the species in this group that show the plesiomorphic condition (e.g. 38 for<tei:lb/>taxon 943 and 47-1 for taxa 944 and 945), suggesting a reversal may have occurred. The<tei:lb/>exceptions are 22-1 and 33 which are plesiomorphic for taxa 910 and 911. Both are unlabelled in<tei:lb/>the primary label matrix (Appendix 4). Of the 17 characters listed above as possible apomor-<tei:lb/>phies of this complex, all except 22-1, 33 and 63 occur in the apomorphic condition in a large<tei:lb/>number of other ophionine taxa in the matrix. Individually therefore, they are not good<tei:lb/>characters for defining the group. Character 49 is plesiomorphic only in the solitary taxon 926,<tei:lb/>suggesting 49 may be an apomorphy of all ophionines, and 926, an otherwise specialized species,<tei:lb/>may have undergone a reversal. Character 16-1 is apomorphic for all taxa except 901-3 and 921;<tei:lb/>character 25-1 for all except 948 and 951 ; character 25-2 for all except 918, 920, 922, 923, 938-41,<tei:lb/>945, 948, 949 and 951; character 28-1 for all except 939; character 28-2 for all except 908, 920,<tei:lb/>923, 928, 938-41, 949 and 951; character 36-1 for all except 909, 917, 920, 921, 922, 937 and 944;<tei:lb/>character 38 for all except 938, 939, 941, 943, 948 and 951; character 42-1 for all except 905, 922,<tei:lb/>925, 938-41 and 948-50; character 43-1 for all except 901^, 908, 909, 917, 921-22, 925 and 941;<tei:lb/>character 45-1 for all except 901-4, 907-8, 921, 923, 925-26, 931, 941 and 948; character 474 for<tei:lb/>all except 938, 939, 943, 944, 948 and 951; character 51-1 for all except 920, 922, 939-41 and<tei:lb/>949-51; and character 51-2 for all except 920, 922, 932, 938-41 and 948-51. Ten of these<tei:lb/>characters (25-1, 25-2, 28-1, 28-2, 38, 42-1, 474, 49, 514 and 51-2) have been stated above (p.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>

Both cite their congeners as nearest neighbours, but neither is cited as<tei:lb/>near neighbours by its congeners.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>911 -- 28 - 28 30 27 30 +</tei:p>
         <tei:p>90) to be apomorphies of the ThyreodonlEuryophion complex, suggesting they are characters<tei:lb/>that unite the EnicospiluslStauropoctonus and ThyreodonlEuryophion generic complexes.<tei:lb/>Character 16- 1 could also be considered an apomorphy of both these major groups if one were to<tei:lb/>postulate reversal in 901-3 and 921.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Character 22-1 is found in the apomorphic state outside the EnicospiluslStauropoctonus<tei:lb/>complex only in taxa 920, 940, 949 and 951; character 33 in taxa 901^, 907-8, 920-22 and 949<tei:lb/>and character 63 in 905, 906 and 923. Character 33 is a loss apomorphy and has been cited above<tei:lb/>as an apomorphy of the ThyreodonlDictyonotus lineage. It is perhaps not unreasonable to<tei:lb/>postulate parallel loss in the EnicospiluslStauropoctonus, the ThyreodonlDictyonotus and the<tei:lb/>920, 922 and 949 lineages. However, this feature, the loss of the umbo, is not apomorphic for<tei:lb/>taxa 910 and 911 included above in the Enicospilus group. It is biologically rather unlikely that<tei:lb/>the umbo would be lost then redeveloped, so this feature favours placing Ophiogastrella<tei:lb/>(910-11) primitive with respect to the rest of the group. Such a position is also favoured by<tei:lb/>character 22-1. The apomorphic condition, a lengthened anterior part of the propodeum, is<tei:lb/>rather unlikely to have undergone reversal.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It is interesting to note that character 22 has two alternative derived states, 22-1 or 22-2. The<tei:lb/>derived state 22-2 is an apomorphic feature of the ThyreodonlEuryophion complex and is only<tei:lb/>found elsewhere in taxa 906 and 927. The alternative derived state characteristic of the<tei:lb/>EnicospiluslStauropoctonus group (less Ophiogastrella) is also found in very few other taxa (see<tei:lb/>above). The plesiomorphic condition (0,0) is found in taxa 905, 910, 911, 922, 923, 938, 939, 941<tei:lb/>and 948. The character seems to be important in defining two major sister-lineages of the<tei:lb/>subfamily.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>97</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Using the CLIQUE option of PHYLIP eight cliques were found with 12 or more informative<tei:lb/>characters. These were</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A (12)<tei:lb/>B(12)<tei:lb/>C(12)<tei:lb/>D(12)<tei:lb/>E(13)<tei:lb/>F(12)<tei:lb/>G(12)<tei:lb/>H(12)<tei:lb/>ADB</tei:p>
         <tei:p>18-1, 18-2, 21-1, 22-1, 27-3, 33, 35, 36-3, 42-2,61-1, 61-2, 64]<tei:lb/>15-1, 15-2, 18-1, 18-2, 21-1, 22-1, 27-3, 33, 35, 36-3, 42-2, 64]<tei:lb/>17, 18-1, 18-2,21-1, 22-1, 27-3, 31, 33, 39, 42-2, 60, 64]<tei:lb/>15-1, 17, 18-1, 18-2, 21-1, 224, 27-3,31, 33, 42-2, 60, 64]<tei:lb/>12, 14-2, 17, 18-2, 21-1, 22-1, 27-3, 31, 33, 39, 42-2, 60, 64]<tei:lb/>12, 15-1, 17, 18-2, 21-1, 22-1, 27-3, 31, 33,42-2, 55, 64]<tei:lb/>13, 18-1, 18-2, 21-1, 22-1, 33, 35, 36-3, 42-2, 61-1, 61-2, 64]<tei:lb/>13, 15-1, 15-2, 18-1, 18-2, 21-1, 22-1, 33, 35, 36-3, 42-2, 64]<tei:lb/>H = (18-2, 21-1, 22-1, 33, 42-2, 64}</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Av. O/E = 0-76<tei:lb/>Av. O/E = 0-75<tei:lb/>Av. O/E =0-78<tei:lb/>Av. O/E = 0-77<tei:lb/>Av. O/E = 0-78<tei:lb/>Av. O/E = 0-76<tei:lb/>Av. O/E = 0-79<tei:lb/>Av. O/E = 0-78</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The best clique in the sense of the largest is E but this has a lower average O/E value (0-78) than<tei:lb/>several others. B has the lowest average O/E value with 0-75, closely followed by A and F with<tei:lb/>0-76. The remainder have higher values. The cladograms based on the largest clique (E) and the<tei:lb/>best O/E scoring clique (B) are shown in Figs 14, 15. The cladogram produced from clique B<tei:lb/>associated the various taxa fairly well with their congeners. Species of Enicospilus (942-47),<tei:lb/>Dicamptus (932-34) and the Hawaiian genera (924-26) (regarded by Townes, 1971, as derived<tei:lb/>Enicospilus) cluster together, except for E. cionobius (945) which is excluded by having the<tei:lb/>plesiomorphic condition of 15-2 (possibly a reversal). Laticoleus (912-15) and Leptophion<tei:lb/>(928-30) species form a separate cluster as do the Stauropoctonus group (916-18) plus<tei:lb/>Lepiscelus (909). The cladogram derived from clique E has more confusing groupings, uniting<tei:lb/>some species of Enicospilus and Laticoleus (character 17) or defining a clade containing<tei:lb/>Dicamptus neavei, Leptophion tetus and Abanchogastra hawaiiensis (character 12). The heter-<tei:lb/>ogeneous collection of species united by character 14-2 includes representatives of Dicamptus,<tei:lb/>Enicospilus, Laticoleus and Leptophion; other species of these genera are excluded. The largest<tei:lb/>clique, E, is therefore not considered particularly useful in this case; clique B appears to be a<tei:lb/>better indicator of relationship. It is noteworthy that clique B is more informative (s = 0-681)<tei:lb/>than clique E (s = 0-632).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 14 Cladogram for taxa in the Enicospilus/ Stauropoctonus complex based on the largest clique (E).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>98</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 15 Cladogram for taxa in the EnicospiluslStauropoctonus complex based on the favoured clique (B) .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It is notable that the intersect of these cliques includes several characters previously<tei:lb/>considered to be good indicators of phylogenetic relationship (Cushman, 1947; Townes, 1971).<tei:lb/>Three (18-2, 21-1 and 42-2) support the group 909 + 916-18, whilst two others (22-1 and 33)<tei:lb/>place Ophiogastrella (910-11), primitive to the other taxa. Character 64 is an autapomorphy of<tei:lb/>Ophiogastrella.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A LeQuesne test was undertaken on the EnicospiluslStauropoctonus data set and the O/E<tei:lb/>values are given in Table 14. Stepwise elimination of all characters scoring worse than 1-00 (a<tei:lb/>total of 15) resulted in considerable cleaning up. The overall ratio improved from 0-89 to 0-74.<tei:lb/>Amongst the scoring characters the most striking changes in rank occurred to 1-2 which rose<tei:lb/>from thirty-fifth to eleventh position, and 62 which dropped from thirty-first place to position<tei:lb/>forty-three. Amongst the best scoring characters 42-2 and 18-2 rose from fourteenth and<tei:lb/>sixteenth positions to seventh and eighth positions (Table 15). Using the S option of FOURS the<tei:lb/>data set was reorganized with characters ranked as per O/E value after removal of the 15 most<tei:lb/>discordant characters (Table 16). It can be seen that the characters with the lowest O/E values,<tei:lb/>22-1 and 33, exclude Ophiogastrella (910-11) whilst 64 is an autapomorphy of this genus. A<tei:lb/>number of other characters may be postulated as apomorphies of Ophiogastrella, though all<tei:lb/>apparently have been derived in parallel elsewhere. Characters 18-2 and 42-2 support the<tei:lb/>Stauropoctonus group -I- 909, whilst 21-1 supports just the former. Character 1-2 is incompatible<tei:lb/>with 21-1. Initially it had a poor O/E score (0-93 compared with 0-54 for 21-1) but progressive<tei:lb/>elimination of the poorest characters produced rapid 'clean-up' until with 15 characters<tei:lb/>eliminated it scored 0-57 compared with 0-34 for 21-1. With only the 18 best characters left in the<tei:lb/>matrix both taxa scored equally 0-13. A considerable number of slightly homoplastic characters<tei:lb/>(e.g. 5-1, 5-2, 37, 52-1) support 21-1 but no other character supports 1-2 and it is for this reason<tei:lb/>that one would prefer the arrangement supported by the former character.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Several other characters support the Stauropoctonus + 909 group but necessitate postulating<tei:lb/>parallel derivation in other places . These include 1 1 (parallelism in 925 and 945) , 39 (parallelism<tei:lb/>in 930) ,61-1 (parallelism in 924-26 and 942-47) . Many of these parallelisms are also suggested in<tei:lb/>the reduced labels matrix (Appendix 6), e.g. taxon 930 for character 39 acquires almost half of its<tei:lb/>total number of labels and taxa 925 and 945 are quite highly labelled for character 1-1.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>99</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Character number: incompatibilities observed expected 0/E ratio</tei:p>

      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>100 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 16 The EnicospiluslStauropoctonus complex data set reordered according to O/E values of the<tei:lb/>characters given in Table 15. Characters to the left of 17 have an O/E value of average (0-74) or less.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>22.1 64 27.3 42.2 36.3 1.2 61.1 47.1 7.2 15.1 55 29.2 1.1 48.2 20.2 27.2 5.1 20.1 5.2 60 59 62 37 47.2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Character 15-1 is compatible with those characters that suggest treating 910 + 911 and 909 +<tei:lb/>916-18 as the first two branches. This unites all the other taxa to form a residual group that<tei:lb/>includes Enicospilus (942-47), Dicamptus (932-34), Leptophion (928-31), Laticoleus (912-15)<tei:lb/>and Pamophion (919). This is rather a difficult group to resolve. Two of the best characters, 13<tei:lb/>and 27-3, are incompatible. Character 35 suggests uniting Laticoleus (912-15) with Leptophion<tei:lb/>(928-3 1 ) , and this is partially supported by character 3 . No character unites all the taxa that show<tei:lb/>the plesiomorphic condition of 35. Three characters, 5-1, 61-1 and 61-2, suggest uniting the<tei:lb/>Hawaiian genera (924-26) with Enicospilus (942-47). Only one taxon, 944, is at variance for a<tei:lb/>single character, 61-2, and this has a high label value suggesting that a reversal to the<tei:lb/>plesiomorphic state may have occurred. In several places in the data set it is apparent that similar<tei:lb/>cases of a single taxon being at variance with its congeners is observable. In the case of 944, it is<tei:lb/>one of only about ten Enicospilus species out of nearly a thousand to have the plesiomorphic<tei:lb/>condition of character 61-2. Similarly 945 has the plesiomorphic state of 15-2. Both of these taxa<tei:lb/>do not appear to be primitive in any other features and as they are thus unlikely to be ancestral to<tei:lb/>all other taxa in the genus it is probable that the apparently unspecialized condition is a reversal.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Character 15-2 favours uniting the Hawaiian genera, Enicospilus and Dicamptus (932-34) and<tei:lb/>this is partially supported by character 40 although it is necessary to postulate reversal in the<tei:lb/>Hawaiian genera. Character 46 is similar. Character 7-2 is contradictory, suggesting a group<tei:lb/>comprising 912-15, 919 and 928-34. No characters satisfactorily separate Laticoleus (912-15)<tei:lb/>from Leptophion (928-31) though 27-1, 27-2 and 55 suggest some separation. Character 3<tei:lb/>suggests that Pamophion belongs to the Laticoleus I Leptophion lineage.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>101</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Using the CLIQUE option of PHYLIP on the data set with the basal taxa (910-11, 909,<tei:lb/>916-18) removed revealed the existence of four cliques with eight or more informative<tei:lb/>characters. These are</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A (8)<tei:lb/>B(9)<tei:lb/>C(8)<tei:lb/>D(9)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4-1, 5-1, 18-1, 27-3, 35, 36-3, 61-1, 61-2]<tei:lb/>4-1, 5-1, 27-1, 27-2, 27-3, 35, 36-3, 61-1, 61-2]<tei:lb/>4-1, 54, 13, 18-1, 35, 36-3, 61-1, 61-2]<tei:lb/>4-1, 5-1, 13, 27-1, 27-2, 35, 36-3, 61-1, 61-2]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Av. O/E = 0-81<tei:lb/>Av. O/E = 0-83<tei:lb/>Av. O/E = 0-86<tei:lb/>Av. O/E = 0-87</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A n B C D = (4-1, 5-1, 35, 36-3, 61-1, 61-2}</tei:p>
         <tei:p>These sets support very similar cladograms; the favoured one, with the lowest average O/E, is<tei:lb/>shown in Fig. 16, but all are similar in showing two large groups (912-15 + 928-31 and 924-26 +<tei:lb/>942-47) and leaving taxa 919 and 932-34 unresolved.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>18.1</tei:p>
         <tei:p/>
         <tei:p>61.2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5.1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>61.1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 16 Cladogram for taxa in the EnicospiluslStauropoctonus complex less taxa 909-911 and 916-8,<tei:lb/>based on the favoured clique (A).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Using the WAGNER option of PHYLIP several attempts were made to construct the shortest<tei:lb/>rooted tree possible. The minimum length tree (Fig. 17) necessitated 242 transformation steps.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Both parsimony and compatibility analyses have certain similarities. Both taxa 909 + 916-18<tei:lb/>formed a group primitive to most other taxa whilst Enicospilus (942-47) and Dicamptus<tei:lb/>(932-34) are amongst the most specialized taxa and separate from Laticoleus (912-15) and<tei:lb/>Leptophion (928-31). However, the Wagner parsimony method usually separated the Hawaiian<tei:lb/>taxa (924-26) as a relatively primitive, discrete group but placed Ophiogastrella (910-11) well in<tei:lb/>the Enicospilus/ Dicamptus/ Leptophion/ Laticoleus complex. Compatibility methods suggested<tei:lb/>the reverse. To assess the relative merits of these alternative arrangements it is necessary to<tei:lb/>evaluate the characters upon which they are based. As mentioned above, the exclusion of taxa<tei:lb/>910 and 911 is based on characters 15-1, 22-1 and 33 which are present in the apomorphic<tei:lb/>condition in all other taxa. The former two are striking structural modifications and whilst the<tei:lb/>latter is a loss apomorphy , it is an unusual reduction (when considered for the family as a whole).<tei:lb/>There is no apparent functional reason why these characters should be linked, so their<tei:lb/>congruence can be viewed as strong evidence for excluding 910-11 as the first branch. However,<tei:lb/>910 and 911 do have a number of apomorphies in common with many other taxa in the group,</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>102</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>IO CO</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 17 Minimum length cladogram produced by Wagner parsimony analysis of the Enicospilusl<tei:lb/>Stauropoctonus complex. This tree requires 242 transformation steps.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>especially the Laticoleusl Leptophion complex (e.g. characters 7-2, 27-1, 27-2, 20-1) which it<tei:lb/>must be assumed has been derived in parallel if Ophiogastrella is indeed the most primitive<tei:lb/>branch.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Wagner analysis united all taxa excluding the Stauropoctonus/909 complex on the basis of<tei:lb/>characters 15-1, 36-2 and 43-1. The former has been postulated as having undergone reversal in<tei:lb/>the stem 910 + 911 so cannot be considered a group apomorphy, whilst 36-2 is highly<tei:lb/>homoplastic in any favoured arrangement, and in the minimum length tree necessitates six<tei:lb/>transformations that include being developed, lost and subsequently redeveloped. In fact, this<tei:lb/>character is also present in the apomorphic condition in some Stauropoctonus (916, 918), and it<tei:lb/>is not stretching credibility to consider it an apomorphy of the entire group here being analysed,<tei:lb/>and postulate reversal in taxa 909 and 917. This hypothesis involves only a single additional<tei:lb/>transformation step, and would seem biologically more feasible than the gain-loss-gain scheme<tei:lb/>favoured by the Wagner analysis. The character itself, relative position of two wing veins, has<tei:lb/>not been used in higher classification, though it is of considerable use in separating species<tei:lb/>(Gauld &amp; Mitchell, 1978), and has doubtfully assigned polarity. It is also amongst the very worst<tei:lb/>characters suggested by the original LeQuesne test (see Table 6). The third character, 43-1, is<tei:lb/>found widely in the apomorphic condition throughout the Ophioninae. Either it has been</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE 103</tei:p>
         <tei:p>derived in parallel in the Euryophion group, in most Ophion and related taxa and in certain<tei:lb/>members of the present group, or it is an apomorphy of the Ophioninae and the apparently<tei:lb/>plesiomorphic state of most Stauropoctonus group taxa represents a further apomorphy.<tei:lb/>Initially the polarity of this character was considered to be tentatively assigned (p. 77).<tei:lb/>Elsewhere in the Ichneumonidae, although reliance is often placed on character 43-1 in generic<tei:lb/>keys, it is variable in most higher taxa (cf. Pimplinae in Townes, 1969), suggesting it is a highly<tei:lb/>homoplastic feature.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Other characters involved in placing Ophiogastrella high up the tree are 7-2, 20-2, 27-1, 27-2,<tei:lb/>37, 43-2, 45-2, 48-1 and 59. Of these, 7-2 and 59 are highly homoplastic, gain-loss-gain characters<tei:lb/>which seem biologically implausible, and they also have dubious polarity assignment. Character<tei:lb/>45-2 is postulated as having undergone reversal in the stem 910 + 911 so there remains five<tei:lb/>reasonably robust apomorphies uniting Ophiogastrella with the most specialized taxa (20-2,<tei:lb/>27-1, 27-2, 43-2 and 48-1). Considered individually, all of these characters are rather 'weak'. The<tei:lb/>remarks made above about 43-1 can also be applied to 43-2; the loss apomorphies 27-1 and 27-2<tei:lb/>have identical state distributions in this group and should perhaps be considered as a single<tei:lb/>feature, the loss of the posterior mesosternal transverse carina. This carina has been lost,<tei:lb/>presumably independently, in other ophionine evolutionary lines (e.g. Ophion, some Lepto-<tei:lb/>phion, some of the Stauropoctonus group) and has commonly been lost in many ichneumonid<tei:lb/>evolutionary lineages outside the subfamily under consideration. As a consequence it is not a<tei:lb/>character which seems to unite convincingly Laticoleus (912-5) with Ophiogastrella. It is<tei:lb/>interesting to note that there is at least some degree of correlation between the presence or<tei:lb/>absence of this carina and the type of habitat occupied. In groups where it is usually absent (e.g.<tei:lb/>the Phygadeuontinae), species inhabiting very wet areas have the carina complete. In the<tei:lb/>subfamily mentioned this includes common species of Paraphylax, Amauromorpha and<tei:lb/>Apsilops found in Old World rice padi. In the Anomaloninae the two closely related genera<tei:lb/>Therion and Heteropelma differ in this feature; the former is characteristically found on dry open<tei:lb/>areas, whilst most Heteropelma species occur in more humid woodlands (Gauld, 1976). In the<tei:lb/>Ophioninae the carina is always present in those species found in humid rain forests (e.g. most<tei:lb/>Enicospilus, Leptophion and Dicamptus) but is incomplete in species favouring drier, more<tei:lb/>exposed habitats (e.g. some Australian Leptophion, most Ophion). Both Ophiogastrella species<tei:lb/>and Laticoleus seem to favour drier forest habitats than Leptophion.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Character 20-2, the development of scutellar carinae, has probably been derived indepen-<tei:lb/>dently in several evolutionary lineages (e.g. some species of Ophion and Leptophion (Gauld &amp;<tei:lb/>Mitchell, 1981)), but it also appears to have undergone reversal in other groups (e.g. in taxon<tei:lb/>944 and also Enicospilus arduus (Gauld &amp; Mitchell, 1978)). It would be only slightly less<tei:lb/>parsimonious to suggest that the presence of complete scutellar carinae is an apomorphy of the<tei:lb/>entire Enicospilus I Stauropoctonus complex, and to suggest that it has been lost in a few lineages.<tei:lb/>Certainly the shared presence of these carinae is not a convincing character for uniting<tei:lb/>Ophiogastrella with other genera.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The remaining character, 48-1, is a difference in relative lengths of wing veins and its<tei:lb/>apomorphic state is found scattered throughout the subfamily.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>To summarize therefore, the decision on where to position Ophiogastrella hinges on two<tei:lb/>character sets, one of three unusual and fairly convincing apomorphies (15 1 , 22- 1 and 33) versus<tei:lb/>five widely distributed, and thus unconvincing, apomorphies (20-2, 27-1, 27-2, 43-2 and 48-1).<tei:lb/>The Wagner method, in attempting to minimize tree length, opts for including Ophiogastrella<tei:lb/>amongst the most derived species, whilst the compatibility method favours treating it as the most<tei:lb/>primitive taxon, thus eliminating homoplasy in three characters (22-1, 33 and 15-1) as the other<tei:lb/>characters are mutually incompatible.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The position of the Hawaiian genera (924-6) also presents a problem. In the parsimony<tei:lb/>dendrogram (Fig. 17) the five characters defining the stem 924 + 925 + 926 (5-1, 15-2, 36-3, 61-1<tei:lb/>and 61-2) also define at least part of the Enicospilus + Dicamptus branch (932-4 + 942-7)<tei:lb/>suggesting the Hawaiian genera could be placed on the larger branch, as in the compatibility<tei:lb/>dendrogram. The parsimony method has excluded the Hawaiian genera on the basis of<tei:lb/>characters 7-2, 20-2, 40, 43-2, 45-2, 46, 48-1 and 59. Of these 7-2 and 59 are the biologically</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>104 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>implausible gain/loss/gain characters with dubiously assigned polarity, so the real choice has to<tei:lb/>be made between the two character sets 5-1, 15-2, 36-3, 61-1 and 61-2 versus 20-2, 40, 43-2, 45-2,<tei:lb/>46 and 48-1.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Considering the first set first, characters 5-1, 61-1 and 61-2 are all mandible characters. The<tei:lb/>apomorphic state of all three is elsewhere only found in taxa 916-8 and 942-7 (excluding 944).<tei:lb/>Although this character set has almost certainly been derived independently in Stauropoctonusl<tei:lb/>Aulophion and Enicospilus it is not found elsewhere in the Ophioninae. It is of very rare<tei:lb/>occurrence in other parts of the family, and where it does occur it is usually characteristic of a<tei:lb/>group of genera e.g. the Orthocentrinae (Townes, 1971) and the XanthopimplalEchthromorpha<tei:lb/>group of Pimplini (Townes, 1969). Character 15-2, a completely concealed spiracular sclerite, is<tei:lb/>found in virtually all species of Enicospilus and Dicamptus. Elsewhere it is found in the derived<tei:lb/>condition only in the Hawaiian genera, in a few species of Leptophion and in the aberrant<tei:lb/>monotypic genus Sicophion (922). The final character in this set, 36-3, an extreme reduction in<tei:lb/>the length of a wing vein, is only found in a very few taxa, notably (in the matrix) the Hawaiian<tei:lb/>genera, some Enicospilus, Euryophion and Xylophion. Elsewhere in the Ophioninae it only<tei:lb/>occurs in some Dicamptus and one aberrant Laticoleus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The second and alternative character set (20-2, 40, 43-2, 45-2, 46 and 48-1) has partially been<tei:lb/>considered above where characters 20-2, 43-2 and 48-1 have been suggested to be rather poor<tei:lb/>indicators of phylogenetic affinity. Two of the Hawaiian genera show the derived state of 48-1,<tei:lb/>so it would be equally parsimonious to postulate that a reversal had occurred in one Hawaiian<tei:lb/>genus, as opposed to parallel derivation in the subgroup of two Hawaiian taxa and the major line<tei:lb/>in the larger group. The remaining characters all refer to the fore wing, in particular the<tei:lb/>antero-distal part of the discosubmarginal cell and the adjacent vein, Rs+2r. The apomorphic<tei:lb/>conditions of characters 40, 45-2 and 46 are the most characteristic features of Enicospilus/<tei:lb/>Dicamptus, though the same combination is also found in a very few other taxa (e.g. Riekophion<tei:lb/>species). Several species of Enicospilus may have one or more characters in the plesiomorphic<tei:lb/>state (e.g. the E. senescens species-group (Gauld &amp; Mitchell, 1978)), but the trace features<tei:lb/>found in one or two species suggests this condition represents a reversal. This suite of characters<tei:lb/>does seem therefore to be good evidence for excluding the Hawaiian taxa from the Enicospilus<tei:lb/>lineage. However, the plesiomorphic condition of all three of these characters occasionally is<tei:lb/>found in some Enicospilus species inhabiting oceanic islands, and in these cases it can be seen<tei:lb/>that a reversal has occurred as related taxa still have the apomorphic states. For example, the<tei:lb/>three species E. vidus, E. ditor and E. donor form a closely interrelated group on the Galapagos<tei:lb/>Islands (Gauld &amp; Carter, 1983) . They belong to the E. capensis species-group and probably have<tei:lb/>evolved from a migrant South American species, all of which have the apomorphic condition for<tei:lb/>characters 40, 45-2 and 46, as has E. vidus. In E. donor they all are plesiomorphic, whilst in E.<tei:lb/>ditor intermediate conditions exist. This strongly suggests reversal has occurred. A similar case<tei:lb/>can be demonstrated for Hawaiian Enicospilus (see Cushman, 1944). The majority of Enicospi-<tei:lb/>lus species are both synchronous and sympatric with numerous congeners. The three characters<tei:lb/>are developed in such a way as to form a distinctive, species-specific pattern (especially the exact<tei:lb/>shape of the sclerite, character 46) (see figs 384-641 in Gauld &amp; Mitchell, 1981). In areas where<tei:lb/>few species occur, such as deserts, there is considerable variation within a species in the exact<tei:lb/>expression of these characters. Possibly their reversal on oceanic islands is facilitated by a<tei:lb/>reduction in selection pressure that favours uniformity in areas of high possible interspecific<tei:lb/>interaction. It is possible that the apparent plesiomorphic condition of these characters in the<tei:lb/>Hawaiian genera is also a reversal, though in this case no definite close relatives are known.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The remaining character in the second set, 48-1, refers to the relative lengths of veins 3r-m<tei:lb/>and M . The apomorphic condition has previously been used only to characterize species and<tei:lb/>both states can be found in most genera, suggesting it is a rather homoplastic feature.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>To sum up, once again the Wagner method positioned a group on the basis of the larger set<tei:lb/>and again biological evidence suggests that perhaps this is incorrect and the position indicated by<tei:lb/>the compatibility method is more plausible.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The parsimony analysis united all species of Enicospilus (942-47) into a single clade but<tei:lb/>Dicamptus was paraphyletic with respect to this. This is not surprising as traditionally Enico-</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>105</tei:p>
         <tei:p>spilus is separated from Dicamptus on account of its specialized mandibles; Dicamptus is<tei:lb/>recognized only by the specialized features it has in common with Enicospilus plus the<tei:lb/>possession of unspecialized mandibles, a plesiomorphic feature (Townes, 1971). The compati-<tei:lb/>bility method proved to be less successful at producing groups corresponding with recognized<tei:lb/>genera, probably because Enicospilus and Leptophion are polythetic taxa (Gauld &amp; Mound,<tei:lb/>1982).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The relative positions of Leptophion, Laticoleus and Pamophion are less clear. The Wagner<tei:lb/>method suggested Leptophion and Laticoleus form separate groups, though both are charac-<tei:lb/>terized by the apomorphic condition of 35, and with one exception, 37. The compatibility<tei:lb/>method suggests Laticoleus + Leptophion form a group defined by character 35 and these two<tei:lb/>taxa, plus Pamophion, form a group defined by character 3.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>To conclude this section, on balance, secondary evidence suggests Ophiogastrella and the<tei:lb/>Hawaiian genera are better placed by the compatibility method whilst Enicospilus is most<tei:lb/>successfully aggregated by parsimony analysis. A 'hybrid' compromise cladogram was post-<tei:lb/>ulated that required 249 transformation steps (Fig. 18). This compromise arrangement groups<tei:lb/>various congeneric species together, thus to some extent corroborating the initial assumption<tei:lb/>that ophionine genera are not polyphyletic groups.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The relationship of the component genera of the Enicospilus/ Stauropoctonus complex can be<tei:lb/>illustrated most clearly if the highly homoplastic characters are omitted, the relative positions of</tei:p>
         <tei:p>"O X5</tei:p>
         <tei:p>o</tei:p>

         <tei:p>00 K) GO</tei:p>

      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>106</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>16-1, 25-1. 25-2, 28-1. 361, 38,42-1,<tei:lb/>43-1, 45-1, 471, 49, 51-1,51-2,63'</tei:p>

         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p/>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE 107</tei:p>
         <tei:p>species within genera disregarded (and the object of this part of the analysis is to establish the<tei:lb/>phylogenetic relationships of the genera) and single exceptional character scores, that are<tei:lb/>almost certainly incidences of homoplasy (e.g. 15-2 in taxon 945; 61-2 in taxon 944), ignored.<tei:lb/>This simplified cladogram together with supporting characters is illustrated in Fig. 19. Essenti-<tei:lb/>ally it is the same arrangement as Fig. 18.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This cladogram suggests that Stauropoctonus is paraphyletic with respect to Aulophion,<tei:lb/>Leptophion is paraphyletic with respect to Laticoleus and Enicospilus is paraphyletic with<tei:lb/>respect to the PycnophionlAbanchogastralBanchogastra lineage.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The major groups and their relationship with the unassigned taxa</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The inter-relationship of the two major generic complexes</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Enicospilus/ Stauropoctonus complex has been defined above as a holophyletic group on the<tei:lb/>basis of 17 apomorphies (16-1, 224, 25-1, 25-2, 28-1, 28-2, 33, 36-1, 38, 42-1, 43-1, 45-1, 47-1, 49,<tei:lb/>51-1, 51-2 and 63) (though Ophiogastrella is primitive in respect of two, 22-1 and 33) and the<tei:lb/>Thyreodon/Euryophion complex has similarly been defined by a possible 19 apomorphies (2,<tei:lb/>7-1, 22-2, 24-1, 24-2, 25-1, 25-2, 28-1, 28-2, 38, 42-1, 42-2, 47-1, 49, 51-1, 51-2, 54, 58-1 and 614).<tei:lb/>Ten of these apomorphic features (25-1, 25-2, 28-1, 28-2, 38, 42-1, 47-1, 49, 51-1 and 51-2) are<tei:lb/>common to both sets, suggesting a sister group relationship. Of the apomorphies remaining for<tei:lb/>defining the Thyreodon/Euryophion lineage, three (24-1, 24-2 and 61-1) occur extensively in<tei:lb/>various species-groups and species in the Enicospilus/ Stauropoctonus complex, thus weakening<tei:lb/>their credibility as characters defining the former lineage. Character 42-2 has apparently been<tei:lb/>derived in parallel in the Stauropoctonus line, but the remaining five features (2, 7-1, 22-2, 54<tei:lb/>and 58-1) are robust characters that strongly support the monophyly of the Thyreodonl<tei:lb/>Euryophion lineage. Of the six remaining apomorphies defining the Enicospilus/ Stauropoctonus<tei:lb/>lineage (16-1, 22-1, 33, 36-1, 45-1 and 63) two (22-1 and 33) exclude Ophiogastrella; the<tei:lb/>apomorphic state of 33 has also been derived in parallel in the Thyreodon line. The derived<tei:lb/>states of characters 16-1 and 36-1 occur in most species of the Thyreodon/Euryophion complex,<tei:lb/>suggesting they are group apomorphies, whilst the derived state of 45-1 also occurs, in parallel,<tei:lb/>in Euryophion. Character 63 is the single convincing apomorphy supporting the monophyly of<tei:lb/>the Enicospilus/ Stauropoctonus complex. A cladogram showing the putative phylogeny of these<tei:lb/>taxa is shown in Fig. 20.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The position of the unassigned taxa</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The position of the remaining taxa (905, 906, 920, 922, 923, 927, 938-41 and 948-51) can now be<tei:lb/>considered in relation to the robust arrangement of the majority of ophionine taxa presented<tei:lb/>above. To reduce the data matrix to more manageable proportions a number of hypothetical<tei:lb/>taxonomic units (HTUs) were constructed to represent genera reasonably placed in the earlier<tei:lb/>part of the work. Scores were assigned to these HTUs by marking each character with the<tei:lb/>condition found in the majority of species of the genus (including all taxa examined in earlier<tei:lb/>taxonomic studies (Gauld, 1977; Gauld &amp; Mitchell, 1978, 1981) but not included in the primary<tei:lb/>data matrix). This method of scoring, rather than deducing a hypothetical ancestor, was adopted<tei:lb/>because of the high incidence of homoplasy. This idiosyncracy is unlikely to alter any cladistic<tei:lb/>arrangement significantly, whereas the assumption that the group-ancestor has a particular<tei:lb/>character present in the plesiomorphic condition, based on occasional incidence of the occur-<tei:lb/>rence of the plesiomorphic (and possibly reversed) condition in some members of the group,<tei:lb/>could result in considerable alteration to the position assigned to the group. The HTUs utilized<tei:lb/>are 960 (Laticoleus), 961 (Ophiogastrella), 962 (Leptophion), 963 (Stauropoctonus), 964<tei:lb/>(Thyreodon/ Dictyonotus) , 965 (Euryophion), 967 (Dicamptus), 968 (Enicospilus). [N.B. There<tei:lb/>is no 966.] The character scores of these HTUs are given in Appendix 7.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The results of a LeQuesne test on taxa 905, 906, 920, 922, 923, 927, 938-41, 948-51 and 960-68<tei:lb/>are given in Table 17. The overall O/E value is strikingly high (0-90), indicating the extremely<tei:lb/>homoplastic nature of this data set. Perusal of the labels matrix (Appendix 8) shows that a large</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>108</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>16.1*', 25.1*. 25.2*. 28.1*. 28.2*, 36. 1'^<tei:lb/>38*', 42.1, 47.1', 49, 51.1*. 51.2*B</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 20 Putative phylogenetic inter-relationships between groups of taxa in the Enicospilus/Stauropocto-<tei:lb/>nus and ThyreodonlEuryophion complexes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>number of characters have been labelled highly for certain taxa; this will be discussed below.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Wagner analysis of this data set yielded a number of equally short cladograms with quite<tei:lb/>different topologies (Figs 21-24). A large number of other trees that were only slightly less<tei:lb/>parsimonious were also generated (Gauld, unpublished data). Compatibility analysis yielded a<tei:lb/>single largest clique of 11 informative characters (2, 3, 7-1, 17, 25-1, 26, 38, 40, 41, 47-1 and 52-1)<tei:lb/>which supports the cladogram shown in Fig. 25. Although differing in many topological details,<tei:lb/>certain features are common to the dendrograms. In all of the Wagner trees the two major<tei:lb/>complexes emerged as the most derived groups. Five taxa (938, 939, 941, 948 and 951) occupy<tei:lb/>the most primitive position in three of the dendrograms and are amongst the eight most primitive<tei:lb/>taxa in the other two, suggesting these species are amongst the most primitive of all ophionines.<tei:lb/>This group of species comprises examples of the genera Xylophion, Ophion, Agathophiona,<tei:lb/>Rhopalophion and Sclerophion, Gauld (1979) suggested these might represent a holophyletic<tei:lb/>group, the Ophion subgroup, characterized by having a slender Rs+2r, which is also straight<tei:lb/>basally, having an incomplete posterior transverse carina of the mesosternum, having a<tei:lb/>subapically impressed clypeus, having Im-cu usually with a ramellus, and always angled, and<tei:lb/>having the anterior area of the propodeum 'occluded'. However, the holophyly of the group is<tei:lb/>open to question. The shape of Rs+2r (corresponding to characters 39, 40 and 62), of Im-cu (38</tei:p>

      </tei:div>

         <tei:p>Ranking ratios of scoring characters</tei:p>
         <tei:p>47.1 25.1 40 2 38 3 46 22.1 36.3 59 7.2 55 6.1 19 45.2 15.2 33 58.1 23 54 14.2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>48.2 63 52.1 61.1 37 24.2 43.2 29.2 24.1 18.1 15.1 47.2 20.2 27.1 51.2 44.2 61.2<tei:lb/>5.1 9 27.2 18.2 7.1 17 26 57 12 25.2 28.2 41 44.1 1.1 16.2 62 51.1 22.2 32 29.1<tei:lb/>42.2 20.1 36.1 1.2 42.1 39 35 48.1 36.2 45.1 31 30 14.1 43.1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>and 47) and the form of the propodeum (22) are symplesiomorphies and therefore not<tei:lb/>admissable for defining a holophyletic group. Both the incomplete posterior transverse carina of<tei:lb/>the mesosternum (equivalent to 1 scores for 27-1 and 27-2) and the impressed clypeus<tei:lb/>(corresponding to a 1 score for character 7-2) are apomorphic features found in many other taxa.<tei:lb/>In many of the Wagner trees generated the five taxa formed a clade defined by characters 18-1<tei:lb/>and 44-1 in addition to 7-2 and 27-2 (27-1 is most parsimoniously considered an apomorphy of<tei:lb/>the subfamily) . All of these characters are highly homoplastic so it is not surprising that the<tei:lb/>compatibility cladogram leaves these taxa as an almost unresolved paraphyletic assemblage.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Four further taxa, 920 (Riekophion emandibulator) , 922 (Sicophion pleuralis) , 940 (Eremo-<tei:lb/>tylus boguschi) and 950 (Hellwigiella nigripennis) have been placed in the same group as the<tei:lb/>Ophion subgroup (Townes, 1971; Gauld, 1979). The undescribed genus (949) would, on<tei:lb/>Townes' (1971) criteria, also belong to this group. There is no evidence in any analysis that<tei:lb/>suggests that these taxa and the Ophion subgroup constitute a holophyletic clade. The definition<tei:lb/>of the group as adopted by previous authors rests on a plesiomorphic feature, possession of a<tei:lb/>membranous flange on the fore tibial spur, suggesting this 'group' is in fact a paraphyletic<tei:lb/>assemblage. In Wagner analyses 920, 922, 940, 949 and 950 may be positioned primitively with<tei:lb/>respect to most other taxa (e.g. Figs 22, 24) but some members may occasionally be united with<tei:lb/>other taxa. Taxa 949 and 950 are sometimes placed in much more derived positions, the former<tei:lb/>within the Enicospilusl Stauropoctonus complex (e.g. Fig. 23) and the latter as the sister-lineage<tei:lb/>to the ThyreodoniEuryophion complex (e.g. Fig. 21). Hellwigiella (950) is placed as the<tei:lb/>sister-group to the ThyreodoniEuryophion complex on the basis of a number of shared, rather<tei:lb/>striking, derived characters. These characters (which may be shared by several or all species in<tei:lb/>the complex) are adaptations to a diurnal eremic existence, and include possession of small ocelli<tei:lb/>(12), a shorter stouter flagellum (14-1), pendant epipleuron 2 (30), cylindrical hind tibial spurs<tei:lb/>(54) and long weakly curved claws (58-1). Many or all of these features are also found in the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>110</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3&gt; ' i</tei:p>
         <tei:p>t ( )</tei:p>
         <tei:p>O</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 21 283 transformation step cladogram derived from Wagner analysis of HTUs plus unplaced taxa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>apomorphic condition in other diurnal eremic ophionines including an undescribed species of<tei:lb/>Ophion from Australia (in ANIC) and Agathophiona species from Mexico. In another group of<tei:lb/>ichneumonids, the Anomaloninae, similar differences occur between closely related eremic and<tei:lb/>non-eremic organisms (e.g. Gravenhorstia (Erigorgus) and Gravenhorstia (Gravenhorstia)<tei:lb/>species (Gauld, 1976)). The occurrence of so many apomorphic states of these characters<tei:lb/>together in day-flying species strongly suggests the characters should be considered as a<tei:lb/>character suite and perhaps accorded less taxonomic weight. Unlike members of the Thyreodonl<tei:lb/>Euryophion complex, Hellwigiella shows the plesiomorphic state of important characters used<tei:lb/>for defining the group (2, 7-1, 44-2). Furthermore, a position near to the base of the common</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>111</tei:p>
         <tei:p>-~ -&lt;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 22 283 transformation step cladogram derived from Wagner analysis of HTUs plus unplaced taxa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>stem of the two major complexes is suggested by the fact that Hellwigiella shows the plesiomor-<tei:lb/>phic states of characters 16-1, 42-1, 52-1 and 52-2.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The position of the new genus (949) is rather perplexing as the taxon exhibits a number of<tei:lb/>derived features shared with the more specialized taxa, especially those in the Enicospilusl<tei:lb/>Stauropoctonus complex (e.g. 15-1, 16-1, 22-1, 33, 45-1) yet at the same time lacks one major<tei:lb/>apomorphy of the group (63) . Taxon 949 also shows the plesiomorphic state of many of the stem<tei:lb/>characters, including 25-2, 28-2, 42-1, 51-1 and 52-2. It does, however, share a small number of<tei:lb/>derived features (including 1 1 , 15 1 , 16- 1 , 33 and 45-1) with another enigmatic taxon , Sicophion<tei:lb/>pleuralis (922). Sicophion, like taxon 949, is primitive in a surprising array of other features and<tei:lb/>it seems plausible that these two taxa have a sister-group relationship and represent a primitive<tei:lb/>group that evolutionarily converged with the Enicospilus group, possibly as a result of similar<tei:lb/>selection pressures. The striking phenetic resemblance between 949 and some species of<tei:lb/>Leptophion is perhaps more understandable when one considers these taxa have apparently<tei:lb/>evolved in mid altitude tropical cloud forests - 949 in the Neotropics and Leptophion in South<tei:lb/>East Asia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Taxon 920, Riekophion emandibulator , is often placed with 967 and 968 (Dicamptus and</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>112</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>co m GO</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 23 284 transformation step cladogram derived from Wagner analysis of HTUs plus unplaced taxa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Enicospilus) in compatibility analyses on the basis of sharing the derived states of characters 40<tei:lb/>and 46 (e.g. Fig. 25). In other respects Riekophion does not appear to be at all closely related to<tei:lb/>either Dicamptus or Enicospilus (Gauld, 1977) and the high label scores obtained by the species<tei:lb/>for the derived states of these characters (Appendix 8) strongly suggests parallel derivation in<tei:lb/>two lineages.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>113</tei:p>
         <tei:p>C/&gt; i i i i</tei:p>
         <tei:p/>
         <tei:p>Fig. 24 284 transformation step cladogram derived from Wagner analysis of HTUs plus unplaced taxa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Accepting that the taxa of the Ophion 'genus group' (920, 922, 938-41, 948-51) are the most<tei:lb/>primitive ophionines, then the most parsimonious arrangement of these taxa with respect to all<tei:lb/>other groups is that presented in Fig. 26. All other ophionine taxa, 922 + 949 + 920 and 950 +<tei:lb/>940 remain as an unresolved trichotomy. The Ophion genus-group (i.e. the Ophionini of<tei:lb/>Townes, 1971) is therefore a paraphyletic grade, an assemblage of less-specialized ophionines.<tei:lb/>The 'group' possibly comprises three apparently holophyletic clades, the Ophion-group (=<tei:lb/>Ophion subgroup of Gauld, 1979), the Eremotylus group (940, 950) and the Sicophion group<tei:lb/>(920, 922, 949). The clade, 'all other ophionine taxa', comprises the two groups discussed above<tei:lb/>(the Thyreodon/Euryophion complex and the Enicospilusl Stauropoctonus complex) and four<tei:lb/>unplaced taxa, 905, 906, 923 and 927. The position of these four taxa can now be considered in<tei:lb/>relation to the fairly rigid structure derived above.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Taxa 905 and 906 (Simophion calvus and Orientospilus melasmd) share 27 derived characters<tei:lb/>(Appendix 3); 906 also has a large number in common with other taxa, particularly 947 (28), 946</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>114</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>O O O "O -O O O "O O O -O<tei:lb/>E:ao*&lt;&gt;KJK)p!OpOi</tei:p>
         <tei:p>O CO ' O K3 NJ C*&gt;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Oi</tei:p>
         <tei:p>*_zt</tei:p>
         <tei:p>"O ^O O O *O O<tei:lb/>a ^ O O K) |v<tei:lb/>(Ji O SI 00</tei:p>

         <tei:p>47.1'</tei:p>

         <tei:p>25.1*</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 25 Cladogram based on largest compatible set of characters obtained from HTUs plus unplaced taxa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(27), 942 (26), 918, 915, 914, 911 and 910 (25). Taxon 905 is less closely associated with other<tei:lb/>taxa but shows some affinity with the Euryophion group (937 (25), 936 (24) and 935 (23)). Taxa<tei:lb/>905 and 906 share several unusual apomorphic features including 6-1 (elsewhere only found in<tei:lb/>the derived state in 909, 935-37 and 946), 19 (elsewhere only found in 908, 918, 935 and 937), 23<tei:lb/>(elsewhere only found in the DictyonotuslThyreodon lineage) and 41 (elsewhere only found in<tei:lb/>922 and 923). Taxa 905 and 906 also share all the stem characters of the Enicospilusl<tei:lb/>Stauropoctonus + Thy reodonl Euryophion lineage, except that 905 is plesiomorphic for 42-1.<tei:lb/>This suggests that they may belong near the other groups, possibly as a sister-species pair. Of the<tei:lb/>features defining the two major complexes these taxa share only one, an apomorphy of 63,<tei:lb/>suggesting placement near the base of the Enicospilusl Stauropoctonus lineage. It is noteworthy<tei:lb/>that in earlier Wagner analyses (e.g. Figs 22-24) 905 and 906 generally were split up, 905 often<tei:lb/>grouping with 923 , 964 or 965 , whilst 906 usually was united with 960 or 961 . If the two taxa were<tei:lb/>entered together first in the data file, then they were not separated , but remained as a distinct<tei:lb/>clade(Fig.21).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Taxon 927 (Barytatocephalus mocsaryi) shares 24 derived characters with taxon 936, 23 with<tei:lb/>914 and 946 and 22 with 913. It shares all the stem features with the major complexes and<tei:lb/>additionally has the apomorphic condition for 22-2 and 58- 1 , suggesting it belongs near the base<tei:lb/>of the Thy reodonl Euryophion lineage. It does not have the major apomorphies of the<tei:lb/>Enicospilusl Stauropoctonus branch (that is 22-1, 33 and 63).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Taxon 923 (Prethophion latus) is an enigmatic Neotropical taxon that has relatively few<tei:lb/>characters in common with any other species. The largest number, 22, are shared with 918 and it<tei:lb/>has 21 in common with 906. It does have all the 'gain' stem apomorphies in common with other<tei:lb/>higher taxa, but is plesiomorphic for 25-2, 28-2 and 45. It does not have any of the apomorphies<tei:lb/>defining the Thyreodonl Euryophion complex, but is apomorphic for character 63, suggesting it<tei:lb/>belongs near the base of the Enicospilusl Stauropoctonus stem. It is most parsimonious to treat<tei:lb/>Prethophion latus as the sister species of the 905 -I- 906 lineage (on the basis of the derived state<tei:lb/>of characters 27-1 and 27-2), but this association must be regarded as very tenuous.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>115</tei:p>
         <tei:p>941 951 939 948 938 950 940 922 949 920 o</tei:p>
         <tei:p>51.1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 26 Most parsimonious arrangement of 'Ophion genus-group' and all other taxa. Conventions as in<tei:lb/>Fig. 13.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The cladogram showing the preferred arrangement of taxa as described above is shown in Fig.<tei:lb/>27. It is interesting to note that this user defined cladogram is one step more parsimonious than<tei:lb/>any obtained by Wagner analysis.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>116</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>o . .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 27 Cladogram derived from subjective evaluation of character complexes involved in grouping taxa<tei:lb/>in cladograms presented in Figs 21-25. It is noteworthy that this, at 242 steps, is a more parsimonious<tei:lb/>arrangement than the best obtained by Wagner analysis, though this is a fortuitous event.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Discussion of suggested phytogeny</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A putative phylogeny of the Ophioninae is shown in Fig. 27. Parts of this cladogram seem to be<tei:lb/>fairly robust, but other groups are only supported by weak homoplastic characters. The overall<tei:lb/>arrangement, placing the Ophion and Eremotylus groups in primitive positions and having a<tei:lb/>bifurcated evolutionary line, does seem reasonably sound. It corresponds with increasing<tei:lb/>morphological complexity, particularly in the form of the fore tibial spur (character 51), the<tei:lb/>region of the spiracular sclerite (character 15), the modification of the propodeum (characters<tei:lb/>22, 25) and the loss of umbo (character 33). What little is known about the structure of the final<tei:lb/>instar larvae supports this arrangement. The cephalic capsules of the larvae of Enicospilus,<tei:lb/>Dicamptus, Euryophion and Thyreodon are clearly more specialized than those of Ophion in<tei:lb/>having a modified hypostoma (Short, 1978). The larvae of Euryophion and Thyreodon are<tei:lb/>similar in having numerous setae (11+) on each part of the maxillary lobe median to the<tei:lb/>hypostomal spur and adjoining the maxillary palp. Dicamptus and Enicospilus have eight or less<tei:lb/>setae in this position. Certain venational characters also support the phylogeny proposed. These<tei:lb/>include modification of Im-cu and broadening of the base of Rs+2r (characters 38, 47 and 62).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE 117</tei:p>
         <tei:p>However, in almost all adult characters it is necessary to postulate parallelism. Reduction of the<tei:lb/>tibial spur membrane has occurred independently in Xylophion and the main evolutionary line,<tei:lb/>and specialization of the propodeum has occurred in both the main lineage and Eremotylus. It is<tei:lb/>quite disconcerting to see the degree of evolutionary convergence that has occurred in separate<tei:lb/>lineages (such as the development of alar sclerites and a sinuous Rs+2r in Riekophion and<tei:lb/>DicamptuslEnicospilus and the general similarity of structure between the undescribed Costa<tei:lb/>Rican genus and species of Leptophiori) . No amount of rearrangement of lineages could possibly<tei:lb/>remove any but a small proportion of such homoplasy. Perhaps the development of such<tei:lb/>similarities is due to some underlying adaptation of the genotype not visually manifested (the<tei:lb/>underlying synapomorphies of Saether, 1979). It is difficult to explain otherwise (unless one<tei:lb/>postulates reticulate evolution - 'ancient hybrids' giving introgression) how such an unusual<tei:lb/>feature as alar sclerites has appeared, apparently independently in at least six evolutionary<tei:lb/>lineages of Ophioninae (Afrophion, Sclerophion, Leptophion, Laticoleus, Riekophion and<tei:lb/>DicamptuslEnicospilus). Similar examples of such unusual parallelisms can be found in the<tei:lb/>modification of the penultimate distal hamulus, the projecting pecten of the hind tarsal claw and<tei:lb/>the development of a spine on the hind trochantelli.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Ophion group of genera (Ophion, Alophophion, Sclerophion, Afrophion, Rhopa-<tei:lb/>lophion, Agathophiona, Xylophion) is defined by the possession of the apomorphic states of<tei:lb/>four rather homoplastic characters, the loss of the posterior transverse carina of the meso-<tei:lb/>sternum (27-2), the possession of a diagonal mesopleural furrow (18-1), possession of an<tei:lb/>impressed clypeal margin (7-2) and having Rs in the hind wing at least slightly curved (44-1). Not<tei:lb/>all species of these genera necessarily possess all these apomorphies; Afrophion species are<tei:lb/>exceptional in having both a blunt clypeal margin and a straight Rs whilst some Rhopalophion<tei:lb/>species have the mesopleural furrow obsolescent. Although this genus-group is amongst the<tei:lb/>most primitive of ophionines, its position at the base of the phylogenetic tree rests on the<tei:lb/>assumptions that characters 38 and 47-1 (shape of Im-cu and presence of a ramellus) are cor-<tei:lb/>rectly polarized. As mentioned above (pp. 77, 78) the polarity of both features is questionable<tei:lb/>and if it could be demonstrated that the assigned polarity is incorrect then these two features<tei:lb/>would become convincing apomorphies supporting the holophyly of the Ophion group. This<tei:lb/>change in polarity would necessitate placing the Ophion group a little higher up the evolutionary<tei:lb/>tree, possibly as the sister lineage to the Eremotylus group; these two groups share the<tei:lb/>apomorphic states of characters 18-1 and 44-1.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The holophyly of the Eremotylus group is supported by the angulate base of Rs+2r (39),<tei:lb/>which is somewhat thickened (62), and by the form of the clypeus. In most species it is slightly<tei:lb/>flared outwards in profile (7-1) and often slightly concave. The mandibles are a subtly different<tei:lb/>shape to those of virtually all other ophionines but this feature is very difficult to define.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Sicophion group is a rather tenuous association of primitive taxa. The holophyly of the<tei:lb/>group is supported by the apomorphic states of characters 33 and 45-2. Apart from possession of<tei:lb/>certain primitive features such as the plesiomorphic state of character 51-2, and more extensive<tei:lb/>propodeal carination, all of these taxa appear to be highly specialized, sharing a variety of<tei:lb/>apomorphic features with other taxa placed higher up the phylogenetic tree. More evidence of<tei:lb/>the holophyly of this group needs to be obtained before it can confidently be accepted.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The holophyly of the Thyreodon group is supported by the specialized form of the anterior<tei:lb/>part of the propodeum (character 22-2) and by the form of the claw (character 58-1). The<tei:lb/>inclusion of Barytatocephalus within this clade does seem reasonable. In addition to the<tei:lb/>characters used in the analysis, two other features suggest Barytatocephalus belongs here. Vein<tei:lb/>3r-m in the fore wing of species of this genus forms a more obtuse angle with Rs+2r than is the<tei:lb/>case with most other ophionine taxa. Most other members of this clade have a similar<tei:lb/>specialization. At the base of the hind wing, in the anal cell, a vestige of a vein (? 2A) is often<tei:lb/>discernible. In most ophionines this trace, when observable, can be seen to be fairly near to and<tei:lb/>parallel with the hind margin of the wing; in both Barytatocephalus and other members of the<tei:lb/>Thyreodon complex (but not Euryophion) this vein trace is remote from the wing margin and<tei:lb/>close to and parallel with \A. Townes (1971) considered Barytatocephalus to be a derivation of<tei:lb/>Enicospilus, but there is little evidence for this supposition. The exposed spiracular sclerite, the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>118 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>general head shape and form of the propodeum suggest Barytatocephalus should not be included<tei:lb/>in the Enicospilus lineage.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Enicospilus group is the largest complex and one of the most difficult to define. Its<tei:lb/>holophyly is supported by a single apomorphy, loss of vestigial first laterotergites (character 64),<tei:lb/>but the included taxa do resemble each other in possessing a large number of derived features in<tei:lb/>common. Within this group five subordinate lineages are recognizable, the Orientospilus,<tei:lb/>Ophiogastrella, Stauropoctonus, Leptophion and Enicospilus subgroups. Each of these is<tei:lb/>apparently a holophyletic group. These are the various groupings recognized in the classification<tei:lb/>proposed below.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A classification of the Ophioninae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hennig (1966) pointed out the existence of two sorts of monophyletic taxa - holophyletic and<tei:lb/>paraphyletic groups. Traditional taxonomists may accord either group the status of a super-<tei:lb/>generic rank, though cladists do not recognize-paraphyletic taxa (Farris, 1979; Carpenter, 1982).<tei:lb/>Whilst there are many cases of small paraphyletic taxa that can be satisfactorily amalgamated<tei:lb/>with a holophyletic taxon to form a slightly larger holophyletic taxon (e.g. Aulophion +<tei:lb/>Stauropoctonus), there are other cases where dogmatic adherence to cladistic tenets produces<tei:lb/>impractical results. For example, if the Hawaiian genera were incorporated into Enicospilus to<tei:lb/>give a single holophyletic taxon, the resultant genus would contain an extraordinary range of<tei:lb/>morphological and probably biological diversity. I concur with Martin (1981) in believing that a<tei:lb/>classification, as opposed to a phylogeny, is a compromise between known or hypothesized<tei:lb/>inter-relationships and nomenclatural convenience. A good classification has at least two<tei:lb/>important facets: (a) it facilitates generalizations to be made about the component taxa, and (b)<tei:lb/>it is predictive. Farris (1979) and Mickevich (1978) both contend that a purely phylogenetic<tei:lb/>classification is an optimum as it is both more predictive and more stable than one that is not<tei:lb/>entirely phylogenetic. Whilst I agree with these authors that this is often the case, I do not think it<tei:lb/>is always so, especially where there are very unequal rates of evolution in different lineages.<tei:lb/>Consider, for example, the ichneumonid subfamily Mesochorinae. Five genera, Cidaphus,<tei:lb/>Astiphromma, Mesochorus, Stictopisthus and Plectochorus each show progressive morphologi-<tei:lb/>cal complexity. All are quite large genera and are functionally useful, but only Plectochorus<tei:lb/>appears to be holophyletic. Each of the other four taxa is apparently paraphyletic with respect to<tei:lb/>the genera that are more specialized than it (Townes, 1971; Gauld, 19846). Although not a strict<tei:lb/>phylogenetic classification, this arrangement of the species (which is based on adult morpho-<tei:lb/>logical features) was found to have predictive value for larvae (see Short, 1978) which seem to<tei:lb/>corroborate the idea that these taxa are a nesting paraphyletic series. I personally see no way of<tei:lb/>establishing a strict phylogenetic classification for such a group, other than by lumping all the<tei:lb/>genera, an action that would result in a much less informative and less useful classification than<tei:lb/>the present one.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The existence of such nesting paraphyletic groups would seem to be a corollary of the<tei:lb/>punctuational model of evolution. Stanley (1979) argues convincingly that many major adaptive<tei:lb/>changes have occurred very rapidly in isolated populations - thus a new organizational level<tei:lb/>(higher taxon) may have arisen from a small population of a pre-existing (and, if the rate of<tei:lb/>phyletic evolution is small, virtually unchanging) species placed in a different higher taxon.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>To return to the present example. If the Hawaiian genera have resulted from rapid radiation<tei:lb/>from an Enicospilus ancestor into niches hitherto, for enicospilines, unexploited, it is fairly<tei:lb/>unlikely that any prediction made from study of the biology of continental Enicospilus species<tei:lb/>will apply to Pycnophion. Similarly, any generalizations made about Enicospilus are likely to<tei:lb/>have to be prefaced by 'except in some Hawaiian species'. Consequently the purposes of<tei:lb/>prediction and generalization would both be better served by recognizing the Hawaiian taxa as<tei:lb/>distinct genera, even though Enicospilus thus becomes a paraphyletic taxon.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A second area of contention relevant to the present work concerns the reality and recognition<tei:lb/>of polythetic superspecific taxa. The currently recognized ophionine genera have been accepted<tei:lb/>initially as monophyletic groups, though in several instances it has been mentioned that a</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>119</tei:p>
         <tei:p>number are polythetic (Cushman, 1947). Some authors (e.g. L0vetrup, 1973) tend to dismiss<tei:lb/>polythetic taxa as the product of unsatisfactory discrimination. Whilst I accept that this is an<tei:lb/>explanation, I dispute that it is the most obvious one. Most cladistic studies reveal that<tei:lb/>homoplasy is a common phenomenon. If a data set is highly homoplastic, then logically it follows<tei:lb/>that some phylogenetically 'real' clades will only be definable in a disjunct (sensu Hull, 1965)<tei:lb/>way. Imposing a monothetic classification on such groups would result in the erection of a<tei:lb/>multiplicity of new genera, many of which would be monobasic. The resultant classification will<tei:lb/>have little predictive value as a high proportion of new taxa are likely to necessitate new genera<tei:lb/>for their accommodation (Gauld &amp; Mound, 1982).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The following classification is suggested for the subfamily Ophioninae. It is not strictly<tei:lb/>cladistic, as it recognizes some paraphyletic taxa; however it is a fair approximation of the<tei:lb/>presumed phylogeny. Formal tribes are not recognized, but these could be used for the various<tei:lb/>genus-groups. It should be noted that some very small genera were not incorporated in the<tei:lb/>cladistic analysis (these are denoted by an asterisk), but they were closely studied in an earlier<tei:lb/>work (Gauld, 1979). This has facilitated their placement in the present system.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subfamily OPHIONINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ophionidae Shuckard, 1840<tei:lb/>Enicospilini Townes, 1971</tei:p>
         <tei:p>OPHION genus-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Op/iion Fabricius, 1798<tei:lb/>Alophophion Cushman, 1947*<tei:lb/>Sclerophion Gauld, 1979 rfitC<tei:lb/>Afrophion Gauld, 1979*<tei:lb/>AgathophionaWestwood, 1882<tei:lb/>Rhopalophion Seyrig, 1935<tei:lb/>Xylophion Gauld, 0-979 / ? y</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SICOPHION genus-group<tei:lb/>Riekophion Gauld, 1977<tei:lb/>Sicophion Gauld, 1979<tei:lb/>Janzophion gen. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>EREMOTYLUS genus-group<tei:lb/>Eremoty/usFoerster, 1869<tei:lb/>Trophophion Cushman, 1947*<tei:lb/>Hel/wig/e/faSzepligeti, 1905</tei:p>
         <tei:p>THYREODON genus-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BarytatocephaIusSchu\z, 1911<tei:lb/>Euryophion Cameron, 1906</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rictophion Townes, 1971 Syn. n.<tei:lb/>Dictyonotus Kriechbaumer, 1894<tei:lb/>Ophionopsis Tosquinet, 1903</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>IWiync/iop/iJonEnderlein, 1912<tei:lb/>T/rjreodonBrulle, 1846</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ENICOSPILUS genus-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Orientospilus subgroup<tei:lb/>Prethophion Townes, 1971<tei:lb/>Simophion Cushman, 1947<tei:lb/>Orientospilus Morley, 1912</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ophiogastrella subgroup<tei:lb/>OphiogastrellaBrues, 1912</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Leptophion subgroup<tei:lb/>Pamophion Gauld, 1977<tei:lb/>Laticoleus Townes, in Townes &amp;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Townes, 1973<tei:lb/>Leptophion Cameron, 1901</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Enicospilus subgroup</tei:p>
         <tei:p>P/campfusSzepligeti, 1905<tei:lb/>Enicospilus Stephens, 1835<tei:lb/>Pycnophion Ashmead, 1900<tei:lb/>Banchogastra Ashmead, 1900<tei:lb/>Abanchogastra Perkins, 1902</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Zoogeographic discussion<tei:lb/>Present day distribution</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The approximate numbers of species per area are given in Table 18. For the purposes of this<tei:lb/>discussion Melanesia, Australia and New Zealand are considered as a single region, the<tei:lb/>Australo-Pacific, whilst for purposes of comparison Hawaii, with three endemic and one<tei:lb/>cosmopolitan genera, is ignored.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Altogether 20 of the 32 ophionine genera (62-5%) are restricted to a single zoogeographic<tei:lb/>region. This is a surprisingly high proportion compared with many other ichneumonid subfami-<tei:lb/>lies. For example, only about 30% of pimpline genera are endemic to a single region (Townes,</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
