         <tei:p>ENICOSPILUS 50 150 180 150 50 2 20 100</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PYrNflPHTflN 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1969) and a similar proportion of genera of other subfamilies are likewise restricted. The<tei:lb/>majority of the restricted ophionine genera are small taxa with three or fewer species; only<tei:lb/>Alophophion, Ophiogastrella and Laticoleus are larger than this and they have ten or more<tei:lb/>species each.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Six of the more widely distributed genera occur in only two regions: Rhynchophion and<tei:lb/>Thyreodon (Neotropical/Nearctic), Euryophion and Orientospilus (Afrotropical/Oriental),<tei:lb/>Leptophion (Oriental/ Australo-Pacific) and Simophion (Palaearctic/Nearctic). Two genera<tei:lb/>occur in just three regions, Dictyonotus (Palaearctic/Oriental/Afrotropical) and Dicamptus<tei:lb/>(Afrotropical/Oriental/Australo-Pacific), whilst Eremotylus occurs in four regions (Nearctic/<tei:lb/>Palaearctic/Oriental/Neotropic). Ophion occurs in all regions except the Afrotropical and<tei:lb/>Stauropoctonus in all but the Nearctic (though it is absent from the African mainland). Only<tei:lb/>Enicospilus is truly cosmopolitan with quite large numbers of species in all areas.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE 121</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Considered from a geographical standpoint the Neotropical region contains both the most<tei:lb/>genera (12) and has the highest degree of generic endemicity (50%). The Afrotropical and<tei:lb/>Oriental regions both contain ten genera, but the former has a far higher degree of endemicity<tei:lb/>(40% compared with 10%). The Australo-Pacific region contains eight genera, three of which<tei:lb/>(37%) are endemic whilst the Palaearctic, with a similar number of genera, has only two<tei:lb/>endemics (25%). The Nearctic is the most impoverished with seven genera, one of which (14%)<tei:lb/>is endemic. The faunal similarity (at generic level) between the regions is shown in Table 19.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 19 The generic faunal affinities between major zoogeographic regions (Hawaii is excluded). The<tei:lb/>values at the intersects of rows and columns V may be defined as:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>, _ number of genera common to areas X and Y<tei:lb/>total number of genera present in areas X and Y</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It is noteworthy that contiguous or recently contiguous areas have a significantly higher value for V than<tei:lb/>do areas that are not contiguous or that have only been contiguous in the distant past (more than 40<tei:lb/>million years ago), suggesting that dispersal may be a more important event than vicariance in the<tei:lb/>biogeographical history of the subfamily.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>o r 1 o f r 1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PALAEARCTIC 0.36 0.25 0.23 0.38 0.20</tei:p>
         <tei:p>AFROTROPICAL 0.06 0.10 0.20 0.43</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ORIENTAL 0.21 0.22 0.38</tei:p>
         <tei:p>AUSTRALO-PACIFIC 0.15 0.18<tei:lb/>NEOTROPICAL 0.36</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hypothesized evolutionary history of the group: a scenario</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Primitive ichneumonids are known from the Upper Cretaceous (80-90mya) (Townes, 1973ft)<tei:lb/>and the family may have originated at the beginning of the Cretaceous (Rodendorf &amp; Rasnitsyn,<tei:lb/>1980), possibly from a protoichneumonoid ancestor such as the Praeichneumonidae (Rasnitsyn,<tei:lb/>1983). The age of the subfamily Ophioninae is not known but it is presumed that it post-dates the<tei:lb/>primitive Upper Cretaceous groups. A fossil Ophion species is known from from the Lower<tei:lb/>Oligocene (35-40mya) in France and Rodendorf (1962) states that the Ophioninae (?sensu lato,<tei:lb/>i.e. including the Campopleginae) dates back to the Palaeocene (55-60mya). Possibly the group<tei:lb/>radiated around the beginning of the Tertiary some 65-70 million years ago.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>At this time the continents were still in close proximity to one another ( Audley-Charles et al. ,<tei:lb/>1981; Owen, 1981). Australia was connected to Antarctica and an archipelagic connection<tei:lb/>probably existed between this landmass and South America. Europe and North America were<tei:lb/>contiguous and South America was not widely separated from Africa. The most primitive<tei:lb/>lineage of the Ophioninae (the Ophion genus-group) may have been widespread at this time, as<tei:lb/>would have been its sister-group, the stem group of the remaining Ophioninae. The Sicophion<tei:lb/>lineage became isolated in the southern continent of Australia/ Antarctica/South America at an<tei:lb/>early stage whilst its sister-lineage, the ancestor of the Eremotylus, Enicospilus and Thyreodon<tei:lb/>lineages, remained in Laurasia or Africa. The ancestor of the Eremotylus lineage probably<tei:lb/>differentiated in Laurasia whilst the ancestor of the Enicospilus I Thyreodon radiated in Africa. I<tei:lb/>suggest that early offshoots of this line must have spread to South America, either by flying</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>122 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>across the widening South Atlantic, or by dispersal through Laurasia and across a water gap to<tei:lb/>South America. Some kind of barrier to the spread of organisms to and from South America is<tei:lb/>suggested by the high degree of generic endemicity and the fact that the Neotropical species of<tei:lb/>Enicospilus seem to belong to very few species-groups compared with those of other tropical<tei:lb/>areas. I suggest that the less vagile Thyreodon lineage reached South America much later,<tei:lb/>possibly from Asia via the Bering Straits. Probably the radiation of the Enicospilus lineage<tei:lb/>resulted in widespread extinction of members of the Ophion group, thus leaving the isolated<tei:lb/>specialized groups extant today. Ophion almost certainly has undergone secondary radiations<tei:lb/>giving rise to species complexes in South America (derived from the Nearctic) and Australia<tei:lb/>(derived initially from the Palaearctic fauna spreading through the Oriental region, where it has<tei:lb/>subsequently become isolated on mountain tops) (Gauld, 19840). Except for Xylophion, a<tei:lb/>remnant of the early widespread Ophion group-distribution, and Riekophion, a remnant of the<tei:lb/>southern radiation of the Sicophion lineage, the ophionine fauna of the Australo-Pacific has<tei:lb/>largely been derived from the Oriental region (as has been observed for other groups, e.g.<tei:lb/>Wilson, 1959; Gupta, 1962), though New Guinea has served as the epicentre of a considerable<tei:lb/>radiation, particularly in the case of Enicospilus , over 100 endemic species of which occur on the<tei:lb/>island.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although the above scenario is largely speculative it is the most parsimonious interpretation<tei:lb/>of the present distribution in relation to the postulated phylogenetic history of the group. Other<tei:lb/>scenarios would involve postulation of more widespread extinctions, more transoceanic disper-<tei:lb/>sive events or necessitate postulating a much earlier origin for the subfamily.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The subfamily Ophioninae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the following section the various genera and new synonymies are discussed in some detail.<tei:lb/>Keys have not been given here to genera as any attempt to produce a key to world genera would<tei:lb/>involve the usage of rather difficult couplets to allow for evolutionary parallelism between<tei:lb/>different species-groups in similar habitats in different zoogeographic regions. Practical keys to<tei:lb/>genera on a regional basis already exist. The Afrotropical region is covered by Gauld &amp; Mitchell<tei:lb/>(1978) and the Indo- Australian region by Gauld &amp; Mitchell (1981). This latter key will also<tei:lb/>suffice for the Palaearctic region. A key to the Neotropical genera is currently in preparation and<tei:lb/>this will suffice for the Nearctic. Townes (1971) also offers reasonable generic keys, but these are<tei:lb/>now rather dated, particularly his key to the 'Ophionini' (see Gauld, 1979).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The OPHION genus-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This group contains seven genera, Afrophion, Agathophiona, Alophophion, Xylophion, Scler-<tei:lb/>ophion, Rhopalophion and Ophion. The first six are holophyletic groups but Ophion is probably<tei:lb/>paraphyletic with respect to them (see p. 125).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The group is characterized by the absence of a posterior mesosternal transverse carina,<tei:lb/>usually by possession of a diagonal mesopleural furrow, generally by possession of an impressed<tei:lb/>clypeal apex and by having Rs in the hind wing usually at least slightly curved and often very<tei:lb/>strongly bowed. Virtually all species in this genus-group have Im-cu in the fore wing centrally<tei:lb/>angled somewhat, and usually have a distinct ramellus present at this point.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As Ophion is apparently the paraphyletic stem-group from within which all other genera in<tei:lb/>this group have arisen, and the genus is primarily a Holarctic taxon, it seems probable that this<tei:lb/>group originated in the temperate north. It is probable that at some period it was present in most<tei:lb/>regions and has gradually disappeared from equatorial regions leaving isolated relicts in South<tei:lb/>Africa (Afrophion), Australia (Xylophion), Madagascar (Rhopalophion} and Patagonia<tei:lb/>(Alophophion). The possibility that there has been repeated expansion into and extinction<tei:lb/>within the tropics is suggested by the presence of some groups of Ophion species on isolated<tei:lb/>mountains in South East Asia, New Guinea and South America, and by the occurrence of<tei:lb/>distinctive Ophion species-complexes in Australia and New Zealand (Gauld, 19840).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE 123</tei:p>
         <tei:p>AFROPHION Gauld</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Afrophion Gauld, 1979: 79. Type-species: Ophion nubilicarpus Tosquinet, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mandibles stout, not twisted, subequally bidentate, barely narrowed apically; outer mandibular surface<tei:lb/>convex, with strong proximal concavity. Maxillary palp 5-segmented, labial palp 4-segmented; clypeus in<tei:lb/>profile weakly convex with apical margin sharp but not clearly impressed; clypeus in anterior aspect weakly<tei:lb/>convex. Ocelli large, the posterior ones very close to the eyes; frontal carina absent; occipital carina<tei:lb/>complete, ventrally joining hypostomal carina. Antennae moderately long, 1-3 times length of fore wing.<tei:lb/>Pronotum unspecialized; spiracular sclerite exposed; notauli vestigial; epicnemial carina complete;<tei:lb/>mesopleural furrow strong, diagonal. Scutellum moderately convex, quite narrow and not carinate<tei:lb/>laterally; posterior transverse carina of mesosternum absent except laterally. Propodeum with anterior<tei:lb/>area either occluded or extremly short, the remainder of the propodeum rather abruptly declivous, with<tei:lb/>irregular vestiges of carinae and rather coarsely microreticulate. Fore wing with pterostigma broad;<tei:lb/>marginal cell elongate ; Rs+2r very broad and slightly angled before joining pterostigma; anterior corner of<tei:lb/>discosubmarginal cell glabrous, in one species extensively so and with a detached alar sclerite (Gauld &amp;<tei:lb/>Mitchell, 1978); Im-cu with small ramellus, centrally angled. Hind wing with Rs from straight to weakly<tei:lb/>curved. Fore tibial spur with a membranous flange behind macrotrichial comb; mid and hind trochantelli<tei:lb/>unspecialized; inner hind tibial spur flattened, with a margin of close fine hair; hind tarsal claws<tei:lb/>unspecialized, those of male slightly more closely pectinate than those of the female. Gaster slender;<tei:lb/>tergite 2 elongate, with thyridia very weak, close to anterior margin; umbo distinct; epipleuron up- turned.<tei:lb/>Ovipositor sheath slender; male with gonosquamae very large, ploughshare-like.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Afrophion is restricted to the extreme south of Africa. The genus contains two species, the type-species<tei:lb/>and A. hynnis (Gauld &amp; Mitchell). It is distinguished from Ophion by the form of the propodeum, the<tei:lb/>unique structure of the male genitalia and by the basally incrassate Rs+2r in the fore wing.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>AGATHOPHIONA Westwood<tei:lb/>Agathophiona Westwood, 1882: 19. Type-species: Agathophiona fulvicornis Westwood, by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mandibles twisted 5-10, barely tapered, with lower tooth slightly the longer; outer mandibular surface<tei:lb/>slightly convex, with a strong proximal concavity. Maxillary palp 5-segmented, labial palp 4-segmented;<tei:lb/>mouthparts exceptionally specialized in that the distal part of the maxilla projects below the clypeus and<tei:lb/>the labial glossae project by a distance almost equal to length of hind wing; clypeus in profile rather flat,<tei:lb/>margin blunt; clypeus in anterior aspect broad, very weakly convex. Ocelli quite small, the posterior ones<tei:lb/>separated from eye by about their own minimum diameter; frontal carina absent or present but weak;<tei:lb/>occipital carina dorsally complete or narrowly obsolescent centrally, ventrally obsolescent, not joining the<tei:lb/>very weak hypostomal carina. Antennae rather short and quite stout, distal segments quadrate. Pronotum<tei:lb/>unspecialized; spiracular sclerite exposed; notauli short but strongly impressed near anterior margin;<tei:lb/>epicnemial carina more or less complete; mesopleural furrow virtually absent. Scutellum moderately<tei:lb/>strongly convex, not laterally carinate; posterior transverse carina of mesosternum present only laterally as<tei:lb/>vestiges. Propodeum with anterior area occluded, rather deeply impressed; propodeal carinae vestigial;<tei:lb/>posterior area striate or coriaceous. Fore wing with pterostigma moderately broad; marginal cell slender;<tei:lb/>Rs+2r more or less straight, not thickened before joining pterostigma; discosubmarginal cell without a<tei:lb/>glabrous anterior area; Im-cu generally with only a trace of a ramellus, rather evenly but quite strongly<tei:lb/>curved. Hind wing with Rs quite strongly curved. Fore leg with tibial spur bearing a membranous flange<tei:lb/>behind the macrotrichial comb; mid and hind trochantelli unspecialized; inner hind tibial spur cylindrical,<tei:lb/>with scattered hairs marginally; hind tarsal claws long and weakly curved. Gaster rather stout; tergite 2 in<tei:lb/>profile only slightly longer than posteriorly deep; thyridia small and close to anterior margin; epipleuron<tei:lb/>up-turned. Female with subgenital plate enlarged, as long as tergite 2 and medially notched; ovipositor<tei:lb/>sheath unspecialized.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agathophiona is a monobasic genus; the type-species occurs in Mexico. A. fulvicornis is diurnally active<tei:lb/>(Townes, 1971). Structurally this is one of the most specialized of all ophionine genera. The remarkable<tei:lb/>mouthparts are presumably an adptation to feeding from certain types of flowers but the function of the<tei:lb/>rather unusually modified female terminalia is not known.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>124 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ALOPHOPHION Cushman<tei:lb/>Alophophion Cushman, 1947: 439. Type-species: Ophion chilensis Spinola, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mandibles not twisted, weakly narrowed apically, subequally bidentate; outer mandibular surface flat,<tei:lb/>usually punctate and hirsute. Maxillary palp 5-segmented, labial palp 4-segmented; clypeus in profile<tei:lb/>weakly convex, margin often impressed, sometimes very narrowly so; clypeus in anterior aspect weakly<tei:lb/>convex. Ocelli generally large, the posterior ones close to the eyes; frontal carina absent; occipital carina<tei:lb/>absent. Antennae moderately to very long, at least 1-3 times length of fore wing. Pronotum unspecialized<tei:lb/>or mediodorsally somewhat flattened and quite long; spiracular sclerite exposed; notauli present on<tei:lb/>anterior part of mesoscutum; epicnemial carina generally strong; mesopleural furrow distinct, diagonal,<tei:lb/>extending from episternal scrobe to near subalar prominence. Scutellum very weakly convex, usually<tei:lb/>narrow and not carinate laterally; posterior transverse carina of mesosternum absent except for lateral<tei:lb/>vestiges. Propodeum with anterior area occluded, transverse and often lateromedian longitudinal carinae<tei:lb/>discernible, often almost complete; posterior area smooth or rugulose. Fore wing with pterostigma broad;<tei:lb/>marginal cell long; Rs+2r slender, curved near proximal 0-3 before joining pterostigma near centre;<tei:lb/>dicosubmarginal cell with glabrous area anterior; Ira-cu generally centrally angled, sometimes with a short<tei:lb/>ramellus which is directed more anteriorly than that of Ophion. Hind wing with Rs curved. Fore tibial spur<tei:lb/>with a membranous flange behind macrotrichial comb; mid and hind trochantelli unspecialized; inner hind<tei:lb/>tibial spur flattened, with a margin of long close hairs; hind tarsal claws unspecialized. Gaster moderately<tei:lb/>slender; tergite 2 in profile elongate, thyridia oval, separated from anterior margin of tergite by its own<tei:lb/>length or less, umbo distinct; epipleuron up-turned. Ovipositor sheath narrow.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Alophophion is a moderately large genus that is restricted to South America. The majority of species<tei:lb/>occur in southern Chile and Patagonia. Cushman, when describing Alophophion as a distinct genus,<tei:lb/>commented that it barely warranted generic distinction from Ophion. Whilst it is undoubtedly very close to<tei:lb/>Ophion, the combination of characters exhibited by the group clearly separate it as a holophyletic lineage.<tei:lb/>This lineage is characterized by the following apomorphies: occipital carina entirely absent; Rs+2r joining<tei:lb/>pterostigma near centre; first subdiscal cell stouter than normal; ramellus, when present, directed more<tei:lb/>anteriorly than that of other ophionines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>OPH/OJVFabricius</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ophion Fabricius, 1798: 210, 235. Type-species: Ichneumon luteus L., by subsequent designation, Curtis,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1836: 600.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paniscus Schrank, 1802: 316. Type-species: Ichneumon luteus L., by monotypy.<tei:lb/>Psylonychia Szepligeti, 1905: 21. [Nomen nudum.]<tei:lb/>Stenophthalmus Szepligeti, 1905: 23. Type-species: Stenophthalmus algiricus Szepligeti, by subsequent</tei:p>
         <tei:p>designation, Viereck, 1914: 137. [Homonym of Stenophthalmus Becker, 1903.]<tei:lb/>Pachyprotoma Kohl, 1906: 223. Type-species: Ophion (Pachyprotoma) capitatus Kohl, by monotypy.<tei:lb/>Australophion Morley, 1912: 4, 30. Type-species: Ophion peregrinus Smith, by monotypy.<tei:lb/>Neophion Morley, 1912: 4, 30. Type-species: Neophion crassus Morley, by subsequent designation,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Viereck, 1914: 100.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Apatophion Shestakov, 1926: 262. Type-species: Apatophion mirsa Shestakov, by original designation.<tei:lb/>Platophion Hellen, 1926: 13. Type-species: Platophion areolaris Brauns, by subsequent designation,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cushman, 1947: 475.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Potophion Cushman, 1947: 476. Type-species: Potophion caudatus Cushman, by original designation.<tei:lb/>Psylonychia Cushman, 1947: 476. [Unavailable name, proposed in synonymy.]<tei:lb/>Apomesus Townes, 1971: 54. Type-species: Apomesus longiceps Townes, by original designation.<tei:lb/>Mecetron Townes, 1971: 60. Type-species: Stenophthalmus choaspese Uchida, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mandibles not twisted, from very weakly to moderately narrowed distally, generally subequally bidentate<tei:lb/>or with upper tooth slightly the longer; outer mandibular surface more or less flat, except for basal<tei:lb/>concavity, moderately punctate. Maxillary palp 5-segmented, labial palp 4-segmented; clypeus in profile<tei:lb/>weakly to moderately convex, margin impressed, acute; clypeus in anterior aspect weakly convex, rarely<tei:lb/>truncate or even slightly concave. Ocelli usually large, the posterior ones separated from eyes by less than<tei:lb/>their own diameters; frontal carina absent; occipital carina usually complete dorsally, ventrally not<tei:lb/>reaching the hypostomal carina, rarely with occipital carina mediodorsally obsolescent, or in a few species<tei:lb/>with it entirely absent. Antennae generally of moderate length, in a few deserticolous species the flagellum<tei:lb/>short and with central segments quadrate. Pronotum unspecialized; spiracular sclerite usually completely<tei:lb/>exposed; notauli weak but discernible on anterior 0-2 of mesoscutum; epicnemial carina generally strong<tei:lb/>and well developed on mesopleuron; mesopleural furrow strongly impressed, extending diagonally from</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE 125</tei:p>
         <tei:p>episternal scrobe towards subalar prominence. Scutellum weakly to moderately convex, usually carinate<tei:lb/>only on anterior 0-2 or less, rarely with lateral longitudinal carinae complete to posterior margin; posterior<tei:lb/>transverse carina of mesosternum usually present only laterally as vestiges. Propodeum with anterior area<tei:lb/>occluded except for a small semicircular depression centrally; propodeal carina variously developed, at<tei:lb/>most with both transverse carinae and the lateromedian longitudinal carinae complete, enclosing an area<tei:lb/>superomedia, in the most exceptional cases with all carinae only vestigial; posterior area usually rather<tei:lb/>smooth. Fore wing with pterostigma moderately to very stout; marginal cell very long and slender; Rs+2r<tei:lb/>usually virtually straight, slender, barely broadened before joining pterostigma, in some species evenly<tei:lb/>broadened to join pterostigma; discosubmarginal cell with glabrous area in anterior corner; Im-cu usually<tei:lb/>with a well-developed ramellus, rarely with stub-like indication of this vein present; Im-cu centrally<tei:lb/>strongly geniculate. Hind wing with Rs from weakly to very strongly curved. Fore tibial spur with<tei:lb/>membranous flange behind the macrotrichial comb; mid and hind trochantelli unspecialized; inner hind<tei:lb/>tibial spur flattened, with a margin of close long hairs; hind tarsal claws unspecialized, those of males<tei:lb/>usually more closely pectinate than those of the female. Gaster moderately slender; tergite 2 in profile<tei:lb/>moderately to strongly elongate, usually with thyridia large, close to anterior margin; umbo well<tei:lb/>developed; epipleuron up-turned. Ovipositor sheath usually slender, in one species-group exceptionally<tei:lb/>stout.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ophion is a very large genus that is widely distributed throughout the world except for the Afrotropical<tei:lb/>region. In tropical South America and South East Asia few species occur and these are restricted to high<tei:lb/>altitudes (Gauld &amp; Mitchell, 1981). Ophion as currently defined is almost certainly a paraphyletic<tei:lb/>assemblage; Agathophiona, Rhopalophion, Sclerophion, Xylophion, Alophophion and Afrophion are<tei:lb/>phenetically highly divergent (Gauld, 1979), holophyletic species-groups which have probably arisen from<tei:lb/>within Ophion. A number of other phenetically less divergent species-groups were included by Gauld<tei:lb/>(1979) within Ophion, but as the phylogenetic relationship of the taxa becomes better understood it will be<tei:lb/>necessary to erect a number of additional genera in order to establish a system of holophyletic taxa.<tei:lb/>Previous authors (e.g. Morley, 1912; Cushman, 1947; Townes, 1971) have attempted to remove other<tei:lb/>species-groups from Ophion and treat these as separate genera, but in each case the group removed has not<tei:lb/>been holophyletic as comparatively few of the subtropical and eremic Ophion species are known. Recent<tei:lb/>collecting has greatly increased our knowledge of these insects but more work needs to be undertaken<tei:lb/>before it is possible to fully resolve this genus. The major species-groups of Ophion are outlined below; all<tei:lb/>except the unsatisfactorily resolved luteus-group are holophyletic but I have avoided treating these groups<tei:lb/>as distinct genera until the luteus anathema can be resolved. As each of these groups appears to be defined<tei:lb/>by a series of unique apomorphies it is not possible to suggest their phylogenetic inter-relationship.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ophion peregrinus species-group. This species-group contains all the described New Zealand Ophion<tei:lb/>species (Townes et al, 1961). Its monophyly is suggested by the possession of a mediodorsally<tei:lb/>lengthened pronotum, having Rs+2r joining the pterostigma distal to the pterostigma base and having<tei:lb/>the longitudinal lateral carina of the propodeum with a raised ridge diverging towards the propodeal<tei:lb/>spiracle. In O. peregrinus this is only weakly developed but in other taxa this ridge is frequently very<tei:lb/>strong and continuous with the carina, and the front part of the carina is absent so the apparent carina<tei:lb/>curves anteriorly towards the spiracle where it terminates. O. peregrinus is apparently the most<tei:lb/>primitive taxon as it retains most of the propodeal carinae and has a strongly geniculate Im-cu; the<tei:lb/>other taxa have only a vestige of the anterior carina (the lateromedian and posterior transverse carina<tei:lb/>are lacking) and frequently have a reduced ramellus and more evenly curved Im-cu. Most also have a<tei:lb/>- fairly straight Rs in the hind wing.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>O. bicarinatus species-group. This complex contains O. bicarinatus Cameron, O. facetious Gauld &amp;<tei:lb/>Mitchell, O. gerdius Gauld &amp; Mitchell, O. horus Gauld &amp; Mitchell and all of the described Australian<tei:lb/>species (Gauld, 1977). The group is characterized by possession of a proximally broadened Rs+2r<tei:lb/>which is slightly curved before reaching the pterostigma. The European species, O. minutus, may<tei:lb/>belong to this group. The five Australian species form a monophyletic subgroup characterized by the<tei:lb/>black interocellar area. In the Oriental region the species of the bicarinatus group are restricted to<tei:lb/>mountains in Sri Lanka, India, Burma, Malaysia, Taiwan and Sumatra. Their present fragmented<tei:lb/>distribution and their paraphyletic nature with respect to the Australian species-group suggests that<tei:lb/>this group was more widespread throughout the Indo- Australian region in the past, probably when the<tei:lb/>climate was cooler (Gauld, 1984a).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>O. cronus species-group. This monobasic group is restricted to montane New Guinea (Gauld &amp; Mitchell,<tei:lb/>1981). The group is characterized by having a very sparsely hirsute discosubmarginal cell and a very<tei:lb/>short 3r-m. It does not appear to be closely related to any other Indo- Australian species.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>126 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>O. caudatus species-group. This group is characterized by the elongate head shape; the eyes are more oval<tei:lb/>than normal and the labium is specialized in having the prementum extended far beyond the insertion<tei:lb/>of the labial palps (Gauld &amp; Mitchell, 1981). This group contains O. caudatus (Cushman), O. silus<tei:lb/>Gauld &amp; Mitchell, O. longiceps (Townes), O. ascus Gauld &amp; Mitchell, O. sumptions Gauld &amp;<tei:lb/>Mitchell, O. mastrus Gauld &amp; Mitchell and an undescribed species from Sulawesi (BMNH). All these<tei:lb/>species occur in mountains in the Oriental region. An undescribed species from high altitude in Peru<tei:lb/>(TC) has a similarly modified head and like other members of the O. caudatus group it has large wings,<tei:lb/>elongate trochantelli and virtually obscured mesopleural punctures. This Neotropical species clearly<tei:lb/>seems to belong in this species-group, but it is possible that the apomorphies defining the group are a<tei:lb/>suite of characters facilitating existence at high altitude and that the Neotropical and Oriental lineages<tei:lb/>have undergone morphological convergence.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>O. areo/ar/s species-group. This group is characterized by the loss of occipital carina, possession of a<tei:lb/>quadrate scutellum and a somewhat broadened ovipositor sheath, and by having a characteristic<tei:lb/>pattern of propodeal carina in which the area superomedia is more or less discernible, the posterior<tei:lb/>transverse carina is often complete and the anterior transverse carina is absent except centrally. This<tei:lb/>group contains O. areolaris Brauns, O. ocellaris Ulbricht and O. fuscomaculatus Cameron. The first<tei:lb/>two are western Palaearctic species whilst O. fuscomaculatus has an eastern Palaearctic range that<tei:lb/>extends into the higher mountains of the Oriental region.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>O. similis species-group. This group contains the Palaearctic species O. similis (Szepligeti), O. mirsa<tei:lb/>(Shestakov), O. buchariensis Meyer and two undescribed Nearctic species. All are stout insects with<tei:lb/>short, compact gasters, rather convex, irregularly sculptured propodea and somewhat shorter<tei:lb/>antennae than is usual for species of this genus. The ocelli and eyes are moderately small so the<tei:lb/>orbital-ocellar distance and the malar space are broader than is normal for Ophion species. All are<tei:lb/>apparently diurnally active and most are associated with dry areas.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>O. dentatus species-group. This group contains O. dentatus Smith, O. turcomanicus Szepligeti and O. virus<tei:lb/>Gauld &amp; Mitchell. The group is characterized by possession of unusually long, fairly slender<tei:lb/>mandibles, having long, weakly curved claws and possessing numerous spines on hind tarsal segments<tei:lb/>1-3. Species of this group are widely distributed throughout the eastern Palaearctic region, particu-<tei:lb/>larly Central Asia. Several also extend into the drier parts of the Indian subcontinent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>O. luteus species-group. This large group contains all of the other described species of the genus from the<tei:lb/>Palaearctic, Nearctic and Neotropical regions. It is apparently a paraphyletic group and I can only<tei:lb/>define it in terms of plesiomorphic features (i.e. absence of apomorphic characters exhibited by other<tei:lb/>species-groups). With more study it may be possible to subdivide this group into several holophyletic<tei:lb/>species-complexes but little is yet known about either the eastern Palaearctic or the Nearctic species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>RHOPALOPHION Seyrig</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rhopalophion Seyrig, 1935: 49. Type-species: Rhopalophion curvus Seyrig (= Ophion discinervus<tei:lb/>Morley), by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mandibles not twisted, weakly narrowed apically, more or less equally bidentate; outer mandibular surface<tei:lb/>slightly convex with distinct proximal concavity. Maxillary palp 5-segmented, labial palp 4-segmented;<tei:lb/>clypeus in profile weakly convex, margin slightly impressed and reflexed or sometimes almost blunt;<tei:lb/>clypeus in anterior aspect weakly convex or truncate. Ocelli moderately small to large, the posterior ones<tei:lb/>separated from the eyes by less than 0-8 times their own maximum diameter; frontal carina absent;<tei:lb/>occipital carina complete, joining hypostomal carina close to base of mandible. Antennae of moderate<tei:lb/>length, at least 1-2 times as long as fore wing. Pronotum unspecialized; spiracular sclerite exposed; notauli<tei:lb/>virtually absent; epicnemial carina present, extending onto pleuron; mesopleural furrow absent or very<tei:lb/>indistinct. Scutellum weakly to moderately convex, laterally carinate for its entire length; posterior<tei:lb/>transverse carina of mesosternum absent except for lateral vestiges. Propodeum with anterior area<tei:lb/>occluded; anterior and posterior transverse carinae usually complete, rarely with the former vestigial, very<tei:lb/>rarely all carinae absent; longitudinal carinae not developed; posterior area finely alutaceous to smooth.<tei:lb/>Fore wing with pterostigma moderately broad; marginal cell long; Rs+2r almost straight, not or only very<tei:lb/>slightly expanded before joining pterostigma; discosubmarginal cell anteriorly broadly glabrous from base<tei:lb/>of Rs+2r to ramellus; Im-cu very angulate, with an extremely long ramellus that reaches at least 0-6 of<tei:lb/>distance to Rs&amp;M. Hind wing with Rs virtually straight or very weakly curved. Fore tibial spur with<tei:lb/>membranous flange behind macrotrichial comb reaching 0-5-0-7 of length of spur; mid and hind<tei:lb/>trochantelli unspecialized; inner hind tibial spur moderately flattened, with a fringe of long close hairs;</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE 127</tei:p>
         <tei:p>hind tarsal claws unspecialized, those of male far more closely and finely pectinate than those of the female.<tei:lb/>Gaster slender; tergite 2 in profile moderately long with thyridia oval and close to anterior margin; umbo<tei:lb/>quite well developed; epipleuron up-turned. Ovipositor sheath slender.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rhopalophion is a small genus with three described species, discinervus which is widespread throughout<tei:lb/>the Afrotropical mainland, and divergens and parallelus which are restricted to Madagascar (Delobel,<tei:lb/>1975). R. divergens and R. parallelus are apparently sister-species and constitute a clade defined by the<tei:lb/>following apomorphic features, possession of small ocelli, possession of subquadrate lower face and<tei:lb/>possession of a relatively long malar space. This clade is the sister- lineage to R. discinervus which is defined<tei:lb/>by possession of a very angulate Im-cu and a distally swollen ramellus (Gauld &amp; Mitchell, 1978). The<tei:lb/>females of discinervus are unusual amongst ophionines in that the distal tarsal segment of the female has a<tei:lb/>lateral projection. This is similar to one found in a species of Ophiogastrella (Cushman, 1947). Rhopa-<tei:lb/>lophion species are easily distinguished from other taxa in the Ophion genus-group on account of their<tei:lb/>unique venation, total lack of propodeal longitudinal carinae and long fore tibial spur.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SCLEROPHION Gauld</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sclerophion Gauld, 1979: 77. Type-species: Pleuroneurophion longicornis Uchida, by original desig-<tei:lb/>nation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mandibles stout, not twisted, barely narrowed apically; outer mandibular surface weakly convex.<tei:lb/>Maxillary palp 5-segmented, labial palp 4-segmented; clypeus in profile weakly convex, margin not<tei:lb/>impressed; clypeus in anterior aspect weakly convex. Ocelli large, the posterior ones separated from eyes<tei:lb/>by less than 0-2 of their minimum diameter; frontal carina absent; occipital carina complete, ventrally<tei:lb/>reaching hypostomal carina. Antennae very long and slender, more than 1-7 times length of fore wing.<tei:lb/>Pronotum unspecialized; spiracular sclerite exposed; notauli weak but discernible; epicnemial carina<tei:lb/>complete, strong; mesopleural furrow weak, diagonal, with upper end rather broad and shallow. Scutellum<tei:lb/>moderately convex, carinate laterally on at least its anterior 0-4; posterior transverse carina of meso-<tei:lb/>sternum absent except as lateral vestige. Propodeum with anterior area occluded except medially where it<tei:lb/>is semicircular; anterior and posterior transverse carinae usually complete, other carinae weak; posterior<tei:lb/>area usually rather smooth. Fore wing with pterostigma moderately slender; marginal cell elongate; Rs+2r<tei:lb/>thickened and evenly curved before joining pterostigma; discosubmarginal cell with an extensive glabrous<tei:lb/>area anteriorly, the distal margin of this area with a thickened corneous mark; Im-cu with long ramellus,<tei:lb/>centrally geniculate. Hind wing with Rs very weakly curved. Fore tibial spur with a membranous flange<tei:lb/>behind macro trichial comb; mid and hind trochantelli unspecialized; inner hind tibial spur flattened, with<tei:lb/>margin of close, long hairs; hind tarsal claws unspecialized. Gaster slender; tergite 2 very elongate, with<tei:lb/>thyridia elliptical, close to anterior margin; umbo well developed; epipleuron up-turned. Ovipositor<tei:lb/>sheath slender.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sclerophion species may be recognized by their characteristic fore wing venation, particularly the<tei:lb/>thickened Rs+2r and the corneous mark in the discosubmarginal cell. The genus contains two species, the<tei:lb/>type-species and S. uchidai Gauld &amp; Mitchell. These occur in the mountains at the eastern Palaearctic/<tei:lb/>Oriental interface (Gauld &amp; Mitchell, 1981).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>XYLOPHION Gauld<tei:lb/>Xylophion Gauld, 1979: 77. Type-species: Ophion xylus Gauld, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mandibles not twisted, weakly to moderately tapered, subequally bi dentate; outer mandibular surface flat,<tei:lb/>punctate, with proximal concavity. Maxillary palp 5-segmented, labial palp 4-segmented; clypeus in profile<tei:lb/>convex, margin impressed, acute; clypeus in anterior aspect weakly convex. Ocelli large, the posterior ones<tei:lb/>separated from eyes by their own minimum diameter or less; frontal carina absent; occipital carina strong,<tei:lb/>ventrally often reaching hypostomal carina, sometimes ventrally obsolescent. Antennae of moderate<tei:lb/>length or long, usually at least 1-5 times length of fore wing. Pronotum more or less unspecialized, though<tei:lb/>one species has trace of a median transverse crest; spiracular sclerite exposed; notauli quite weak but<tei:lb/>usually distinct on anterior 0-2 of segment, rarely absent; epicnemial carina strong, reaching onto pleuron<tei:lb/>above level of lower corner of pronotum ; mesopleural furrow weak , diagonal . Scutellum weakly convex , at<tei:lb/>most carinate laterally on anterior 0-2; posterior transverse carina of mesosternum present only laterally as<tei:lb/>vestiges. Propodeum with anterior area more or less occluded except centrally where it is discernible as a<tei:lb/>semicircular area; anterior transverse carina usually more or less complete, posterior transverse carina<tei:lb/>from present laterally as vestiges to almost complete; longitudinal carinae vestigial; posterior area rather<tei:lb/>smooth. Fore wing with pterostigma large and triangular; marginal cell long; Rs+2r evenly broadened and<tei:lb/>curved before joining pterostigma; discosubmarginal cell with a large glabrous area in anterior corner;</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>128 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>lra-cu with a short ramellus, centrally angulate. Hind wing with Rs strongly curved. Fore tibia with a<tei:lb/>membranous flange extending from 0-1-0-3 of its length behind macrotrichial comb; mid and hind<tei:lb/>trochantelli unspecialized; inner hind tibial spur flattened, with a margin of long, close hairs; hind tarsal<tei:lb/>claws of female unspecialized, of male unique in having a central gap between an inner and outer row of<tei:lb/>pectinal teeth. Gaster slender; tergite 2 in profile very elongate with thyridia elliptical, separated from<tei:lb/>anterior margin by its own length or less; umbo strongly developed; epipleuron up-turned. Ovipositor<tei:lb/>sheath slender.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Xylophion is a small genus restricted to the Australian tectonic plate. Three species, one of which is<tei:lb/>undescribed, occur in south-eastern Australia. One of these, X. xylus, also occurs more widely throughout<tei:lb/>Australia and has been found in the New Guinea highlands (Gauld, 1984a).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Xylophion is characterized by the venation, particularly the possession of a very short 3r-w, and the<tei:lb/>reduced flange on the fore tibial spur. A particularly striking, and hitherto unrecognized, autapomorphy of<tei:lb/>the genus is the form of the male tarsal claw. Instead of having a sinuous row of pectinal teeth present (as is<tei:lb/>normal for ophionines), Xylophion males have a marked discontinuity in the centre of the row between the<tei:lb/>teeth on the inner and outer edges of the claw. In its least derived form only the central gap exists<tei:lb/>(Xylophion species 1, BMNH) but the other two species are specialized further in different ways. X. ketus<tei:lb/>has the inner and outer marginal rows extended laterally so that there is a central overlap between the two<tei:lb/>parallel ends of the rows of teeth. In X. xylus there is a less pronounced overlap but the distal portion of the<tei:lb/>claw is flattened and the terminal tooth reduced so the pectinal row forms a 'fence' around the distal end of<tei:lb/>the claw.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The SICOPHION genus-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This group comprises three genera, Sicophion and Janzophion from montane tropical South<tei:lb/>America and Riekophion from Australia. The species in this complex exhibit an unusual<tei:lb/>combination of plesiomorphic and apomorphic features. All possess a well-developed membra-<tei:lb/>nous flange on the fore tibial spur though none has an umbo on tergite 2 and often the upper<tei:lb/>corner of the pronotum is expanded to partially occlude the spiracular sclerite. It is suggested<tei:lb/>here that these three genera comprise a distinct lineage which is derived with respect to the<tei:lb/>Ophion group, and that the Sicophion group represents a separate southern radiation of the<tei:lb/>ophionines. However, as mentioned above (see p. 117), if the polarity of characters 38 and 47-1<tei:lb/>has been misinterpreted then the Ophion lineage may represent a more derived group than the<tei:lb/>Sicophion lineage. If this were the case then it is possible that the Sicophion group is a collection<tei:lb/>of relict genera whose present southern distribution can be explained by Darlington's (1965)<tei:lb/>'glove hypothesis'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>JANZOPHION gen. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Type-species: Janzophion nebosus sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mandibles twisted perhaps 5, slightly tapered distally, with upper tooth slightly the longer; outer<tei:lb/>mandibular surface with a diagonal line of hair extending from upper proximal corner to near centre.<tei:lb/>Maxillary palp 5-segmented, labial palp 4-segmented; clypeus in profile convex, margin impressed, in<tei:lb/>anterior aspect with margin weakly convex. Ocelli very large, the hind ones more or less contiguous with<tei:lb/>eyes; frontal carina absent; occipital carina absent. Antennae very long and slender, about 1-5 times length<tei:lb/>of fore wing. Pronotum unspecialized; spiracular sclerite partially concealed; notauli vestigial; epicnemial<tei:lb/>carina present laterally and ventrally; mesopleural furrow indistinct. Scutellum weakly convex, laterally<tei:lb/>carinate only on anterior 0-1-0-3; posterior transverse carina of mesosternum complete. Propodeum with<tei:lb/>anterior area long; anterior transverse carina and usually posterior transverse carina complete, often with a<tei:lb/>median longitudinal carina present; propodeum otherwise rather smooth. Fore wing with pterostigma<tei:lb/>moderately broad; marginal cell very long; Rs+2r bowed, thickened before joining pterostigma; discosub-<tei:lb/>marginal cell with glabrous area near anterior corner, but anterior to this is narrow hirsute region; \m-cu<tei:lb/>without a ramellus, proximally fairly straight, distally strongly bowed. Hind wing with Rs weakly curved;<tei:lb/>marginal cell proximally glabrous; penultimate distal hamulus longer than its fellows, the distal one slightly<tei:lb/>shorter but longer than the proximal ones. Fore tibial spur with a membranous flange behind the<tei:lb/>macrotrichial comb; mid and hind trochantelli unspecialized; inner hind tibial spur flattened, with margin<tei:lb/>of close long hairs; hind tarsal claw unspecialized. Gaster slender; tergite 2 in profile very elongate, with<tei:lb/>thyridia remote from anterior margin; umbo vestigial; epipleuron up-turned. Ovipositor sheath slender.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE 129</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Janzophion is a distinctive genus which bears a very strong phenetic similarity to the Old World genus<tei:lb/>Leptophion. Unlike Leptophion, Janzophion species lack the occipital carina, and have a well-developed<tei:lb/>membranous flange present on the fore tibial spur, behind the macrotrichial comb.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Janzophion nebosus sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fore wing length 14-16 mm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head slightly more elongate than normal for ophionines; lower face polished, 1-4-1 -5 times as long as<tei:lb/>broad; malar space 0-50-0-55 times basal mandibular width; head strongly narrowed behind eyes, occiput<tei:lb/>mediodorsally slightly concave. Flagellum with 66-68 segments, the tenth segment about 2-0 times as long<tei:lb/>as wide. Mesoscutum with margin slightly out-turned; scutellum finely shagreened; mesopleuron with<tei:lb/>upper part highly polished, finely and sparsely punctate, ventrally slightly more coriaceous; metapleuron<tei:lb/>similar. Propodeum in profile evenly declivous; propodeal spiracle joined to pleural carina by weak ridge;<tei:lb/>most of alitrunk bearing fine pale pubescence. Fore wing with AI = 1-20-1-25; CI = 0-43-0-47; ICI =<tei:lb/>0-61-0-70; SDI = 1-14-1-17; cu-a proximal to base of Rs&amp;M by about 0-3 times its own length; outer hind<tei:lb/>corner of 2nd discal cell about 90. Hind wing with about 8 distal hamuli; NI = 3-70-4-60. Legs<tei:lb/>unspecialized; hind tarsal claws of male with slightly finer and denser pectinate comb than that of female.<tei:lb/>Gaster slender, male with subgenital plate bearing long fine pubescence; gonosquamae quite long, dorsally<tei:lb/>somewhat membranous.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pale yellowish species, with interocellar area, part of mesoscutum, much of mesopleuron, metapleuron<tei:lb/>and part of propodeum blackish; gaster with distal part of tergite 5 and tergites 6+ infuscate. Pterostigma<tei:lb/>and Rs+2r blackish, other veins flavous; wing hyaline, proximal angle of marginal cell infumate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species has been taken at light in cloud forests between 1500 and 2350 m in Costa Rica.<tei:lb/>Nothing is known of its biology.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Costa Rica: Alajuela Prov; Volcan Poas N. P., xii.1982 (Janzen &amp; Hallwachs) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Costa Rica: 1 cf , same data as holotype (BMNH); 1 cf , same locality as holotype, xii.1981<tei:lb/>(Janzen &amp; Hallwachs} (BMNH); 1 $, Monte Verde Reserve, 1500 m, ii.1980 (Mason) (TC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>RIEKOPHION Gauld<tei:lb/>Riekophion Gauld, 1977: 21. Type-species: Allocamptus emandibulator Morley, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mandibles not twisted, weakly evenly tapered or distally parallel-sided, subequally bidentate; outer<tei:lb/>mandibular surface flat, punctate. Maxillary palp 5-segmented, labial palp 4-segmented; clypeus in profile<tei:lb/>convex, margin usually blunt, in one species, impressed; clypeus in anterior aspect from weakly convex to<tei:lb/>slightly concave. Ocelli from large, the hind ones contiguous with eyes, to rather small, the hind ones<tei:lb/>separated from eyes by 0-5 times their minimum diameter; frontal carina absent, or weakly present in one<tei:lb/>species; occipital carina usually complete, in one species ventrally obsolescent, not reaching hypostomal<tei:lb/>carina. Antennae moderately long and relatively slender, at least 1-3 times length of fore wing. Pronotum<tei:lb/>either unspecialized, or in two species mediodorsally long and flat; spiracular sclerite exposed, or in one<tei:lb/>species with slight expansion of dorsal lobe of pronotum; notauli vestigial or absent; epicnemial carina<tei:lb/>complete, generally curved to meet anterior margin of pleuron; mesopleural furrow very weak to quite<tei:lb/>distinct diagonally. Scutellum weakly convex, very characteristic in being fairly narrow and barely tapered,<tei:lb/>and medially longitudinally higher than laterally; carinae if present only on anterior 0-3 or less; posterior<tei:lb/>transverse carina of mesosternum complete. Propodeum with anterior area moderately to very long, often<tei:lb/>irregularly striate; propodeum usually with anterior and posterior transverse carinae complete, latero-<tei:lb/>median ones weaker but often complete behind anterior transverse carina and usually enclosing a long<tei:lb/>narrow area superomedia. Fore wing with pterostigma moderately to very slender; marginal cell usually<tei:lb/>long; Rs+2r proximally sinuous, only weakly broadened and not curved abruptly to join the pterostigma,<tei:lb/>unusual in joining stigma distal to proximal end; discosubmarginal cell anteriorly glabrous, often with<tei:lb/>group of isolated hairs near base of Rs+2r, always bearing a detached corneous or sclerotized patch in<tei:lb/>membrane. Im-cu weakly sinuous or fairly evenly curved. Hind wing with Rs straight or very weakly<tei:lb/>curved. Fore tibial spur with a membranous flange behind macrotrichial comb; mid and hind trochantelli<tei:lb/>unspecialized; inner hind tibial spur flattened, the margin with close long hairs; hind tarsal claws elongate,<tei:lb/>with thyridia small, widely separated from anterior margin to which it is joined by a groove; umbo absent;<tei:lb/>epipleuron up-turned. Ovipositor sheath slender; unusual in having male subgenital plate ornamented<tei:lb/>with projections.<tei:lb/>Riekophion is a very distinctive genus, characterized by the quadrate scutellum, unusual venation and</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>130 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ornamented subgenital plate (Gauld, 1977). It contains three species which occur in southern and western<tei:lb/>Australia. The phylogenetic inter-relationships of these species are suggested in Fig. 28. Nothing is known<tei:lb/>of the biology of these insects.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SICOPHION Gauld<tei:lb/>Sicophion Gauld, 1979: 71. Type-species: Sicophion pleuralis Gauld, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mandibles stout, twisted about 25-35 and with lower tooth slightly the longer; outer mandibular surface<tei:lb/>more or less flat, sparsely punctate. Maxillary palp 5-segmented, labial palp 4-segmented; maxillae<tei:lb/>elongate; clypeus in profile convex, apical margin not impressed, in anterior aspect truncate. Ocelli very<tei:lb/>large, the posterior ones close to margin of eye; frontal carina absent; occipital carina mediodorsally<tei:lb/>incomplete, ventrally obsolescent, not reaching hypostomal carina. Antennae very long and slender, at<tei:lb/>least 1-4 times length of fore wing. Pronotum unspecialized; spiracular sclerite virtually completely<tei:lb/>occluded by enlarged flap formed from hind corner of pronotum; notauli absent; epicnemial carina strong,<tei:lb/>extending onto mesopleural furrow; mesopleural furrow strong, extending from episternal scrobe forward.<tei:lb/>Scutellum quite convex, narrow, carinate only on anterior 0-2-0-3; posterior transverse carina of<tei:lb/>mesosternum present only laterally as vestiges. Propodeum with anterior area occluded; anterior trans-<tei:lb/>verse carina present centrally, laterally obsolescent; posterior transverse carina present as lateral vestiges;<tei:lb/>propodeum otherwise rather smooth, posterior area not differently sculptured from spiracular area. Fore<tei:lb/>wing with pterostigma broad, distally abruptly narrowed; marginal cell moderately long and slender,<tei:lb/>unique amongst ophionines in being broadest distad of centre at sinuation in distal abscissa of Rs; Rs+2r<tei:lb/>not angled near junction with pterostigma, but somewhat broadened, somewhat angled slightly proximal<tei:lb/>to centre; discosubmarginal cell very extensively glabrous anteriorly, the glabrous area bearing indistinct<tei:lb/>corneous areas; Im-cu without a ramellus, rather abruptly curved. Hind wing with Rs unique in the<tei:lb/>Ophioninae in being slightly convex. Fore tibial spur with membranous flange behind macro trichial comb;<tei:lb/>mid and hind trochantelli very elongate, but unspecialized; inner hind tibial spur strongly flattened with a<tei:lb/>fringe of long, close hairs; hind tarsal claws unspecialized, markedly sexually dimorphic, those of male<tei:lb/>being far more closely pectinate than those of the female. Gaster exceptionally slender; tergite 2 elongate,<tei:lb/>thyridia absent; umbo absent; epipleuron very narrow, pendant. Ovipositor sheath slender, ovipositor<tei:lb/>unique in being proximally angled and without a subapical notch.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sicophion is a small Neotropical genus with a single described Bolivian species (Gauld, 1979). In the<tei:lb/>BMNH is a short series of a putative second species collected in Costa Rica by Janzen &amp; Hallwachs. These<tei:lb/>differ from S. pleuralis in having a more extensive glabrous area in the discosubmarginal cell and a less<tei:lb/>obviously 'bent' Rs+2r. There are subtle differences in colour and head shape also.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sicophion is one of the most distinctive of ophionine genera. The sinuous Rs in the fore wing, the slightly<tei:lb/>convex Rs in the hind wing and the basally angulate, acutely pointed ovipositor with no subapical notch are,<tei:lb/>amongst ophionines, unique autapomorphies of the genus. Their very slender form with extensive<tei:lb/>semi-matt black coloration is a typical feature of ophionines from higher elevations (e.g. Enicospilus<tei:lb/>ruwenzorius Gauld &amp; Mitchell) and the rather elongate head shape is also found in some upper montane<tei:lb/>species (e.g. Ophion longiceps (Townes), Gauld &amp; Mitchell, 1981). The presumed loss of the dorsal notch<tei:lb/>is a feature that occurs in several genera of ichneumonids with more slender ovipositors (e.g. Parania in the<tei:lb/>Anomaloninae, Gauld, 1976).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sicophion species are only known to occur at mid and high elevation in the Neotropical region.<tei:lb/>Specimens have been taken between 1600 and 3000 m. Nothing is known of their host ranges.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The EREMOTYLUS genus-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This group contains three genera, Eremotylus, Trophophion and Hellwigiella. The last two are<tei:lb/>monobasic and probably really represent single phenetically highly divergent species of Ere-<tei:lb/>motylus. The majority of species of all genera are eremic organisms.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Eremotylus genus-group is characterized by the fore wing venation; Rs+2r is strongly<tei:lb/>geniculate and thickened before joining the pterostigma whilst \m-cu is usually fairly evenly<tei:lb/>arcuate. The clypeus is usually flat or out-flared and the margin is not subapically impressed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>EREMOTYLUS Foerster</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eremotylus Foerster, 1869: 150. Type-species: Ophion marginatus Gravenhorst (= Anomalon margina-<tei:lb/>tum Jurine), by subsequent monotypy, Thomson, 1888: 1193.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>131</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 28 Suggested phylogenetic inter- relationships of species of Riekophion. The apomorphic characters<tei:lb/>supporting this arrangement are: 1, mandible slender; 2, ocelli small; 3, occipital carina mediodorsally<tei:lb/>broadened; 4, body extensively black; 5, pronotal lobe expanded; 6, pronotum medio-dorsally flat and<tei:lb/>lengthened; 7, presence of hair patch in fenestra; 8, cubital index small; 9, distal sclerite lost; 10, ocelli<tei:lb/>grossly enlarged; 11, scutellum quadrate; 12, possession of alar sclerites; 13, metapleuron inflated; 14,<tei:lb/>Rs+2r sinuous; 15, Rs+2r joining pterostigma near centre; 16, male subgenital plate ornamented.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Camptoneura Kriechbaumer, 1901: 23. Type-species: Ophion marginatus Gravenhorst (= Anomalon<tei:lb/>marginatum Jurine), by subsequent designation, Viereck, 1914: 27. [Junior homonym of Camptoneura<tei:lb/>Agassiz, 1846.]</tei:p>
