         <tei:p>Clistorapha Cushman, 1947: 450. Type-species: Ophion subfuliginosus Ashmead, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Boethoneura Cushman, 1947: 450. Type-species: Boethoneura arida Cushman, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Chilophion Cushman, 1947: 450. Type-species: Ophion abnormum Felt, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Chlorophion Townes, 1971: 55. Type-species: Chlorophion vitripennis Townes, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>132 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mandibles not twisted, usually quite long, moderately strongly narrowed, usually subequally bidentate or<tei:lb/>with upper tooth slightly the longer; outer mandibular surface flat or slightly convex, punctate. Maxillary<tei:lb/>palp 5-segmented, labial palp 4-segmented; clypeus in profile more or less flat or even slightly out-flared,<tei:lb/>margin never impressed; clypeus in anterior aspect truncate or slightly concave. Ocelli usually moderately<tei:lb/>large to large, the posterior ones separated from the eyes by less than 0-5 their own maximum diameter, or<tei:lb/>in a few species with the ocelli small and the posterior ones separated from the eyes by more than their own<tei:lb/>maximum diameter; frontal carina absent or rarely very faintly indicated; occipital carina complete, rarely<tei:lb/>ventrally somewhat obsolescent. Antennae moderately long, at least 1-2 times length of the fore wing.<tei:lb/>Pronotum unspecialized; spiracular sclerite exposed; notauli vestigial or absent; epicnemial carina usually<tei:lb/>complete; mesopleural furrow usually rather weak but discernible, faintly indicated between episternal<tei:lb/>scrobe and subalar prominence. Scutellum weakly convex, usually carinate 0-3 to 0-8 of its length, rarely<tei:lb/>without carinae; posterior transverse carina of mesosternum from complete to present only laterally as<tei:lb/>vestiges. Propodeum generally with anterior area short but not occluded, in some species moderately long;<tei:lb/>anterior transverse carina usually distinct, at least centrally, sometimes complete, rarely absent; posterior<tei:lb/>transverse carina present laterally as vestiges or absent, other carinae generally absent; posterior area from<tei:lb/>smooth and polished to rugulose. Fore wing with pterostigma moderately slender; marginal cell long and<tei:lb/>slender, rarely rather short; Rs+2r abruptly geniculate and thickened near pterostigma; discosubmarginal<tei:lb/>cell with a small glabrous area in anterior corner; Im-cu without a ramellus, arcuate or very weakly<tei:lb/>sinuous. Hind wing with Rs from almost straight to strongly curved. Fore tibial spur with a membranous<tei:lb/>flange behind macrotrichial comb; mid and hind trochantelli unspecialized; inner hind tibial spur generally<tei:lb/>flattened with a marginal fringe of close hairs; hind tarsal claws usually unspecialized, sometimes slightly<tei:lb/>longer and less evenly curved than normal. Gaster slender; tergite 2 in profile elongate with thyridia<tei:lb/>separated from fore margin by its own length or a little more, characteristically at the posterior end of a<tei:lb/>weak trough; umbo usually distinct, rarely weak; epipleuron up-turned. Ovipositor sheath slender.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eremotylus is a moderately large genus containing about 35 species, most of which occur in the drier<tei:lb/>regions around the Mediterranean, the Middle East, Central Asia, the south-western United States and<tei:lb/>northern Mexico. Isolated species have a wider distribution; E. subfuliginosus occurs in the north-eastern<tei:lb/>part of the U.S.A., whilst the morphologically very specialized species E. marginatus is not uncommon<tei:lb/>throughout much of western Europe. E. vitripennis occurs in the drier parts of southern South America,<tei:lb/>whilst E. perdix occurs in the Indian subcontinent (Gauld &amp; Mitchell, 1981). The Palaearctic species were<tei:lb/>monographed recently by Horstmann (1981) who recognized eight species. The New World species are<tei:lb/>extremely poorly known. Virtually nothing is known about the host ranges of species of Eremotylus. The<tei:lb/>only reliable host record to hand is of one European species (E. curvinervis Kriechbaumer) which has been<tei:lb/>reared from a species oiDryobota Lederer (Lepidoptera: Noctuidae) (Seyrig, 1926).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Some authors (e.g. Cushman, 1947; Townes, 1971) divided the species of Eremotylus between a number<tei:lb/>of small genera characterized mostly by differences in the development of carinae, particularly the<tei:lb/>transverse mesosternal carina. Gauld (1979) pointed out that despite these differences, all species share a<tei:lb/>large number of features and seem to comprise a natural group. Horstmann (1981) accepted this treatment.<tei:lb/>The present study has reinforced the author's opinion that this is a natural group; it is definable on the basis<tei:lb/>of several apomorphies including the characteristically modified Rs+2r, the arcuate or slightly sinuous<tei:lb/>Im-cu and the unoccluded anterior propodeal area. The characteristic clypeus and rather slender, longish<tei:lb/>mandibles are useful confirmatory characters.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The present disjunct distribution of the genus suggests that at one time the range of the genus must have<tei:lb/>been wider. Further discussion of zoogeography is best left until the New World species are better known.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HELLWIGIELLA Szepligeti</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hellwigiella Szepligeti, 1905: 23. Type-species: Hellwigiella nigripennis Szepligeti, by subsequent desig-<tei:lb/>nation, Viereck, 1914: 67.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mandible twisted about 15, not appreciably narrowed, with upper tooth slightly shorter than the lower and<tei:lb/>bearing a pronounced very sharp ventral flange; outer mandibular surface punctate, with a strong proximal<tei:lb/>concavity. Maxillary palp 5-segmented, labial palp 4-segmented; clypeus in profile quite convex centrally,<tei:lb/>with margin reflexed, quite thin; clypeus in anterior aspect almost truncate. Ocelli small, the posterior ones<tei:lb/>separated from eye margin by more than their own maximum diameter; frontal carina absent; occipital<tei:lb/>carina strong, ventrally joining hypostomal carina. Antennae short and stout, central segments transverse,<tei:lb/>the flagellum barely longer than the fore wing. Pronotum mediodorsally quite long, otherwise unspecial-<tei:lb/>ized; spiracular sclerite exposed; notauli absent; epicnemial carina strong, complete; mesopleural furrow<tei:lb/>vestigial. Scutellum quite convex, laterally carinate about 0-8 of its length; posterior transverse carina of<tei:lb/>mesosternum complete or obsolescent centrally. Propodeum with anterior area quite short, impressed as a</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE 133</tei:p>
         <tei:p>deep U-shaped groove; anterior transverse carina more or less complete, other carinae indistinct, posterior<tei:lb/>area reticulate. Fore wing with pterostigma moderately stout; marginal cell quite long and slender; Rs+2r<tei:lb/>abruptly geniculate and slightly broadened before joining pterostigma; discosubmarginal cell with a very<tei:lb/>small glabrous area anteriorly; Im-cu evenly curved, usually without a ramellus. Hind wing with Rs evenly<tei:lb/>bowed. Fore tibial spur with a membranous flange behind macrotrichial comb; mid and hind trochantelli<tei:lb/>unspecialized; inner hind tibial spur almost cylindrical, with a fringe of sparse hairs; hind tarsal claw quite<tei:lb/>long and weakly curved. Gaster moderately slender, tergite 2 about twice as long as deep with thyridia<tei:lb/>separated from anterior margin by about their own length; umbo distinct; epipleuron membranous,<tei:lb/>pendant in most individuals. Ovipositor sheath slender.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hellwigiella contains what is, I believe, a single Mediterranean species, though it is sculpturally and<tei:lb/>chromatically rather variable and has been divided into two (Szepligeti, 1905). Hellwigiella is morphologi-<tei:lb/>cally extremely distinctive on account of the characteristic clypeus and mandible, and the form of the<tei:lb/>propodeum. The majority of apomorphic features characterizing the genus are obviously adaptations to a<tei:lb/>diurnal existence and most are paralleled in other genera with similar habits. It is possible that Hellwigiella<tei:lb/>is merely a specialized diurnal offshoot of Eremotylus, but if this were so then it is necessary to postulate<tei:lb/>that the specialized invaginated condition of the anterior area of the propodeum (character 22-2) has been<tei:lb/>derived from the partially elongated condition of Eremotylus (character 22-1). In the preceding phylo-<tei:lb/>genetic analysis it has been suggested that the apomorphic states of these characters represent alternative<tei:lb/>specializations, so it is possible that Eremotylus and Hellwigiella have a sister-group relationship. Nothing<tei:lb/>is known of the biology of Hellwigiella.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TROPHOPHION Cushman</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trophophion Cushman, 1947: 447. Type-species: Trophophion tenuiceps Cushman, by original desig-<tei:lb/>nation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mandibles barely twisted, quite stout, weakly narrowed, subequally bidentate; outer mandibular surface<tei:lb/>weakly convex. Maxillary palp 5-segmented, labial palp 4-segmented; maxilla and labium elongate,<tei:lb/>projecting below mandibles; clypeus in profile flat, in anterior aspect almost truncate. Ocelli small, the<tei:lb/>posterior ones separated from the eye by more than their own maximum diameter; frontal carina absent;<tei:lb/>occipital carina complete dorsally, ventrally incomplete. Antennae short, slightly clavate, barely longer<tei:lb/>than fore wing. Pronotum unspecialized; spiracular sclerite exposed; notauli absent; epicnemial carina<tei:lb/>complete; mesopleural furrow indistinct. Scutellum weakly convex, without lateral carinae; posterior<tei:lb/>transverse carina of mesosternum present only laterally as vestiges. Propodeum with anterior area short<tei:lb/>but not occluded; anterior transverse carina present medially, posterior one present laterally as vestiges,<tei:lb/>other carinae obsolescent; posterior area polished, punctate. Fore wing with pterostigma moderately<tei:lb/>slender; marginal cell moderately short; Rs+2r thickened and curved to join pterostigma; discosubmar-<tei:lb/>ginal cell with glabrous area anteriorly; Im-cu evenly curved, without a ramellus. Hind wing with Rs<tei:lb/>bowed. Fore tibial spur with a membranous flange behind macrotrichial comb; mid and hind trochantelli<tei:lb/>unspecialized; inner hind tibial spur weakly flattened, fringed with long fine hairs; tarsal claws rather long<tei:lb/>and weakly curved. Gaster moderately stout and rather more cylindrical than that of most ophionines;<tei:lb/>tergite 2 in profile less than twice as long as posteriorly deep, with thyridia separated from anterior margin<tei:lb/>by about its own length; umbo rather weak; epipleuron up-turned. Female with tergites 3-7 shallowly<tei:lb/>notched medially, with subgenital plate large, strongly sclerotized and centrally notched; ovipositor and<tei:lb/>sheath rather stout.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Only a single species of Trophophion is known. This occurs in the drier south-west of the U.S. A. Its host<tei:lb/>is unknown. Trophophion is recognizable on account of the specializations of the head and mouthparts and<tei:lb/>the female gaster. In other respects it is very similar to some Eremotylus species, and it is almost certainly a<tei:lb/>specialized offshoot of this genus. However, I have hesitated to synonymize Trophophion until some<tei:lb/>details of its biology and host relationship are known. If these are very different from those of Eremotylus<tei:lb/>then I suggest if be left as a separate genus even though this leaves Eremotylus as a paraphyletic taxon.<tei:lb/>Additional material from the dry parts of the U.S. A. and northern Mexico might help in elucidating the<tei:lb/>phylogenetic position of this bizarre species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The THYREODON genus-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This group contains five genera, Barytatocephalus, Euryophion, Thyreodon, Rhynchophionand<tei:lb/>Dictyonotus. The first of these is included in the complex on the basis of three apomorphies, the<tei:lb/>possession of an impressed anterior propodeal area (22-2), long, weakly curved tarsal claws, and</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>134</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>absence of any transverse carinae on the propodeum. Barytatocephalus lacks the tilted mandibu-<tei:lb/>lar axis, slender pterostigma and cylindrical hind tibial spurs of other genera, and thus seems to<tei:lb/>constitute the most primitive branch of the lineage. The remaining genera form a holophyletic<tei:lb/>group, and this may be divided into two holophyletic subgroups, one comprising Thyreodon,<tei:lb/>Dictyonotus and Rhynchophion, the other containing just Euryophion. The former subgroup is<tei:lb/>defined by the possession of a pointed clypeus, a very short and stout flagellum and an<tei:lb/>exceptionally elongate propodeal spiracle. A further possible apomorphy of this lineage is the<tei:lb/>possession of an evenly hirsute anterior part of the discosubmarginal cell (assuming that<tei:lb/>presence of a small glabrous area is an apomorphy of the subfamily). Euryophion has a slightly<tei:lb/>concave clypeus and a somewhat thickened and usually proximally curved Rs+2r. These two<tei:lb/>lineages seem to be biologically distinct; species of theThyreodon subgroup have only been<tei:lb/>recorded as parasites of Sphingidae (Gauld &amp; Mitchell, 1978; 1981; Carlson, 1979), whilst<tei:lb/>Euryophion species attack Eupterotidae and Saturniidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The close relationship between Dictyonotus, an Old World genus, and Rhynchophion and<tei:lb/>Thyreodon, primarily Neotropical genera, suggests they may have had a common ancestor that<tei:lb/>was widely distributed throughout the Nearctic and eastern Palaearctic regions. D. purpuras-<tei:lb/>cens, which could well be rather similar to the group ancestor, is currently widely distributed in<tei:lb/>the eastern Palaearctic, occurring as far north as 50 (Townes et al. , 1965) , so a slight extension of<tei:lb/>its range northwards would have permitted migration across the Bering Strait. Movement from<tei:lb/>Asia to America is postulated on the belief the group has had an Old World origin, a suggestion<tei:lb/>favoured by the present distribution of the most primitive member of the group (Barytato-<tei:lb/>cephalus) and the sister-lineage of the Thyreodon subgroup (Euryophion).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The exact relationship between the genera Thyreodon, Rhynchophion and Dictyonotus is<tei:lb/>unclear, as slight evidence in the form of a very few highly homoplastic characters can be<tei:lb/>marshalled for placing Thyreodon as the sister-group of either Rhynchophion or Dictyonotus, or</tei:p>
         <tei:p>S</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$</tei:p>
         <tei:p>w.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>10</tei:p>
         <tei:p>16</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 29 Suggested phylogenetic inter-relationships of Dictyonotus species. The length of the lines is<tei:lb/>proportional to the number of apomorphies characterizing it. The apomorphic characters supporting<tei:lb/>this arrangement are: 1, presence of a metapleural tubercle; 2, striation present on gena; 3, hind tarsus<tei:lb/>flattened; 4, Im-cu sinuous; 5, body densely pubescent; 6, tergite 2 posteriorly deeper than long; 7,<tei:lb/>malar space longer than basal mandibular width; 8, occipital carina mediodorsally broadened; 9, petiole<tei:lb/>depressed; 10, tergite 2 posteriorly at least as deep as long; 11, petiolar spiracles anterior to margin of<tei:lb/>sternite; 12, presence of metanotal swelling; 13, reduction in number of hamuli; 14, development of<tei:lb/>strongly punctate scutellum; 15, thyridia remote from anterior margin of tergite; 16, complete posterior<tei:lb/>transverse carina of mesosternum (? a reversal); 17, presence of tubercle on metanotal margin; 18,<tei:lb/>epipleuron 2 pendant.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE 135</tei:p>
         <tei:p>even Rhynchophion + Dictyonotus (see p. 93). What is clear is that both Rhynchophion and,<tei:lb/>more particularly, Thyreodon, are characterized by a string of apomorphies (as is nigrocyaneus),<tei:lb/>whilst purpurascens may well have changed very little from the form of the group ancestor (Fig.<tei:lb/>29). One wonders what adaptation acquired by the Thyreodon lineage has allowed it to radiate<tei:lb/>so markedly in the Neotropics and give rise to a complex of 30 or more quite closely related<tei:lb/>species attacking sphingids, whilst in Asia, Dictyonotus, although presented with a very similar<tei:lb/>diversity of potential hosts (Rothschild &amp; Jordan, 1903), has apparently failed to radiate<tei:lb/>appreciably.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BARYTATOCEPHALUS Schulz</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Barycephalus Brauns, 1895: 43. Type-species: Barycephalus mocsaryi Brauns, by subsequent designation,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Viereck, 1914: 19. [Homonym of Barycephalus Guenther, I860.]<tei:lb/>Barytatocephalus Schulz, 1911: 23. [Replacement name for Barycephalus Brauns.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mandible not twisted, very weakly narrowed, with upper tooth a little stouter but no longer than the lower;<tei:lb/>outer mandibular surface with a strong proximal concavity, and with a weak trace of a diagonal groove.<tei:lb/>Maxillary palp 5-segmented, labial palp 4-segmented; clypeus in profile convex, margin impressed, acute;<tei:lb/>clypeus in anterior aspect weakly convex. Ocelli small, the posterior ones remote from the eyes; frontal<tei:lb/>carina absent, though a small trace may be discernible in some specimens; occipital carina complete,<tei:lb/>ventrally reaching to hypostomal carina. Antennae quite short, about 1-3 times as long as fore wing, central<tei:lb/>segments slightly elongate. Pronotum unspecialized; spiracular sclerite exposed; notauli absent; epic-<tei:lb/>nemial carina complete, present on mesopleuron; mesopleural furrow weak but discernible as a short<tei:lb/>diagonal impression extending from episternal scrobe towards subalar prominence. Scutellum convex,<tei:lb/>carinate laterally only on anterior 0-4; posterior transverse carina of mesosternum complete. Propodeum<tei:lb/>convex, with anterior area impressed as a deep groove; propodeal carinae absent; posterior area coarsely<tei:lb/>punctate. Fore wing with pterostigma moderately slender; marginal cell moderately long; Rs+2r slender,<tei:lb/>proximally almost straight; discosubmarginal cell with a small glabrous area at anterior corner, remainder<tei:lb/>of cell sparsely hirsute; \m-cu somewhat irregularly convex, without a ramellus. Hind wing with Rs<tei:lb/>virtually straight; genus unusual in having distal abscissa of Cu\ very weak and the first abscissa of Cu\ and<tei:lb/>cu-a forming an almost straight line, oblique, so anterior corner of first submarginal cell is about 50. Fore<tei:lb/>tibial spur without membranous flange behind macrotrichial comb; mid and hind trochantelli simple; inner<tei:lb/>hind tibial spur somewhat flattened (though less so than in most taxa in this subfamily), with a fringe of<tei:lb/>moderately long hairs; hind tarsal claws long, weakly curved. Gaster moderately slender; tergite 2 in<tei:lb/>profile with thyridia close to anterior margin, elongate, umbo vestigial; epipleuron up-turned. Ovipositor<tei:lb/>slender.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Barytatocephalus is a small genus containing a single species that is widely distributed throughout the<tei:lb/>eastern Mediterranean region and the southern U.S.S.R. Nothing is known of its biology.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DICTYONOTUS Kriechbaumer</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dictyonotus Kriechbaumer, 1894a: 198. Type-species: Dictyonotus melanarius Kriechbaumer (=</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thyreodon purpurascens Smith), by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Aglaophion Cameron, 1903: 131. Type-species: Aglaophion flavinervis Cameron, by monotypy.<tei:lb/>Ophionopsis Tosquinet, 1903: 389. Type-species: Ophionopsis fulvipes Tosquinet (= Ophionopsis nigro-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>cyaneus Tosquinet), by subsequent designation, Viereck, 1914: 106. Syn. n.<tei:lb/>Hybopleurax Enderlein, 1912: 624. Type-species: Hybopleurax sumatranum Enderlein (= Thyreodon</tei:p>
         <tei:p>purpurascens Smith), by monotypy.<tei:lb/>Hypselogastrina Enderlein, 1918: 217. Type-species: Hypselogastrina saliina Enderlein (= Ophionopsis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>nigrocyaneus Tosquinet), by original designation. Syn. n.<tei:lb/>Coracophion Shestakov, 1926: 260. Type-species: Coracophion manganicolor Shestakov (= Thyreodon</tei:p>
         <tei:p>purpurascens Smith), by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mandibles stout, not twisted, barely narrowed distally, equally bidentate or with lower tooth slightly the<tei:lb/>longer; outer mandibular surface more or less flat, with scattered hairs. Maxillary palp 5-segmented, labial<tei:lb/>palp 4-segmented; clypeus in profile flat, with margin often slightly out-flared, in anterior aspect convex<tei:lb/>with a median obtuse point. Ocelli small, the hind ones separated from the eye margins by at least their own<tei:lb/>minimum diameter; frontal carina present; occipital carina complete, ventrally usually not joining the<tei:lb/>hypostomal carina. Pronotum unspecialized; spiracular sclerite exposed; notauli absent; epicnemial carina<tei:lb/>more or less complete, always present on mesopleuron; mesopleural furrow weakly impressed, horizontal,</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>136 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>extending from episternal scrobe to near upper end of epicnemial carina. Scutellum moderately convex,<tei:lb/>with longitudinal lateral carinae present only on anterior end; posterior transverse carina of mesosternum<tei:lb/>complete; metanotum exceptional in being produced into a blunt prominence above upper end of spiracle.<tei:lb/>Propodeum with anterior area short, impressed as a deep groove; propodeal carinae absent or with vestiges<tei:lb/>of lateromedian ones discernible; posterior area convex, rugose-reticulate. Fore wing with pterostigma<tei:lb/>slender; marginal cell of moderate length; Rs+2r very slightly bowed proximally, not appreciably<tei:lb/>broadened; Im-cu evenly curved to somewhat sinuous, without a ramellus; discosubmarginal cell evenly<tei:lb/>hirsute anteriorly. Hind wing with Rs weakly curved or almost straight. Fore tibial spur without a<tei:lb/>membranous flange behind macro trichial comb; mid and hind trochantelli unspecialized; inner hind tibial<tei:lb/>spur cylindrical, without a row of long marginal hairs; hind tarsal claws long and weakly curved. Caster<tei:lb/>stout to very stout; tergite 2 in profile from about 1-5 times as long as posteriorly deep to less than 1-0 times<tei:lb/>as long as deep, with thyridia oval, separated from anterior margin by about its own diameter or more;<tei:lb/>umbo absent; epipleuron pendant. Ovipositor sheath slender.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This genus contains four species, D. purpurascens (Smith), D. flavinervis (Cameron) from the Oriental<tei:lb/>and eastern Palaearctic regions and D. nigrocyaneus (Tosquinet) comb. n. and D. setus (Gauld &amp; Mitchell)<tei:lb/>comb. n. from the Afrotropical region. The last two were formerly placed in Ophionopsis, a genus<tei:lb/>originally proposed to accommodate the morphologically aberrant nigrocyaneus. D. setus is much more<tei:lb/>similar to the main Dictyonotus line than is nigrocyaneus, suggesting the two genera should be united<tei:lb/>(Gauld &amp; Mitchell, 1978). The Dictyonotus lineage is distinguished only by one weak apomorphy (Fig. 29),<tei:lb/>and purpurascens in turn by a further one, suggesting this species may resemble the ancestor of this genus,<tei:lb/>and also the ancestors of Rhynchophion and Thyreodon.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The hosts of Dictyonotus are apparently the larvae of Sphingidae (Townes et al. , 1965 ; Gauld &amp; Mitchell ,<tei:lb/>1978; 1981).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>EURYOPHION Cameron</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euryophion Cameron, 1906: 83. Type-species: Euryophion nigripennis Cameron, by monotypy.<tei:lb/>Eurycamptus Morley, 1912: 27. Type-species: Ophion latipenne Kirby, by subsequent designation,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Viereck, 1914: 57.<tei:lb/>Thoracophion Roman, 1943: 22. Type-species: Thoracophion ventrator Roman (= Ophion latipenne</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Kirby), by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Primophion Townes, 1971: 65. Type-species: Primophion adustus Townes, by original designation.<tei:lb/>Rictophion Townes, 1971: 66. Type-species: Euryophion nebulifer Morley (= Cymatoneura ikuthana</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Kriechbaumer), by original designation. Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mandibles large, not twisted, weakly narrowed apically, subequally bidentate. Maxillary palp 3-5<tei:lb/>segmented, labial palp 3-4 segmented; clypeus in profile flat or with apex out-turned, in anterior aspect<tei:lb/>usually with margin slightly concave. Ocelli small to large; frontal carina present or absent; occipital carina<tei:lb/>usually complete, rarely dorsally incomplete. Antennae rather stout, not longer than fore wing. Pronotum<tei:lb/>unspecialized, spiracular sclerite exposed; notauli weak or vestigial; epicnemial carina present ventrally,<tei:lb/>sometimes laterally absent; mesopleural furrow usually vestigial. Scutellum without lateral carinae; hind<tei:lb/>margin of metanotum at the most only weakly swollen before propodeal spiracle; posterior transverse<tei:lb/>carina of mesosternum absent except for lateral and rarely central vestiges. Propodeum with anterior area<tei:lb/>short, impressed as a deep trough; carinae virtually absent though their former position may be indicated<tei:lb/>by rugosities; posterior area from punctate to finely wrinkled to coriaceous. Fore wing with pterostigma<tei:lb/>slender; marginal cell moderately long; Rs+2r abruptly curved and thickened basally; discosubmarginal<tei:lb/>cell without a distinct fenestra, but usually with a small glabrous area in anterior corner; Im-cu fairly<tei:lb/>evenly curved, without a distinct ramellus. Hind wing with Rs from weakly to strongly curved. Fore tibial<tei:lb/>spur without a membranous flange behind macro trichial comb; mid and hind trochantelli simple; inner<tei:lb/>hind tibial spur subcylindrical or slightly flattened, often with a reduced fringe of hairs; hind tarsal claws<tei:lb/>long and weakly curved, rarely with a small apical flange. Gaster stout, tergite 2 in profile short and deep,<tei:lb/>generally less than 3 times as long as deep posteriorly; thyridia present or absent; umbo vestigial;<tei:lb/>epipleuron pendant or up- turned. Ovipositor sheath slender, often concealed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although no character is a unique autapomorphy of this genus, the species share a large number of<tei:lb/>apomorphic features (p. 87). They resemble each other greatly in venation, shape of the gaster and form<tei:lb/>of the head. No other ophionines have reduced palpar segments nor do any have the claw flange found in<tei:lb/>some more specialized Euryophion. The initial analysis suggested that Euryophion is paraphyletic with<tei:lb/>respect to Rictophion. In order to resolve this matter further a more detailed analysis was undertaken using<tei:lb/>all species in the two genera, and this confirmed the paraphyletic nature of Euryophion. The sole</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE 137</tei:p>
         <tei:p>representative of Rictophion, R. ikuthana, can be considered a specialized species of Euryophion, and it is<tei:lb/>on this basis that Rictophion is here treated as a synonym.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The more detailed analysis involved eight species, E. latipennis (201), E. adustus (202), E. ikuthana<tei:lb/>(203), E. nigripennis (204), E. meridionalis (205), E. variegatus (206), E. vexatious (207) and E. pisinnus<tei:lb/>(208). Eighteen characters from the original set (1-1, 8-1, 8-2, 9, 13, 18-2, 19, 27-2, 29-1, 29-2, 30, 36-1,<tei:lb/>36-2, 37, 43-2, 54, 57 and 59) were used together with the following eight characters.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>70 Labrum shape. In most ichneumonids the labrum is either semicircular or triangular, but broader</tei:p>
         <tei:p>basally than medially long; some Euryophion are specialized in having the labrum longer than broad</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>71 Hind tarsal claw. In some Euryophion the hind claw, is specialized in having a small flange near the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>apex (1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>72 Rs in hind wing. The moderately curved condition is considered plesiomorphic for Euryophion; in</tei:p>
         <tei:p>some taxa it is strongly curved (1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>73 Wing patterning. The plesiomorphic condition for ophionines (and members of out-groups) is</tei:p>
         <tei:p>unpatterned wings. In some Euryophion species the fore wings are distinctly patterned (1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>74 Wing ground colour. Transparent, virtually colourless wings are plesiomorphic for ophionines. The</tei:p>
         <tei:p>strongly infumate condition found in some Euryophion species is considered to be a derived feature</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>75 Rs in fore wing. The plesiomorphic condition is for this vein to be simply arcuate. The sinuous</tei:p>
         <tei:p>condition of a few species of Euryophion is considered to be derived (1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>76 Rugosity of propodeum. The plesiomorphic condition for Euryophion species and related genera</tei:p>
         <tei:p>appears to be possession of at least some rugae close to the position of the vestigial carinae; the<tei:lb/>smooth, punctate propodeum of one Euryophion species is considered to be derived (1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>77 Hairiness of ovipositor sheath. The plesiomorphic condition for most ophionines, and other</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ichneumonids, is for the sheath to bear close, moderately long pubescence. The short sparse<tei:lb/>pubescence of one species is considered to be a derived characteristic (1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The primary data matrix obtained (Table 20) was analysed using the methods outlined in the generic<tei:lb/>analysis. Characters 8-1, 18-2, 29-1, 29-2, 76 and 77 each have only a single derived state and therefore<tei:lb/>make no contribution to resolving phylogenetic relationships. A LeQuesne test on the remaining data set<tei:lb/>(Table 21) showed three characters (9, 59, 74) to be particularly homoplastic. Removal of these caused an<tei:lb/>improvement in the overall O/E ratio from 0-62 to 0-45. The high values evident in the labels matrix</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 20 Primary data matrix for genus Euryophion. The taxa corresponding to the numbers are given in<tei:lb/>the text (p. 137).</tei:p>

         <tei:p>138 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Appendix 9) strongly suggest parallelism for the derived state of character 9 (in taxa 202 and 203), of<tei:lb/>character 59 (in taxon 208 with respect to other taxa) and character 74 (in taxa 202 and 204). The single<tei:lb/>largest compatible clique comprises nine informative characters, 1-1, 8-2, 30, 37, 54, 70, 71, 73 and 75.<tei:lb/>These support a cladogram that resolves all taxa except 206-8 which remain as a trichotomy. Parsimony<tei:lb/>analysis yields two equally long minimum length trees which differ in their arrangement of taxa 206-8.<tei:lb/>There is little biological justification for preferring one or other of these two arrangements (Figs 30, 31) but<tei:lb/>the larger number of reversals involved in Fig. 31 mitigate marginally in favour of treating taxa 206 and 207<tei:lb/>as sister-species.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE 139</tei:p>
         <tei:p>203 202 208 207 206 205 201 204</tei:p>
         <tei:p>8.2<tei:lb/>18.2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>29.1</tei:p>
         <tei:p/>
         <tei:p>27.2<tei:lb/>36. Ir</tei:p>
         <tei:p/>
         <tei:p>36.2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 30, 31 Alternative cladograms showing most parsimonious arrangement of species of Euryophion.<tei:lb/>Squares indicate autapomorphic developments; circles that an apomorphic feature has been derived in<tei:lb/>parallel in two separate lineages; diamonds that a feature has undergone three transformations.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>140 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>All methods of analysis yielded similar results in suggesting that E. latipennis and E. nigripennis are very<tei:lb/>closely related, with the former possibly the ancestor of the latter. E. meridionalis was always placed on the<tei:lb/>sister-species to the clade latipennis + nigripennis, and these three taxa formed a rather distinct<tei:lb/>species-group. The three taxa whose interrelationship is difficult to resolve, E. variegatus, E. vexatious and<tei:lb/>E. pisinnus, form a very distinct clade whilst E. ikuthana and E. adustus are less closely related. Clearly it<tei:lb/>would be unsatisfactory to place ikuthana in a separate genus without at least creating separate genera for<tei:lb/>the variegatus species-group and the latipennis species-group. E. adustus could be incorporated into the<tei:lb/>former or also treated as a separate genus. As these insects are essentially similar animals that form a<tei:lb/>distinct group with respect to other ophionines, it is suggested that they be placed in a single genus,<tei:lb/>Euryophion, but to represent the phylogeny of the group four species-groups may be recognized. The<tei:lb/>formal classification may thus be summarized as follows.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>EUR YOPHION Cameron</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rictophion Townes<tei:lb/>latipennis species-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>latipennis (Kirby)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>nigripennis Cameron</tei:p>
         <tei:p>meridionalis (Morley)<tei:lb/>ikuthana species-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ikuthana (Kriechbaumer)<tei:lb/>adustus species-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>adustus (Townes)<tei:lb/>variegatus species-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>variegatus Gauld &amp; Mitchell</tei:p>
         <tei:p>pisinnus Gauld &amp; Mitchell</tei:p>
         <tei:p>vexatious Gauld &amp; Mitchell</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euryophion is primarily an Afro tropical genus with one species, E. vexatious, inhabiting southern India<tei:lb/>(Gauld &amp; Mitchell, 1978; 1981). This taxon is one of the most derived in the genus, and it is very closely<tei:lb/>related to two African species. This suggests that Euryophion may only have recently become established<tei:lb/>in the Oriental region. The data strongly suggest an African origin for the genus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>RHYNCHOPHION Enderlein</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rhynchophion Enderlein, 1912: 630. Type-species: Rhynchophion odontandroplax Enderlein, by original<tei:lb/>designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mandibles stout, not twisted, barely narrowed distally, with lower tooth somewhat longer than the upper;<tei:lb/>outer mandibular surface more or less flat, with scattered hairs. Maxillary palp 5-segmented, labial palp<tei:lb/>4-segmented; maxilla and labium elongate, projecting below apex of clypeus by about a distance equal to<tei:lb/>half the length of the head; clypeus in profile flat, with margin often slightly out-flared, in anterior aspect<tei:lb/>with median obtuse point. Ocelli small, the hind ones separated from the eye by at least their own<tei:lb/>diameter; frontal carina absent or present but weak; occipital carina complete, ventrally not joining<tei:lb/>hypostomal carina. Antennae short and stout, not as long as fore wing, and centrally with segments<tei:lb/>transverse. Pronotum unspecialized; spiracular sclerite exposed; notauli obsolescent; epicnemial carina<tei:lb/>present only ventrally, not extending onto mesopleuron; mesopleural furrow weakly impressed, hori-<tei:lb/>zontal. Scutellum convex, laterally carinate only at extreme anterior end; posterior transverse carina of<tei:lb/>mesosternum present only laterally as vestiges. Propodeum with anterior area short, present as a deep<tei:lb/>transverse groove; propodeal carinae absent or with lateral longitudinal ones present as vestiges posterior-<tei:lb/>ly; posterior area convex, rugose-reticulate grading to punctate. Fore wing with pterostigma very slender;<tei:lb/>marginal cell quite short; Rs+2r slightly bowed proximally, barely widened near pterostigma; discosub-<tei:lb/>marginal cell uniformly hirsute; \m-cu fairly evenly curved, without a ramellus. Hind wing with Rs very<tei:lb/>weakly bowed. Fore tibial spur without a membranous flange behind macrotrichial comb; mid and hind<tei:lb/>trochantelli simple; inner hind tibial spur cylindrical, without a fringe of long close hairs; hind tarsal claw<tei:lb/>long, weakly curved. Gaster stout; tergite 2 in profile about as deep posteriorly as long, sometimes deeper,<tei:lb/>with thyridia close to anterior margin; umbo absent; epipleuron up- turned. Ovipositor sheath slender.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rhynchophion is a small genus restricted to the southern part of the U.S. A. and the Neotropical region.<tei:lb/>Three species have been described, but these may be variants of a single species. They differ principally in<tei:lb/>the colour of the wings and antennae.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE 141</tei:p>
         <tei:p>THYREODON Bm\\6</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thyreodon Brulle, 1846: 150. Type-species: Thyreodon cyaneus Brulle, by subsequent designation,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hooker, 1912: 107.<tei:lb/>Athyreodon Ashmead, 1900: 87. Type-species: Athyreodon thoracicus Ashmead (= Ophion atriventris</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cresson), by original designation.<tei:lb/>Tipulophion Kriechbaumer, 19016: 75. Type-species: Tipulophion gigas Kriechbaumer (= Ophion</tei:p>
         <tei:p>atriventris Cresson), by monotypy.<tei:lb/>Macrophion Szepligeti, 1905: 32. Type-species: Macrophion ornatus Szepligeti (= Ophion atriventris</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cresson), by subsequent designation, Viereck, 1912: 640.<tei:lb/>Oleter Shestakov, 1926: 259. Type-species: Oleter selenaction Shestakov (= Thyreodon laticinctus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cresson), by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mandibles not twisted, massive, weakly to moderately narrowed distally, usually fairly evenly bidentate,<tei:lb/>or with lower tooth slightly the longer; outer mandibular surface flat except for a deep proximal concavity.<tei:lb/>Maxillary palp 5-segmented, labial palp 4-segmented; clypeus in profile from flat to slightly out-flared<tei:lb/>ventrally, generally with margin sharp; clypeus in anterior aspect with a median apical tooth. Ocelli usually<tei:lb/>small, the posterior ones widely separated from the eyes, or in a few species with ocelli very large, almost<tei:lb/>contiguous with eyes; frontal carina present, often very strong; frons medially unusual in many species in<tei:lb/>being quite strongly raised between the antennal bases; occipital carina present, usually complete,<tei:lb/>sometimes not reaching hypostomal carina ventrally. Antennae short and stout, central flagellar segments<tei:lb/>transverse. Pronotum mediodorsally specialized in having anterior and posterior margins raised to form<tei:lb/>flanges or transverse crests; spiracular sclerite exposed; notauli often strong, generally extending the entire<tei:lb/>length of the mesoscutum, frequently with crests across anterior ends; epicnemial carina complete, present<tei:lb/>on mesopleuron; mesopleural furrow absent. Scutellum rather small, moderately convex, either without<tei:lb/>lateral carinae, or, at most, with carinae present on anterior 0-4; posterior transverse carina of meso-<tei:lb/>sternum present as lateral and central vestiges. Propodeum highly modified, with central part strongly<tei:lb/>swollen so anterior part is in a very deep groove, as is the spiracle, and with the metapleuron appearing<tei:lb/>unusually small ; propodeal carinae absent, but usually with postero-dorsal surface of propodeum bearing a<tei:lb/>deep longitudinal concavity; posterior area otherwise from almost smooth to very strongly reticulate. Fore<tei:lb/>wing with pterostigma slender; marginal cell from short to moderately long; Rs+2r usually only slightly<tei:lb/>curved and weakly broadened before joining pterostigma; discosubmarginal cell without a glabrous area<tei:lb/>anteriorly; Im-cu usually evenly curved, without a ramellus. Hind wing with Rs more or less straight. Fore<tei:lb/>tibial spur without a membranous flange behind the macrotrichial comb; mid and hind trochantelli simple;<tei:lb/>inner hind tibial spur cylindrical, without a pronounced marginal fringe of long close hairs; hind tarsal claws<tei:lb/>long and weakly curved. Gaster from moderately stout to long and slender; tergite 2 in profile from slightly<tei:lb/>to very elongate, with thyridia widely separated from anterior margin; umbo absent; epipleuron pendant,<tei:lb/>but often creased anteriorly. Ovipositor sheath slender.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thyreodon is a New World genus with about 25 described species. The majority are diurnally active, and<tei:lb/>frequently seen feeding from flowers. These species are generally black or brightly coloured, and have<tei:lb/>small ocelli whereas a few nocturnal species are predominantly brown and have large ocelli. It is perhaps an<tei:lb/>interesting behavioural 'hangover' from their nocturnal ancestry, that predominantly diurnal species are<tei:lb/>quite frequently nocturnally active as well and are taken at light.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The centre of diversity of the genus appears to be in northern South America. One species extends as far<tei:lb/>north as Canada.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The ENICOSPILUS genus-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This is the largest genus-group in the subfamily, containing both the greatest number of genera<tei:lb/>and species; it also contains some of the most morphologically specialized of all ophionines. The<tei:lb/>14 genera in this group can be divided into five subgroups (the Orientospilus, Ophiogastrella,<tei:lb/>Stauropoctonus, Leptophion and Enicospilus subgroups) which correspond with the main<tei:lb/>evolutionary lineages apparent in the group. The holophyly of this group is supported by a single<tei:lb/>apomorphy, the loss of the vestigial first laterotergites, which is not a particularly convincing<tei:lb/>reason for uniting the component genera. However, all share a number of other features,<tei:lb/>including the complete atrophy of the flange on the fore tibial spur, though this feature is shared<tei:lb/>with the Thyreodon genus-group. It is possible that the Enicospilus group may be paraphyletic<tei:lb/>with respect to the Thyreodon group but this relationship could not be resolved further with the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>142 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>characters and material at hand. The majority of genera in this group (that is the Stauropocto-<tei:lb/>nus, Leptophion and Enicospilus subgroups) clearly constitute a holophyletic group (see Fig.<tei:lb/>19); the Ophiogastrella subgroup would seem to be the sister-lineage to these. The position of<tei:lb/>the Orientospilus subgroup is less clear, but it seems reasonably placed as the most primitive<tei:lb/>extant lineage of the group.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This genus-group is primarily a Pan-tropical complex of genera. Only isolated species of<tei:lb/>Simophion, Stauropoctonus, Dicamptus and Enicospilus occur in the Holarctic region. The<tei:lb/>hosts of the majority of species appear to be tree- and shrub-feeding lepidopterous larvae,<tei:lb/>though only a small percentage of all the species has been reared.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The ORIENTOSPILUS subgroup</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This group contains three genera, Orientospilus, Simophion and Prethophion. The systematic position of<tei:lb/>the latter genus is far from clear as it is united with Orientospilus and Simophion solely on the basis of a<tei:lb/>weak character - an incomplete posterior transverse carina of the mesosternum - and its present position is<tei:lb/>really only the most parsimonious possible. Prethophion does share certain features with Thyreodon - it<tei:lb/>has a slightly twisted mandibular axis, though not as pronounced as that of species in the Thyreodon<tei:lb/>lineage, and a similarly stout gaster; like species of the Thyreodon lineage the anterior margin of the tegula<tei:lb/>is not reflexed (possibly a derived feature). However, the plesiomorphic form of the anterior part of the<tei:lb/>propodeum and tarsal claws seem to exclude Prethophion from the Thyreodon group as here defined.<tei:lb/>Furthermore, the first laterotergite is lost and the mandibles are specialized in a quite different way, and<tei:lb/>much more closely resemble the derived form found in Orientospilus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Simophion and Orientospilus are more convincingly related; both have a similarly modified clypeus,<tei:lb/>have a basally angulate Rs+2r in the fore wing, have lost the epicnemial carina laterally and have a short<tei:lb/>marginal cell.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ORIENTOSPILUS Morley</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Orientospilus Morley, 1912: 6. Type-species: Orientospilus individuus Morley, by subsequent designation,<tei:lb/>Morley, 1913: 378.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mandibles not twisted, long, strongly and evenly tapered, with upper tooth much longer than the lower;<tei:lb/>outer mandibular surface flat, sparsely hirsute. Maxillary palp 5-segmented, labial palp 4-segmented;<tei:lb/>clypeus in profile flat with margin out-flared; in anterior aspect concave. Ocelli moderately large, the<tei:lb/>posterior ones separated from the eyes by 0-3-1-3 times their minimum diameter; frontal carina absent;<tei:lb/>occipital carina complete, though ventrally not reaching hypostomal carina. Antennae moderately stout,<tei:lb/>the distal segments quadrate, the flagellum barely longer than the fore wing. Pronotum mediodorsally with<tei:lb/>anterior and posterior margins reflexed, raised as keels; spiracular sclerite exposed; notauli absent;<tei:lb/>epicnemial carina present ventrally, not reaching above level of lower corner of pronotum; mesopleural<tei:lb/>furrow vestigial or absent. Scutellum quadrate, weakly to moderately convex, with lateral longitudinal<tei:lb/>carinae complete; posterior transverse carina of mesosternum present only laterally as vestiges. Prop-<tei:lb/>odeum with anterior area short, deeply impressed as groove; anterior transverse carina from complete to<tei:lb/>obsolescent, other carinae absent; posterior area coarsely reticulate, usually medially concave. Fore wing<tei:lb/>with pterostigma of moderate breadth, evenly narrowed distally; marginal cell short; Rs+2r curved and<tei:lb/>broadened before joining pterostigma; discosubmarginal cell with a glabrous area anteriorly; Im-cu<tei:lb/>evenly arcuate without a ramellus. Hind wing with Rs from virtually straight to curved abruptly proximally.<tei:lb/>Fore tibial spur without a membranous flange behind macro trichial comb; mid and hind trochantelli<tei:lb/>unspecialized; hind inner tibial spur more or less flattened, with margin of long close hairs; hind tarsal claw<tei:lb/>unspecialized. Gaster slender; tergite 2 in profile elongate, with thyridia obsolescent, or if discernible,<tei:lb/>small and quite close to anterior margin; umbo present; epipleuron usually up-turned, rarely, in some<tei:lb/>individuals, the posterior part is pendant. Ovipositor sheath slender.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This small genus contains three described species, capitatus Gauld &amp; Mitchell from southern and west<tei:lb/>Africa, melasma Townes from Madagascar and individuus Morley from eastern peninsular India.<tei:lb/>Structurally these are very similar insects. The Madagascan species is the least specialized; both the Indian<tei:lb/>and African species have lost the anterior transverse carina of the propodeum and have a shorter, stouter<tei:lb/>and apically more setaceous flagellum and have a broader malar space suggesting they are sister-species<tei:lb/>(Fig. 32). The Madagascan species may well be the ancestor of the other two.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>143</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 32 Putative phylogenetic arrangement of species of Orientospilus . This cladogram is supported by<tei:lb/>the following apomorphic features: 1 , malar space very wide; 2, ocelli widely separated from eyes; 3, Rs<tei:lb/>in hind wing curved proximally; 4, flagellum with proximal segments almost quadrate; 5, anterior<tei:lb/>transverse carina of propodeum absent; 6, malar space moderately wide, at least 0-4 times basal<tei:lb/>mandibular width.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PRETHOPHION Townes<tei:lb/>Prethophion Townes, 1971: 74. Type-species: Prethophion latus Townes, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mandibles very slightly twisted, very strongly narrowed, subequally bidentate; outer mandibular surface<tei:lb/>slightly convex, with a proximal concavity. Maxillary palp 5-segmented, labial palp 4-segmented; clypeus<tei:lb/>in profile almost flat, margin centrally blunt, clypeus in anterior aspect virtually almost truncate. Ocelli<tei:lb/>large, the posterior ones more or less touching eyes; frontal carina absent; occipital carina entirely absent.<tei:lb/>Antennae moderately slender, barely longer than fore wing but with central segments clearly elongate.<tei:lb/>Pronotum unspecialized; spiracular sclerite exposed; notauli vestigial; epicnemial carina present on<tei:lb/>mesosternum, present but very weak on mesopleuron; mesopleural furrow very distinct, oblique,<tei:lb/>extending from episternal scrobe to subalar prominence, the speculum posterodorsal to this carina strongly<tei:lb/>inflated. Scutellum convex, laterally carinate only on extreme anterior end; posterior transverse carina of<tei:lb/>mesosternum absent except for lateral vestiges. Propodeum short and abruptly declivous posteriorly;<tei:lb/>anterior area unspecialized; anterior transverse carina complete; blunt tubercles (which are possibly<tei:lb/>vestiges of posterior transverse carina) discernible; posterior area concave, very finely alutaceous. Fore<tei:lb/>wing with pterostigma moderately slender; marginal cell slender; Rs+2r proximally not broadened, almost<tei:lb/>straight; discosubmarginal cell without a glabrous area anteriorly; Im-cu fairly evenly curved, without a<tei:lb/>ramellus. Hind wing with Rs strongly curved. Fore tibial spur without a membranous flange behind<tei:lb/>macrotrichial comb; mid and hind trochantelli not specialized; inner hind tibial spur flattened, with a<tei:lb/>margin of long close hairs; hind tarsal claw unspecialized. Gaster quite stout, centrally almost cylindrical;</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>144 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>tergite 2 in profile elongate, with thyridia close to anterior margin; umbo low but distinct; epipleuron<tei:lb/>up-turned. Ovipositor sheath stout.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This enigmatic genus contains a single species which occurs at low altitudes in Peru and Bolivia. Nothing<tei:lb/>is known of its biology.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SIMOPHION Cushman<tei:lb/>Simophion Cushman, 1947: 446. Type-species: Simophion excarinatus Cushman, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mandibles fairly evenly tapered, not or barely twisted, subequally bidentate or with lower tooth slightly the<tei:lb/>shorter; outer mandibular surface punctate, proximally concave. Maxillary palp 5-segmented, labial palp<tei:lb/>4-segmented; clypeus in profile flat, apically sometimes slightly out-flared, in anterior aspect concave.<tei:lb/>Ocelli moderately large, the posterior ones separated from eye by 0-2-0-7 times their maximum diameter;<tei:lb/>frontal carina absent; occipital carina complete, though generally not reaching hypostomal carina<tei:lb/>ventrally. Antennae moderately long and slender, about 1-4-1-6 times length of fore wing. Pronotum<tei:lb/>unspecialized; spiracular sclerite exposed; notauli vestigial; epicnemial carina present ventrally, not<tei:lb/>reaching onto mesopleuron laterally; mesopleural furrow weak, diagonal, extending from episternal<tei:lb/>scrobe to near subalar prominence. Scutellum moderately convex, narrow, without lateral carinae;<tei:lb/>posterior transverse carina of mesosternum present only laterally as vestiges. Propodeum with anterior<tei:lb/>area short, striate slightly centrally; anterior transverse carina absent as are other propodeal carinae, the<tei:lb/>propodeum being narrowed distally; marginal cell short; Rs+2r very abruptly angled before joining<tei:lb/>pterostigma, its extreme end abruptly broadened; discosubmarginal cell very sparsely hirsute, with a<tei:lb/>glabrous area anteriorly; Im-cu curved or sinuous, without a ramellus. Hind wing with Rs very strongly<tei:lb/>bowed. Fore tibial spur without a membranous flange behind macrotrichial comb; mid and hind<tei:lb/>trochantelli unspecialized; inner hind tibial spur flattened, with a margin of long hairs; hind tarsal claws<tei:lb/>unspecialized. Gaster slender; tergite 2 in profile elongate, with thyridia obsolescent, or if present quite<tei:lb/>large and relatively close to anterior margin of tergite; umbo distinct; epipleuron up-turned. Ovipositor<tei:lb/>sheath slender.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This moderately small genus is restricted to the 'Mediterranean' type biomes of the northern hemi-<tei:lb/>sphere. Two species occur in the Middle East and Central Asia (Horstmann, 1981), whilst five or six occur<tei:lb/>in the south-west of the United States (Townes, 1971). Similar disjunct distributions occur in several<tei:lb/>genera of lower Aculeata (M. C. Day, pers. comm.) and in the myrmicine ant genus Messor (Bolton,<tei:lb/>1982). Amongst ophionines Eremotylus has a similar, though slightly more extensive distribution.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The OPHIOGASTRELLA subgroup</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This group comprises a single Neotropical genus, Ophiogastrella, which was treated as a member of the<tei:lb/>Ophion genus-group by Cushman (1947), but as a member of the Enicospilini by Townes (1971). Townes &amp;<tei:lb/>Townes (1973) considered it to be closely related to Laticoleus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Structurally Ophiogastrella shows a remarkable combination of primitive and derived features. The<tei:lb/>specialized fore tibial spur and first laterotergite suggest it belongs close to the base of the Enicospilus<tei:lb/>lineage, but the well-developed umbo, exposed spiracular sclerite and unspecialized anterior part of the<tei:lb/>propodeum suggest it is more primitive than many other genera. These features, together with the lack of<tei:lb/>an impressed clypeal apex, externally flat mandible and slender ovipositor sheath suggest it is not at all<tei:lb/>closely related to Laticoleus. The peculiar male claws are an autapomorphy of this taxon.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ophiogastrella is confined to the southern part of Central America and northern South America. There<tei:lb/>is no evidence to suggest the group has ever occurred elsewhere.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>OPHIOGASTRELLA Brues</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ophiogastrella Brues, 1912: 201. Type-species: Ophiogastrella maculithorax Brues, by original desig-<tei:lb/>nation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Brachyscenia Enderlein, 1921: 36. Type-species: Brachyscenia nigriventris Enderlein, by original desig-<tei:lb/>nation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mandibles not twisted, evenly but only moderately narrowed apically, subequally bidentate; outer<tei:lb/>mandibular surface flat except for small proximal concavity, centrally with scattered hairs. Maxillary palp<tei:lb/>5-segmented; labial palp 4-segmented; clypeus in profile flat or weakly convex, margin blunt or sharp,<tei:lb/>never impressed; clypeus in anterior aspect weakly convex, straight or very slightly concave. Ocelli large,<tei:lb/>the posterior ones generally very close to the eyes; frontal carina absent; occipital carina complete,<tei:lb/>ventrally (as genal carina) usually sharply angled and complete to hypostomal carina. Antennae of</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE 145</tei:p>
         <tei:p>moderate length, 1-2-1-5 times the length of the fore wing, rarely slightly longer. Pronotum unspecialized;<tei:lb/>spiracular sclerite exposed; notauli absent; epicnemial carina complete; mesopleural furrow absent or<tei:lb/>weakly impressed, diagonal, extending from episternal scrobe to near subalar prominence. Scutellum<tei:lb/>weakly to moderately convex, with lateral longitudinal carina extending about 0-8 of its length; posterior<tei:lb/>transverse carina of the mesosternum vestigial. Propodeum with anterior area short, unspecialized;<tei:lb/>anterior transverse carina from complete to absent, other carinae at most present only as vestiges;<tei:lb/>posterior part of propodeum generally rather smooth. Fore wing with pterostigma quite large and broad;<tei:lb/>marginal cell long; Rs+2r curved or slightly angled proximally, from slender to moderately broadened;<tei:lb/>discosubmarginal cell with a small glabrous area anteriorly; Im-cu very strongly and evenly curved,<tei:lb/>without a ramellus. Hind wing with Rs from almost straight to strongly bowed. Fore tibial spur without a<tei:lb/>membranous flange behind the macrotrichial comb; mid and hind trochantelli simple or with a blunt tooth<tei:lb/>near distal margin; inner hind tibial spur flattened, with a fringe of close hairs; hind tarsal claws of female<tei:lb/>unspecialized, of male flattened with pectinal comb present on both sides (Fig. 47). Gaster moderately<tei:lb/>slender; tergite 2 in profile elongate, with thyridia remote from anterior margin; umbo quite well<tei:lb/>developed; epipleuron generally upturned. Ovipositor sheath slender.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ophiogastrella is a small genus containing about 10 species, of which only three are described (Townes &amp;<tei:lb/>Townes, 1966). They are restricted to the Neotropical region from Costa Rica to about 10S in Brazil, and<tei:lb/>seem to be associated with areas which have a pronounced dry season.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The species are rather similar to each other, and best separated by differences in the length of 3r-w,<tei:lb/>shape of Rs in the hind wing and sculpture of the propodeum. There are also more subtle differences in the<tei:lb/>shape of the clypeus, and the head.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The STAUROPOCTONUS subgroup</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This subgroup contains two genera, Stauropoctonus (including as a synonym Aulophiori) and Lepiscelus.<tei:lb/>The exposed spiracular sclerites of species in this complex suggest it is one of the more primitive of<tei:lb/>enicospiline lineages. It is also one of the taxonomically most distinctive as its members are characterized<tei:lb/>by an incomplete occipital carina, a transverse mesopleural furrow, slender pterostigma, basally thickened<tei:lb/>and bent Rs+2r and a very sinuous Im-cu. Most species have Im-cu and Cw la basally widely separated,<tei:lb/>and all have the mid and hind trochantelli specialized.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The group contains few species. The most primitive Stauropoctonus species and the solitary Lepiscelus<tei:lb/>occur in the Old World, suggesting an Old World origin for the group.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>LEPISCELUS Townes</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lepiscelus Townes, 1971: 73. Type-species: Lepiscelus gracile Townes (= Eremotylus distorts Seyrig), by<tei:lb/>original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mandibles twisted about 5, proximally strongly narrowed, distally parallel-sided with upper tooth about<tei:lb/>twice as long as the lower; outer mandibular surface more or less flat. Maxillary palp 5-segmented, labial<tei:lb/>palp 4-segmented; clypeus in profile weakly convex, margin narrowly acute, laterally blunted, short,<tei:lb/>exposing labrum; clypeus in anterior aspect truncate or even slightly concave. Ocelli large, the hind ones<tei:lb/>very close to the eyes; frontal carina absent; occipital carina entirely absent. Antennae very long and<tei:lb/>slender, about 1-7 times length of the fore wing. Pronotum mediodorsally rather long, flat; spiracular<tei:lb/>sclerite exposed; notauli very short but often strongly impressed in part; epicnemial carina weak, laterally<tei:lb/>becoming obsolescent at level of lower corner of pronotum; mesopleural furrow very weakly impressed,<tei:lb/>transverse. Scutellum almost rectangular, carinate laterally only at extreme anterior end; posterior<tei:lb/>transverse carina of mesosternum complete. Propodeum with anterior area moderately long, dorsally<tei:lb/>without carinae, with posterior area finely wrinkled to rugulose. Fore wing with pterostigma slender;<tei:lb/>marginal cell long; Rs+2r abruptly curved and broadened before joining pterostigma; discosubmarginal<tei:lb/>cell anteriorly glabrous; Im-cu very strongly sinuate. Hind wing with Rs strongly curved; hamuli arranged<tei:lb/>in two groups, the proximal group comprising two which are longer and flatter than those in the distal group<tei:lb/>of three. Fore tibial spur without a membranous flange behind the macrotrichial comb; mid and hind<tei:lb/>trochantelli extended apically as a broad flange over the proximal end of the femur; inner hind tibial spur<tei:lb/>flattened, with a margin of long, close hairs; hind tarsal claws quite long, those of male more closely<tei:lb/>pectinate than those of the female. Gaster slender; tergite 2 in profile elongate, with thyridia remote from<tei:lb/>anterior end; umbo vestigial; epipleuron up-turned. Ovipositor sheath slender; male with gonosquama<tei:lb/>unusually long.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lepiscelus contains a single species which is widespread, but apparently rather uncommon, throughout<tei:lb/>the Afrotropical region between latitude 10N and 20S. The most distinctive feature of this genus is the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>146 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>flanged mid and hind trochantelli which are, amongst the Ichneumonidae, a unique feature of Lepiscelus<tei:lb/>distans. Nothing is known of the biology of this insect, but the form of the mandibles and head shape are<tei:lb/>reminiscent of some species of Enicospilus that either inhabit arid areas or are active in the dry season.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>STAUROPOCTONUS Brauns</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Stauropoctonus Brauns, 1889: 75. Type-species: Ophion bombycivorus Gravenhorst, by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Stauropodoctonus Morley, 1913: 375. [Unjustified emendation.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nipponophion Uchida, 1928: 201. Type-species: Nipponophion variegatus Uchida (= Ophion bombyci-<tei:lb/>vorus Gravenhorst), by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Aulophion Cushman, 1947: 458. Type-species: Aulophion bicarinatus Cushman, by original designation.<tei:lb/>Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mandibles twisted about 85, evenly, but quite strongly narrowed apically, subequally bidentate. Maxillary<tei:lb/>palp 5-segmented, labial palp 4-segmented; clypeus in profile weakly convex, in anterior aspect with<tei:lb/>margin slightly convex. Ocelli large, the posterior ones close to eye margins; frontal carina absent; occipital<tei:lb/>carina usually absent, partially present in one species. Antennae very long and slender, sometimes up to 2<tei:lb/>times length of fore wing. Pronotum unspecialized, spiracular sclerite exposed; notauli vestigial or absent;<tei:lb/>epicnemial carina from present and complete to absent; mesopleural furrow strong, extending from<tei:lb/>episternal scrobe to upper end of prepectal carina (or the corresponding position if this carina is absent), in<tei:lb/>some species impressed as a deep groove. Scutellum moderately convex to convex, either without lateral<tei:lb/>carinae or with carina incomplete; posterior transverse carina of mesosternum from complete to reduced to<tei:lb/>lateral vestiges. Propodeum with anterior area long; anterior transverse carina usually complete, the<tei:lb/>posterior one sometimes discernible; posterior area from weakly rugulose to reticulate. Fore wing with<tei:lb/>pterostigma moderately slender; marginal cell long; Rs+2r abruptly curved and slightly thickened basally;<tei:lb/>discosubmarginal cell with a glabrous area anteriorly, which may be expanded along Rs+2r; Im-cu<tei:lb/>without a ramellus, either evenly bowed or sinuous. Hind wing with Rs from almost straight to weakly<tei:lb/>bowed. Fore tibial spur without a membranous flange behind macrotrichial comb; mid and hind<tei:lb/>trochantelli specialized in having the outer distal margin produced into a strongly decurved sharp spine;<tei:lb/>inner hind tibial spur flattened, with a marginal fringe of long hairs; hind tarsal claws unspecialized. Gaster<tei:lb/>slender; tergite 2 in profile very elongate, with the thyridia remote from anterior margin; umbo vestigial;<tei:lb/>epipleuron pendant or up-turned. Ovipositor sheath slender.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the analysis of the genera Stauropoctonus appeared to be paraphyletic with respect to Aulophion. The<tei:lb/>latter genus has been separated from Stauropoctonus by possession of two apomorphic features (Cushman,<tei:lb/>1947; Townes, 1971). No apomorphies have ever been suggested for Stauropoctonus, though the clade<tei:lb/>Stauropoctonus + Aulophion is one of the most clearly defined in the subfamily. It is characterized by the<tei:lb/>following combination of apomorphies (though none is actually unique to the clade) - at least partial loss of<tei:lb/>occipital carina; presence of projections on mid and hind trochantelli; presence of impressed transverse<tei:lb/>furrow on mesopleuron; presence of strongly twisted mandibles; having Rs+2r in the fore wing basally<tei:lb/>angled. In addition to these features the head and mesoscutal profile of species of this clade are<tei:lb/>characteristic, though these 'apomorphies' are so subtle I have not been able to code them. To further<tei:lb/>resolve the relationship between Aulophion and Stauropoctonus more data were analysed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The following taxa were included - Aulophion sp. 1 (? bicarinatus) (301), Aulophion sp. 2 (302),<tei:lb/>Stauropoctonus bombycivorus (303), 5. torresi (304), 5. townesorum (305) and S. occipitalis (306). This is<tei:lb/>all the species in the group except for one (or possibly two) Aulophion species which are very closely<tei:lb/>related to taxon 302. To represent the range of interspecific variation in the group the following characters<tei:lb/>from the primary set were utilized- 1-2, 19, 20-1, 24-1, 25-2, 27, 30, 36, 43-1, 43-2, 44-1, 45-2, 47-2, 57 and<tei:lb/>59. (It is noteworthy that 27 and 36 are composites of 27-1 and 27-2 and 36-1 and 36-2 respectively; these<tei:lb/>characters showed identical state distribution over the data and therefore were treated as single characters<tei:lb/>to avoid excess weighting.) In addition to these fifteen, three further characters were used.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>80 Median carina of propodeum. This apomorphic feature (1) is found only in a few isolated Neotropical</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ophionines. The plesiomorphic condition, no median carina, is found in virtually all ophionines and<tei:lb/>members of the various out-groups.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>81 Metapleural sculpture. In most out-group taxa, most ophionines and several species of this group the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>metapleuron is smooth and finely punctate. Some Stauropoctonus species are specialized in having<tei:lb/>this region coarsely rugose (1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>82 Position of cu-a with respect to Rs&amp;M in fore wing. The plesiomorphic condition for ophionines</tei:p>
         <tei:p>apparently is for cu-a to be proximal to the base of Rs&amp;M. A few Stauropoctonus are specialized in<tei:lb/>having these veins opposite (1).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>147</tei:p>

         <tei:p>k45.2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1.2, 43.2</tei:p>

         <tei:pb/>
