      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>148</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The primary data matrix for taxa 301-6 is shown in Table 22. Parsimony and compatibility analyses,<tei:lb/>using techniques outlined above, yielded two 'best' alternative hypotheses of phylogenetic relationship<tei:lb/>(Figs 33, 34). The cladograms have a large number of features in common. Firstly, both suggest<tei:lb/>Stauropoctonus is paraphyletic with respect to Aulophion, and this in turn suggests that Aulophion can be<tei:lb/>treated as a synonym of Stauropoctonus , as has been formally proposed above. Secondly, both suggest that</tei:p>
         <tei:p>i</tei:p>
         <tei:p/>
         <tei:p>19, 27.1, 30<tei:lb/>i 43.1, 44.1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>45.2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>|47.2r, 57</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1.2, 43.2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>25.2 , 47.2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 34 Alternative cladogram for species of Stauropoctonus. This is the most parsimonious arrangement<tei:lb/>of taxa discovered and requires 24 transformation steps. (Symbols as for Figs 30-31.)</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE 149</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Aulophion is both a holophyletic clade and the most derived lineage in the group. Thirdly, both place 5.<tei:lb/>ocdpitalis as the most primitive taxon in the group. The two cladograms differ in their arrangement of 5.<tei:lb/>bombycivorus, S. torresi and 5. townesorum and these different arrangements depend on the alternative<tei:lb/>compatible sets of characters 36 and 45-2 versus 59, 81 and 82. Character 36 has been demonstrated to be<tei:lb/>both unreliable and of dubious polarity, whilst 45-2 can be regarded as a loss apomorphy (loss of hairs on<tei:lb/>wing membrane). Character 59 (colour of interocellar area) is also far from a convincing apomorphy, but<tei:lb/>81 and 82 strongly suggest that torresi and townesorum are sister-species. S. bombycivorus is rather difficult<tei:lb/>to place, but could be either the ancestor of, or a close relative of the ancestor of both the 'Aulophion'<tei:lb/>species-group and torresi/townesorum.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The more primitive species of this genus (ocdpitalis and bombycivorus) are restricted to the Old World,<tei:lb/>the former to the mountains of Madagascar and the latter to the southern part of the Palaearctic, except in<tei:lb/>Asia where it extends north into Kamchatka and the Kurile Islands (Townes, Momoi &amp; Townes, 1965).<tei:lb/>Possibly the ancestor of these taxa was widely distributed in the Old World at one time, and the<tei:lb/>Madagascan survivor is a relict of this. There are clear indications in the Madagascan fauna of an ancient<tei:lb/>Palaearctic affinity amongst the Hymenoptera. The symphytan taxon Cephidae is represented on the<tei:lb/>island and in the Holarctic only (Benson, 1935), and a number of ichneumonid genera have rather similar<tei:lb/>distributions, e.g. Neliopisthus, Euceros (Townes, 1969: Barren, 1978). As the widespread Palaearctic<tei:lb/>species bombycivorus may be almost directly ancestral to the two other species-groups, it may at one time<tei:lb/>have also occurred in the Nearctic region. The torresi/townesorum group is Malesian/Melanesian, with the<tei:lb/>former species constituting part of the characteristically intrusive, Indo-Papuan faunal element in northern<tei:lb/>Australia (Gauld, 19840). The distribution of torresi, in transcending both Wallace's and Weber's lines,<tei:lb/>suggests its current range is the result of a dispersive rather than a vicariance event. The Neotropical<tei:lb/>species form a rather distinctive clade. The most northerly extent of their distribution seems to be Costa<tei:lb/>Rica where one species occurs in lower montane (1000-1500 m) forest, whilst none has been found south of<tei:lb/>25S. Perhaps the ancestor of this group reached South America from the north during the Miocene when<tei:lb/>an archipelagic connection existed between the two continents (Rich &amp; Rich, 1983). This evolutionary<tei:lb/>'scenario' is based on the supposition that a Stauropoctonus occurred in the United States. At present there<tei:lb/>is no evidence for this; the scenario presented is merely the most parsimonious interpretation of data.<tei:lb/>Other scenarios would necessitate advocating much more widespread extinction.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The LEPTOPHION subgroup</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This complex of genera is characterized by the form of the mandibles, which have a more or less discernible<tei:lb/>impressed groove extending diagonally, the convex clypeus with an impressed acute margin, the very long<tei:lb/>slender antennae and, for most species, a somewhat broadened ovipositor sheath. The venation of all<tei:lb/>species is rather similar in having Rs+2r basally broadened, and often angulate before joining the<tei:lb/>pterostigma; Im-cu is either sinuate or evenly curved.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This subgroup contains three genera, Leptophion, Laticoleus and Pamophion which are difficult to<tei:lb/>resolve as the holophyly of Leptophion cannot convincingly be demonstrated. Pamophion, a monobasic<tei:lb/>taxon, is holophyletic and is apparently the sister-lineage of Leptophion + Laticoleus. The latter is a<tei:lb/>holophyletic group, but it may have arisen from within the former. The only apomorphy that can be<tei:lb/>postulated for Leptophion is the presence of a specialized penultimate hamulus. (The apomorphies shown<tei:lb/>in Fig. 19 are subject to much exception and parallelism in some species of Laticoleus, and reference to the<tei:lb/>overall classification suggests that presence of a complete posterior transverse carina of the mesosternum is<tei:lb/>plesiomorphic for this complex - though some taxa have partially lost this carina.) The assumption that the<tei:lb/>specialized hamulus is a group apomorphy necessitates speculating that reversal has occurred in several<tei:lb/>taxa, but there is some evidence that this has happened. For example, L. tetus has a slight indication of<tei:lb/>some enlargement of the hamulus and its sister-species, L. yampus, has it clearly specialized, though not as<tei:lb/>large as that of L. iochus, the sister-species of yampus + tetus. L. ankylosus and L. eithos are highly<tei:lb/>specialized species (without a modified hamulus) which are closely related to L. vernalis which has a long<tei:lb/>penultimate hamulus, and Leptophion species 1 (BMNH) which has it only slightly modified. These four<tei:lb/>species apparently belong to the maculipennis lineage, the remainder of which all have a highly specialized<tei:lb/>hamulus. A tentative phylogeny for this subgroup is proposed in Fig. 35. Laticoleus is retained as a separate<tei:lb/>genus, but its validity needs to be reassessed as more material becomes available for study and the<tei:lb/>phylogeny of the species of Leptophion is better understood.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Judging from the present distribution of this group (Fig. 36) it is most parsimonious to postulate an Old<tei:lb/>World origin for this complex of genera. The more primitive taxa are restricted to Melanesia or Australia<tei:lb/>which suggests an Australo-Melanesian origin for this group. However, if Laticoleus is truly primitive with<tei:lb/>respect to Leptophion, then an alternative hypothesis is that this group was once widely spread in the Old</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>LEPTOPHION</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MACULIPENNIS GROUP</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 35 Cladogram showing putative phylogeny of groups of species in the Leptophion subgroup. Black<tei:lb/>squares represent apomorphic features, white plesiomorphic; diagonally divided squares indicate a<tei:lb/>mixture of the two states in the component species of a particular lineage. The characters that support<tei:lb/>this arrangement are: 1, loss of specialized hamulus; 2, Rs+2r emitted from centre of pterostigma; 3,<tei:lb/>Im-cu very sinuous; 4, specialized hind tarsal claws; 5, loss of posterior transverse carina of mesoster-<tei:lb/>num; 6, presence of a 'hair brush' on mandible; 7, genal carina evanescent before joining hypostomal<tei:lb/>carina; 8, lengthened penultimate distal hamulus; 9, exceptional broad ovipositor sheath that in profile is<tei:lb/>almost quadrate; 10, long malar space; 11, ovipositor sheath at least moderately broad, in profile more<tei:lb/>than 0-4 times as deep as long; 12, marginal cell of hind wing at least partially glabrous; 13, anterior area<tei:lb/>of propodeum elongate; 14, epipleuron 2 pendant; 15, hind trochantellus marginally produced into blunt<tei:lb/>tooth; 16, posterior transverse carina of mesosternum present.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>151</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 36 The geographical distribution of taxa of the Leptophion subgroup.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>World tropics and has suffered considerable extinction, leaving only a rather specialized primitive lineage<tei:lb/>in the Afrotropical region and a few relicts east of Wallace's line. Gauld (1984a) suggested that the anici<tei:lb/>and iochus groups of Leptophion, in Australia, have had a northern origin, and that once their ancestors<tei:lb/>had adapted sufficiently to cross the rain forest/savannah interface (Taylor, 1972) then they had ample<tei:lb/>opportunity to give rise to radiations in species-poor Australia (Gauld, 1984a). The most specialized group<tei:lb/>of Leptophion, the maculipennis group, is best represented in the more easterly parts of Indonesia and<tei:lb/>Melanesia. It is probable that this species-group arose in this area and a few species have spread west to the<tei:lb/>Asian mainland.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>LATICOLEUS Townes</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Laticoleus Townes, in Townes &amp; Townes, 1973: 358. Type-species: Coiloneura unicolor Szepligeti, by<tei:lb/>original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mandibles not twisted, weakly narrowed apically, generally subequally bidentate; outer mandibular<tei:lb/>surface with subbasal swelling weak or well developed, with a diagonal groove extending from the upper<tei:lb/>proximal corner to between bases of teeth. Maxillary palp 5-segmented, labial palp 4-segmented; clypeus<tei:lb/>in profile convex, margin impressed, in anterior aspect with margin weakly convex. Ocelli generally<tei:lb/>moderately large, the posterior ones separated from the eyes by 0-2-1-0 times their minimum diameter;<tei:lb/>frontal carina absent; occipital carina complete, the lower part (genal carina) reaching to hypostomal<tei:lb/>carina. Antennae very long and slender, at least 1-5 times length of fore wing. Pronotum usually<tei:lb/>unspecialized, or in one Madagascan species with anterior margin mediodorsally expanded and curved<tei:lb/>back; spiracular sclerite partially concealed; notauli vestigial or absent; epicnemial carina complete, weak<tei:lb/>or even absent on mesopleuron; mesopleural furrow undeveloped. Scutellum weakly convex, with lateral<tei:lb/>longitudinal carinae present, more or less complete; posterior transverse carina of the mesosternum<tei:lb/>incomplete, present as lateral or rarely central vestiges. Propodeum with anterior area moderately long,<tei:lb/>striate or smooth; anterior transverse carina present or absent, other carinae usually absent; posterior area<tei:lb/>from rugose to virtually smooth. Fore wing with pterostigma moderately stout; marginal cell long; Rs+2r</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>152 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>conspicuously thickened near pterostigma, often abruptly curved in proximal part; discosubmarginal cell<tei:lb/>with a glabrous area in anterior corner, this area generally quite large, and in one species, bearing a weak<tei:lb/>sclerite; Im-cu without a ramellus, usually fairly evenly bowed, in a few species slightly sinuous. Hind wing<tei:lb/>with Rs from almost straight to strongly curved, with marginal cell proximally, at least narrowly glabrous;<tei:lb/>distal hamuli unspecialized, or with proximal three enlarged. Fore tibial spur without a membranous flange<tei:lb/>behind macrotrichial comb; mid and hind trochantelli unspecialized or with a weak tooth projecting<tei:lb/>distally; inner hind tibial spur flattened with a margin of close long hairs; hind tarsal claws usually<tei:lb/>unspecialized, rarely with very coarse pectinae. Gaster slender; tergite 2 in profile very elongate, with<tei:lb/>thyridia well removed from anterior margin; umbo absent; epipleuron up-turned. Ovipositor sheath<tei:lb/>exceptionally broad.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Laticoleus is a moderately small Afrotropical genus containing 11 described species (Gauld &amp; Mitchell,<tei:lb/>1978) . The majority occur in Madagascar and east Africa. Nothing is known of the biology of species of this<tei:lb/>genus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>LEPTOPHION Cameron</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leptophion Cameron, 1901: 227. Type-species: Leptophion longiventris Cameron, by monotypy.<tei:lb/>Spilophion Cameron, 1905: 124. Type-species: Spilophion maculipennis Cameron, by monotypy.<tei:lb/>Coiloneura Szepligeti, 1905: 35. Type-species: Coiloneura melanostigma Szepligeti (= Leptophion lon-<tei:lb/>giventris Cameron), by subsequent designation, Viereck, 1914: 35.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mandibles not twisted, weakly narrowed apically, generally subequally bidentate; outer mandibular<tei:lb/>surface often with a basal swelling, and with a diagonal groove extending from near upper corner to<tei:lb/>between bases of teeth, sometimes with this groove bearing a brush of long hairs, other times with the<tei:lb/>groove very weak. Maxillary palp 5-segmented, labial palp 4-segmented; clypeus in profile convex, margin<tei:lb/>impressed acute, in anterior aspect usually with margin weakly convex, rarely slightly concave. Ocelli<tei:lb/>generally large, the posterior ones close to the margins of the eyes, or rarely in some Australian examples,<tei:lb/>with ocelli smaller; frontal carina absent; occipital carina either complete or obsolescent at extreme ventral<tei:lb/>end so the carina fails to join the hypostomal carina. Antennae in most species very long and slender, at<tei:lb/>least 1-5 times the length of the fore wing, in some Australian species shorter, barely longer than the fore<tei:lb/>wing. Pronotum unspecialized; spiracular sclerite partially concealed, in a few Malesian taxa almost<tei:lb/>completely covered; notauli vestigial or absent; epicnemial carina complete; mesopleural furrow usually<tei:lb/>undeveloped. Scutellum moderately convex, from without lateral carinae to with these carinae complete;<tei:lb/>posterior transverse carina of mesosternum complete, interrupted before mid coxae, or rarely absent.<tei:lb/>Propodeum with anterior area long and usually striate; anterior transverse carina usually complete, rarely<tei:lb/>absent, the other carinae usually not discernible; posterior area from strongly rugose to smooth and<tei:lb/>shining. Fore wing with pterostigma moderately broad; marginal cell long; Rs+2r conspicuously thickened<tei:lb/>near pterostigma, usually abruptly curved or angled near base; discosubmarginal cell usually with a<tei:lb/>glabrous area in anterior corner, this area usually large and extending 0-2 of the way down Rs+2r, rarely<tei:lb/>with a weak alar sclerite, sometimes secondarily with micro trichia obscuring part of glabrous area; Im-cu<tei:lb/>usually without a ramellus, either evenly bowed or, more usually, sinuous. Hind wing with Rs from almost<tei:lb/>straight to very strongly bowed, with marginal cell adjacent to this vein at least narrowly glabrous; distal<tei:lb/>hamuli unspecialized or with penultimate hamulus long and coiled. Fore tibial spur without a membranous<tei:lb/>flange behind macrotrichial comb; mid and hind trochantelli unspecialized; inner hind tibial spur flattened,<tei:lb/>with a fringe of long close hairs; hind tarsal claws unspecialized or with distal pectinal tooth projecting<tei:lb/>beyond the apex of the claw. Gaster usually slender, tergite 2 in profile from moderately to very elongate,<tei:lb/>with thyridia remote from anterior margin; umbo absent; epipleuron up-turned. Ovipositor sheath<tei:lb/>moderate, broad.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leptophion is a moderately large Indo-Pacific genus containing 30 described species (Gauld, 1977;<tei:lb/>Gauld &amp; Mitchell, 1981). The majority are restricted to lower montane forests on the islands to the east of<tei:lb/>the Sunda Shelf. Many are endemic to a particular island and recent collecting has yielded an undescribed<tei:lb/>species from Sulawesi (BMNH). Most species are only known from relatively few individuals.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The genus is divisible into four species-groups, the largest of which, the maculipennis species-group, may<tei:lb/>be subdivided into three species-complexes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to species-groups and complexes of Leptophion</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Anterior transverse carina of mesosternum incomplete; propodeum often with anterior trans-<tei:lb/>verse carina absent anici species-group</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE 153</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Anterior transverse carina of mesosternum complete; propodeum almost always with anterior</tei:p>
         <tei:p>transverse carina complete 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Hind tarsal claw simple ; genal carina usually joining hypostomal carina 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Hind tarsal claw with distal pectinal tooth projecting apically; genal carina usually not reaching</tei:p>
         <tei:p>hypostomal carina (maculipennis species-group) 4</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Mandible with a dense brush of long stout hair on outer surface iochus species-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Mandible with scattered hairs on outer surface longicornis grade-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4 Fore wing with Rs+2r emitted from near centre of pterostigma; anterior corner of discosubmar-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ginal cell partially hirsute eithos species-complex</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Fore wing with Rs+2r emitted from proximal end of pterostigma; anterior corner of discosub-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>marginal cell glabrous 5</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5 Penultimate distal hamulus unspecialized; fore wing with Im-cu from evenly curved to weakly</tei:p>
         <tei:p>sinuous radiatus species-complex</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Penultimate distal hamulus long and coiled; fore wing with Im-cu moderately to strongly</tei:p>
         <tei:p>sinuous maculipennis species-complex</tei:p>
         <tei:p>longicornis grade-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This paraphyletic assemblage contains two species, L. longicornis (Szepligeti) and L. bakeri (Cheesman).<tei:lb/>The group can only be characterized by symplesiomorphies. It is restricted to New Guinea and the New<tei:lb/>Hebrides.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>anici species-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This holophyletic group contains three species, L. anici Gauld, L. antennatus (Morley) and L. unical-<tei:lb/>caratus Gauld. The group is characterized by the loss of the posterior transverse carina of the mesoster-<tei:lb/>num; species tend to have less propodeal sculpture than most Leptophion species, and usually the<tei:lb/>transverse carina is lost. The anici species-group is restricted to Australia and New Caledonia where<tei:lb/>species occur in drier habitats than mos't Leptophion.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>iochus species-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This holophyletic group contains three Australian species, L. iochus Gauld, L. yampus Gauld and the<tei:lb/>aberrant L. tetus Gauld. The group is characterized by possession of a brush of hair on the outer surface of<tei:lb/>the mandible; they are generally more robust species with more densely pubescent wings than most<tei:lb/>Leptophion species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>maculipennis species-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This holophyletic group is characterized by the presence of a modified hind tarsal claw; the majority of<tei:lb/>species have infumate marks in the proximal corner of the marginal cells and in most the genal carina does<tei:lb/>not join the hypostomal carina. This is the largest species-group and may be subdivided into three<tei:lb/>apparently holophyletic species-complexes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>eithos species-complex. This group contains four species, L. eithos Gauld &amp; Mitchell, L. ankylosus<tei:lb/>Gauld &amp; Mitchell, L. vernalis Gauld &amp; Mitchell and Leptophion species 1 (BMNH). It is characterized by<tei:lb/>the highly modified fore wing venation in which Rs+2r is emitted near the centre of the pterostigma. This<tei:lb/>complex is restricted to Western New Guinea, Sulawesi and the intervening islands.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>radiatus species-complex. This group contains six species, L. radiatus (Uchida), L. pterospilus Gauld &amp;<tei:lb/>Mitchell, L, vechti Gauld &amp; Mitchell, L. lavellai Gauld &amp; Mitchell, L. cheesmanae Gauld &amp; Mitchell and<tei:lb/>L. illustrious Gauld &amp; Mitchell. It is characterized by the possession of unspecialized hamuli; most species<tei:lb/>have a rather evenly curved Im-cu and very few have Rs in the hind wing appreciably curved. This group is<tei:lb/>widely distributed from the Solomon Islands to the Continental Asian mainland.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>maculipennis species-complex. This group contains 13 species, L. maculipennis (Cameron), L. pubes-<tei:lb/>cens Gauld &amp; Mitchell, L. gobius Gauld &amp; Mitchell, L. kus Gauld &amp; Mitchell, L. juxtus Gauld &amp; Mitchell,<tei:lb/>L. magus Gauld &amp; Mitchell, L. townesi Gauld &amp; Mitchell, L. alleni Gauld &amp; Mitchell, L. nodus Gauld &amp;<tei:lb/>Mitchell, L. samari Gauld &amp; Mitchell, L. samuelsoni Gauld &amp; Mitchell, L. quorus Gauld &amp; Mitchell and<tei:lb/>L. longiventris Cameron. These are the characteristic Leptophion species of Cushman (1947) and Townes<tei:lb/>(1971) in that they possess both a specialized hind tarsal claw and modified penultimate hamulus. Most<tei:lb/>species have Im-cu very strongly sinuous and Rs in the hind wing strongly bowed. This is the most<tei:lb/>widespread of all groups with species throughout the Indo-Pacific region. One species has colonized<tei:lb/>tropical Australia (Gauld, 1984a).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>154 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PAMOPHION Gauld<tei:lb/>Pamophion Gauld, 1977: 28. Type-species: Pamophion sorus Gauld, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mandibles not twisted, weakly narrowed apically, subequally bidentate; outer mandibular surface with<tei:lb/>subbasal swelling, and with a diagonal groove. Maxillary palp 5-segmented, labial palp 4-segmented;<tei:lb/>clypeus in profile convex, margin impressed, acute, in anterior aspect weakly convex. Ocelli large, the<tei:lb/>posterior ones close to the eye margins; frontal carina absent; occipital carina complete except at extreme<tei:lb/>ventral end. Antennae long and slender. Pronotum unspecialized; spiracular sclerite partially concealed;<tei:lb/>notauli vestigial; epicnemial carina quite strong, present on mesopleuron; mesopleural furrow unde-<tei:lb/>veloped. Scutellum weakly convex, carinate laterally most of its length; posterior transverse carina of<tei:lb/>mesosternum incomplete, usually discernible as a discontinuous ridge. Propodeum with anterior area<tei:lb/>rather short, striate; anterior transcarina complete, other carinae absent, posterior area rugose-reticulate.<tei:lb/>Fore wing with pterostigma moderately broad; marginal cell long; Rs+2r conspicuously thickened near<tei:lb/>pterostigma, proximally curved; discosubmarginal cell broadly glabrous anteriorly; Im-cu without a<tei:lb/>ramellus, moderately sinuous. Hind wing with Rs straight; marginal cell evenly hirsute; hamuli unspecial-<tei:lb/>ized. Fore tibial spur without a membranous flange behind the macro-trichial comb; mid and hind<tei:lb/>trochantelli with a distinct blunt distal tooth; inner hind tibial spur flattened, with a fringe of long, close<tei:lb/>hairs; hind tarsal claws unspecialized. Gaster slender; tergite 2 in profile very elongate, with thyridia<tei:lb/>moderately close to anterior margin; umbo absent; epipleuron pendant, narrow. Ovipositor sheath<tei:lb/>slender, unspecialized.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A single species, P. sorus, is known to occur in Queensland. It is apparently the most primitive species in<tei:lb/>this genus-group. Nothing is known of its biology.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The ENICOSPILUS subgroup</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This group contains five genera, Dicamptus, Enicospilus, Pycnophion, Banchogastra and Abanchogastra.<tei:lb/>The last three are endemic Hawaiian taxa and probably constitute a monophyletic clade which almost<tei:lb/>certainly arose from within Enicospilus. They are so phenetically divergent, however, that it would be<tei:lb/>quite impractical to include them within Enicospilus, an otherwise structurally uniform genus of over 700<tei:lb/>species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The relationship of Enicospilus to Dicamptus is not clear; the latter may be paraphyletic with respect to<tei:lb/>the former though subtle differences in venation, alar sclerite form, sculpture and body shape suggest that<tei:lb/>Dicamptus is actually holophyletic.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Enicospilus group is characterized by a number of apomorphic features including having the<tei:lb/>spiracular sclerite concealed, having an elongate anterior propodeal area, having a rather sinuous Rs+2r<tei:lb/>and generally having alar sclerites. Individual species may be exceptional in one or two of these features.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dicamptus, clearly the least specialized genus in this complex, is restricted to the Old World, and<tei:lb/>Enicospilus is apparently most diverse in the Old World tropics, suggesting a palaeotropical origin for the<tei:lb/>group. Preliminary study of Neotropical species of Enicospilus suggests that very few large species-groups<tei:lb/>occur in South America; several of these also occur in the Nearctic region. The Australian Dicamptus and<tei:lb/>Enicospilus have apparently been derived from immigration from South East Asia (Gauld, 1984o).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Hawaiian genera seem to be a holophyletic group. This is attested by the total lack of alar sclerites,<tei:lb/>possession of a straight, rather slender Rs+2r and loss of the last 0-3 or so of the lateral scutellar carinae.<tei:lb/>There are a number of other similarities in sculpture and exact position of wing veins that further supports<tei:lb/>this clade.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The inter-relationship of these three genera may be misrepresented in the cladogram (Fig. 37).<tei:lb/>Considering only the characters in the primary data matrix five (16-2, 27-3, 37, 48-1 and 49) support<tei:lb/>Pycnophion + Abanchogastra whilst three (13, 42-2, 43-1) support the group Pycnophion + Banchogastra.<tei:lb/>None supports the third combination. Of the first five characters 16-2 has almost certainly undergone<tei:lb/>reversal in Banchogastra as the character is apomorphic in the greater part of the presumed ancestral<tei:lb/>lineage of the species. The plesiomorphic state is otherwise generally only found in primitive ophionines<tei:lb/>and (again as a reversal) in a few diurnal specialized species (Banchogastra has not been taken at light and<tei:lb/>thus may well be diurnally active). Character 27-3, a centrally interrupted posterior mesosternal carina, is<tei:lb/>only found in the primary data set in Pycnophion and Abanchogastra, but this carina is weak centrally in<tei:lb/>Banchogastra and may even be absent narrowly in some specimens. A medioventrally evanescent<tei:lb/>mesosternal carina can therefore be considered an apomorphy of the Hawaiian genera. Character 49,<tei:lb/>position of Cu\ in the fore wing, is plesiomorphic only for Banchogastra. The derived condition must<tei:lb/>therefore be considered to be an apomorphy of the subfamily and the anomalous inclination of this vein in<tei:lb/>Banchogastra is presumably a further specialization, perhaps resulting from the very close proximity of the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>155</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 37 Putative phylogenetic arrangement of Hawaiian genera in relation to Enicospilus moea Chees-<tei:lb/>man. This cladogram is supported by the following apomorphic features: 1, petiolar spiracles anterior to<tei:lb/>margin of sternite 1; 2, tergite 2 depressed; 3, epipleuron 2 pendant; 4, further reduction in ocellar size;<tei:lb/>5, possession of an elongate ovipositor; 6, loss of hair in discosubmarginal cell centrally; 7, development<tei:lb/>of a stout gaster; 8, possession of large thyridia close to anterior margin of tergite; 9, metapleuron<tei:lb/>inflated; 10, epicnemial carina medioventrally incomplete; 11, possession of a short, rounded prop-<tei:lb/>odeum; 12, presence of incipient frontal carinae; 13, possession of inflated hind trochanters; 14, loss of<tei:lb/>occipital carina mediodorsally; 15, upper tooth of mandible compressed; 16, increase in torsion of<tei:lb/>mandible; 17, reduction in size of ocelli; 18, loss of fenestra; 19, development of fine, granulate thoracic<tei:lb/>sculpture; 20, loss of alar sclerites; 21, reduction in length of second abscissa of Cui in fore wing; 22,<tei:lb/>medially evanescent posterior transverse carina of mesosternum ; 23 , straight and slender Rs +2r; 24, loss<tei:lb/>of posterior part of lateral carina of scutellum.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>bases of \m-cu and Cw la . In some individuals this abscissa of Cui is occluded. The remaining two<tei:lb/>apomorphies (37 and 48-1) are venational features which are usually rather variable. The three apomor-<tei:lb/>phies uniting Pycnophion with Banchogastra are slightly more convincing, particularly 42-2, the ptero-<tei:lb/>stigma shape. Furthermore, Pycnophion and Banchogastra resemble each other in many other specialized<tei:lb/>features. Both have smaller ocelli than normal, have a medioventrally interrupted epicnemial carina, have</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>156 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>a strongly inflated metapleuron and a rather short anterior propodeal area and possess rather inflated<tei:lb/>trochanters. The thyridia of tergite 2 are large and close to the anterior margin (? a reversal) and the gaster<tei:lb/>is stouter than most other ophionines. The first segment of the gaster is very much broader and shorter than<tei:lb/>the corresponding segment in other enicospilines. In view of these marked similarities it would seem that<tei:lb/>Pycnophion + Banchogastra constitute a distinct clade.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A Marquesan species, Enicospilus moea Cheesman, shares a number of apomorphies with the Hawaiian<tei:lb/>genera, including possession of a straight, rather slender Rs+2r, having a medioventrally obsolescent<tei:lb/>posterior mesosternal carina and having only the anterior 0-7 of the scutellum carinate. Like the Hawaiian<tei:lb/>genera the abscissa of Cui between Im-cu and Cw la is very short and cu-a is well proximal to the base of<tei:lb/>Rs&amp;M. This species does, however, possess fenestra but this, rather than any of the extant Hawaiian<tei:lb/>species, may be closest to the base of the Pycnophion/ Banchogastra/ Abanchogastra evolutionary line (Fig.<tei:lb/>37).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ABANCHOGASTRA Perkins<tei:lb/>Abanchogastra Perkins, 1902: 141. Type-species: Abanchogastra debilis Perkins, by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mandibles twisted about 45, strongly and evenly narrowed with teeth subequal, slightly depressed; outer<tei:lb/>mandibular surface almost flat. Maxillary palp 5-segmented, labial palp 4-segmented; clypeus in profile<tei:lb/>weakly convex, margin blunt; clypeus in anterior aspect weakly convex. Ocelli large, the posterior ones<tei:lb/>separated from eye by 0-1-0-2 times their own diameter; frontal carina absent; occipital carina present,<tei:lb/>mediodorsally interrupted, ventrally weak but joining hypostomal carina. Antennae incomplete. Pro-<tei:lb/>notum unspecialized; spiracular sclerite concealed by pronotal flange; notauli absent; epicnemial carina<tei:lb/>weak but present on mesopleuron; mesopleural furrow absent. Scutellum weakly convex, carinate laterally<tei:lb/>about 0-7 of its length; posterior transverse carina of mesosternum centrally obsolescent. Propodeum with<tei:lb/>anterior area long, striate, carinae absent, posterior area coriaceous. Fore wing with pterostigma of<tei:lb/>moderate width; marginal cell long; Rs+2r straight and slender; discosubmarginal cell uniformly hirsute;<tei:lb/>Im-cu evenly curved, without a ramellus. Hind wing with Rs weakly curved. Fore tibial spur without a<tei:lb/>membranous flange behind macrotrichial comb; mid and hind trochantelli unspecialized; inner hind tibial<tei:lb/>spur flattened, hind tarsal^claws unspecialized. Gaster slender; tergite 2 very elongate, thyridia elliptical,<tei:lb/>remote from anterior margin, umbo absent; epipleuron up-turned. Ovipositor sheath slender.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This genus contains a single Hawaiian species which differs strikingly from any Enicospilus in the fore<tei:lb/>wing venation. Nothing is known of its biology.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BANCHOGASTRA Ashmead<tei:lb/>Banchogastra Ashmead, 1900: 87. Type-species: Banchogastra nigra Ashmead, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mandibles twisted about 25, strongly and evenly narrowed apically with upper tooth a little longer than the<tei:lb/>lower; outer mandibular surface with strong proximal concavity, remainder of surface virtually flat but with<tei:lb/>diagonal tract of dense hair. Maxillary palp 5-segmented, labial palp 4-segmented; clypeus in profile<tei:lb/>weakly convex, margin sharp, not impressed at all; clypeus in anterior aspect with margin very weakly<tei:lb/>convex. Ocelli small, the posterior ones separated from eyes by more than their own minimum diameter;<tei:lb/>frontal carina very weak but discernible; occipital carina complete, ventrally not quite reaching hypo-<tei:lb/>stomal carina. Antennae moderately slender, about 1-2 times length of fore wing. Pronotum unspecialized;<tei:lb/>spiracular sclerite completely occluded by pronotal flange; notauli weak; epicnemial carina strong, present<tei:lb/>on mesopleuron but medioventrally interrupted; mesopleural groove virtually absent. Scutellum convex,<tei:lb/>carinate laterally about 0-8 of its length; posterior transverse carina of mesosternum complete, or slightly<tei:lb/>weak medioventrally. Propodeum with anterior area moderately short but clearly discernible; anterior<tei:lb/>transverse carina complete; posterior transverse carina vestigial, others absent; posterior area rugose.<tei:lb/>Fore wing with pterostigma moderately slender; marginal cell long; discosubmarginal cell evenly hirsute;<tei:lb/>Rs+2r straight, expanded slightly immediately before joining pterostigma; Im-cu evenly arcuate, ramellus<tei:lb/>absent; unusual in having Im-cu and Cw la basally contiguous or united. Hind wing with Rs almost straight.<tei:lb/>Fore tibial spur without a membranous flange behind macrotrichial comb; mid and hind trochantelli short<tei:lb/>and stout, otherwise unspecialized; inner hind tibial spur slightly flattened, with a fringe of fine hairs; hind<tei:lb/>tarsal claws long but closely pectinate. Gaster stout; tergite 2 depressed, barely longer than deep, not<tei:lb/>longer than broad; thyridia large, oval, close to anterior margin; umbo absent; laterotergite narrow,<tei:lb/>pendant. Ovipositor sheath short, slender.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Banchogastra is a small genus containing two Hawaiian species (Townes, 1971). Nothing is known of<tei:lb/>their biology.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>157</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 38-^t3 Stereoscan photographs of ophionines: 38-41, mandibles of (38) Ophion sp.; (39) Ophio-<tei:lb/>gastrella sp.; (40) Enicospilus sp.; (41) Leptophion alleni Gauld &amp; Mitchell. 42, 43, hind corner of<tei:lb/>pronotum and spiracular sclerite of (42) Ophion sp. ; (43) Enicospilus sp.</tei:p>

      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>159</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 50-52 Stereoscan photographs of dorsal region of posterior part of alitrunk of: 50, Ophion sp. ; 51,<tei:lb/>Enicospilus sp.; 52, Thyreodon sp.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DICAMPTUS Szepligeti<tei:lb/>Dicamptus Szepligeti, 1905: 21. Type-species: Dicamptus giganteus Szepligeti, by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mandibles not twisted, generally very weakly narrowed, almost equally bidentate; outer mandibular<tei:lb/>surface weakly convex with proximal concavity, sometimes with pronounced proximal swelling and<tei:lb/>diagonal hirsute groove. Maxillary palp 5-segmented, labial palp 4-segmented; clypeus in profile from flat<tei:lb/>to convex or even pyramidal, usually with margin impressed and acute; clypeus in anterior aspect truncate<tei:lb/>or weakly convex. Ocelli generally large, the posterior ones usually virtually contiguous with eyes except in<tei:lb/>a few Afro tropical species; frontal carina absent; occipital carina usually complete, ventrally joining<tei:lb/>hypostomal carina. Antennae moderately to extremely elongate, from slightly longer than fore wing to 2-0<tei:lb/>times fore wing length and with upwards of 90 flagellar segments. Pronotum unspecialized; spiracular<tei:lb/>sclerite virtually completely concealed by pronotal lobe; notauli vestigial or absent; epicnemial carina<tei:lb/>usually complete, often strong; mesopleural furrow generally absent. Scutellum weakly to moderately<tei:lb/>convex, with lateral longitudinal carinae strong, usually complete; posterior transverse carina of meso-<tei:lb/>sternum complete. Propodeum with anterior area long, striate; anterior transverse carina usually complete<tei:lb/>and other carinae obsolescent or absent; posterior area usually coarsely reticulate. Fore wing with<tei:lb/>pterostigma fairly slender; marginal cell very long; Rs+2r broadened and variously sinuate before joining<tei:lb/>pterostigma; discosubmarginal cell with a large glabrous fenestra near anterior corner, this fenestra<tei:lb/>bearing at least one sclerite (proximal one); Im-cu from arcuate to sinuous, usually without a ramellus.<tei:lb/>Hind wing with Rs virtually straight. Fore tibial spur without a membranous flange behind macrotrichial<tei:lb/>comb; mid and hind trochantelli unspecialized; inner hind tibial spur flattened, with a margin of long close<tei:lb/>hairs; hind tarsal claws unspecialized. Gaster slender; tergite 2 very elongate, with thyridia remote from<tei:lb/>anterior margin; umbo absent; epipleuron up-turned. Ovipositor sheath slender.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dicamptus is a moderate-sized genus with 27 described species and two undescribed species (ANIC;<tei:lb/>BMNH) in the Palaeotropical region. A few species extend into temperate areas, D. fuscicornis (Erichson)<tei:lb/>reaches Tasmania and D. nigropictus (Matsumura) occurs northwards as far as Japan and Korea.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Two quite distinct species-groups are recognizable. The pulchellus group comprises gracile species with a<tei:lb/>very small cubital index (0-55 or less), a short vein 3r-m (less than 0-5 of the length of M between 2m-cu<tei:lb/>and 3r-ra) and a fairly well-developed mandibular groove. This group contains D. collessi Gauld, D.<tei:lb/>uptoni Gauld and Dicamptus species 1 (ANIC) which are Australian endemics, D. indicus Nikam and D.<tei:lb/>fuscicornis which are widespread Indo- Australian species, D. isshikii, an Oriental species and the<tei:lb/>Afrotropical species D. crassellus (Morley), D. xhosa Delobel, D. betsileo Delobel, D. pellucidus<tei:lb/>(Kriechbaumer), D. seyrigi Delobel, D. townesi Delobel and D. pulchellus (Morley).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The remaining species (the giganteus group) are in general very much larger insects with a larger cubital<tei:lb/>index, a longer 3r-m and stouter mandibles. This may well be a paraphyletic grade-group, as almost</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>160 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>certainly the characters defining it are plesiomorphic for the genus. The majority of species in this group<tei:lb/>occur in areas with a pronounced dry season , particularly parts of Africa and India. Some of the very largest<tei:lb/>species (reticulatus (Cameron), nigropictus (Matsumura) and giganteus Szepligeti) occur in montane<tei:lb/>forest, a very wet habitat. None of the species in the giganteus group occur east of Weber's line. In New<tei:lb/>Guinea they seem to have been replaced by some exceptionally large species of Enicospilus (E. enormous<tei:lb/>Gauld &amp; Mitchell species complex).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ENICOSPILUS Stephens</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Enicospilus Stephens, 1835: 126. Type-species: Ophion merdarius Gravenhorst sensu Stephens (=<tei:lb/>Ichneumon ramidulus L.), by subsequent monotypy, Stephens, 1845.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Henicospilus Agassiz, 1846: 138. [Unjustified emendation.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Allocamptus Foerster, 1869: 150. Type-species: Ophion undulatus Gravenhorst, by subsequent desig-<tei:lb/>nation, Thomson, 1888: 1189.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dispilus Kriechbaumer, 18946: 309. Type-species: Ophion (Dispilus) natalensis Kriechbaumer, by<tei:lb/>monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pleuroneurophion Ashmead, 1900: 86. Type-species: Pleuroneurophion hawaiiensis Ashmead, by original<tei:lb/>designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cymatoneura Kriechbaumer, 1901a: 22. Type-species: Ophion undulatus Gravenhorst, by subsequent<tei:lb/>designation, Viereck, 1914: 8.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pterospilus Kriechbaumer, 1901c: 156. Type-species: Ophion (Enicospilus) dubius Tosquinet, by subse-<tei:lb/>quent designation, Viereck, 1914: 126. [Junior homonym of Pterospilus Rondani, 1856.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trispilus Kriechbaumer, 1901c: 156. Type-species: Ophion (Enicospilus) trimaculatus Tosquinet (=<tei:lb/>Henicospilus seminiger Szepligeti), by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Metophion Szepligeti, 1905: 28. Type-species: Metophion bicolor Szepligeti, by subsequent designation,<tei:lb/>Viereck, 1914: 94.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ceratospilus Szepligeti, 1905: 28. Type-species: Ceratospilus biroi Szepligeti, by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Atoponeura Szepligeti, 1905: 34. Type-species: Atoponeura concolor Szepligeti (= Enicospilus ato-<tei:lb/>poneurus Cushman), by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ophiomorpha Szepligeti, 1905: 34. Type-species: Ophion curvinervis Cameron (= Enicospilus cameronii<tei:lb/>Dalla Torre), by subsequent designation, Hooker, 1912: 134. [Junior homonym of Ophiomorpha<tei:lb/>Nilsson, 1836.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cryptocamptus Brethes, 1909: 230. [Unnecessary replacement name for Allocamptus Foerster.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eremotyloides Perkins, 1915: 530. Type-species: Eremotyloides orbitalis Ashmead, by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Amesospilus Enderlein, 1918: 222. Type-species: Ophion unicallosus Snellen, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Schizospilus Seyrig, 1935: 79. Type-species: Schizospilus divisus Seyrig, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mandibles twisted from 10 to 90, weakly to very strongly narrowed, from equally bidentate to with upper<tei:lb/>tooth conspicuously the longer, rarely with lower tooth the longer; outer mandibular surface usually with a<tei:lb/>proximal concavity, the remainder either almost flat or with a diagonal hirsute groove. Maxillary palp<tei:lb/>5-segmented, labial palp 4-segmented; clypeus in profile from flat to nasute, with margin blunt or acute or<tei:lb/>acute and subapically impressed; clypeus in anterior aspect usually weakly convex, rarely truncate or<tei:lb/>joncave, in one Neotropical species with an indication of a median tooth. Ocelli usually large, generally<tei:lb/>with the posterior ones very close to or contiguous with the eyes, in a few species with the ocelli smaller;<tei:lb/>frontal carina absent; occipital carina usually complete, sometimes mediodorsally obsolescent or inter-<tei:lb/>rupted. Antennae usually more than 1-5 times as long as the fore wing. Pronotum usually unspecialized, in<tei:lb/>some Madagascan species with median transverse crests; spiracular sclerite almost always completely<tei:lb/>occluded by flange of pronotum; notauli vestigial or absent; epicnemial carina usually well developed,<tei:lb/>present on mesopleuron, usually reaching to level of lower corner of pronotum; mesopleural furrow<tei:lb/>usually absent. Scutellum from almost flat to strongly convex, almost always with strong lateral carinae<tei:lb/>virtually entire, rarely with these carinae short; posterior transverse carina of mesosternum usually<tei:lb/>complete. Propodeum with anterior area moderately long to long, generally striate; anterior transverse<tei:lb/>carina of propodeum usually present, almost always complete; posterior transverse carina usually absent,<tei:lb/>rarely present laterally; posterior area usually reticulate or rugose, sometimes finely irregularly wrinkled,<tei:lb/>in a few species concentrically striate, very rarely the posterior area almost smooth or punctate. Fore wing<tei:lb/>with pterostigma moderately broad to quite slender; marginal cell long; Rs+2r almost always broadened<tei:lb/>and variously sinuate before joining the pterostigma; discosubmarginal cell usually with a glabrous fenestra<tei:lb/>adjacent to the vein Rs+2r, this fenestra often bearing one or more detached sclerites; Im-cu usually<tei:lb/>arcuate or sinuous, rarely somewhat angulate; ramellus usually absent, rarely in one or two species<tei:lb/>well-developed. Hind wing with Rs straight or weakly bowed. Fore tibial spur without a membranous</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE 161</tei:p>
         <tei:p>flange behind macrotrichial comb; mid and hind trochantelli usually simple, rarely with a marginal tooth;<tei:lb/>inner hind tibial spur flattened, with margin of close long hairs; hind tarsal claws various, most usually<tei:lb/>unspecialized and slightly sexually dimorphic, sometimes extremely sexually dimorphic, the male having a<tei:lb/>very fine pectinal comb, in a few taxa with the claws strongly geniculate, occasionally with the claws<tei:lb/>asymmetrical, in other taxa with the distal pectina projecting beyond the apex of the true claw, and very<tei:lb/>rarely, in a few eremic species, with the pectina reduced. Gaster from moderately stout to very slender;<tei:lb/>tergite 2 usually very long and slender, rarely posteriorly almost as deep as long, almost always with<tei:lb/>thyridia remote from anterior margin; umbo vestigial or absent; epipleuron usually up- turned, pendant in a<tei:lb/>few (or one) Neotropical species. Ovipositor sheath slender; ovipositor usually short, straight, in isolated<tei:lb/>taxa it may be upcurved or decurved, and very rarely it may be straight but project well beyond the apex of<tei:lb/>the gaster.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Enicospilus is an extremely large genus, most species of which occur in the tropics. The major centres of<tei:lb/>radiation appear to be New Guinea, where there are about 200 endemic species, and Madagascar, which<tei:lb/>has about half that number. The Philippines, Hawaii and Zaire river basin are other areas of pronounced<tei:lb/>endemicity. In the tropics, the greatest diversity of species seems to occur at mid-elevation in the cloud<tei:lb/>forests (moss forests) between 1200 and 2000 m. A number of species are restricted to areas that have a<tei:lb/>pronounced dry season (e.g. Enicospilus capensis), and a few species seem to" inhabit deserts (e.g. E.<tei:lb/>psammus). Many species are capable of sustained flight over great distances (e.g. across the Tasman Sea<tei:lb/>from Australia to New Zealand) and several occur on almost all South Pacific archipelagos as far east as the<tei:lb/>Tuamotus. Most small oceanic islands apparently have several species of Enicospilus present, and on the<tei:lb/>Micronesian islands six of the 33 recorded ichneumonids are Enicospilus (Townes, 1958). Outside the<tei:lb/>tropics there are notably fewer species. Scaramozzino (1983) records only ten from Italy whilst Viktorov<tei:lb/>(1957) knew of only 15 species from the Soviet Union. Five nominal species are recorded from Britain, but<tei:lb/>probably only four species occur there (Fitton et al., 1978).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Certain generalized distribution patterns can be observed in the genus. New Guinea and Madagascar<tei:lb/>have large numbers of endemic species in endemic species-groups; for example eight of the 24 species-<tei:lb/>groups recognized as occurring in the Afrotropical region are restricted to Madagascar, and these eight<tei:lb/>groups contain 35 species (Gauld &amp; Mitchell, 1978). The Philippines, Hawaii and South America each<tei:lb/>contain very few species-groups, but these may be very large. Relatively few of the numerous other<tei:lb/>species-groups are endemic to a single zoogeographic area. Several of the species-groups that are<tei:lb/>widespread in South East Asia have their greatest diversity in New Guinea (e.g. the xanthocephalus and<tei:lb/>tremulus species-groups, Gauld &amp; Mitchell, 1981). Virtually no widespread South East Asian groups have<tei:lb/>a localized centre of diversity outside Melanesia; most species seem to be widespread with isolated local<tei:lb/>endemics (e.g. theflavicaput species-group, Gauld &amp; Mitchell, 1981). Many widespread South East Asiaa<tei:lb/>groups are also represented in mainland Africa (e.g. the capensis and antefurcalis species-groups). A<tei:lb/>number of species-groups are either endemic to mainland Africa (e.g. the babaultii, biimpressus and<tei:lb/>rubens species-groups) or are most diverse in Africa (e.g. the dolosus species-group). Most species<tei:lb/>occurring in the Palaearctic region belong to species-groups that are well-represented in the Nearctic<tei:lb/>region, but neither region appears to have any endemic species-groups, nor is any species-group endemic<tei:lb/>to the Holarctic region. The Enicospilus species of Australia are virtually all either widespread South East<tei:lb/>Asian species or are endemics derived from South East Asia (Gauld, 1984a). New Zealand has no endemic<tei:lb/>species, but shares two with Australia. A distinct faunal region is apparent which comprises part of the<tei:lb/>Mediterranean basin, most of the Middle East and extends eastwards into Central Asia and south-<tei:lb/>eastwards into north-west India. Although the fauna of this area is poorly known, it seems that at least one<tei:lb/>species-group may be endemic to the region (the przewalskii species-group).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gauld &amp; Mitchell (1978; 1981) outline a very large number of species-groups and several of these are<tei:lb/>refined by Gauld (1984a). Large numbers of other species are currently unplaced; these may belong to less<tei:lb/>clearly definable groups, or they may be aberrant members of existing groups, or they may represent<tei:lb/>numerous monobasic species-groups. The phylogenetic inter- relationships of most of these species-groups<tei:lb/>are very difficult to assess as most are definable on the basis of a number of autapomorphies. Few share<tei:lb/>obvious specializations with other species-groups.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Repeated attempts have been made to subdivide Enicospilus into a number of smaller genera<tei:lb/>(Kriechbaumer, 1901c; Szepligeti, 1905; Seyrig, 1935) but none of these subdivisions has endured, largely<tei:lb/>for two reasons - the authors proposing the separation have very limited experience of the range of<tei:lb/>morphological diversity afforded by the genus, and the characters used to effect separation are superficial<tei:lb/>differences, usually in the number of alar sclerites. The clearest demonstration of the great variability of<tei:lb/>alar sclerite form and number can be seen between the closely related species of the unidens species-group,<tei:lb/>a group definable by several autapomorphies. The proximal sclerite is present in all species but only E.<tei:lb/>unidens has a central sclerite; the distal sclerite is present in E. unidens, E. akainus and E. mirax but absent</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>162 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>in E. gonidius and E. amygdalis. The most important features for recognizing apparently 'natural'<tei:lb/>groupings seem to be the form of the tarsal claws (including the degree of sexual dimorphism), the structure<tei:lb/>of the mandibles and clypeus, the presence or absence of the proximal sclerite and the structure of the male<tei:lb/>genitalia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Little is known of the biology of species of Enicospilus. The majority of host records refer to species<tei:lb/>parasitizing larvae of Noctuidae, Geometridae, Lymantriidae or Saturniidae. A few species attack<tei:lb/>pyralids. Many of the larger species that attack saturniid larvae spin their cocoon within the host cocoon,<tei:lb/>but other species spin a cocoon that is not enclosed by that of the host. Most species seem to attack larvae<tei:lb/>that are free-living, tree-leaf-feeding caterpillars, but the few with longer ovipositors seem to attack larvae<tei:lb/>mining stems (e.g. E. terebrus). It must be stressed that the hosts of the majority of tropical species are not<tei:lb/>known.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PYCNOPHION Ashmead<tei:lb/>Pycnophion Ashmead, 1900: 87. Type-species: Pycnophion molokaiensis Ashmead, by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mandibles twisted about 20, evenly tapered, with upper tooth broader but of about equal length to the<tei:lb/>lower tooth; outer maridibular surface slightly concave, sparsely pubescent. Maxillary palp 5-segmented,<tei:lb/>labial palp 4-segmented; clypeus in profile moderately convex, margin blunt; clypeus in anterior aspect<tei:lb/>weakly convex. Ocelli moderately large, the posterior ones separated from the eye by about 0-5 times their<tei:lb/>own diameter; frontal carina very weak; occipital carina complete, mediodorsally with a depression.<tei:lb/>Antennae moderately long, about 1-3 times the length of the fore wing. Pronotum slightly flattened<tei:lb/>mediodorsally; spiracular sclerite covered by pronotal flange; notauli vestigial; epicnemial carina strong,<tei:lb/>curved to nearly reach the anterior margin of the pleuron above the level of the lower corner of the<tei:lb/>pronotum; mesopleural furrow absent. Scutellum convex, laterally carinate at least 0-6 of its length;<tei:lb/>posterior transverse carina of the mesosternum centrally obsolescent. Propodeum with anterior area<tei:lb/>moderately short but clearly discernible; anterior transverse carina complete, at least centrally, the<tei:lb/>posterior one vestigial, the other absent; posterior area finely coriaceous. Pterostigma moderately slender;<tei:lb/>marginal cell long; Rs+2r virtually straight, evenly but abruptly widened before joining pterostigma;<tei:lb/>discosubmarginal cell with an ill-defined glabrous area anteriorly, the entire cell very sparsely hirsute;<tei:lb/>Im-cu fairly evenly arcuate, ramellus absent. Hind wing with Rs straight. Fore tibial spur without a<tei:lb/>membranous flange behind macro trichial comb; mid and hind trochantelli unspecialized; inner hind tibial<tei:lb/>spur somewhat flattened, with a fringe of long hairs; tarsal claws unspecialized. Gaster moderately stout;<tei:lb/>tergite 2 in profile, slightly longer than posteriorly deep, with thyridia large, oval and close to anterior<tei:lb/>margin; umbo vestigial; epipleuron up-turned. Ovipositor exceptional in being very long and up-curved,<tei:lb/>reaching beyond apex of gaster by at least length of tergites 2-5.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pycnophion is a small genus containing three Hawaiian species (Townes etal., 1961). It is one of the most<tei:lb/>atypical of ophionine genera and females superficially resemble campoplegines or phygadeuontines. One<tei:lb/>species, P. fuscipennis Perkins, has been reared as fuparasite of the larvae of Hyposmocoma chilonella<tei:lb/>(Lepidoptera: Cosmopterygidae) (Swezey, 1931) which are borers in the pith of stems of Rubus, Acacia<tei:lb/>and a variety of other woody plants.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acknowledgements</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Much of this work was undertaken as part of a PhD thesis under the supervision of Dr Garth Underwood. I<tei:lb/>am extremely grateful for his advice at all stages of the study. I would like to thank Dr J. Felsenstein for<tei:lb/>providing a copy of his program PHYLIP, and the staff of the computing centre at the City of London<tei:lb/>Polytechnic for their assistance with computational problems. I am grateful to many of my colleagues at the<tei:lb/>British Museum (Natural History) for their opinions on various problems and comments on various drafts,<tei:lb/>though the conclusions expressed do not necessarily reflect their points of view; in particular I would like to<tei:lb/>thank Dr A. D. Austin, Mr B. Bolton, Mr M. C. Day, Dr M. G. Fitton, Dr J. D. Holloway, Dr L. A.<tei:lb/>Mound, Dr G. S. Robinson, Mr R. I. Vane- Wright and Dr P. Whalley. Zombori, and I am particularly grateful to all those entomologists, too numerous to<tei:lb/>mention, who have sent me ophionines from all over the world. Finally I would like to thank Mr J. Carter<tei:lb/>for taking the stereoscan pictures and Ms P. A. Mitchell for typing the manuscript.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE 173</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Appendix 3 Shared derived character matrix for the 51 selected ophionines.</tei:p>

      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>PHYLOGENY OF THE OPHIONINAE 175</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Appendix 4 Primary labels matrix derived from analysis of 5 1 selected ophionines . The figure in brackets<tei:lb/>to the immediate right of the taxon number indicates the number of times that taxon alone is responsible<tei:lb/>for the failure of a character in the LeQuesne test. Notably high values in any column suggest that a<tei:lb/>particular character state shared by the respective characters is likely to be the result of parallel<tei:lb/>development or reversal. For example, character 1-2 has high values for taxa 909 and 923; as both taxa<tei:lb/>share an apomorphic 1 state, the labels matrix suggests this condition has been independently derived in<tei:lb/>the two taxa, and thus should not be considered a synapomorphy uniting 909 + 923.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>iUNLABELLED TAXA: 912, 913, 933</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>

         <tei:pb/>

      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>An introduction to the Ichneumonidae of Australia</tei:p>
         <tei:p>/. D. Gauld</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the important field of biological and integrated control of pests the parasitic Hymenoptera<tei:lb/>are of particular significance, and this work considers one of the largest families of Parasitica,<tei:lb/>the Ichneumonidae. The group has received little attention in Australia - though it has already<tei:lb/>been utilized successfully in curtailing the ravages caused by accidentally introduced pests. For<tei:lb/>selective control programmes to be effective, however, a sound knowledge of the biology of<tei:lb/>both the pest and its parasites is essential - and a sound taxonomic base is vital for the<tei:lb/>development of such knowledge.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ironically, considering the group's economic importance, the parasitic Hymenoptera is<tei:lb/>amongst the least studied of any group of living organisms, and taxonomic difficulties have<tei:lb/>presented major problems to many entomologists working with the Parasitica. An<tei:lb/>Introduction to the Ichneumonidae of Australia will go a long way towards rectifying this<tei:lb/>situation, being a taxonomic treatment, by genus, of the Australian ichneumonids, a<tei:lb/>comprehensive illustrated identification guide, and a summary of all available information on<tei:lb/>the group. It will also serve as an introduction to the biology and distribution of Australian<tei:lb/>ichneumonids, and provide a check-list of the described species and an index to their known<tei:lb/>hosts. It provides an important revision of ichneumonid nomenclature in order to bring the<tei:lb/>group into line with the generally accepted principles of zoological nomenclature.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1984, 413pp, 3 maps, 580 figs. Paperback. 565 00896 X 40.00</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>Titles to be published in Volume 51</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The ichneumon-fly genus Banchus (Hymenoptera) in the Old World<tei:lb/>By M. G. Fitton</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The phylogeny, classification and evolution of parasitic wasps of the subfamily Ophioninae<tei:lb/>(Ichneumonidae)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>By I. D. Gauld</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A cladistic analysis and classification of trichodectid mammal lice (Phthiraptera: Ischnocera)<tei:lb/>By C. H. C. Lyal</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The British and some other European Eriococcidae (Homoptera: Coccoidea)<tei:lb/>By D. J. Williams</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Photoset by Rowland Phototypesetting Ltd, Bury St Edmunds, Suffolk<tei:lb/>Printed in Great Britain by Henry Ling Ltd, Dorchester</tei:p>
