      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>BRITISH MUSEUM<tei:lb/>NATURAL HISTORY)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bulletin of the 26AUGI987</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PRESENTED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A cladistic analysis and classification of<tei:lb/>trichodectid mammal lice<tei:lb/>(Phthiraptera: Ischnocera)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>C. H. C. Lyal</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Entomology series</tei:p>
         <tei:p>VolSl No 3 31 October 1985</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>The Bulletin of the British Museum (Natural History), instituted in 1949, is issued in four<tei:lb/>scientific series, Botany, Entomology, Geology (incorporating Mineralogy) and Zoology,<tei:lb/>and an Historical series.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Papers in the Bulletin are primarily the results of research carried out on the unique and<tei:lb/>ever-growing collections of the Museum, both by the scientific staff of the Museum and by<tei:lb/>specialists from elsewhere who make use of the Museum's resources. Many of the papers are<tei:lb/>works of reference that will remain indispensable for years to come.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Parts are published at irregular intervals as they become ready, each is complete in itself,<tei:lb/>available separately, and individually priced. Volumes contain about 300 pages and several<tei:lb/>volumes may appear within a calendar year. Subscriptions may be placed for one or more of<tei:lb/>the series on either an Annual or Per Volume basis. Prices vary according to the contents of<tei:lb/>the individual parts. Orders and enquiries should be sent to:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Publications Sales,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History),<tei:lb/>Cromwell Road,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>London SW75BD,<tei:lb/>England.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>World List abbreviation: Bull. Br. Mus. nat. Hist. (Ent.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trustees of the British Museum (Natural History), 1985</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Entomology series is produced under the general editorship of the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Keeper of Entomology: Laurence A. Mound</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Assistant Editor: W. Gerald Tremewan</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ISBN 565 06013 9</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ISSN 0524-6431 Entomology series</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vol 51 No 3 pp 187-346<tei:lb/>British Museum (Natural History)<tei:lb/>Cromwell Road<tei:lb/>London SW7 5BD Issued 31 October 1985</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>A cladistic analysis and classification of trichodectid<tei:lb/>mammal lice (Phthiraptera: Ischnocera)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2v<tei:lb/>C. H. C. Lyal</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Department of Entomology, British Museum (Natural History), Cromwell Road, London<tei:lb/>SW7 5BD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Contents</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synopsis 187</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction 187</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acknowledgements 188</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Method of systematic analysis 188</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Relationship of systematic analysis and classification 189</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Morphology 189</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Character survey 203</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Character analysis 213</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Identification of apomorphic states 213</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cladistic analysis 223</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Taxonomic history of Trichodectidae 234</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Proposed classification 241</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Descriptions of genera and subgenera 247</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bovicolinae Keler 247</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eutrichophilinae Keler 265</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dasyonyginae Keler 267</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trichodectinae Kellogg 286</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Neotrichodectinae subfam. n 321</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Keys to Trichodectidae 334</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to subfamilies 335</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to genera and subgenera 335</tei:p>
         <tei:p>References 340</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Index 344</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synopsis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Observations on phthirapteran morphology are analysed with particular reference to the Trichodectidae.<tei:lb/>Problems of structure, homology and nomenclature associated with major morphological features are<tei:lb/>briefly reviewed and solutions suggested where possible; where appropriate, the morphological terminolo-<tei:lb/>gy is clarified. A cladistic analysis of the 351 species and subspecies of Trichodectidae is carried out using<tei:lb/>the states of 187 characters, and the taxa are re-classified in accordance with the results and the principles of<tei:lb/>phyletic sequencing. Twenty genera are accepted in five subfamilies. Ten of the genera are divided into 27<tei:lb/>subgenera. This necessitates the description of one new subfamily, three new genera and four new<tei:lb/>subgenera. Three genera are newly synonymised, eight genera and subgenera are recalled from<tei:lb/>synonomy, and four genera are reduced to subgenera. The generic placements of 106 species and<tei:lb/>subspecies are changed. Keys to the subfamilies, genera and subgenera are provided, and the genera and<tei:lb/>subgenera are described.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Trichodectidae is a family of ischnoceran chewing lice parasitic on mammals. There are 351<tei:lb/>described species and subspecies grouped into between 13 and 39 genera, various workers<tei:lb/>having widely differing views on generic limits. The classification of the Trichodectidae at the<tei:lb/>generic level is perhaps more confused than that of any other group of lice (Hopkins, 1949, 1960;<tei:lb/>Emerson &amp; Price, 1981) and no workable keys to genera are available. The confusion and</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bull. Br. Mus. nat. Hist. (Ent.) 51 (3): 187-346 Issued 31 October 1985</tei:p>
         <tei:p/>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>188 C. H. C. LYAL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>disagreement surrounding the classification of the family persists despite a sound basis of<tei:lb/>taxonomic knowledge at the species level, derived largely from the works of Werneck (1948,<tei:lb/>1950), although this author did not attempt to produce any keys.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The purpose of this study is to present a classification of the species of Trichodectidae and to<tei:lb/>describe and provide a key to the recognised genera and subgenera. The foundation of the<tei:lb/>classification proposed below is a cladistic analysis, and for the purpose of determining character<tei:lb/>polarity in that analysis a suitable out-group had to be identified first. Ideally this out-group<tei:lb/>should be the sister-group of the taxon studied, and in this case would be expected to be a group<tei:lb/>in the same suborder, the Ischnocera. However, the holophyly of the Ischnocera has not been<tei:lb/>demonstrated (Lyal, 1985), although there is evidence that indicates the holophyly of a group<tei:lb/>comprising most of the Ischnocera (including the Trichodectidae). The classification of the<tei:lb/>Ischnocera is unsettled, and the sister-group of the Trichodectidae has not been identified. A<tei:lb/>single teneral male specimen of a possible sister-group has been seen, purportedly collected<tei:lb/>from a corvid in Austria. The specimen has the single tarsal claws of a mammal parasite, but no<tei:lb/>other apomorphies of the Trichodectidae, although it has the same general facies as members of<tei:lb/>the family. As out-group, therefore, the Ischnocera s.l. is used, reference being made where<tei:lb/>appropriate to the other three suborders of Phthiraptera (Lyal, 1985).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The term 'holophyletic' is used below to refer to groups of taxa comprising a single ancestral<tei:lb/>species (known or inferred) and all of its descendants. The more familiar term 'monophyletic' is<tei:lb/>avoided because ambiguities in its use have caused misunderstandings in the resolution of<tei:lb/>systematic problems.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scale lines equivalent to 50 /am are given in most figures.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This study formed part of the results of a research project submitted to the University of<tei:lb/>London for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acknowledgements</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I am very grateful to all those who have given advice and read parts of this paper whilst in preparation,<tei:lb/>particularly Dr R. G. Davies, University of London; Dr L. A. Mound, Dr T. Clay, Mr W. R. Dolling, Mr<tei:lb/>D. Hollis and Mrs J. M. Palmer, British Museum (Natural History); and Dr B. Heming, University of<tei:lb/>Alberta. I also thank the following people who were of great assistance during part of this study which was<tei:lb/>carried out in the United States: Dr K. C. Emerson, Florida; Dr K. C. Kim, Pennsylvania State University;<tei:lb/>Dr R. D. Price, University of Minnesota; Dr O. Flint, United States National Museum; Dr R. Traub and<tei:lb/>Miss H. Starke, University of Maryland School of Medicine; and Dr W. A. Drew and Dr D. Peters,<tei:lb/>Oklahoma State University.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Method of systematic analysis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Systematic analysis is carried out in order to determine 'relationships' between different taxa,<tei:lb/>the relationships discovered being employed to study some aspect of the biology or evolution of<tei:lb/>the taxa and/or to provide a framework for their classification. Taxa may be deemed to be<tei:lb/>'related' according to a number of different criteria, so the type of analysis performed is dictated<tei:lb/>by the requirements of other studies to be undertaken. In this case the systematic analysis is<tei:lb/>preliminary to an examination of the phylogenetic linkages between Trichodectidae and their<tei:lb/>hosts (Lyal, in prep. , a). The relationships required from the analysis are therefore phylogenetic<tei:lb/>in nature. Although it has been suggested that phylogenetic relationships can be determined by<tei:lb/>phenetic analysis (Sneath &amp; Sokal, 1973), this is generally believed not to be the case, and a<tei:lb/>phyletic analysis is required (Wiley, 1981). In this study a manual cladistic analysis was deemed<tei:lb/>most suitable as computerized methods of sufficient power and capacity were unavailable when<tei:lb/>the study was initiated (Lyal, 1983).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The first stage in the analysis was a character survey of all species of the family, with the aim of<tei:lb/>discovering suitable apomorphies. As analysis proceeded some characters initially selected were<tei:lb/>rejected, if the polarity of their states could not be determined, or if their apomorphic states<tei:lb/>were restricted to single species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The observations were recorded in a data matrix, but it rapidly became apparent that this</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTID MAMMAL LICE 189</tei:p>
         <tei:p>matrix was too large to be manipulated conveniently. Preliminary inspection of the taxa had led<tei:lb/>to the recognition of sufficient apomorphies to divide the family into five or six plausible<tei:lb/>holophyletic groups, so secondary data matrices were compiled for each of these. The smaller<tei:lb/>number of species and apomorphies then necessary on each of these matrices enabled manual<tei:lb/>analysis to proceed. These matrices were inclusive rather than exclusive, and taxa with low<tei:lb/>probabilities of membership were included; as a consequence some taxa were included in more<tei:lb/>than one matrix. The matrices were examined and taxa or holophyletic groups sharing the<tei:lb/>greatest number of synapomorphies were united as sister-groups. This process was continued<tei:lb/>until the cladistic relationships within each matrix were resolved as fully as possible. The full<tei:lb/>matrix was then compiled using the largest holophyletic groups identified in the analysis of the<tei:lb/>secondary matrices. This matrix was then analysed using the same technique and the full<tei:lb/>cladogram drawn. The cladogram, which gave the full distribution of apomorphies, was<tei:lb/>examined to ensure that the most parsimonious distribution of apomorphies had been achieved.<tei:lb/>Character states were weighted by a simple 'gain' or 'loss' criterion. 'Loss' states were only<tei:lb/>used in the analysis where 'gain' states were not available, and after 'gain' states had been used to<tei:lb/>resolve the cladogram as fully as possible. It follows that, whereas the distribution of 'gain' states<tei:lb/>should be maximally parsimonious over the cladogram, this is unlikely to be the case for 'loss'<tei:lb/>states.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Relationship of systematic analysis and classification</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Biological classifications afe designed not only to enable the taxa classified to be located in the<tei:lb/>literature and in collections, but also to store information about those taxa. In many cases the<tei:lb/>nature of this information is not clear from the classification, and taxa are grouped together on<tei:lb/>the basis of some ill-defined combination of phenetic and phyletic relationships. The type of<tei:lb/>information stored in the classification (i.e. the type of relationship used in its construction)<tei:lb/>may, however, be indicated precisely, and the classification used as an efficient data-retrieval<tei:lb/>system. This can only be done by utilisation of cladistic information alone; attempts to<tei:lb/>incorporate phenetic or anagenetic information lower the retrieval facility (Cracraft, 1974).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The method whereby the classification was constructed from the results of the cladistic<tei:lb/>analysis in this study was by using both rank and sequence in which taxa of equal rank are listed<tei:lb/>(G. Nelson, 1972, 1974; Cracraft, 1974; Wiley, 1979, 1981). This process has been termed<tei:lb/>phyletic sequencing (Cracraft, 1974). The convention employed is that within a classification<tei:lb/>holophyletic taxa of equal rank are listed ('sequenced') so that each taxon is the sister-group of<tei:lb/>all those taxa of the same rank (and within the same taxon of immediately higher rank) listed<tei:lb/>below it in the classification (modified from Cracraft, 1974). Use of this criterion allows recovery<tei:lb/>of a dichotomously-branching cladogram from the classification. However, holophyletic groups<tei:lb/>with a trichotomous or polychotomous interrelationship must also be accommodated. Wiley<tei:lb/>(1979) recommends that these be placed in the classification with equal rank and be noted as<tei:lb/>'sedis mutabilis' to indicate that their order is unknown or interchangeable. It must be<tei:lb/>remembered that this convention is for a formal classification, not for regular use in discussion.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>All hierarchical groups may be sequenced, but it is probably more efficient to employ informal<tei:lb/>groups below the subgenus level, especially with larger genera.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Morphology</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The discussion below is intended to clarify morphological terms used in this study, to point out<tei:lb/>structures of taxonomic or systematic interest, and to describe briefly the morphology of the<tei:lb/>insects.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figures 1 and 2 depict the dorsal and ventral aspects of a generalised trichodectid head with the<tei:lb/>regions and major features labelled with the terms used in this study.<tei:lb/>The internal carinae of the head are strongly developed in many species, and differences in the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>190</tei:p>
         <tei:p>C. H. C. LYAL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>dorsal preantennal<tei:lb/>sulcus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>median broadening of<tei:lb/>clypeal marginal carina</tei:p>
         <tei:p>clypeo-f rental sulcus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>pulvinus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>clypeal marginal carina</tei:p>
         <tei:p>? frontal sulcus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>f lagellum</tei:p>
         <tei:p>eye</tei:p>
         <tei:p>occipital ring</tei:p>
         <tei:p>osculum</tei:p>
         <tei:p>clypeus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>clypeus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>sub-genal area</tei:p>
         <tei:p>genal area</tei:p>
         <tei:p>temple</tei:p>
         <tei:p>f rons</tei:p>
         <tei:p>gula</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 1, 2 Terminology applied to trichodectid head, modified slightly from Symmons (1952). Mandible,<tei:lb/>maxilla, hypopharynx and labium omitted. 1, structures of head ($); 2, regions of head ($).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>degree of sclerotisation and position are useful taxonomically, particularly at the species level.<tei:lb/>The postoccipital sulcus is marked by a greatly-developed internal carina ('occipital ring')<tei:lb/>projecting posteriorly into the thorax; this structure is present in many other lice, but rarely so<tei:lb/>well developed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The postero-lateral margins of the head ('temple margins') are more or less rounded and may<tei:lb/>be produced at the postero-lateral angles in some species. The lengths of the setae on the<tei:lb/>postero-lateral angles may provide characters of taxonomic value. The eyes are positioned<tei:lb/>adjacent to the antennae or more posteriorly; in some species (e.g. those in the genus<tei:lb/>Cebidicold) the eyes occupy lateral projections.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Anterior to the antennal socket the margin of the head is produced into a variable sclerotised<tei:lb/>conus (Fig. 1), but the trabecula (Clay, 1946) is absent. A sclerotised conical projection from the<tei:lb/>dorsal nodus of the clypeo-frontal sulcus may be present projecting parallel to the margin of the<tei:lb/>antennal socket. This projection is frequently present in only one sex of a species.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTID MAMMAL LICE 191</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The anterior margin of the head may, in plan, form an unbroken arc ('circumfasciate head'),<tei:lb/>but in most Trichodectidae it is interrupted medially by the pulvinus or the osculum (Symmons,<tei:lb/>1952). The pulvinus is a thick bilobed pad of unsclerotised tissue developed from the clypeo-<tei:lb/>labral suture, and is found in all Ischnocera (Fig. 1). The osculum is a median indentation of the<tei:lb/>anterior margin of the head (Fig. 2). When the insect is at rest the pulvinus and osculum have<tei:lb/>been observed to be applied to the hair of the host (see discussion of mandibular morphology<tei:lb/>below). The width of the osculum is therefore probably influenced by the diameter of the hair in<tei:lb/>the region of the host's body inhabited by the louse. In cases where the pulvinus fails to reach the<tei:lb/>anterior margin of the head a small ventral sulcus ('ventral preantennal sulcus' of Clay, 1951)<tei:lb/>may connect it to the margin or osculum. Many species have a small dorsal preantennal sulcus<tei:lb/>(Clay, 1951) also interrupting the anterior margin medially.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Between the antennae and the osculum the margin of the head may, in plan, be shallowly or<tei:lb/>broadly convex, sinuate or straight (Figs 3-6); sclerotisation along the margin (forming the<tei:lb/>'clypeal marginal carina') may be minimal or heavy, but is usually pronounced in the median<tei:lb/>dorsal region (Fig. 1). Much of the variation is possibly influenced by the density and texture of<tei:lb/>the hair of the host.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Only two structures of the mouthparts need be mentioned, the mandibles and the cibarial<tei:lb/>sclerite.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The mandibles of Trichodectidae, like those of many other Amblycera and Ischnocera, are<tei:lb/>asymmetric. There are three apical teeth on the right mandible and two on the left; on the right<tei:lb/>the centre tooth is generally longest, whilst on the left the posterior tooth is normally the better<tei:lb/>developed (Figs 7-10). Mandibular asymmetry is considered by Snodgrass (1935) to be a feature<tei:lb/>of insects that masticate their food, and the lack of asymmetry in the mandibles of some species<tei:lb/>oiRidnus (Amblycera) is associated by B. Nelson (1972) with blood-feeding in those species.<tei:lb/>Trichodectes canis, the only trichodectid known to take blood meals (Bouvier, 1945), has<tei:lb/>dimorphic mandibles, as do all other Trichodectidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In addition to the collection and preparation of food the mandibles of Trichodectidae are<tei:lb/>employed in anchoring the insect. When at rest, Trichodectes canis and T. metis have been<tei:lb/>observed to enclose a hair in the pulvinus with the mandibles and whilst in this position may<tei:lb/>completely release the grip of the tarsal claws and straighten the legs laterally from the body.<tei:lb/>The insect is then held on only by the mandibles. In addition to the species above, specimens of<tei:lb/>Felicola sp. collected from dried museum skins have been found in this position, and specimens<tei:lb/>of most genera have been found preserved in alcohol clinging to single hairs by their mandibles<tei:lb/>alone. The selective pressures on the mandibles of Trichodectidae are different, therefore, from<tei:lb/>those operating on lice that do not have a mandibular anchoring mechanism, and possibly<tei:lb/>precludes the assumption of monomorphy in blood-feeding species. The 'interior' face of the<tei:lb/>right or of both mandibles may be ridged, so that when the mandibles are folded closed, the<tei:lb/>ridges on one mandible are not covered by the other, and all or most of the exposed mandibular<tei:lb/>area is ridged. The ridges are therefore not positioned in such a way that they can act against one<tei:lb/>another, and it is suggested that they are developed to prevent the mandibles slipping on a hair<tei:lb/>when clasping it (Figs 8-10). When the mandibles are closed, the right is always interior to the<tei:lb/>left, which may have a concavity to receive it (Figs 7, 9, 10); the left mandible is not then kept by<tei:lb/>the right from contact with the hair, and the greatest possible mandibular area is utilised. In<tei:lb/>some species the right mandible has a basal notch on the anterior margin, which receives the tip<tei:lb/>of the left mandible (Figs 7, 10); this feature may act in concert with the restraint of the right<tei:lb/>mandible to 'lock' the mandibles closed about a hair. Although, as said above, none of the<tei:lb/>Trichodectidae have monomorphic mandibles, the mandibles of Damalinia (T.) conectens (Fig.<tei:lb/>7) are very slender and pointed, and the centre tooth of the right mandible of Dasyonyx spp. and<tei:lb/>Eurytrichodectes spp. (Fig. 9) is long and pointed, suggesting in each case a piercing function and<tei:lb/>thus possible haemophagy . In contrast, the mandibles of Damalinia (T.) indica (Fig. 8) are blunt<tei:lb/>and broad, suggesting an adaptation to grinding and chewing.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The sitophore sclerite (Figs 11, 12) varies considerably in the Psocodea (Cummings, 1913;<tei:lb/>Haub, 1967, 1972, 1973, 1977). The form of the sclerite, particularly of its posterior border, is<tei:lb/>obscured in slide-mounted specimens, and differential inclination of the specimens may change</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>192</tei:p>
         <tei:p>C. H. C. LYAL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 3-10 Variation in trichodectid head and mouthpart structure. 3-6, $ head, dorsal aspect, of (3)<tei:lb/>Bovicola caprae; (4) Damalinia lineata; (5) Felicola subrostratus; (6) Trichodectes zorillae. 7-10,<tei:lb/>mandibles, dorsal aspect, of (7) Damalinia conectens; (8) Damalinia indica; (9) Eurytrichodectes<tei:lb/>paradoxus, showing mandibles interlocking; (10) Trichodectes canis, with detail of postero-dorsal<tei:lb/>margin of left mandible.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTID MAMMAL LICE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>193</tei:p>
         <tei:p>14</tei:p>
         <tei:p>13</tei:p>
         <tei:p>12</tei:p>
         <tei:p>11</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 11-16 Trichodectid morphology. 1 1 , Damalinia neotheileri, sitophore sclerite. 12, Bovicola hemitra-<tei:lb/>gi, sitophore sclerite. 13, Damalinia indica, right antenna of d", dorsal, arrow indicating prolongation of<tei:lb/>antero-ventral pedicel margin. 14-16, lateral aspect of metatarsal claws of (14) Dasyonyx (D.)<tei:lb/>smallwoodae; (15) Dasyonyx (N.) diacanthus; (16) Eurytrichodectesparadoxus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>the apparent dimensions (Haub, 1977). Trichodectidae differ from other Psocodea in having an<tei:lb/>open posterior border to the sclerite, a character state identified by Haub (1973) as plesiomor-<tei:lb/>phic, but which is almost certainly apomorphic. Within the family the sclerite is present in all<tei:lb/>species and the form is fairly constant (Fig. 11), although in two species groups the posterior<tei:lb/>arms are extended laterally (Fig. 12) and the sclerite is difficult to see. The minor variation in the<tei:lb/>form of the sclerite at the species level is so far unexploited in taxonomic study.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The sitophore sclerite is cup-shaped, and is opposed on the dorsal surface of the sitophore by a<tei:lb/>closely-fitting projection, the epipharyngeal crest. These two structures have been identified as a<tei:lb/>'mortar and pestle' for grinding food (Weber, 1936) and as components of a salivary pump</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>194 C. H. C. LYAL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Buckup, 1959; Keler, 1966). Rudolph (19820, 19826, 1983) demonstrates that it is a pump,<tei:lb/>sucking water absorbed from the atmosphere onto the lingual sclerites through the Y-shaped<tei:lb/>duct linking these and the sitophore sclerite.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The antennae are made up of a scape, pedicel and flagellum. In common with other<tei:lb/>Thysanura-Pterygota the pedicel and flagellum are annulations formed by subdivision of a single<tei:lb/>segment (Imms, 1939; Matsuda, 1965). Consequently, the only intrinsic muscles of the antennae<tei:lb/>are in the scape and insert on the pedicel, moving the pedicel and flagellum as a unit; the scape<tei:lb/>itself is moved by muscles inserted on its basal margin and arising on the anterior arms of the<tei:lb/>tentorium. The positions of the muscle insertions on the scape and pedicel are such that the an-<tei:lb/>tenna can be moved through 360 degrees, but there is no muscular mechanism for flexing the<tei:lb/>flagellum. Whilst the prime function of the antenna is sensory, secondary modification in the<tei:lb/>male has taken place in some Ischnocera (including almost all Trichodectidae) and some<tei:lb/>Anoplura, the antennae being used to clasp the female round the abdomen during copulation<tei:lb/>(Keler, 19380; Sikora &amp; Eichler, 1941; Lyal, in prep., b). This development has led to an<tei:lb/>increase in length and degree of sclerotisation of the pedicel and flagellomeres and an increase in<tei:lb/>strength of the antennal muscles. The intrinsic muscles of the scape are enlarged and the scape<tei:lb/>expanded; the extrinsic muscles are also enlarged and the head concomitantly broader in the<tei:lb/>male than in the female. To facilitate free movement of the flagellum the joint between the scape<tei:lb/>and the pedicel is broad and membranous (other than at the two articulatory points). However,<tei:lb/>because there is no direct muscular control of the flagellum, the degree of free movement<tei:lb/>relative to the pedicel must be limited, so that control may be effected by the intrinsic muscles of<tei:lb/>the scape. Observations made in this study reveal that the apex of the pedicel is angled relative to<tei:lb/>the long axis of the annulation, the longest margin of the pedicel being the antero-ventral (Fig.<tei:lb/>13). There is very little membrane between the pedicel and the flagellum on the antero-ventral<tei:lb/>margin, but more on the postero-dorsal, so some flexibility between the pedicel and flagellum is<tei:lb/>possible, although limited in the anterior direction by the prolongation of the pedicel. During<tei:lb/>copulation the male clasps the female around the top of the abdomen from underneath<tei:lb/>(Werneck, 1936; Sikora &amp; Eichler, 1941), the pedicel and flagellum being curved to match the<tei:lb/>curvature of the abdomen. The antennae are raised above the head of the male and the intrinsic<tei:lb/>adductor muscles contracted. The pedicel and flagellum are thus brought down over the<tei:lb/>abdomen of the female, the flagellum being constrained by the form of its junction with the<tei:lb/>pedicel. The form of the pedicel-flagellum joint is such that, should the haemolymph pressure be<tei:lb/>reduced, the joint membrane would collapse and further contract the flagellum against the<tei:lb/>female. However, lice are not known to have control over haemolymph pressure in their<tei:lb/>antennae, although larvae of Lepidoptera are known to control their antennal movement<tei:lb/>partially by this means (Matsuda, 1965). The mechanical strength and degree of possible control<tei:lb/>of a system involving joints as described above is likely to be inversely proportional to the<tei:lb/>number of joints in succession, with a single joint being the most efficient. The degree of<tei:lb/>curvature attainable using three segments is sufficient to grasp the female. For these reasons<tei:lb/>only the first flagellomere is required to take on a clasping function; the apical two flagellomeres<tei:lb/>may be retained in a sensory capacity (most Ischnocera) or lost (Trichodectidae). In<tei:lb/>Trichodectidae the last two flagellomeres have contracted and fused to the first flagellomere in<tei:lb/>all males (although a small semicircular sclerotisation, probably representing the apical flagello-<tei:lb/>mere, is present in the male of Eurytrichodectes paradoxus) and in females of the Neo-<tei:lb/>trichodectinae, Trichodectinae, Bovicolinae and most Eutrichophilinae. The sensilla of the two<tei:lb/>apical flagellomeres are retained on the remaining flagellomere.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The firmness with which the female is held may be increased by projections in the form of<tei:lb/>spikes or denticles on the antennae, particularly on the flagellum. Trichodectidae are character-<tei:lb/>ised by the possession of two modified setae apically on the male flagellum, which take the form<tei:lb/>of sharp, stout teeth (Fig. 13).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trichodectidae have two sensilla coeloconica and three sensilla placodea on the terminal<tei:lb/>flagellomere, sometimes closely associated (Clay, 1970; Kim &amp; Ludwig, 1978). In Lorisicola<tei:lb/>malaysianus and L. mjoebergi the sensilla are in pits with tongue-like projections around them.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTID MAMMAL LICE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>195</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thorax</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figures 17 and 18 depict a generalised trichodectid thorax, labelled with the terms used in this<tei:lb/>study. In all Trichodectidae the rhombic sclerite anterior to the pronotum is present; the<tei:lb/>pronotum itself generally bears two lateral sclerites, sometimes narrowly joined medially. The<tei:lb/>mesonotum and metanotum are fused, with prominent pleural ridges extending onto them;<tei:lb/>there may, as with the pronotum, be a medial zone of desclerotisation. Contrary to the assertion<tei:lb/>of Mayer (1954), the lateral cervical sclerite is always present and bears two anterior setae. The<tei:lb/>pronotum is fused to the propleuron, which in turn is fused to the prosternum. The prosternum<tei:lb/>may extend anteriorly between the fore-coxae and be unsclerotised medially. The mesosternite,<tei:lb/>fused to the prosternite, may also be medially divided. The mesepisternum is difficult to delimit,<tei:lb/>but rarely extends unbroken between the metasternite and the metanotum. The metasternite, if<tei:lb/>present, is only rarely fused to the mesosternite, and is never sclerotised medially. Posterior to</tei:p>
         <tei:p>rhombic sclerite</tei:p>
         <tei:p>prothorax</tei:p>
         <tei:p>pterothorax</tei:p>
         <tei:p>abdominal<tei:lb/>pleurum I</tei:p>
         <tei:p>prosternum</tei:p>
         <tei:p>lateral cervical<tei:lb/>sclerite</tei:p>
         <tei:p>mesothoracic<tei:lb/>spiracle</tei:p>
         <tei:p>profurcal pit</tei:p>
         <tei:p>mesofurcal pit</tei:p>
         <tei:p>mesosternum<tei:lb/>metasternum</tei:p>
         <tei:p>postcoxale</tei:p>
         <tei:p>met epimeron</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 17, 18 Diagrammatic representations of generalised trichodectid thorax, with terms used in this<tei:lb/>study. 17, dorsal. 18, ventral.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>196 C. H. C. LYAL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>the metacoxa may be a semicircular sclerite ('postcoxale' of Matsuda, 1970). In Procavicola<tei:lb/>(Meganarionoides) this is very heavily sclerotised and fused to abdominal pleurum II; the two<tei:lb/>postcoxales may also fuse medially.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>One, two or three setae are always present medially on the anterior margin of the thorax<tei:lb/>posterior to the temple margin of the head. The lateral margins of the thorax also bear setae,<tei:lb/>which may be more or less abundant. A row of setae is generally present across the posterior<tei:lb/>dorsal margin of the prothorax and pterothorax, sometimes interrupted medially ('median<tei:lb/>gap'). Setae are sometimes present on the dorsal disc of the prothorax and pterothorax<tei:lb/>('anterior setae'), and medially on the mesosternum.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The legs of Trichodectidae, in common with those of most other mammal lice, terminate in a<tei:lb/>single tarsal claw. In most species this claw is smooth ventrally, but it is toothed ventrally in<tei:lb/>Dasyonyx (Figs 14, 15) and ridged in Eurytrichodectes (Fig. 16). In many species a small hyaline<tei:lb/>projection, which may be pointed or blunt (Figs 14, 15), is present at the base of the claw. Mayer<tei:lb/>(1954), in her study of Bovicola caprae, terms this structure a 'pulvillus' but, as a true pulvillus is<tei:lb/>generally paired (Richards &amp; Davies, 1977; Chapman, 1982), this term is inappropriate. The<tei:lb/>projection is more probably an empodium or arolium, or even a simple basal tooth of no wider<tei:lb/>homology. Kim &amp; Ludwig (1978, 1982) maintain that the pulvillus and empodium do not occur<tei:lb/>in the Phthiraptera, but Clay (1969) demonstrates the presence of an empodium in Menoponi-<tei:lb/>dae (Amblycera), and Clay (1970) figures structures in Boopia (Amblycera) that almost<tei:lb/>certainly are pulvilli, although she follows Keler (no reference given) in terming them euplantu-<tei:lb/>lae (plantulae) of the second tarsomere.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdomen</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In this study the 'true' segment number is referred to by roman numerals to distinguish it from<tei:lb/>the apparent number. The terms 'sternite', 'pleurite' and 'tergite' are used for the sclerites of the<tei:lb/>sternum, pleurum and tergum respectively of each segment.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Segment I is represented in Trichodectidae by the reduced tergum I only. In this respect the<tei:lb/>family is similar to the Trichophilopteridae, but differs from all other Ischnocera, in which<tei:lb/>segment I is absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Segments III-VIII bear the spiracles, if these are present; spiracles are never present on<tei:lb/>segments I and II. Within the Trichodectidae many species have fewer than the plesiomorphic<tei:lb/>number of six pairs of abdominal spiracles (Table 1). Loss has apparently taken place<tei:lb/>sequentially from the posterior, so that if any spiracles are present one pair is on segment III, and<tei:lb/>if more than one pair is present there are no intercalating segments which lack spiracles between<tei:lb/>those segments with spiracles. There is, however, no evidence that spiracles have necessarily<tei:lb/>been lost one pair at a time. Whilst in Procaviphilus (Meganarionoides) angolensis, P. (M.)<tei:lb/>colobi and P. (M.) baculatus the posterior pair of spiracles only is very small and apparently in<tei:lb/>process of being lost, in Lorisicola (L.) hercynianus and L. (L.) siamensis the posterior two pairs<tei:lb/>are extremely small, probably non-functional, and apparently in process of being lost. In a<tei:lb/>number of clades, sister-groups exhibit multiple discontinuities in spiracle number. The<tei:lb/>sister-species Lorisicola (L.) mjoebergi and L. (L.) malaysianus have six and zero pairs<tei:lb/>respectively; Felicola viverriculae and an undescribed sister-species have three and zero pairs<tei:lb/>respectively; the Lorisicola (P.) lenicornis - wernecki clade and the sister L. (P.) acuticeps -<tei:lb/>neoafricanus clade have four and zero pairs respectively. Variation within species can occur,<tei:lb/>although it is generally erratic. Felicola subrostratus normally has three pairs of abdominal<tei:lb/>spiracles; the species is widespread and found on many hosts, but on Madagascar, where the host<tei:lb/>is Eupleres goudoti, there may be three or two pairs, and specimens exhibiting asymmetry are<tei:lb/>present in the British Museum (Natural History) collection. Asymmetry has also been noted in<tei:lb/>Trichodectes emeryi, one paratype of which has six spiracles on one side of the abdomen and five<tei:lb/>on the other. Trichodectes (S.) potus is unusual in that the female has three pairs of abdominal<tei:lb/>spiracles and the male only two, the only known example in the lice of sexual dimorphism in<tei:lb/>spiracle number.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Most Trichodectidae have either six, three or no pairs of abdominal spiracles, other numbers</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTID MAMMAL LICE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>197</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 1 Distribution of number of pairs of abdominal spiracles in the Trichodectidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>being less common (Table 1). From the cladogram, reduction to five, four and one pair can be<tei:lb/>seen to have occurred once, reduction to two and three pairs twice, and reduction to none eight<tei:lb/>times. The loss of abdominal spiracles plainly cannot be used a priori as a taxonomic character<tei:lb/>defining (holophyletic) genera, as proposed by Ewing (1936), but neither is it as variable as<tei:lb/>suggested by Keler (1938) and Hopkins (1941), who treat it as a character of specific value only.<tei:lb/>The selective advantage of this reduction is not known, but it may be an adaptation to exclude<tei:lb/>dust from the tracheal system, or to reduce water loss.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A posterior commissure joining the two main abdominal tracheal trunks is present in<tei:lb/>Anoplura, Rhyncophthirina, Boopiidae and Trimenoponidae (Amblycera), Philopteridae<tei:lb/>(Ischnocera) and 'some Trichodectidae' (Harrison, 1915; Ferris, 1931). All species of<tei:lb/>Trichodectidae examined in this study possess a posterior commissure, which is consequently<tei:lb/>assumed to have a universal distribution throughout the family. The presence of the posterior<tei:lb/>commissure is assumed to be plesiomorphic for the Phthiraptera (Clay, 1970).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In all lice segment IX is the genital segment, and the male genitalia open to its posterior and<tei:lb/>the female genitalia to its anterior. Modifications of this segment are discussed in detail below.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In both sexes of Trichodectidae segments X and XI are fused. In females segment XI lies<tei:lb/>caudally, posterior to X, but in males the modifications of segment IX have led to the<tei:lb/>displacement of both X and XI onto the dorsal surface of the abdomen. Most male Trichodecti-<tei:lb/>dae have the genital opening posterior or postero-dorsal. The postgenital segments are reduced<tei:lb/>to form a small anal cone arising from the dorsal (anterior) wall of the genital chamber (Keler,<tei:lb/>1957) (Fig. 19).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Conical projections are present either dorsoposteriorly or ventroposteriorly on the first three</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>198</tei:p>
         <tei:p>C. H. C. LYAL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>tVllp</tei:p>
         <tei:p>sVII</tei:p>
         <tei:p>tergum VII</tei:p>
         <tei:p>tVllla</tei:p>
         <tei:p>sternum VII</tei:p>
         <tei:p>tergum VIII</tei:p>
         <tei:p>tVlllp</tei:p>
         <tei:p>gc</tei:p>
         <tei:p>segment IX<tei:lb/>p-gs'</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 19 Diagrammatic representation of terminal segments of trichodectid male abdomen, with terms<tei:lb/>used in this study, t - tergite; s - sternite; p - pleurite; ac - anal cone; gc - genital chamber; p-gs -<tei:lb/>post-genital sclerite; sgpr- lateral rods of subgenital plate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>pleura (II, III and IV) in many Trichodectidae. The distribution of the pleural projections is<tei:lb/>summarised in Table 2.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male Trichodectidae, alone among Phthiraptera, possess 'lateral abdominal flecks', first<tei:lb/>noted in Werneckiella by Moreby (1978). The flecks are small pits positioned on the antero-<tei:lb/>dorsal angles of pleura III-VII, occasionally on II and VIII, and anterolaterally on terga III-V in<tei:lb/>many species (Fig. 218). In Werneckiella there are small sclerites situated anteriorly and<tei:lb/>posteriorly of the pit; in Trichodectes canis there are no sclerites bordering the pit but a small<tei:lb/>sclerite is present at its base; in Neotrichodectes there are no sclerites associated with the pit at<tei:lb/>all. The function of these structures is unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In some species of Phthiraptera terga II and/or III of the males are ornamented with large<tei:lb/>setae or projections. Such developments are numerous in the Trichodectidae. Many species of<tei:lb/>Felicola have a pair of long setae medially on male tergum II (Figs 180, 187, 188), whilst<tei:lb/>Geomydoecus (Thomomydoecus) spp., Trichodectes ovalis, T. ugandensis and an undescribed<tei:lb/>subspecies of T. galictidis have paired 'combs' of long setae on male terga II and III (Fig. 161),<tei:lb/>and Bovicola multispinosa and B. hemitragi have paired semicircular 'brushes' of setae on male<tei:lb/>tergum II (Fig. 41). Damalinia ornata has sclerotised blunt projections on male terga II and III.<tei:lb/>These specialised setae and projections may in some way assist the male to hold the female<tei:lb/>during copulation, although in no case have the setae or projections been observed to be<tei:lb/>damaged, as they might be expected to be should they operate against the female abdomen, and<tei:lb/>there is no observational evidence to support the hypothesis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Males of Neotrichodectes species have a pair of small median setae on terga II-VII , sometimes<tei:lb/>separated by a seta of normal length (Fig. 229). This feature, not found in females or males of<tei:lb/>any other group, is of unknown function.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female genitalia</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The female subgenital plate of Trichodectidae comprises either sternite VIII or sternites VIII<tei:lb/>and VII fused. The posterior margin of sternum VIII forms the ventral margin of the vulva. In<tei:lb/>many species the margin is expanded posteriad and slightly laterad (Fig. 94), and in others the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTID MAMMAL LICE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>199</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 2 Distribution of abdominal pleural projections in the Trichodectidae. For pleura II, III and IV an<tei:lb/>indication is given whether a dorsal ('D') or ventral ('V') projection is present, and whether those<tei:lb/>projections are sclerotised ('S'). In each case the presence state is indicated by ' + '. Very light<tei:lb/>sclerotisations are indicated by '?'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>centre of the margin is greatly expanded into a flat lobe termed the 'subgenital lobe' (Figs 149,<tei:lb/>153, 175). The subgenital lobe appears to have evolved at least three times in the Trichodecti-<tei:lb/>dae, and its form is of taxonomic and systematic value. Its function, however, is not known.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>To each side of the vulva is a projection from sternum VIII, the gonapophysis of segment VIII<tei:lb/>(Lyal, in prep., b). The structure of this is variable. In all cases a basal internal apophysis is<tei:lb/>produced, presumably as a muscle attachment (Keler, 1938a). The gonapophysis lies longitudi-<tei:lb/>nally, parallel to the abdomen; it may curve onto the dorsal surface apically. It may be long,<tei:lb/>slender and apically acute (Fig. 235), long and apically rectangular (Fig. 154), broad and<tei:lb/>membranous (Fig. 243), produced into a rounded, toothed or rectangular medial lobe with an<tei:lb/>apical 'spur' (Figs 175, 233, 236), with the spur reduced (Fig. 237) or absent (Fig. 211),<tei:lb/>sometimes with serrations laterally (Fig. 211). Setae may be present on the gonapophyses and<tei:lb/>the ventral vulval margin in various configurations, occasionally arising from sclerotised<tei:lb/>tubercles. In some cases a sclerotised band links the gonapophyses and the vulval margin, but in<tei:lb/>most cases this is not present and the connection is membranous.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The curvature of the gonapophyses about both longitudinal and lateral axes produces a<tei:lb/>complex three-dimensional structure difficult to interpret on slide-mounted specimens. The<tei:lb/>orientation of the gonapophysis may be altered by pressure of the coverslip during mount-<tei:lb/>ing, especially if it has a membranous base. In addition, differences in orientation, either</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>200 C. H. C. LYAL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>natural or caused by the mounting process, may give the impression of very different shapes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Observations by Ferris (1951) and Murray (1957a, 19576) indicate that the gonapophyses are<tei:lb/>used, at least in some species, to trap the hair on which the egg is to be laid, guide the egg onto it,<tei:lb/>and mould the attaching cement. For Bovicola ovis the diameter of the hair is of importance in<tei:lb/>determining whether the egg will be laid (Murray, 19576) and this is almost certainly detected by<tei:lb/>the gonapophysis. There is thus selection pressure on the form of the gonapophysis relating to<tei:lb/>the structure of the host hair.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Posterior to the vulva and sometimes covered by the subgenital lobe is the 'sub-vulval area',<tei:lb/>which sometimes bears characteristic spines or scales.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Also posterior to the vulva is a single sclerite which, as it cannot be homologised with either<tei:lb/>the gonangulum or sternite IX + X (Lyal, in prep., 6), is termed the 'post-vulval sclerite'<tei:lb/>(Moreby, 1978). This sclerite may be single, medially divided, narrow and strip-like, broad and<tei:lb/>triangular, fused to the postgenital pleurite, or absent (Figs 154, 175, 236, 237, 243).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The female genital chamber, opening at the vulva, is oval, dorso-ventrally compressed, and<tei:lb/>lightly-sclerotised. The dorsal wall of the chamber may be heavily sculptured and bear<tei:lb/>sclerotised spicules, ridges or spines; this sculpturing may extend on to the postgenital sterna.<tei:lb/>The ventral wall may be similarly sculptured, although usually to a lesser extent; where the<tei:lb/>subgenital lobe is present the sculpturing of the genital chamber may extend onto its dorsal<tei:lb/>surface . The sculpturing of the walls of the chamber probably provides a highly f rictional surface<tei:lb/>against which the spicular surface of the endophallus acts to provide a firm union during<tei:lb/>copulation. The nature of the sculpturing and the distributions of spicules or spines may be<tei:lb/>taxonomically useful at the specific or subspecific level. The common oviduct opens into the<tei:lb/>anterior end of the genital chamber and curves sharply posteriad to lie dorsally to the chamber.<tei:lb/>Dorsal to the vulva the common oviduct curves sharply anteriad and divides into the two paired<tei:lb/>oviducts (Fig. 20). The genital chamber, although assuming a more or less circular cross-section<tei:lb/>during the passage of an egg and perhaps during copulation, is, when at rest, a dorso-ventrally</tei:p>
         <tei:p>gonapophysis VIII</tei:p>
         <tei:p>paired oviducts</tei:p>
         <tei:p>common oviduct</tei:p>
         <tei:p>sternum VII</tei:p>
         <tei:p>sternum VIM</tei:p>
         <tei:p>genital chamber</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 20 Diagrammatic three-dimensional representation of trichodectid female genital chamber and<tei:lb/>oviducts (internal), with terms used in this study.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTID MAMMAL LICE 201</tei:p>
         <tei:p>flattened, fairly rigid structure, the minimum width of which is governed by the diameter of the<tei:lb/>egg. The oviduct, however, is an elastic, folded membranous tube, compressed and folded to<tei:lb/>reduce volume, and expanding only to allow passage of the egg. The common oviduct must, at<tei:lb/>the junction with the genital chamber, be the same diameter as the chamber. At its division into<tei:lb/>the paired oviducts, however, it is narrow and greatly folded when at rest. Between these two<tei:lb/>points it narrows more or less abruptly, and folds may be apparent in its walls. Price &amp; Emerson<tei:lb/>(1971) interpret these folds in Geomydoecus as striations of the dorsal wall of the genital<tei:lb/>chamber, and term this apparently membranous structure the 'genital sac'. The true dorsal wall<tei:lb/>is interpreted as the ventral wall and the true ventral wall is apparently not observed. The form<tei:lb/>of the folds of the 'genital sac' (common oviduct), as well as its length and the width of its<tei:lb/>junction with the genital chamber, have been utilised by Price and his co-workers as specific and<tei:lb/>subspecific characters in their re visionary work on Geomydoecus (e.g. Price, 1974; Price &amp;<tei:lb/>Emerson, 1971; Price &amp; Hellenthal, 1976; Timm &amp; Price, 1980). The apparent constancy of the<tei:lb/>dimensions of the oviduct is related to the size of the egg and perhaps to the restrictions in<tei:lb/>variability of size of the genital chamber imposed by selection. The apparent constancy of the<tei:lb/>folds is more puzzling although it is possible that tubes of identical length and diameter have an<tei:lb/>optimum folding pattern if compressed in the same way. The wall of the common oviduct<tei:lb/>may also be lightly sclerotised, at least near to the junction with the genital chamber. The<tei:lb/>folds of the common oviduct have not been utilised as a taxonomic character elsewhere in the<tei:lb/>Phthiraptera.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Blagoveshtchenski (1956) examines several species of Trichodectidae but fails to find<tei:lb/>evidence of a spermatheca in the family. In this study examination of slide-mounted specimens<tei:lb/>of most species has failed to reveal a spermatheca in any genus apart from problematically in<tei:lb/>Dasyonyx, where a lightly-sclerotised sac, differing in form between species, is developed from<tei:lb/>the wall of the common oviduct. The relatively anterior position of this sac in comparison to the<tei:lb/>spermatheca of other Phthiraptera suggests that the two structures are not homologous. No<tei:lb/>histological or anatomical studies have been carried out on the sac.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The male abdomen and copulation</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The opening of the male genital chamber ('genital opening') is always posterior to sternum IX,<tei:lb/>and primitively in the lice is ventrally positioned and distant from the anus, which is terminal.<tei:lb/>During copulation the male and female are usually oriented the same way, with male ventral to<tei:lb/>female. The tip of the male's abdomen is curved dorsally and anteriorly so that the genital<tei:lb/>openings of the male and female meet. The male genitalia consequently enter the female genital<tei:lb/>chamber 'upside-down' , with the ventral side of the former coming into contact with the dorsal<tei:lb/>wall of the latter. Should sclerotised tergites be absent (as in Neotrichodectes and Geomydoecus)<tei:lb/>or greatly reduced (as in Trichodectes galictidis and Felicold) flexion of the male abdomen during<tei:lb/>copulation is evenly distributed along the membranous dorsal surface. If sclerotised tergites are<tei:lb/>present and fully-developed, however, flexion must be about the sclerite-membrane-sclerite<tei:lb/>joints of the dorsal surface, these thus functioning as 'hinges'. At each such hinge, there will be<tei:lb/>considerable deformation of the internal structures during flexion, whilst between the hinges<tei:lb/>there will be no deformation. Increasing the number of hinges on the dorsal surface permits<tei:lb/>smoother curvature of the abdomen and reduces the internal deformation at each hinge. Many<tei:lb/>male Trichodectidae have tergal sclerites divided into an anterior and a posterior plate on at<tei:lb/>least some segments (Figs 103, 105, 136), possibly for this reason. The degree of internal<tei:lb/>deformation may be further reduced by modification of the shape of the plates. The form of plate<tei:lb/>which, when placed in series, causes maximum internal deformation and requires maximum<tei:lb/>membrane area: sclerite area ratio for flexion is a simple rectangle, with anterior and posterior<tei:lb/>margins at right angles to the long axis of the abdomen. These factors can be diminished by<tei:lb/>introducing curvature in the anterior and posterior margins of the plates, either with both<tei:lb/>margins parallel or opposite, producing a series of alternating biconvex and biconcave plates<tei:lb/>(Lyal, 1983). Both these patterns are approached in the Trichodectidae (Figs 68, 103, 105). The<tei:lb/>flexibility required of the ventral surface of the abdomen is developed, should the sterna be</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>202 C. H. C. LYAL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>sclerotised, by increasing the lengths of the sclerites and allowing them to overlap when the<tei:lb/>abdomen is at rest (Figs 103, 105).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Despite the increased flexibility of the abdomen achievable by modifications of the tergal and<tei:lb/>sternal plates, the position taken by the male during copulation is compatible with a ventral<tei:lb/>genital opening only if the abdomen is long and slender. A short, broad abdomen will not<tei:lb/>deform sufficiently to turn back on itself and bring the male genital opening into contact with the<tei:lb/>vulva. Such a short, broad abdominal form has been developed several times in the Phthirap-<tei:lb/>tera, however, including at least once in the Trichodectidae. In most cases the limitation<tei:lb/>imposed on the degree of curvature of the abdomen has been met by a posterior or even dorsal<tei:lb/>migration of the genital opening, thus reducing the degree of curvature necessary. This<tei:lb/>displacement has been effected by an increase in length of sterna VII, VIII and IX and a<tei:lb/>concomitant shortening of the corresponding terga. In Trichodectidae this may lead to the<tei:lb/>division of tergite VIII longitudinally by segment IX (Fig. 212). The re-positioning of the genital<tei:lb/>opening has increased its proximity to the anus, and in Trichodectidae the anus is contained<tei:lb/>within the genital chamber with the recuced segments X and XI projecting from the genital<tei:lb/>opening (Fig. 19). The curvature required of the abdomen has been further limited in some<tei:lb/>Trichodectidae by two distinct adaptations. In some species of Felicola segment IX is developed<tei:lb/>into a long, slender posterior process and the genital opening is dorsal and apical (Fig. 187). The<tei:lb/>basal apodeme and parameres are elongate and slender (Fig. 205). Most of the curvature<tei:lb/>required is probably developed at the base of segment IX and the junction of the parameres and<tei:lb/>the basal apodeme. Constriction of the endophallus at the latter fold is prevented by the<tei:lb/>presence of a reduced, circular mesomeral arch, lacking an extension, which, being fused to the<tei:lb/>endophallus, prevents the structure from being pinched shut. In some Lorisicola species<tei:lb/>segment IX projects dorsally from segment VIII, the genital opening being dorsal (Fig. 114).<tei:lb/>This positioning limits the degree of curvature required of the abdomen by increasing the<tei:lb/>proximity of the genital opening to the vulva on minimum curvature.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male terminalia</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In Trichodectidae the subgenital plate is fundamentally uniform in construction, although great<tei:lb/>superficial differences may exist between species. The plate is here considered to comprise eight<tei:lb/>discrete elements: sternites VII, VIII, IX (and, occasionally, VI); a pair of rods (referred to as<tei:lb/>'subgenital plate rods' or 's.g.p.r.' in this study) which lie laterally to the sternites and sometimes<tei:lb/>fuse them together (Figs 19, 165, 212); the two pleurites of segment IX, and the post-genital<tei:lb/>sclerite, which is of uncertain homology (Fig. 19). Any of these elements may be present,<tei:lb/>reduced or absent, or fused to adjacent sclerites. The sternites and the post-genital sclerite may<tei:lb/>be whole or medially divided. In cases of extreme reduction only the lateral rods may be left<tei:lb/>(Fig. 163) or all the sclerites absent (Fig. 187). In the most complete form (Fig. 68), all the<tei:lb/>sclerites are fused, forming a squared plate; usually there are membranous areas surrounding<tei:lb/>the sternal setae ('perisetal gaps'), but these may be absent (Fig. 115).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The subgenital plate rods on sternum VIII are always connected to the ventral wall of the<tei:lb/>genital chamber in Trichodectidae, a feature also observed in some Anoplura. The function of<tei:lb/>this attachment is not known, although in species with ventrally-positioned parameres and a<tei:lb/>median posterior extension to the mesomeral arch, the difference in lengths between the dorsal<tei:lb/>wall of the genital chamber and the membrane between the basal apodeme and the subgenital<tei:lb/>plate might cause divergence of the apices of the parameres and mesomeral arch extension<tei:lb/>during extrusion of the genitalia to allow evertion of the endophallus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In some Trichodectidae the posterolateral angles of the subgenital plate are greatly extended<tei:lb/>into setose lobes termed 'styli' by Eichler (1963) (Figs 46, 68). Abdominal sternal sclerites are<tei:lb/>probably derived from a fusion of the sternal plate and the coxal elements of the paired<tei:lb/>abdominal appendages (coxopodites) (Matsuda, 1976; Richards &amp; Davies, 1977). In the<tei:lb/>subgenital plate of the Acercaria the paired nature of the gonocoxopodite component may be<tei:lb/>expressed as a concavity of the posterior margin of the plate and concomitant projection of the<tei:lb/>posterolateral angles (Matsuda, 1976). True abdominal styli are derived from the paired</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTID MAMMAL LICE 203</tei:p>
         <tei:p>abdominal appendages and are serially homologous with either the shaft of the thoracic legs or<tei:lb/>the coxal styli (spurs of Matsuda, 1976) of the thoracic legs as present in the Machilidae<tei:lb/>(Thysanura) (Matsuda, 1976; Richards &amp; Davies, 1977). Styli are not, therefore, homologous<tei:lb/>with the coxopodites, but arise from them, being separated by a clear sulcus. Although true styli<tei:lb/>are present in some Psocoptera (Matsuda, 1976), the posterior extensions of the subgenital plate<tei:lb/>of Trichodectidae are not demarcated by a sulcus and thus are not homologous with true styli.<tei:lb/>The so-called styli of the Trichodectidae are an indication of the gonocoxopodite component of<tei:lb/>the subgenital plate, and are here termed 'pseudostyli'. Taxonomic use may be made of the form<tei:lb/>of the pseudostyli, which is very variable in the Trichodectidae, but the difficulty of assigning<tei:lb/>polarity to transformation series limits the applicability of this character within phylogenetic<tei:lb/>studies. The distribution of the pseudostyli through the Trichodectidae, however, is utilised in<tei:lb/>the construction of the phylogeny of the family (see below).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male genitalia</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The structure of the male genitalia of lice and the homologies of the major parts are discussed by<tei:lb/>Lyal (1983 and in prep., b). The genitalia consist of a more or less sclerotised basal apodeme<tei:lb/>supporting caudally a pair of parameres which may be fused ventrally and a pair of mesomeres<tei:lb/>which may be fused dorsally; fused to the interior faces of the parameres and mesomeres is the<tei:lb/>permanently-everted portion of the eversible endophallus (Lyal, 1983 and in prep., b}. In most<tei:lb/>Trichodectidae both parameres and mesomeres are present, the latter usually being fused<tei:lb/>apically (Figs 170, 198), the fused portion generally being extended posteriorly (Fig. 224). The<tei:lb/>parameres may also be fused, forming a median ventral plate (Fig. 250). The parameres and<tei:lb/>mesomeres may meet the basal apodeme together (Fig. 170) or separately (Fig. 250). The full<tei:lb/>range of variation of the male genitalia is discussed in the character analysis and taxonomy<tei:lb/>sections below.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>During copulation the endophallus everts into the female genital chamber. As described<tei:lb/>above, the interior of the femlae genital chamber is roughened and lined with scales. The<tei:lb/>endophallus is likewise roughened, being covered with small chitinous spicules or larger<tei:lb/>sclerites. The probable function of this adaptation is to maintain a firm connection between the<tei:lb/>male and female genitalia during copulation. The form of the endophallus and the distribution of<tei:lb/>the spicules and sclerites are species-specific and very variable, possibly functioning as pre-<tei:lb/>zygotic isolating barriers.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Character survey</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As noted above, the characters and character states listed below were selected from a much<tei:lb/>larger set of characters and states. In some cases reasons for rejection are discussed below. The<tei:lb/>full list of characters and the complete data matrix are presented in Lyal (1983) and are<tei:lb/>deposited in the library of the British Museum (Natural History).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Posterior of basal apodeme symmetric in vertical plane<tei:lb/>lateral struts ('b.a.l.s.') asymmetric in vertical</tei:p>

         <tei:p>10 Basiparameral sclerites</tei:p>
         <tei:p>11 Paramere fusion</tei:p>
         <tei:p>12 Paramere fusion</tei:p>
         <tei:p>13 Paramere fusion</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Paramere shape</tei:p>
         <tei:p>17 Parameral plate shape</tei:p>
         <tei:p>18 Parameral orientation</tei:p>

      </tei:div>
