         <tei:p>with posterior sclerite<tei:lb/>longitudinally divided<tei:lb/>medially 1 g</tei:p>
         <tei:p>164 Abdominal lateral flecks absent</tei:p>
         <tei:p>present 1 g</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Character analysis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The character analysis is performed in two interconnected parts, the determination of character<tei:lb/>polarity and the construction of the cladogram. These are linked through the process of<tei:lb/>'reciprocal illumination' (Hennig, 1966), and thus, although they are considered individually in<tei:lb/>the two sections below, there is some interaction between the two processes which will be<tei:lb/>manifested in discussion. The following two sections are intended to explain the reasons for the<tei:lb/>polarity assigned to the characters listed above, and for those groups developed in the cladogram<tei:lb/>where characters are apparently arranged non-parsimoniously.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>To increase clarity and conciseness the distributions of characters and character states<tei:lb/>discussed below are related to taxa and clades developed in the analysis. Clades are referred to<tei:lb/>by the names of the taxa (species or genera) on the extreme left (top) and right (bottom) of the<tei:lb/>clade as depicted on the cladogram (Figs 23 to 34), reading from left (top) to right (bottom).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Identification of apomorphic states</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In many cases an apomorphic character state is identified as such by its distinct complexity and<tei:lb/>very limited distribution and, to avoid pointless repetition in the following discussion, such<tei:lb/>instances are not examined individually.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The characters are examined under the following headings:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male genitalia (characters 1-56); Female genitalia (characters 57-97); Reproduction (character<tei:lb/>98); Male terminal abdominal segments (characters 99-109); Antennae (characters 110-124);<tei:lb/>Head (characters 125-128); Legs (characters 129-130); Postcoxale (character 131); Spiracles<tei:lb/>(characters 133-138); Abdominal setae (characters 139-156); Abdominal pleural projections<tei:lb/>and modifications (characters 157-161); Abdominal sclerae (characters 132, 162-164).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male genitalia (characters 1-56)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Most species of Psocodea have symmetric male genitalia and this state is consequently assumed<tei:lb/>to be plesiomorphic for the superorder. In a few species of Trichodectidae the genitalia are<tei:lb/>asymmetric, but differences in the form of the asymmetry in different species (Figs 170, 174, 249)<tei:lb/>suggest that several independent autapomorphies have been developed. In some cases a<tei:lb/>characteristic asymmetry is limited to a single species and is therefore of no relevance to phyletic<tei:lb/>analysis, but the asymmetries described in characters 1, 18, 19 and 29 are more widely<tei:lb/>distributed and are all employed. The distribution of other apomorphies indicates that character<tei:lb/>1, the vertical asymmetric deflection of the lateral struts of the basal apodeme ('b.a.l.s.'), has<tei:lb/>been developed twice, once in Felicola (S.) bedfordi (Fig. 195), and once in the common<tei:lb/>ancestor of F. (F.) cynictis and F. (F.) setosus (Fig. 193).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In most Psocodea the basal apodeme is not fused to the parameres, but in a few Trichodecti-<tei:lb/>dae this fusion, considered to be apomorphic, has taken place (character 12). In the Damalinia<tei:lb/>(D.) theileri-harrisoni clade the posterior ends of the b.a.l.s. are broad and fused exteriorly to<tei:lb/>the parameres (Fig. 75); this fusion (character 12:1) is unlike that found elsewhere in the family</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>214 C. H. C. LYAL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>and is believed on that account to be autapomorphic. In the Trichodectes (S.) retusus-mustelae<tei:lb/>clade, the T. (S.)fallax-potus clade, Neolutridia lutrae and Lutridia exilis the parameres are also<tei:lb/>fused to the b.a.l.s. (character 12:1'), but there are no features in the fusion pattern to indicate<tei:lb/>whether the apomorphy is homologous or convergent in the four clades. There are a number of<tei:lb/>possible sequences of gains and reversals. The fusion may have taken place three or four times<tei:lb/>with no reversals; once, to be lost at least four times; or twice, to be lost at least twice. The<tei:lb/>genitalia of Lutridia spp. differ from those found in the sister-group (the Trichodectes-<tei:lb/>Neolutridia clade), being more similar to those of Protelicola. Comparison of L. exilis and L.<tei:lb/>matschiei (Figs 144, 145) indicates fusion of the parameres and b.a.l.s. in the former species to be<tei:lb/>associated with the virtual detachment of the basal fused portion of the parameres, a unique<tei:lb/>feature. For this reason the fusion in L. exilis is deemed to be autapomorphic. The Trichodectes<tei:lb/>(S.) retusus-mustelae clade and the T. (S.) fallax-potus clade are placed by character 144 in a<tei:lb/>trichotomy with T. (S.) emery i, a species in which the parameres are not fused to the b.a.l.s. If<tei:lb/>the fusion is homologous in Trichodectes (Stachiella) and Neolutridia, then it must have been lost<tei:lb/>in Werneckodectes, Trichodectes (Trichodectes) and T. (Paratrichodectes), and T. (S.) emeryi.<tei:lb/>Parsimony suggests that fusion was developed independently in Neolutridia and the common<tei:lb/>ancestor of the two clades in Trichodectes (Stachiella) that possess the character, these latter<tei:lb/>being united as sister-groups. Fusion of the parameres to the b.a.l.s. is thus postulated to have<tei:lb/>taken place four times in the Trichodectidae, three of those times in the Trichodectes-Lutridia<tei:lb/>clade.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In most Psocodea the parameres are not fused together, but such fusion is present, probably<tei:lb/>apomorphically, in a number of species of Trichodectidae (character 13:1). In some species<tei:lb/>parameral fusion is difficult to observe, as the portion of the permanently-everted endophallus<tei:lb/>lying between the parameres is faintly sclerotised, giving the impression that the parameres are<tei:lb/>fused together; fusion has probably developed in some cases through sclerotisation of the<tei:lb/>endophallus. The distribution of other apomorphies suggests that parameral fusion exhibits<tei:lb/>more homoplasy than any other apomorphy in the analysis, being derived 24 times and lost once.<tei:lb/>In the Lorisicola (P.) bengalensis-juccii clade the parameres are closely associated with each<tei:lb/>other but are not fused (Figs 223, 224), although fusion has sometimes been assumed (e.g.<tei:lb/>Werneck, 1948). This proximity is believed to be autapomorphic for the clade (character 13:1').<tei:lb/>The form of the fused parameres (parameral plate) may be apomorphic for groups of species<tei:lb/>(characters 15, 17).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In a few Trichodectidae the parameres and mesomeres are fused, a probable apomorphy<tei:lb/>(character 11). The distribution of other apomorphies and slight differences in the fusion pattern<tei:lb/>(Figs 60, 74, 75, 81, 225) indicate some homoplasy in the character.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As described above, the mesomeres are frequently fused apically in the Psocodea, and<tei:lb/>consequently this fusion, when found in the Trichodectidae, is deemed to be plesiomorphic.<tei:lb/>Loss effusion (i.e. reduction to two unfused mesomeres) is therefore believed to be apomorphic<tei:lb/>within the Trichodectidae (character 33), and distribution relative to other apomorphies<tei:lb/>indicates that it has occurred several times in the family (see cladogram). In most species of the<tei:lb/>Procaviphilus-Eurytrichodectes clade there is a lateral desclerotisation on each side of the<tei:lb/>mesomeral arch (Figs 118, 122, 135). This character state is not found elsewhere and this, its<tei:lb/>structure, and the distribution of other apomorphies, all indicate its apomorphic status<tei:lb/>(character 34). The mesomeral arch may also have lateral flexions (Figs 107, 108, 225), which<tei:lb/>can give the arch the appearance of being broken (see Werneck, 1948). This modification is<tei:lb/>found in species of the Lorisicola (P.) lenicornis-neoafricanus clade and of Procavicola<tei:lb/>( Condylocephalus) , which on the basis of other apomorphies are widely separated on the<tei:lb/>cladogram; the lateral flexion of the mesomeral arch (character 35) is consequently believed to<tei:lb/>be a convergent apomorphy in the two clades named. In most species of the genus Eutrichophi-<tei:lb/>lus the mesomeral arch is divided into three parts by total desclerotisations laterally (Figs 91,<tei:lb/>93). This feature is unique within the Phthiraptera and therefore considered apomorphic<tei:lb/>(character 36).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In many Trichodectidae a rod-like sclerite terminating posteriorly in a Y-shape or a broad<tei:lb/>plate is present longitudinally between the b.a.l.s. (Figs 55, 82, 148). Although this sclerite (the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTID MAMMAL LICE 215</tei:p>
         <tei:p>'central sclerotisation') is very clear in some species, it is poorly sclerotised in others, and may be<tei:lb/>either absent or obscured by the sclerotisations of the endophallus in mounted specimens. The<tei:lb/>uncertainty attached to the observation of this structure has precluded its use in analysis,<tei:lb/>although it may be of value taxonomically. The central sclerotisation is probably a derivative of<tei:lb/>the basal apodeme, developed for muscle attachment.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A sclerite or pair of sclerites is present anteriorly to the parameres in some Trichodectidae,<tei:lb/>and are referred to here as the 'basiparameral sclerites' (Figs 107, 225) (character 10: 1+2). They<tei:lb/>may be fused to the parameres (Fig. 225) or to each other (Fig. 93). Their presence is believed to<tei:lb/>be apomorphic and their derivation is probably from the basal ventral flanges of the parameres<tei:lb/>found apomorphically (character 28) in a number of Trichodectidae (Figs 118, 122). If they are<tei:lb/>formed (as suggested here) by detachment of the flange from the main body of the paramere<tei:lb/>(Fig. 21), fusion of the sclerites and the parameres is a stage in the transformation series to the<tei:lb/>development of free sclerites, but fusion of the basiparameral sclerites to each other is a<tei:lb/>'terminal' apomorphic state (although it is not used in the cladistic analysis because of its<tei:lb/>extremely limited distribution).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The anterior end of the basal apodeme may be heavily or lightly sclerotised, or apparently not<tei:lb/>sclerotised at all. This degree of sclerotisation is very susceptible to modification during<tei:lb/>preparation of the specimen, and thus is difficult to assess accurately. The character is not used in<tei:lb/>analysis. The most prominent features of the basal apodeme are the lateral struts (b.a.l.s.),<tei:lb/>which are generally fairly heavily sclerotised. These struts may approach the anterior of the<tei:lb/>basal apodeme in parallel, convergently or divergently; this character is not used in cladistic<tei:lb/>analysis because of the difficulty in assigning polarity to the different forms, but is useful<tei:lb/>taxonomically, and can help in the determination of the form of the anterior margin of the basal<tei:lb/>apodeme. This anterior margin may be straight or broadly convex, shallowly concave, very<tei:lb/>deeply concave (Fig. 52) or acuminate (Fig. 173) (character 2). Of these forms the last two are<tei:lb/>almost certainly apomorphic within the Trichodectidae; the elongation of the apodeme and the<tei:lb/>concomitant parallel-sided concavity is found only in the Bovicola alpinus-tibialis clade<tei:lb/>(character 2:1), and the acuminate form is found only in three species of Trichodectes , although<tei:lb/>in fact the latter apomorphy imparts little useful information for the construction of the<tei:lb/>cladogram. The polarity of the character for the other three states is difficult to assess, and they<tei:lb/>are therefore not used in phyletic analysis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In some species of Damalinia (Tricholipeurus) the b.a.l.s. develop a lateral spur before the<tei:lb/>junction with the parameres, probably at the point at which the dorsal and ventral layers of the<tei:lb/>basal apodeme separate; this feature (the 'anteposterior spur', Fig. 83) is not found elsewhere in<tei:lb/>the Trichodectidae and is considered apomorphic (character 5). The posterior ends of the<tei:lb/>b.a.l.s. are most frequently not, or only slightly, expanded laterally, but in some Trichodectidae<tei:lb/>they are greatly broadened and scoop-shaped. This very broad form, whilst believed to be<tei:lb/>apomorphic, is not used as an apomorphy in phyletic analysis because of difficulties in delimiting<tei:lb/>the state. The posterior forking of the b.a.l.s. (Fig. 173) is also considered apomorphic<tei:lb/>(character 3), but was probably developed twice in Trichodectes (see cladogram). The basal<tei:lb/>apodeme probably extends anteriorly as far as segment VI in the plesiomorphic state, but in a<tei:lb/>few Trichodectidae it extends up to segment II; in some cases this lengthening has been<tei:lb/>accompanied by a width restriction or 'waisting' medially, and this is believed to be apomorphic<tei:lb/>(character 6). Other features of the basal apodeme are, by virtue of their restricted distribution<tei:lb/>and concordance with the distributions of other apomorphies, believed to be apomorphic<tei:lb/>(characters 4, 7, 8, 9).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Whilst it is not possible to be certain of the plesiomorphic form of the parameres in the<tei:lb/>Trichodectidae, it is assumed that this is fairly unspecialised, and that the forms of the parameres<tei:lb/>found in groups of species that are also linked by other apomorphies are apomorphic (characters<tei:lb/>20-27).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As noted above, apical fusion of the mesomeres is plesiomorphic for the Trichodectidae, so<tei:lb/>loss of apical fusion, reduction in size and complete loss of the mesomeres are all considered to<tei:lb/>be apomorphic within the family (characters 30, 31, 33). The presence of a median longitudinal<tei:lb/>extension to the mesomeral arch is also considered plesiomorphic, as it is present in a number of</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>216 C. H. C. LYAL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>taxa outside the Trichodectidae. Loss of this extension, or modification of its form from 'simple<tei:lb/>lanceolate' (Fig. 118), are considered apomorphic within the family (characters 47-49). In the<tei:lb/>plesiomorphic state the mesomeres articulate basally with the basal apodeme; articulation of the<tei:lb/>basal apodeme with any other part of the mesomeres is considered apomorphic. Mesad<tei:lb/>extension of the mesomeres between the b.a.l.s. (character 32) has apparently arisen twice, once<tei:lb/>in the Dasyonyginae, and once in the Lorisicola, and in each case providing an autapomorphy<tei:lb/>for the clade named. In Lorisicola (P.) bengalensis andphilippinensis the parts of the mesomeres<tei:lb/>between the b.a.l.s. are apomorphically deflected posteriad (Fig. 224) (character 37). A similar<tei:lb/>recurving of the mesomeres occurs elsewhere in the Trichodectidae (character 45), but in this<tei:lb/>case the mesomeres are exterior to the b.a.l.s., and their recurved portions lie ventrally to the<tei:lb/>b.a.l.s. This apomorphy is seen as a transformation series of states in Damalinia (Tricho-<tei:lb/>lipeurus) (character 45:1-45:2), the most apomorphic of which (45:2) is also exhibited by<tei:lb/>Lorisicola mjoebergi, although in this case the recurved parts of the mesomeres are very difficult<tei:lb/>to see (Fig. 219). Other modifications to the mesomeres believed to be apomorphic are present<tei:lb/>in restricted groups within the Trichodectidae (characters 38-46).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The endophallus may be sclerotised in a number of apomorphic ways within the Trichodecti-<tei:lb/>dae (characters 51-56).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female genitalia (characters 57-97)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The gonapophyses of most Trichodectidae and many other Psocodea bear at least some setae,<tei:lb/>which arise directly from the structure and not from tubercles. Absence of setae (character 57)<tei:lb/>and development of sclerotised setal tubercles (character 58) are therefore both believed to be<tei:lb/>apomorphic within the Trichodectidae. Setal tubercles are found in Protelicola, Procaviphilus<tei:lb/>and the Trichodectes-Neolutridia clade (T-N), but as a sister-group relationship between the<tei:lb/>latter two is not supported by other apomorphies, and the form of the tubercles differs between<tei:lb/>the two clades (Figs 111, 157), the character is probably convergent. The relationship between<tei:lb/>Protelicola and the T-N clade is discussed below. The characteristic pattern taken by the<tei:lb/>tubercles in each clade is modified by loss (character 60) or fusion (character 59); in both cases<tei:lb/>these are believed to be apomorphic modifications because of their concordance with other<tei:lb/>apomorphies. Tuberculate setae are also found on the ventral vulval margin of most species in<tei:lb/>Trichodectes (Fig. 157); concordance with other apomorphies suggests the apomorphy of this<tei:lb/>character (character 74).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The plesiomorphic form of the gonapophyses is not certain, but some forms, because of their<tei:lb/>very restricted distribution, are believed to be apomorphic (characters 61, 62, 63); some<tei:lb/>convergence in character 62 is indicated by the distribution of other apomorphies. The<tei:lb/>development of a lobe on the ventral margin of the gonapophysis is restricted to the Trichodecti-<tei:lb/>dae and, for this reason, is believed to be apomorphic within the clade (character 64).<tei:lb/>Distribution of other apomorphies suggests that the lobe developed independently in several<tei:lb/>different clades, sometimes taking only one form in a clade (character 70), sometimes being<tei:lb/>apomorphically modified (characters 66-69). The reduction of the 'spur' - the portion of the<tei:lb/>gonapophysis distal to the lobe - is considered apomorphic, as it is confined to two small groups<tei:lb/>of taxa within the family (character 65). Where present, the gonapophyses in most Phthiraptera<tei:lb/>meet the ventral vulval margin at an angle (Figs 94, 175), but in some Trichodectidae they meet<tei:lb/>in a smooth curve (Fig. 154), which may be sclerotised (characters 71, 72). The ventral vulval<tei:lb/>margin may extend in a more or less smooth curve between the gonapophyses, as is most<tei:lb/>frequently the case in lice with gonapophyses, or it may be produced in some manner (characters<tei:lb/>75-78). Each of these projections is considered apomorphic, although the distribution of other<tei:lb/>apomorphies suggests that some are homoplastically developed in different clades of the family.<tei:lb/>The distinction between the subgenital lobe (character 78) and the expansion of the ventral<tei:lb/>vulval margin (character 75, and its apomorphic derivative, character 76), may not be im-<tei:lb/>mediately clear, but whilst the former term is applied to structures that arise abruptly from the<tei:lb/>margin, the latter is a more extensive posterior production of the whole of the margin. Both of<tei:lb/>these apomorphies occur more than once in the Trichodectidae. The form of the subgenital lobe<tei:lb/>is variable, though frequently it is marginally serrate, sometimes with the serrations greatly</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTID MAMMAL LICE 217</tei:p>
         <tei:p>developed (character 79:2). Several other apomorphies, of restricted distribution within the<tei:lb/>Trichodectidae, are found in the form of the subgenital lobe (characters 80-83, 85, 86). Two<tei:lb/>probable apomorphies, the presence of an internal sclerite in the subgenital lobe and the<tei:lb/>presence of lateral setal patch, are not used in the cladistic analysis. The internal sclerite is not<tei:lb/>readily observable, but this is probably due to the sclerite being rendered undetectable during<tei:lb/>preparation of the specimens (especially the smaller species), and this likelihood precludes its<tei:lb/>use. The distribution of the sclerite, where detected, suggests it to be plesiomorphic within the<tei:lb/>Trichodectinae, possibly linked to the development of the subgenital lobe in this clade. The<tei:lb/>lateral marginal setae appear to share part of the distribution of the lateral processes of the lobe<tei:lb/>(character 81), being absent in a few species only, and the two characters are probably closely<tei:lb/>associated; for this reason the setal character is not used.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The plesiomorphic form of the genital chamber in the Trichodectidae is not known, but<tei:lb/>observations on other Phthiraptera suggest light sclerotisation with a few internal spicules. The<tei:lb/>development, in some restricted groups of Trichodectidae, of particular patterns of spicules,<tei:lb/>scales, spines and broad sclerotised areas (characters 92-96) is considered apomorphic.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Reproduction (character 98)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Parthenogenetic reproduction (character 98) occurs in a few Trichodectidae, mostly in the<tei:lb/>Bovicolinae, but also in the species Geomydoecusscleritus. As all other Phthiraptera reproduce<tei:lb/>bisexually, the character is taken as apomorphic. Parthenogenesis appears to have developed at<tei:lb/>least four times in the Trichodectidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male terminal abdominal segments (characters 99-109)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The sclerites of the terminal segments of the male trichodectid abdomen are very variable in<tei:lb/>presence or absence states, extent, and degree of subdivision. This variability is not, in many<tei:lb/>cases, readily associated with transformation series of other characters to which polarity has<tei:lb/>been applied, and the plesiomorphic state (and hence apomorphic states) of the characters of<tei:lb/>these sclerites is, in most cases, not known. In a few instances the sclerites are distinctly modified<tei:lb/>in a restricted group of species, and thus polarity can be assigned (characters 99, 101, 106, 107,<tei:lb/>108, 109).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Segment IX and the genital opening are apomorphically positioned more or less dorsally in<tei:lb/>many species of Trichodectidae, as discussed above. Distortion due to preparative processes<tei:lb/>obscures the position in many of the specimens examined, however, and characters associated<tei:lb/>with this positioning cannot be used with any confidence, and are excluded from analysis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In some species of Trichodectidae the posterior margin of tergum IX is greatly expanded to<tei:lb/>produce a double convex lobe (character 100); this development is believed to be apomorphic,<tei:lb/>although the distribution of other apomorphies indicates that it developed twice.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The presence of pseudostyli, discussed in detail above, is believed to be apomorphic for the<tei:lb/>Trichodectidae (character 102). The plesiomorphic form of the pseudostyli is not known, as the<tei:lb/>extant forms are very variable and cannot, in most cases, be resolved into transformation series.<tei:lb/>In two cases (characters 103, 104), the pseudostyli are of very distinct form and restricted to<tei:lb/>groups of species believed to be holophyletic on other grounds; these character states are<tei:lb/>believed to be apomorphic. The presence of a single projection posteriorly on segment IX in<tei:lb/>some species of Trichodectidae, believed to be formed of fused pseudostyli, is also considered<tei:lb/>apomorphic (character 105). Although found in only three species, the distribution of other<tei:lb/>apomorphies suggests two independent developments of this character state.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Antennae (characters 110-124)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In all Trichodectidae the male flagellomeres are fused together (character 111), a state found<tei:lb/>elsewhere only in the anopluran families Echinophthiriidae and Hamophthiriidae and therefore<tei:lb/>considered apomorphic for the Trichodectidae. Fusion of the flagellomeres has also occurred in<tei:lb/>some female Trichodectidae (character 110), but the distribution of other apomorphies suggests<tei:lb/>four homoplastic derivations of this apomorphy in the family. The expansion of the scape in the<tei:lb/>male to house the enlarged musculature is probably plesiomorphic for the Trichodectidae, as</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>218 C. H. C. LYAL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>similar expansion is found in many Ischnocera and Anoplura. Reduction of this expansion is,<tei:lb/>however, apomorphic within the family (character 112), and is believed to have taken place<tei:lb/>three times. The flagellum of most male Trichodectidae bears a number of setae modified into<tei:lb/>broad pointed 'teeth' (Figs 13, 231), a feature not found in the same form in any other<tei:lb/>Phthiraptera, and therefore considered apomorphic for the family. The plesiomorphic number<tei:lb/>of 'teeth' is almost certainly two, as this number is the most common in all groups of<tei:lb/>Trichodectidae; any variation from this number (to zero, one, three, four or eight) is believed,<tei:lb/>therefore, to be apomorphic (character 115). The loss of the basal articulation of the 'teeth'<tei:lb/>(character 117) and the development of a supporting protuberance (character 116) are both<tei:lb/>apomorphic. In order that the male antennae should clasp the female with maximum efficiency<tei:lb/>the 'inner' (posterior) surface of some or all of the antennal segments may be roughened or bear<tei:lb/>projections; such developments are considered apomorphic in each form (characters 118-121).<tei:lb/>The presence of a membranous projection on the female antenna (character 122) is also believed<tei:lb/>to be apomorphic. In most Phthiraptera the setae of the scape are scattered over its surface in no<tei:lb/>coherent pattern, and this is true of some Trichodectidae (Fig. 70); in most Trichodectidae,<tei:lb/>however, the setae of the dorsoposterior surface of the scape are apomorphically arranged in a<tei:lb/>line along the segment (Fig. 13) (character 113). In some cases where a row of setae might be<tei:lb/>expected from the construction of the cladogram, the number of the setae involved in the<tei:lb/>putative row is only two, and this is believed to represent an apomorphic reduction in number<tei:lb/>(character 118).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The sensilla of the antennae in Trichodectidae and other Phthiraptera have been discussed<tei:lb/>above; the presence of a fringed pit surrounding the sensilla of the flagellum in two species of<tei:lb/>Trichodectidae is unique and believed to be apomorphic (character 124).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head (characters 125-128)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although the sitophore sclerite is variable in most Phthiraptera (Haub, 1973), it is comparative-<tei:lb/>ly uniform in the Trichodectidae. The form found in most Trichodectidae (Fig. 11) is believed on<tei:lb/>this account to be plesiomorphic, and is departed from in Bovicola (Spinibovicola), Dasyonyx<tei:lb/>and Eurytrichodectes , where the posterior arms are extended (Fig. 12) (character 125). The<tei:lb/>distribution of other apomorphies indicates that the modification is convergent in Bovicola<tei:lb/>(Spinibovicola) and Dasyonyx plus Eurytrichodectes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The posterior margins of the temple are generally broadly rounded in Trichodectidae, but in<tei:lb/>species of the genus Eutrichophilus the convexity is much greater than in the rest of the family<tei:lb/>(Fig. 87); this development is believed to be apomorphic (character 127). In the three species of<tei:lb/>the genus Eurytrichodectes (only two of which are described) and the four of Procavicola<tei:lb/>(Condylocephalus) the posterior temple angles are developed into pointed projections (charac-<tei:lb/>ter 126), these being very long in the former genus (character 126: 2). This modification is not<tei:lb/>found elsewhere in the Trichodectidae, although small rounded projections are found in some<tei:lb/>Dasyonyx spp. and some Damalinia spp. The presence of pointed projections is believed, on the<tei:lb/>basis of the distribution of other characters, to be homoplastic in the two genera mentioned.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The form of the osculum has been largely excluded from consideration in the cladistic analysis<tei:lb/>because of the direct influence of the hair of the host (see above). However, in the Damalinia<tei:lb/>(D.) theileri-baxi clade it is quite different from other species of Trichodectidae (Fig. 69), and is<tei:lb/>here suggested to be apomorphic (character 128).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Legs (characters 129, 130)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The loss of one tarsal claw on each leg (character 129) is an apomorphy associated with<tei:lb/>ectoparasitism on mammals. This character is proposed as an autapomorphy of the Trichodecti-<tei:lb/>dae, although it may be autapomorphic for a postulated holophyletic group comprising the<tei:lb/>Anoplura, Rhyncophthirina and Trichodectidae (Lyal, 1985).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A number of Psocodea have teeth on the 'inside' face of the tarsal claws, and many<tei:lb/>Trichodectidae have what appears to be a single basal tooth (Fig. 15). The occurrence of teeth all<tei:lb/>along the 'inside' face of the tarsal claws (Figs 14, 15) is restricted in the Trichodectidae to<tei:lb/>Dasyonyx, .and is believed to be autapomorphic for the genus (character 130). The two</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTID MAMMAL LICE 219</tei:p>
         <tei:p>subgenera of Dasyonyx have tarsal claw teeth of different forms: D. (Dasyonyx) have sharp<tei:lb/>slender teeth (Fig. 14), whilst D. (Neodasyonyx) have blunter, broader teeth (Fig. 15). These<tei:lb/>two forms may be co-apomorphies, indicating that the subgenera are sister-groups, or one may<tei:lb/>be the plesiomorphic state. No other characters have been found within Dasyonyx that indicate<tei:lb/>reliable sister-group relationships within the genus. In this study the two tooth forms are<tei:lb/>accepted as co-apomorphies and the subgenera retained, but further work on the genus may<tei:lb/>cause this hypothesis to be challenged.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Postcoxale (character 131)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In most species of Trichodectidae the metathoracic postcoxale is either not sclerotised or<tei:lb/>sclerotised and small, but the polarity of the transformation series with the extreme states<tei:lb/>'sclerotised' and 'not sclerotised' is not known. In Procaviphilus (Meganarionoides) and some<tei:lb/>species of Dasyonyx (Dasyonyx) the postcoxale is greatly enlarged and heavily sclerotised, an<tei:lb/>apomorphic state not included in the analysis for reasons given below. A further apomorphic<tei:lb/>condition, the fusion of the postcoxales, is also found in some members of the same subgenera.<tei:lb/>The presence of the sclerotised postcoxale is difficult to determine in some of the smaller species<tei:lb/>of Dasyonyx, but in any case the distribution of other apomorphies indicates convergence of the<tei:lb/>postcoxale characters in the two subgenera. Neither apomorphy is used in the analysis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In P. (Meganarionoides), uniquely, the postcoxale is fused to abdominal pleurum II (charac-<tei:lb/>ter 131), and this apomorphy is used in the analysis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It is interesting that the great development of the postcoxales, restricted to lice parasitic on<tei:lb/>hyraxes, is morphologically convergent on the development of the apophysis of abdominal<tei:lb/>sternum II (character 132), which is found in another group of hyrax lice.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Spiracles (characters 133-138)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>For the Phthiraptera (and the Trichodectidae) the plesiomorphic number of spiracles is a single<tei:lb/>thoracic pair and six abdominal pairs; further reduction in the number of abdominal spiracles is<tei:lb/>apomorphic. The numbers of abdominal spiracles in the different species of Trichodectidae are<tei:lb/>summarised in Table 1. Each reduction is considered to be an apomorphy (characters 135-138),<tei:lb/>though some homoplasy has occurred. Inspection of the distribution of other apomorphies<tei:lb/>indicates that reduction to five, four and one pair of spiracles has occurred once, reduction to<tei:lb/>three and two pairs twice, and reduction to none eight times. Because of the sequential pattern<tei:lb/>of spiracle loss, apomorphy 136 is always associated on the cladogram with apomorphy 135, 137<tei:lb/>with 136 and 135, and 138 with 137, 136 and 135.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In most species of lice all of the abdominal spiracles have atria of roughly the same size; as has<tei:lb/>been pointed out in earlier discussion, however, some Trichodectidae have posterior spiracles<tei:lb/>with atria much smaller than those more anterior on the abdomen (character 134). This<tei:lb/>difference in size is believed to be an apomorphic reduction.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In most species of lice the atrium of the thoracic spiracle is as broad or broader than long;<tei:lb/>species of the genus Cebidicola, however, have a tubular atrium associated with the thoracic<tei:lb/>spiracle (character 133). This modification of form is believed to be apomorphic.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdominal setae (characters 140-156)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Study of abdominal setal patterns throughout the Psocodea suggests that the plesiomorphic<tei:lb/>pattern is a row of setae running around the abdomen on each of segments I to VIII. On<tei:lb/>trichodectid abdominal pleura II-VII this row of setae (referred to here as the posterior setal<tei:lb/>row or 'p.s.r.') is generally clear, and is absent in only a few species. The distribution of other<tei:lb/>apomorphies indicates this absence to be apomorphic, although limited to a very few, distantly-<tei:lb/>related, species. In some Trichodectidae, the p.s.r. of pleura II, III and IV comprises setae that<tei:lb/>are much stouter than those of other pleura, and the distribution of other apomorphies suggests<tei:lb/>the apomorphic status of each of these, although each exhibits some homoplasy. Preliminary<tei:lb/>analysis indicated that specialisation of the p.s.r. on pleura II and IV conveys little phylogenetic<tei:lb/>information, and only character 139 (specialisation of the p.s.r. on pleurum III) is used in the<tei:lb/>final cladistic analysis. The setae on pleura VIII and IX are frequently longer than the setae of</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>220 C. H. C. LYAL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>the p.s.r. on anterior pleura; the extreme length of these setae in Eutrichophilus is, however,<tei:lb/>recognised as apomorphic (character 140).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The setal row on sterna II and III is usually similar to the row on other sterna, but in the two<tei:lb/>species of Eurytrichodectes the setae of these two rows are short, stout and conical (Fig. 136).<tei:lb/>This unique feature is believed to be apomorphic (character 153).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The tergal setal row of many Trichodectidae, especially males, is clearly composed of four<tei:lb/>discrete groups - two lateral and two median - each separated by a gap (Fig. 22) . The positioning<tei:lb/>of the groups and the number of setae in them are useful taxonomic characters, and may be<tei:lb/>utilised as landmarks for the identification of particular setae. The groups are, however, difficult<tei:lb/>to use in phyletic analysis because of the difficulty of assigning polarity to any transformation<tei:lb/>series.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In some Trichodectidae (and in no other Phthiraptera) a seta- termed here the 'posterolateral<tei:lb/>seta' or 'p.l.s.' - is present posterolaterally on each side of terga II-VI (Fig. 22). The restriction<tei:lb/>of distribution of this seta within the Phthiraptera suggests that its presence is apomorphic<tei:lb/>(character 151). In some cases there is more than one p.l.s. on each side of the tergum (Fig. 201);<tei:lb/>this is believed to be an apomorphy but its sporadic occurrence (in terms of clades indicated by<tei:lb/>other apomorphies) has led to its omission from the cladistic analysis. The presence of the p.l.s.<tei:lb/>is difficult to assess in some species, either because the lateral group may be reduced in number<tei:lb/>or because the lateral group is composed of very long setae. In the former case, a single seta in<tei:lb/>the position of the p.l.s. may be this seta (the lateral group being absent), or it may be the sole<tei:lb/>remaining seta of the lateral group (the p.l.s. being absent) (Fig. 159). In the latter case (most<tei:lb/>Trichodectes species and the Neotrichodectinae), the most lateral seta of the lateral group<tei:lb/>frequently lies slightly posterior to the rest of the row (Fig. 158) and a more differentiated p.l.s.<tei:lb/>is absent. In both these cases the p.l.s. is postulated to be present, though modified. The</tei:p>
         <tei:p>anterior setae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>posterior setal<tei:lb/>row</tei:p>
         <tei:p>postero-lateral<tei:lb/>seta</tei:p>
         <tei:p>lateral<tei:lb/>gap</tei:p>
         <tei:p>median<tei:lb/>gap</tei:p>
         <tei:p>median setal<tei:lb/>group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>lateral setal<tei:lb/>group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 21, 22 Trichodectid morphology. 21, postulated evolution of basi-parameral sclerite by detachment<tei:lb/>of basal flange of paramere. 22, Abdominal setal arrangement, illustrated by anterior terga and pleura of<tei:lb/>male.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTID MAMMAL LICE 221</tei:p>
         <tei:p>distribution of other characters suggests, however, that secondary loss of the p.l.s. has occurred<tei:lb/>within some taxa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Some setae of the median tergal group, particularly in males, may be specialised. In males of<tei:lb/>Neotrichodectes spp. the two central setae of the united median groups, or two setae very near<tei:lb/>the centre (perhaps separated by one or two unmodified setae) are very much smaller than the<tei:lb/>other setae of the row (Fig. 229). These 'tergocentral microsetae' (character 152) are found<tei:lb/>nowhere else, and this and the concordance of their distribution with that of apomorphy 118:<tei:lb/>l'+2' suggests the apomorphy of the character state. In Felicola (S.) pygidialis and F. (S.)<tei:lb/>macrurus the median group of tergum III is modified in a distinctive manner in the males (Fig.<tei:lb/>178), and this modification is assumed to be apomorphic for the two species (character 147).<tei:lb/>Some or all of the setae of the median group on terga II and III of male Trichodectidae may be<tei:lb/>enlarged relative to the other tergal setae. This enlargement occurs sporadically both within and<tei:lb/>outside the family, and each case is believed to be autapomorphic. Within the Trichodectidae, in<tei:lb/>males of Geomydoecus (Thomomydoecus), G. (G.) copei, Trichodectes (Paratrichodectes)<tei:lb/>ovalis and ugandensis, and the undescribed sister-subspecies of Trichodectes (T.) galictidis, the<tei:lb/>setae of the median row on both terga II and III are enlarged but remain in a straight row (Figs<tei:lb/>161 , 244) ; this arrangement is believed to be apomorphic, but probably convergent in each of the<tei:lb/>four groups (character 149). In Bovicola (Spinibovicola) hemitragi and multispinosa a similar<tei:lb/>enlargement is confined to some of the setae of tergum II, and the lines are curved (Fig. 41)<tei:lb/>(character 150). In males of Felicola, the holophyly of which is supported by several apomor-<tei:lb/>phies, the median setal group is reduced to a single, greatly enlarged seta (Fig. 188). The<tei:lb/>apomorphic status of this character (character 142) is indicated by its restricted distribution and<tei:lb/>correlation with other apomorphies. It is notable that the setae are single, but of normal size<tei:lb/>(very small) in the Felicola (F.) rahmi-viverriculae clade (Fig. 183), and secondarily increased in<tei:lb/>number to six in Felicola (S.) bedfordi and F. (F.) setosus (Figs 180, 189). On the basis of other<tei:lb/>apomorphies, the former is believed to be a single autapomorphic reversal, whilst the latter is<tei:lb/>believed to be a convergent gain.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The sclerite from which the pair of setae arises may be long and of characteristic shape (Fig.<tei:lb/>181); this feature is found only in conjunction with the enlarged setae (character 142) and is<tei:lb/>postulated to be apomorphic (character 155).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In many males of Felicola the median setal group on terga III-VII is also reduced to a single<tei:lb/>seta, although in most cases this does not approach the size of the seta of tergum II. In the<tei:lb/>Felicola (S.) cooleyi-quadraticeps clade this reduction has taken place on terga III-VII, but the<tei:lb/>setae are similar in length to those of tergum II, the latter being reduced relative to those of other<tei:lb/>species of Felicola and the former enlarged (Fig. 186) (character 143). This apomorphy is<tei:lb/>convergent on the apomorphic setal pattern of the males of Trichodectes (Stachiella) (character<tei:lb/>144), although in this case the setae are all generally long and stout. The median setal group of<tei:lb/>the female tergum may also be reduced to a single seta (character 145) or lost (character 146).<tei:lb/>The distribution of these female apomorphies is as follows. The reduction of the median group<tei:lb/>to a single seta is found only in the Trichodectes (S.) fallax-octomaculatus clade; the sister-<tei:lb/>species, T. (S.) potus, and the sister-group to this clade, the T. (S.) retusus-mustelae clade, lack<tei:lb/>the female median group entirely. The sister-species to the whole T. (S.) retusus-potus clade, T.<tei:lb/>(S.) emeryi, has the median group unreduced, numbering three setae, on terga I and II, reduced<tei:lb/>to one seta or absent on tergum III, and absent on terga IV- VIII. It is not certain whether setal<tei:lb/>loss in the female has taken place only once, the setae being regained in the fallax-octomaculatus<tei:lb/>clade, or has taken place independently three times (in emeryi, the retusus-mustelae clade, and<tei:lb/>potus).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The length of the abdominal setae is difficult to employ in phyletic analysis because of the<tei:lb/>problem of establishing the polarity of the transformation series 'very short - medium - very<tei:lb/>long'. The restricted distributions of the two extremes of the series (concordance with other<tei:lb/>apomorphies) indicate their apomorphic status, however. The very short, sparse setae (Fig. 183)<tei:lb/>are found in no other Phthiraptera but the Felicola-Lorisicola clade and some Trichodectes spp. ,<tei:lb/>and are probably apomorphic but convergent in the two groups. The very long refringent setae<tei:lb/>of some Trichodectidae (Fig. 158) are considered apomorphic for a similar reason (character</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>222 C. H. C. LYAL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>141), though in this case similar setae are found in some Philopteridae. These long setae<tei:lb/>probably evolved twice in the Trichodectidae: once in Trichodectes and once in the Neo-<tei:lb/>trichodectinae. The fine, long setae of the females of the Felicola (S.) cooleyi-quadraticeps clade<tei:lb/>are found in no other group and are considered apomorphic (character 154).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The setal bases - the circular 'pits' of the setal articulations - are of fairly constant size relative<tei:lb/>to the setae in most Trichodectidae. However, in the Bovicola (B.) alpinus-tibialis clade the<tei:lb/>bases are noticeably large in relation to the setae, and seem to have a double margin. This<tei:lb/>feature needs to be examined using the scanning electron microscope to elucidate its true<tei:lb/>structure, but examination using the light microscope is sufficient to detect its presence. This<tei:lb/>feature is here considered as apomorphic (character 156).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdominal pleural projections and modifications (characters 157-161)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In many Trichodectidae the dorsoposterior and/or the ventroposterior pleural angles project on<tei:lb/>pleura II, III or IV (see discussion above, and Table 2). Projections on these segments of the<tei:lb/>type found here do not occur elsewhere in the Phthiraptera, and are therefore considered as<tei:lb/>apomorphic (characters 158-160). Preliminary analysis reveals that the projections on pleurum<tei:lb/>III contribute no useful phyletic information, so the apomorphy is omitted from the final<tei:lb/>cladistic analysis. Variation in the degree of development of the dorsal and ventral lobes of the<tei:lb/>projection on pleurum IV is omitted for the same reason, except for the extreme development in<tei:lb/>Eurytrichodectes (character 161). Both the presence of a dorsal and a ventral projection on<tei:lb/>pleurum IV (characters 159 and 160 respectively) are included in the analysis, though the latter<tei:lb/>apomorphy is reversed in some clades. The presence of a projection on pleurum II (character<tei:lb/>158) provides a synapomorphy for Geomydoecus spp., which are also united as a holophyletic<tei:lb/>group on other grounds; the projection on this pleurum is found convergently in Trichodectes<tei:lb/>(Paratrichodectes) zorillae. The sclerotisation of the dorsal projection on pleurum II (character<tei:lb/>158:2) is an autapomorphy of Geomydoecus (Thomomydoecus) (and some species in Geomy-<tei:lb/>doecus s.str. - see discussion below -) and T. zorillae, but sclerotisation of the projections on the<tei:lb/>other pleura is very variable, and is not used in cladistic analysis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In Damalinia (Damalinia) pleurum II extends on to sternum II, and the pleurite is expanded<tei:lb/>at the expense of the sternite (character 157). This extension may be broad (character 157:1') or<tei:lb/>narrow (character 157:1), but the more plesiomorphic state of these two (should they not be<tei:lb/>co-apomorphies) is not known. The species with a broad ventral extension of pleurite II also<tei:lb/>possess a more or less extensive dorsal extension, but this is not found in species with a narrow<tei:lb/>ventral extension. In this treatment the two forms of the ventral extension are used to<tei:lb/>characterise each of two sister-groups, but this hypothesis is open to challenge, as the group<tei:lb/>indicated by character 157:1 has no other supporting apomorphy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdominal sclerae (characters 132, 162-164)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As noted above, in species of the trichodectid genus Procavicola sternite II is greatly developed<tei:lb/>as a heavily sclerotised internal apophysis, articulated to pleurum II (character 132). The<tei:lb/>presence of this unique structure is considered apomorphic.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The presence of the lateral flecks and their associated small sclerite is considered apomorphic,<tei:lb/>as the structure occurs in no Phthiraptera other than the Trichodectidae (character 164).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The pleura, sterna and terga of the trichodectid abdomen may be sclerotised or not; although<tei:lb/>some groups (identified on the basis of other apomorphies) may, in general, be more or less<tei:lb/>sclerotised, the polarity of the transformation series 'sclerotised - not sclerotised' for each<tei:lb/>segment cannot be determined, and these characters are not used in the cladistic analysis. The<tei:lb/>male abdomen may have a characteristic sclerotisation dorsally, in that the terga may have<tei:lb/>anterior and posterior sclerites; this feature is present in some Anoplura, but is probably<tei:lb/>convergent in this suborder. The presence of doubled tergal sclerites in male Trichodectidae is<tei:lb/>believed to be apomorphic for the family, but is not used in cladistic analysis because of the large<tei:lb/>number of reversals. The tergal sclerites are not further modified in most male Trichodectidae,<tei:lb/>but in some there is longitudinal division of the anterior or posterior sclerites (characters 162 and<tei:lb/>163 respectively), this division being accepted as apomorphic.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTID MAMMAL LICE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>223</tei:p>
         <tei:p>D. (Trlchollpeurus)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eutrichophllus</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Neotrichodectinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 23 Cladogram of Trichodectidae. Clades numbered 1-12 are resolved in Figs 24-34. The Eu-<tei:lb/>trichophilinae (Genus Eutrichophllus only) is not resolved further. For explanation of numbered<tei:lb/>apomorphies see text.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cladistic analysis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The holophyly of both monotypic and polytypic species is accepted without the need for<tei:lb/>justification, so species-level autapomorphies have not been indicated unless they are homoplas-<tei:lb/>tic with character states elsewhere on the cladogram. Omission of the autapomorphies of species<tei:lb/>saves both space in the data matrix and time taken for analysis, and for the same reasons many<tei:lb/>sister-species pairs are justified on the cladogram with fewer autapomorphies than are available.<tei:lb/>Of the 187 apomorphic character states used in the analysis, 86 are postulated to have been<tei:lb/>developed more than once or to have been secondarily lost, 363 such homoplasies being<tei:lb/>proposed. When, in the analysis, a choice is available between postulating one reversal or a pair<tei:lb/>of homoplastic gains (i.e. three clades in a holophyletic group are involved and the topography<tei:lb/>of the tree is not affected whichever the choice), the latter is chosen (e.g. character 13:1 in the<tei:lb/>Damalinia theileri-appendiculata clade). This choice is made so that the distribution of<tei:lb/>apomorphic character states can more easily be discerned on the cladogram. The number of</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>224</tei:p>
         <tei:p>C. H. C. LYAL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Blsonlcolg s. seaeclmdecembrll</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 24 Cladogram of Bovicolinae (part) (clades 1-4 of Fig. 23: genera Bovicola, Bisonicola, Tragulicola<tei:lb/>and Werneckiella). For explanation of numbered apomorphies see text.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTID MAMMAL LICE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>225</tei:p>
         <tei:p>D. (D.) oppendlculata</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 25 Cladogram of Damalinia (Damalinia) (clade 5 of Fig. 23). For explanation of numbered<tei:lb/>apomorphies see text.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>homoplasies could be slightly reduced without affecting the topology of the tree because, as<tei:lb/>explained below, the less parsimonious presentation is sometimes chosen to make the clado-<tei:lb/>gram more informative and less potentially misleading. In a number of places in the discussion of<tei:lb/>apomorphic state identification above, reference is made to single apomorphic character states<tei:lb/>arising more than once. This is superficially contradictory, especially if the terms apomorphy<tei:lb/>and homology are equated. Such situations have been detected during one 'round' of reciprocal<tei:lb/>illumination. Should all such convergent apomorphic states be receded as separate apomorphies<tei:lb/>(which they are believed to be, even if they cannot be differentiated morphologically) the<tei:lb/>cladogram would appear more parsimonious.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The loss of the median extension of the mesomeral arch (character 47) is placed on the<tei:lb/>cladogram 17 times, frequently in combination with the loss of apical fusion of the mesomeres<tei:lb/>(character 33). These apomorphies are not arranged in the most parsimonious manner on the<tei:lb/>cladogram, as can be seen by inspection of the Bovicolinae. As presented, the cladogram depicts<tei:lb/>the loss of the extension 11 times in this subfamily. A more parsimonious arrangement of the<tei:lb/>apomorphies is achieved by postulating characters 33 and 47 as synapomorphic for Damalinia<tei:lb/>(Damalinia) and Damalinia (Cervicola), and character 47 as synapomorphic for two clades:<tei:lb/>Werneckiella plus Tragulicola and Bisonicola, and Bovicola (Bovicola) plus B. (Lepikentron)<tei:lb/>and B. (Spinibovicola) . This arrangement reduces the number of proposed homoplasies of<tei:lb/>character 47 to six within the Bovicolinae, and reduces the number of polychotomies on the<tei:lb/>cladogram. Alternatively, the loss of the extension might be postulated to have occurred only<tei:lb/>once, in the common ancestor of the Bovicolinae, and regained six times (B. crassipes, D.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>226</tei:p>
         <tei:p>C. H. C. LYAL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 26 Cladogram of Damalinia (Cervicola) (clade 6 of Fig. 23). For explanation of numbered<tei:lb/>apomorphies see text.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>r-CH</tei:p>
         <tei:p>-+9-</tei:p>

         <tei:p>elongata, D. moschatus, D. clayi and the D. albimarginata-indica clade). The most parsimo-<tei:lb/>nious hypothesis is that the structure was lost in the ancestor of Bovicolinae as suggested above,<tei:lb/>regained twice (B. crassipes and the D. (T.) albimarginata-elongata clade), and secondarily lost<tei:lb/>twice (D. (T.) lineata-victoriae and D. (T.) pakenhami-bedfordi). This last hypothesis, although<tei:lb/>more parsimonious than the distribution on the tree presented, does not change the topology of<tei:lb/>the tree. The distribution of character 47 is not as apparent from inspection of the tree in its most<tei:lb/>parsimonious distribution as it is in the tree presented, as the more scattered distribution of the<tei:lb/>losses and reversals obscures the alternative possible distributions and implies a spurious<tei:lb/>confidence in the tree as supported by them.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The distribution of character 33 (the loss of mesomeral fusion) in Werneckiella is not<tei:lb/>presented in the most parsimonious manner. There is great difficulty in the observation of this<tei:lb/>character state in Werneckiella, and the morphological difference between 'loss of fusion' and<tei:lb/>'fusion' is very slight. A detailed examination of the species of this genus for other characters to</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>228</tei:p>
         <tei:p>C. H. C. LYAL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>, 00</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Fig. 30 Cladogram of Trichodectini (clade 9 of Fig. 23, part: genera Protelicola, Lutridia, Neolutridia and<tei:lb/>Werneckodectes). Clade 14 is resolved in Fig. 31. For explanation of numbered apomorphies see text.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>complete a full analysis was not made, character 33 only being noted because it occurs elsewhere<tei:lb/>on the cladogram. It is possible but not likely that the distribution of character 33 as observed is<tei:lb/>supported by other apomorphies, but the proposal of holophyletic groups within the genus on<tei:lb/>the basis of the observations made of this single character would be unwise. It is notable that<tei:lb/>Werneckiella fulva and W. neglecta, which differ in the state of character 33, are otherwise very<tei:lb/>similar, the females apparently being indistinguishable (Emerson &amp; Price, 1979), and it is very<tei:lb/>likely that they are sister-species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The arrangement of Protelicola, Lutridia and the Trichodectes-Neolutridia clade (T-N) on<tei:lb/>the cladogram (Figs 30, 31) does not accord with the most parsimonious distribution of the<tei:lb/>apomorphies. The cladogram contains four convergences for 'gain' apomorphies: 12:1' (fusion<tei:lb/>of parameres and b.a.l.s.) is postulated as homoplastic in Lutridia, Neolutridia and Trichodectes<tei:lb/>(Stachiella); 13:1 (fusion of parameres to each other) is postulated as homoplastic in Protelicola<tei:lb/>and Lutridia; 20 (development of rod-shaped parameres) is postulated as homoplastic in<tei:lb/>Protelicola and Lutridia; and 58 (development of tubercles for the gonapophysis setae) is<tei:lb/>postulated as homoplastic in Protelicola and T-N. Apomorphy 12: 1 ' has been discussed in detail<tei:lb/>above, and the distribution suggested in the cladogram is believed consistent with the morpholo-<tei:lb/>gical evidence. Apomorphy 58 could be considered in two ways other than that presented: as an<tei:lb/>autapomorphy supporting the sister-group relationship of Protelicola and T-N, or as an<tei:lb/>autapomorphy of the Trichodectini (the Trichodectes-Protelicola clade), reversed in Lutridia.<tei:lb/>The first alternative is not supported by the distribution of any other apomorphies, whereas the<tei:lb/>two alternative arrangements are each indicated by more than one apomorphy (see below); the<tei:lb/>sister-group relationship of Protelicola and T-N is therefore rejected. The plesiomorphic<tei:lb/>arrangement of the gonapophysis tubercles in T-N is clearly distinct from the arrangement in<tei:lb/>Protelicola. If the tubercles are postulated to be homologous in the two clades two further<tei:lb/>apomorphies (the form of the tubercles in each clade) would have to be proposed, as neither<tei:lb/>form appears to be plesiomorphic with respect to the other. This manipulation does not affect<tei:lb/>the topology of the cladogram (whatever the position of Lutridia), and does not clarify the<tei:lb/>relationships of the clades involved, so the hypothesis of convergence of character 58 in<tei:lb/>Protelicola and T-N is retained. The other two apomorphies may now be considered together as<tei:lb/>they both suggest the sister-group relationship of Protelicola and Lutridia. The alternative<tei:lb/>hypothesis (of the cladogram as presented) is supported by apomorphies 72 (development of a<tei:lb/>sclerotisation along the ventral vulval margin) and 47 (loss of the median extension of the<tei:lb/>mesomeral arch). 'Loss' characters are given much less weight than 'gain' characters in this<tei:lb/>analysis, so character 47 should be left out of consideration. The sister-group relationship of<tei:lb/>Protelicola and Lutridia is therefore supported by two apomorphies and the relationship<tei:lb/>proposed on the cladogram supported by one. As noted in the generic descriptions below,<tei:lb/>however, an undescribed species of Protelicola has been seen which does not share apomorphy<tei:lb/>20. The cladistic position of this species with respect to the other two species in the genus has not</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>230</tei:p>
         <tei:p>C. H. C. LYAL</tei:p>

         <tei:p>TRICHODECTID MAMMAL LICE 233</tei:p>
         <tei:p>a Geomydoecus (G.) unresolved species</tei:p>
         <tei:p>G. (G.) copel<tei:lb/>G. (G.) thonoiwus</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Neotrlchodectes (N.) thoraclcus</tei:p>

         <tei:p>N. (Lakshmlnarayanella) gastrodes</tei:p>
         <tei:p>N. (L. ) cunmilngsl</tei:p>
         <tei:p>N. (ConeeatliQlg) chilensls</tei:p>
