         <tei:p>N . ( C . ) semlstrlotus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>N. (C.) arlzonae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 34 Cladogram of Neotrichodectinae (clade 12 of Fig. 23: genera Neotrichodectes and Geomydoecus).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>For explanation of numbered apomorphies see text.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>been determined because of the poor state of preservation of the specimens, but its existence<tei:lb/>raises the possibility that character 20 is an apomorphy not of Protelicola but of only two species<tei:lb/>within the genus (the alternative being a reversal in the undescribed species). Character 20 is<tei:lb/>also homoplastically developed in Felicola and Bovicola (Lepikentron) . If this character is<tei:lb/>disregarded, apomorphies 72 and 13:1 must be compared for their comparative likelihood of<tei:lb/>homoplasy. Apomorphy 13:1 is homoplastically developed at 22 other points on the cladogram<tei:lb/>whilst 72 is found elsewhere only in Bovicola (Lepikentron) . Apomorphy 72 should clearly be<tei:lb/>given much more weight than 13:1 in construction of the cladogram, and 20 is considered of<tei:lb/>uncertain value in view of the undescribed species of Protelicola. For these reasons the<tei:lb/>cladogram is retained as proposed, even though it is not maximally parsimonious.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The dorsal projection of pleurum IV (character 159) is lost in the Trichodectini, but</tei:p>
         <tei:p>postulated as secondarily regained in Werneckodectes and Trichodectes (Paratrichodectes)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>zorillae. The form of the projection is different in the two species, however, which indicates the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>independent development of the structure.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Whilst the genus Geomydoecus s.l. is almost certainly holophyletic, this probably does not</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>234 C. H. C. LYAL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>apply to either of the two included subgenera (Fig. 34). The question of holophyly should be<tei:lb/>addressed first in the smaller subgenus Geomydoecus (Thomomydoecus). All but one of the<tei:lb/>included species (G. (T.) war.di) have characteristically asymmetric male genitalia (character<tei:lb/>29), and are proposed on this basis to be a holophyletic group (the asymmetricus-zacatecae clade<tei:lb/>or 'a-z clade'). G. (T.) wardi and the a-z clade share the following apomorphies: posterolateral<tei:lb/>temple margin with single stout seta and associated shorter, finer setae (a character not included<tei:lb/>in the data matrix); male parameral plate apically pointed (character 14); gonapophysis<tei:lb/>smoothly continuous with ventral vulval margin (character 71); male abdominal terga II and HI<tei:lb/>with median setal group comprising exceptionally long, stout setae (character 149); and pleural<tei:lb/>projections sclerotised, especially in females (character 158:2). The possession of a single stout<tei:lb/>temple seta is unique to these species, but may be a reduction from the two stout setae found in<tei:lb/>this position in some Geomydoecus (Geomydoecus). Apomorphies 14, 71 and 149 are also<tei:lb/>shared by G. (G.) copei, and this species has the mesomeral arch and parameral plate very<tei:lb/>slender, approaching the shape of the genitalia of the a-z clade more closely than does G. (T.)<tei:lb/>wardi; the posterolateral temple margin lacks any specially-modified setae, but this may be due<tei:lb/>to secondary loss. Apomorphies 14, 71 and 158:2 are shared by the G. (G.) thomomyus-<tei:lb/>dakotensis clade, but the male genitalia are considerably broader than those of G. (T.) wardi,<tei:lb/>and the mesomeral arch lacks a median extension (an autapomorphy of the clade). This clade<tei:lb/>has a further autapomorphy in the form of the posterolateral setae of the temple margin, which<tei:lb/>comprise a single long fine seta and associated shorter fine setae. As with G. (G.) copei, the<tei:lb/>plesiomorphic form of the temple setae is unknown, and could have been the form found in G.<tei:lb/>(Thomomydoecus) . Other species of G. (Geomydoecus) have a single apex to the parameral<tei:lb/>plate (character 14), but do not share any of the other apomorphies mentioned. G. (T.) wardi,<tei:lb/>the a-z clade, and the G. (G.) thomomyus-dakotensis clade are all parasitic on Thomomys spp. ,<tei:lb/>whilst G. (G.) copei is a parasite of Orthogeomys hispidus; both host genera are parasitised by<tei:lb/>other members of Geomydoecus (Geomydoecus) .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The apomorphies listed above plainly do not support unequivocally any of the three possible<tei:lb/>sister-group relationships of the a-z clade without invoking homoplasy to an unjustifiable<tei:lb/>extent. It is apparent, however, that G. (Geomydoecus) is paraphyletic with respect to G.<tei:lb/>(Thomomydoecus) and that the latter subgenus is possibly polyphyletic. A full phylogenetic<tei:lb/>analysis of the 102 species and subspecies of Geomydoecus, which would have been necessary to<tei:lb/>resolve the problem, was not attempted. The hosts of the genus are all geomyid rodents, the<tei:lb/>systematic and taxonomic understanding of which is of questionable accuracy (Price, pers.<tei:lb/>comm.). For the purposes of this study the subgeneric concepts proposed by Price &amp; Emerson<tei:lb/>(1972) are retained.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Taxonomic history of Trichodectidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Burmeister (1838) divided the Mallophaga into two families, Liotheidae and Philopteridae, the<tei:lb/>latter comprising the two genera Philopterus and Trichodectes . Kellogg (1896) proposed the<tei:lb/>suborders Amblycera and Ischnocera for Liotheidae and Philopteridae (sensu Burmeister)<tei:lb/>respectively, and erected the family Trichodectidae for the genus Trichodectes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mjoberg (1910) described Damalinia and Eutrichophilus , the second and third genera of<tei:lb/>Trichodectidae, and Stobbe (1913a) described a fourth genus, Eurytrichodectes. Stobbe (1913b)<tei:lb/>revised the family for the first time. Ewing (1929) described four further genera and provided a<tei:lb/>key to all eight, although Ferris (1929) regarded E wing's new genera as of 'most dubious value'.<tei:lb/>Bedford (1929, 19320, 19326, 1936) described a further 10 genera, two of which were junior<tei:lb/>synonyms of genera proposed by Ewing (1929), thus bringing the total to 16; Ewing (1936)<tei:lb/>provided a key to 14 of these. Keler (1938a) recognised 24 genera, 10 of them new (although one<tei:lb/>of these had been published previously by Keler, 1934 as a nomen nudum). The two genera<tei:lb/>omitted by Keler (1938a) were the same two previously omitted by Ewing (Cebidicola Bedford,<tei:lb/>1936 and Lorisicola Bedford, 1936); the three species included in these genera were placed by<tei:lb/>Keler with two others, also from primates, in his new genus Meganarion (although with the<tei:lb/>proviso 'without, of course, intending to establish the congeneric status of these species'). Keler</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTID MAMMAL LICE 235</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(1938fl) provided a key to most of the genera described in his paper (with the sole exception of<tei:lb/>Meganarion) and to many of the species. Werneck (1941) introduced the subgenus concept to<tei:lb/>the taxonomy of Trichodectidae , describing three new subgenera in two of the four genera of the<tei:lb/>family parasitic on hyraxes. During the decade following Keler's (1938a) review of the family a<tei:lb/>number of new genera were described, bringing the total number of available names in the<tei:lb/>genus-group to 43 by the end of 1948. Werneck (1948, 1950) reviewed all the Trichodectidae,<tei:lb/>and recognised 20 genera (though one of these doubtfully) and three subgenera. No genera and<tei:lb/>only one subgenus have been described since 1948. The most recent name to be added<tei:lb/>(Lakshminarayanella Eichler, 1982) was published as a replacement name for a junior<tei:lb/>homonym, and brings the total of available names to 45. There have been no revisionary works<tei:lb/>of the family since those of Werneck (1948, 1950), although Hopkins &amp; Clay (1952), when<tei:lb/>cataloguing the 'Mallophaga', accepted 13 genera, some of these doubtfully, and Eichler (1963)<tei:lb/>recognised 38 genera (with no subgenera).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The problem of establishing criteria by which taxa can be distinguished at the generic level<tei:lb/>received early attention. An attempt to identify morphological characters for this purpose was<tei:lb/>initiated by Bedford (1929). Bedford (1932) provided a more thorough discussion, and<tei:lb/>concluded that whilst the shape of the head, the presence or absence of abdominal sclerites and<tei:lb/>the form of the female gonapophyses were of value, the form of the male genitalia and the<tei:lb/>number of abdominal spiracles provided no useful guide. Ewing (1936) came to a quite different<tei:lb/>conclusion, regarding abdominal spiracle number as 'the most important generic character'.<tei:lb/>Bedford (1939) realised the unworkability of any system involving a priori assessment of<tei:lb/>morphological characters for generic discrimination, although he still felt that abdominal<tei:lb/>spiracle number was not of value at the generic level, and noted that (morphological) generic<tei:lb/>characters 'may not be very striking'. To supplement or replace morphological characters<tei:lb/>Bedford (1939) made use of host data, the possibility of which was first discussed by Kellogg<tei:lb/>(1913, 1914) and Harrison (19166). Bedford (1939) wrote: 'Before placing a species in a new<tei:lb/>genus one should ask oneself: would it be possible to say from what kind of host the parasite was<tei:lb/>taken off had it not been recorded? If it is impossible to answer the question, then one should be<tei:lb/>justified in placing it in a new genus.' Hopkins (1941) used this principle to a certain extent in his<tei:lb/>discussion of Felicola. He also discussed the morphological characters used for the discrimina-<tei:lb/>tion of the genus from others, and pointed out that 'the singling out of one character [on which to<tei:lb/>base genera] . . . only tends to obscure natural relationships'. Werneck (1936) perceived and<tei:lb/>treated the problem of generic discrimination in a rather different way from those described<tei:lb/>above. He noted that whilst the type-species (and sometimes a few species similar to the type) of<tei:lb/>each of the described genera were quite distinct, other species showed intermediate characters.<tei:lb/>The existence of these 'transitional forms' convinced Werneck that there was no validity in the<tei:lb/>separate genera, so he synonymised them all (with the exception of some genera not found in<tei:lb/>South America, which were outside the scope of the paper). Bedford (1939) regarded this action<tei:lb/>as 'unwarrantable' and reinstated all the genera. Hopkins (1942, 1943) reviewed the characters<tei:lb/>used to separate the genera of Trichodectidae parasitic on carnivores and antelopes respect-<tei:lb/>ively. In each case he found annectent species as described by Werneck (1936), and took similar<tei:lb/>action, though modified by the belief that louse genera should somehow reflect host taxa.<tei:lb/>Hopkins (1942) therefore accepted three genera of Trichodectidae parasitic on carnivores and<tei:lb/>later (1943) accepted one genus parasitic on antelopes. Werneck (1948, 1950), although less<tei:lb/>influenced by the host data, recognised more genera than had Hopkins. He accepted the<tei:lb/>morphologically 'distinct' species and species groups as genera, and placed annectent species in<tei:lb/>the genus which they most closely resembled. Hopkins (1949) 'conceded subgeneric status to<tei:lb/>many groups which seem likely to be accepted by systematists whose views . . . differ from mine'<tei:lb/>and recognised 14 genera and 20 subgenera. Hopkins &amp; Clay (1952) synonymised some of the<tei:lb/>subgenera accepted by Hopkins (1949), but raised others to generic status. Ledger (1980) held<tei:lb/>views similar to Hopkins &amp; Clay (1952), although in some cases followed the views of Hopkins<tei:lb/>(1949); the resultant generic arrangement still involved fewer genera than accepted by Werneck<tei:lb/>(1948, 1950), and many more subgenera. Emerson &amp; Price (1981), however, could 'find no basis<tei:lb/>for rejecting the classification of Trichodectidae given by Werneck (1948, 1950)', and suggested</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>236</tei:p>
         <tei:p>C. H. C. LYAL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>that the 'question of genera vs subgenera will perhaps continue until Mallophaga have been<tei:lb/>described from all likely hosts'. A number of other workers also follow these views. A third<tei:lb/>group of taxonomists (e.g. Eichler, 1963; Zlotorzycka, 1972) have accepted not only all the<tei:lb/>genera recognised by Werneck (1948, 1950), but also a number of genera that Werneck<tei:lb/>considered as junior synonyms; the subgenus category is not used, however. The present generic<tei:lb/>placement of most of the Trichodectidae is thus a matter of some contention and a review of the<tei:lb/>variations in status of some genera and subgenera is presented in Tables 3-5.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 3 Generic concepts in the Bovicolinae. The genera included in the table are represented by<tei:lb/>numbers 1-11; '2' indicates that the genus (Bovicola) is given full generic status, '1(2)' indicates that the<tei:lb/>genus (Bovicola) is considered a subgenus (of Damalinia) and ' = 1' indicates that the genus is considered<tei:lb/>as a junior synonym (of Damalinia). The generic name Bovidoecus Bedford, 1929 is omitted, as it was<tei:lb/>synonymised with Bovicola by Bedford (1932a) and has not since been used. There is no reference in the<tei:lb/>table to Werneck (1936), who treated all genera of Trichodectidae as synonyms of Trichodectes .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 4 Generic concepts in the Trichodectini (plus Neotrichodectes and Trigonodectes) . Coding as for<tei:lb/>Table 3. Protelicola is included in Table 5. The generic name Grisonia Keler, 1938a is omitted and its<tei:lb/>replacement name, Galictobius Keler, 1938ft, used throughout.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTID MAMMAL LICE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>237</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 5 Generic concepts in the Felicolini (plus Protelicold). Coding as for Table 3. The generic names<tei:lb/>Bedfordia and Felicinia (a junior homonym and an absolute synonym respectively) have not been<tei:lb/>included as their status has not varied; they are discussed in the comments following the description of<tei:lb/>Felicola s. str. below.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hopkins (1941) presented an explanation for the presence of so many annectent species in the<tei:lb/>Trichodectidae and a justification for synonymising many of the genera, writing: 'I believe the<tei:lb/>explanation to be that the Trichodectidae are in the process of dividing up into genera; in some<tei:lb/>cases the divergence has proceeded far enough for us to recognise the segregates as generically<tei:lb/>distinct, but in a much greater number of cases extreme members of a group may have become<tei:lb/>strikingly distinct whilst the others remain as connecting-links which entirely undo our attempts<tei:lb/>to find characters peculiar to the group.' Hopkins' statement implies that the species in a genus<tei:lb/>are somehow evolving as a unit, and is linked to the typological approach to taxonomy.<tei:lb/>Relationships between three or more taxa, if assessed by a simple count of character states (i.e.<tei:lb/>not distinguishing between plesiomorphies, apomorphies and homoplasies) are frequently<tei:lb/>reticulate in aspect (Simpson, 1961; Hennig, 1966; Mayr, 1969). The greater the number of<tei:lb/>homoplasies the more complex the reticulum is likely to be, and the more difficult it is to<tei:lb/>combine the taxa into groups. If genera are constructed on this principle some morphologically<tei:lb/>distinct species and species-groups will be distinguished, 'linked' by annectent species, with the<tei:lb/>concomitant absence of 'gaps' between genera - precisely the problem with traditional group-<tei:lb/>ings of the Trichodectidae. The 'problem' of annectent species is therefore engendered by the<tei:lb/>typological approach; the difficulties in distinguishing supra-specific groups are also a result of<tei:lb/>this, but combined in the Trichodectidae with a high degree of homoplasy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The difficulties discussed above have discouraged authors from attempting to produce keys to<tei:lb/>genera of the Trichodectidae. Since the key to genera published by Keler (1938a), very few have<tei:lb/>been published, and none included all the genera. Keler (1944) produced a key to some genera,<tei:lb/>slightly emended from Keler (1938), but a promised second half to the paper containing the rest<tei:lb/>of the key was never published. Werneck (1948, 1950), despite describing all of the genera, did<tei:lb/>not attempt to produce a key. A few keys have since been published in faunistic works, for<tei:lb/>example Toulechkoff (1955) produced a key (in Bulgarian) to the genera found in Bulgaria, and<tei:lb/>Zlotorzycka (1972) published a rather inaccurate key (in Polish) to the genera found in Poland.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although most authors follow Kellogg (1896) in their conception of the Trichodectidae, and<tei:lb/>retain familial rank for the group (e.g. Hopkins &amp; Clay, 1952; Hopkins, 1960; Ledger, 1980;<tei:lb/>Emerson &amp; Price, 1983), the rank of the group has been raised by others. Keler (19380) raised<tei:lb/>the Trichodectidae to superfamily level and included three families: Trichodectidae, Bovicoli-<tei:lb/>dae and Dasyonygidae, the latter two being described as new. In the Trichodectidae he placed<tei:lb/>four subfamilies, all of which he indicated to be new: Trichodectinae, Felicolinae, Eury-<tei:lb/>trichodectinae and, dubiously placed in this family, Eutrichophilinae (Fig. 35). Eichler (1940)</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>238</tei:p>
         <tei:p>C. H. C. LYAL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MSIOHIX</tei:p>
         <tei:p>EURYTRICHODECTES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>EUTRICHOPHILVS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PROCAVICOLA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PROCAVIPHILUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BEDFORDIA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FELICOLA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PROTELICOLA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SURICATOECUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GEOMYDOECUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GRISONIA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>LUTRIDIA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>NEOTRICHODECTES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>STACHIELLA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>URSODECTES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BOVICOLA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CERVICOLA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DAWLINIA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOLAKARTIKOS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>LEPIKEKTRON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>RHABDOPEDILON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TRICHOLIPEURUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DASYONYGIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>EURYTRICHODF.CTINAF</tei:p>
         <tei:p>EUTRICHOPHILINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FELICOLINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BOVICOLIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Incertae sedis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MEGANARION __</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 35 Classification of Trichodectoidea' according to Keler (1938a).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>described two further subfamilies in the Trichodectidae (sensu Keler, 19380): Lymeoninae and<tei:lb/>Cebidicolinae. Eichler (1941) described the new subfamily Damaliniinae in the Bovicolidae,<tei:lb/>attributing the nominate subfamily to himself. He also transferred the Eurytrichodectinae and<tei:lb/>the Eutrichophilinae to the Dasyonygidae, again attributing the newly-defined nominate<tei:lb/>subfamily to himself. Eichler (1941) considered the rank of the whole group to be not<tei:lb/>superfamily but 'family group' and termed it the Trichodectiformia (attributed to Keler, 19380);<tei:lb/>the subfamily Trichodectinae is also attributed to Keler (19380) but the nominate family is<tei:lb/>attributed to Burmeister (1838). The classification proposed by Eichler (1941) is depicted in Fig.<tei:lb/>36. Keler (1944) retained the Eurytrichodectinae in Trichodectidae and moved the Eutrichophi-<tei:lb/>linae to Bovicolidae; the subfamilies described by Eichler (1940, 1941) were not mentioned (Fig.<tei:lb/>37). The Trichodectidae were attributed by Keler (1944) to Kellogg (1896) but the nominate<tei:lb/>subfamily to Keler (19380). The superfamily rank was retained and the 'family group' not<tei:lb/>mentioned. Hopkins (1949) regarded the families proposed by Keler (19380) as subfamilies and<tei:lb/>the subfamilies as at most tribes. Hopkins also, following his synonymy of Bovicola with<tei:lb/>Damalinia, considered that 'Bovicolinae must be known as Damaliniinae'. Eichler (1963)<tei:lb/>retained the higher ranks and included 'interfamilia Trichodectiformia' within the superfamily<tei:lb/>Trichodectoidea. He moved the Lymeoninae to Dasyonygidae (wherein he retained Euryt-<tei:lb/>richodectinae), but accepted the move of Eutrichophilinae to Bovicolidae proposed by Keler<tei:lb/>(1944). Eichler (1963) also proposed the division of the Trichodect(oidea) into tribes, indicating<tei:lb/>their existence and composition by variations in typography in the list of genera presented<tei:lb/>(Eichler, 1963: 159, lines 31-37). Eichler (1963) did not publish any of the tribal names, but<tei:lb/>Lakshminarayana (1976) listed all of them. Neither Eichler (1963) nor Lakshminarayana<tei:lb/>(1976), however, gave any statement that purported 'to give characters differentiating the<tei:lb/>tax(a); or ... a definite bibliographic reference to such a statement' as is required by the<tei:lb/>International Code of Zoological Nomenclature for any name published after 1930 (Article 13).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTID MAMMAL LICE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>239</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DASYOtlYX</tei:p>
         <tei:p>EURYTRICHODECTES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>EUTRICHOPHILUS</tei:p>

         <tei:p>BEDFORDIA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FELICOLA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PROTELICOLA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SURICATOECUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GALICTOBIUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GEOMYDOECUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>LUTRIDIA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>NEOTRICHODECTES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>STACHIELLA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>URSODECTES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>LYMEOH</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CEBIDICOLA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>LORISICOLA</tei:p>

         <tei:p>BOVICOLA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOLAKARTIKOS</tei:p>

         <tei:p>RHABDOPEDILOtl</tei:p>
         <tei:p>UERNECKIELLA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TRICHOPHI LOPTEPUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DASYONYGINAE<tei:lb/>EURYTRICHODECTINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>EUTRICHOPHILIHAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FELICOLINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>LYMEONINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CEBIDICOLINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DAMALINIINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BOVICOUNAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DASYONYGIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTIDAF,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BOVTCOLTDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TRIC1IOP11ILOPTERIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 36 Classification of Trichodectiformia' according to Eichler (1941).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>None of the (11) names, therefore, are available for taxonomic use. Eichler (1963) attributed<tei:lb/>Trichodectoidea, Trichodectiformia, Trichodectidae and Trichodectinae to Burmeister (1838)<tei:lb/>but, whilst (correctly) attributing Bovicolidae and Dasyonygidae to Keler (19380) he attributed<tei:lb/>the nominate subfamilies of both to Eichler (1941). The classification proposed by Eichler<tei:lb/>(1963) is depicted in Fig. 38. Keler (1969) proposed a classification similar to that proposed by<tei:lb/>Keler (1944), but omitting a number of genera (Fig. 39).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Article 36 of the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature (1984) states that all<tei:lb/>categories in the family-group (tribe, subfamily, family, superfamily and any supplementary<tei:lb/>categories, according to Article 35a) are co-ordinate, and a name established for any category<tei:lb/>within the group is available with its original date and author for a taxon with the same type<tei:lb/>genus in each of the categories. The Trichodectinae, Trichodectidae, Trichodectiformia and<tei:lb/>Trichodectoidea should therefore all have the same date and author. The first use of a<tei:lb/>family-group name based on the type genus Trichodectes was by Kellogg (1896), who ranked<tei:lb/>'the Nitzschian families as suborders, the Nitzschian genera as families, and the Nitzschian<tei:lb/>subgenera, the genera of present-day writers, as genera.' Kellogg (1908) attributed the<tei:lb/>Trichodectinae (the only subfamily included in the Trichodectidae, which bore no attribution)<tei:lb/>to 'Burmeister (?)'. As explained above, subsequent attribution has frequently been to<tei:lb/>Burmeister (1838) and, in the case of some co-ordinate names, to Keler (19380). Burmeister<tei:lb/>(1838) did not mention any taxon in the family-group with the type genus Trichodectes. All</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>240</tei:p>
         <tei:p>EURWRICHODECTES<tei:lb/>FASTIGATOSCULUM 1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SURICATOECUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MEGANARIONOIDES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GALICTOBIUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GEOMXDOECUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>LUTRIDIA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>NEOTRICHODECTES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>STACHIELLA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TRIGONODECTES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>URSODECTES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>EUTRICHOPHILUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PROCAVICOLA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 ,2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1,2</tei:p>

         <tei:p>TRICHOLIPEURUS 1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TRICHOPHILOPTERUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>C. H. C. LYAL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>EURYTRICHODECTINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FELICOLINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DASYONY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>EUTRICHOPIIILINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BOVICOLINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TRICIIODECTIDAF.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BOVICOLinAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TRICHOPMILOPTERIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 37 Classification of Trichodectoidea' according to Keler (1944). Position of genus inferred from<tei:lb/>Keler (1938a). Position of genus inferred from key in Keler (1944).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>family-group names with the type genus Trichodectes should therefore be attributed to Kellogg<tei:lb/>(1896). Trichodectidae Kellogg, 1896 has been placed on the Official List of Family-group<tei:lb/>Names in Zoology (Opinion 627, Bull. zool. Nom. 19: 91-96, (1962)). The names Bovicolinae,<tei:lb/>Bovicolidae, Dasyonyginae and Dasyonygidae should all be attributed to Keler (1938a), not<tei:lb/>Eichler (1941). The action of Hopkins (1949) is synonymising the senior family-group (Bovicoli-<tei:lb/>nae) with the junior (Damaliniinae) was taken because he believed Bovicola and Damalinia (the<tei:lb/>type-genera) to be synonyms, and Damalinia is senior to Bovicola. This action is incorrect under<tei:lb/>Article 40 of the Code, however, which states that, at least after 1961, in the case of type-genus<tei:lb/>synonymy the senior family-group name is to be used for the family-group taxon that contains<tei:lb/>both senior and junior synonyms. This Rule can be set aside for such an action if taken before<tei:lb/>1961 , if the name has 'won general acceptance' (Article 40b). The subfamily Damaliniinae sensu<tei:lb/>Hopkins (1949) has rarely if ever been used since, whilst the name Bovicolidae (= Damaliniinae<tei:lb/>sensu Hopkins) has been employed by Eichler (1963) and Keler (1969). The action of Hopkins<tei:lb/>(1949) is therefore rejected.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Keler (1944) included the Trichophilopteridae - a family containing a single genus, parasitic<tei:lb/>on Lemurs - within the Trichodectoidea, although Keler (1969) referred this family to the<tei:lb/>Philopteroidea. Eichler (1963) retained the Trichophilopteridae in the Trichodectoidea, but<tei:lb/>distinguished it as 'interfamily Trichophilopteriformia' as opposed to 'interfamily Trichodecti-<tei:lb/>formia'. Stobbe (19130), Ferris (1933) and Werneck (1948) all considered the affinities of</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTID MAMMAL LICE</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Fig. 38 Classification of Trichodectiformia' according to Eichler (1963). The 'tribes' are indicated by<tei:lb/>square brackets in the appropriate column, the first genus in each 'tribe' being intended by Eichler (1963)<tei:lb/>as the type-genus. See text.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trichophilopterus to lie with the Thilopteridae' rather than with the Trichodectidae. In this<tei:lb/>study no apomorphies were found to indicate a sister-group relationship between Trichophilop-<tei:lb/>terus and all or part of the Trichodectidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Proposed classification</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The proposed classification is derived from the results of a cladistic analysis of the Trichodecti-<tei:lb/>dae (Trichodectiformia sensu Eichler, 1963) at the species level (Figs 23-34). The species are<tei:lb/>grouped on the four criteria discussed below, and ranked according to the principles of phyletic<tei:lb/>sequencing.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holophyly. The classification includes, as far as possible, only holophyletic groups. Some genera<tei:lb/>and subgenera, however, may be found not to follow this criterion (see discussion of Damalinia<tei:lb/>s. str., Dasyonyx and Geomydoecus below).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Utility. Genera are ideally of 'moderate' size and relative morphological uniformity. If a genus is<tei:lb/>large and diverse, recognition is difficult and useful discussion on many aspects of biology or<tei:lb/>distribution prohibited; if genera are too small, identification is time-consuming and discussion</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>242</tei:p>
         <tei:p>C. H. C. LYAL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DASYONYX</tei:p>
         <tei:p>NEODASmim</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PROCAVIPHILVS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>EURtTRICHODECTES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PROCAVICOLA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PKOTELICOLA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FELICOLA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SVRICATOECUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>NEOFELICOLA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CEBIDICOLA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>LORISICOLA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GEOMYDOECUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>STACHIELLA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TRIGONODECTES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>URSODECTES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>EVTRICHOPHILUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BOVICOLA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CERVICOLA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DAHALINIA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>LEPIKENTRON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TRICHOLIPEURUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DASYONYGINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>EURYTRICHODECTIHAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FELICOLINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>EUTRICHOPHILINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BOVICOLINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DASYONYGIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTIDAF.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BOVICOLIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1-/ERNECK1ELLA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 39 Classification of Trichodectoidea' according to Keler (1969).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>again impeded. No 'absolute' size can be recommended, however, as the most satisfactory size<tei:lb/>will depend on a number of properties of the species, and must (in this study) conform to such<tei:lb/>limitations as are imposed by the criterion of holophyly. Subfamilies are chosen in this study to<tei:lb/>aid discussion by providing names for holophyletic groups of genera, and to fulfil the logic of the<tei:lb/>phyletic sequencing convention.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Stability. To ensure that the classification has maximal stability the generic concepts accepted in<tei:lb/>this study conflict as little as possible with established usage.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Distinctness. To facilitate identification, taxa in the genus-group should be as distinct from one<tei:lb/>another as possible. The requirements of Mayr (1969) that genera must be separated by a<tei:lb/>decided gap, and that the 'size' of the gap should be inversely proportional to the size of the<tei:lb/>taxon, are not necessarily compatible with the criterion of holophyly followed here, however,<tei:lb/>and the problem of annectent species (that 'fill' any such gap) has been discussed above. Despite<tei:lb/>the apparent drawback of adherence to holophyletic groups at the expense of inter-generic<tei:lb/>'gaps', it has been possible in this study to produce a key to the genera of Trichodectidae (see<tei:lb/>discussion of keys to genera of Trichodectidae above).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The formation of the genera of Trichodectidae is discussed below, to give an indication of the<tei:lb/>rationale behind each decision. The genera are discussed by subfamily, and the division into<tei:lb/>subfamilies is discussed last.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bovicolinae (Figs 24-27, 40)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This clade was not resolved fully in the analysis, and a primary pentachotomy was obtained. The<tei:lb/>clade has been treated as a single genus (see Table 4), but the diversity of morphology and of<tei:lb/>hosts indicates that this concept is too broad to be of great value. Subdivision of the clade into<tei:lb/>smaller holophyletic groups increases the value of the classification for information retrieval,<tei:lb/>and leads to the acceptance of genera that approach the concepts of Werneck (1950). To obtain a</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTID MAMMAL LICE 243</tei:p>
         <tei:p>measure of conformity each of the five branches of the clade has been accorded generic status.<tei:lb/>The monobasic genera Bisonicola and Tragulicola require no comment, and the genus<tei:lb/>Werneckiella was revised by Moreby (1978). Of the two remaining clades, one corresponds<tei:lb/>approximately to a restricted concept of Bovicola, the other to Damalinia plus Tricholipeurus<tei:lb/>(sensu Werneck, 1950). The Bovicola clade (genus Bovicola) has a primary tetrachotomy, with<tei:lb/>most of the species belonging to only one of the four resultant clades (Fig. 24). The species in this<tei:lb/>large clade are morphologically more similar to one another than they are to any of the species in<tei:lb/>the other three clades. To recognise this morphological divergence (and thus facilitate identifica-<tei:lb/>tion), and to demonstrate in the classification the extent of the phylogenetic knowledge, the four<tei:lb/>branches are each accorded subgeneric status. The Damalinia plus Tricholipeurus clade (genus<tei:lb/>Damalinia} has a primary trichotomy (Fig. 23), and it is clear that discussion of the genus will be<tei:lb/>facilitated by the recognition of each of these branches as a subgenus. Damalinia s. str.<tei:lb/>comprises two major clades, each characterised by the form of an apomorphic development of<tei:lb/>abdominal pleurum II onto the sternum. As discussed above, these two forms may be<tei:lb/>co-apomorphies, or may represent two states in a transformation series. If the latter interpreta-<tei:lb/>tion is correct, one of the clades is probably paraphyletic with respect to the other.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eutrichophilinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Only the single genus Eutrichophilus is included, with no change in generic concept.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dasyonyginae (Figs 28, 29)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The previously-accepted generic concepts in this subfamily remain essentially unchanged at the<tei:lb/>subgenus level. The only change is the transfer of the subgenus Meganarionoides from<tei:lb/>Procavicola to Procaviphilus , and the inclusion of Procaviphilus sclerotis and P. serraticus in P.<tei:lb/>(Meganarionoides). Subgenera are used (as in Werneck, 1941, 1950; Ledger, 1980) as no<tei:lb/>advantage accrues from regarding each of the clades so recognised as a full genus, and<tei:lb/>application of the principles of phyletic sequencing allows retention of all the currently-used<tei:lb/>generic and subgeneric names with no higher taxa required, whereas recognition of all these as<tei:lb/>genera would require the description of a number of intercalating family-group taxa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It is notable that one of the two subgenera of Dasyonyx may be paraphyletic with respect to<tei:lb/>the other, as the subgenera are characterised by apomorphic developments of the teeth of the<tei:lb/>tarsal claws. These may be co-apomorphies or two states in a transformation series (see above).<tei:lb/>If the latter interpretation is correct, one of the subgenera is probably paraphyletic with respect<tei:lb/>to the other.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trichodectinae (Figs 23, 30-33, 40)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The first dichotomy in this clade splits it roughly into Felicola (sensu Ledger, 1980, but without<tei:lb/>Protelicola and with Lorisicola) on one side and Trichodectes (sensu Ledger, 1980, but without<tei:lb/>Neotrichodectes and Trigonodectes , and with Protelicola) on the other. The diversity of<tei:lb/>morphology of the lice, and the variety of hosts infested, indicates that the very broad generic<tei:lb/>concepts endorsed by Ledger (1980) are too inclusive to be of great value in data-retrieval and<tei:lb/>discussion. For this reason the genera proposed here are smaller than those of Ledger (1980)<tei:lb/>and, in some cases, approach the concepts held by Werneck (1948).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Most of the species in the Trichodectes side of the initial dichotomy arise from the three<tei:lb/>branches of an apical trichotomy (Figs 30, 31). The branch of this trichotomy comprising the<tei:lb/>pinguis-galictidis clade corresponds roughly to the concept of Trichodectes held by Werneck<tei:lb/>(1948), whilst the other two branches (the ovalis-zorillae clade and the emeryi-potus clade)<tei:lb/>correspond roughly to Stachiella sensu Werneck (1948) (though fallax, octomaculatus andpotus<tei:lb/>were placed in Trichodectes by Werneck, 1948). However, placing two of the three clades of the<tei:lb/>trichotomy in a taxon Stachiella and excluding the third results in a group that is not<tei:lb/>holophyletic. Recognising each of the three branches of the trichotomy as a separate genus is<tei:lb/>undesirable, as the three intergrade phenetically. The course followed here is to recognise the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>244 C. H. C. LYAL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>genus Trichodectes comprising all three branches, each of these being considered a subgenus<tei:lb/>(Fig. 40). Using the principle of phyletic sequencing the sister-group of Trichodectes is also<tei:lb/>considered a genus, for which the name Werneckodectes is available. Likewise the next three<tei:lb/>branches of this clade are also considered genera. This process necessitates dividing Werneck's<tei:lb/>genus Lutridia into two genera, but retention of the genus as it stood calls for recognition of a<tei:lb/>paraphyletic group in the classification, and, although the species in the two clades comprising<tei:lb/>Lutridia (sensu Werneck, 1948) are superficially similar, some of these similarities may be<tei:lb/>homoplastic.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The other branch of the initial dichotomy of the Trichodectinae clade comprises, as noted<tei:lb/>above, most of the species consigned to Felicola by Ledger (1980) plus the single species of the<tei:lb/>genus Lorisicola (sensu Werneck, 1950). The two branches of this clade (Fig. 23) are each<tei:lb/>considered as genera which, taking the most senior available names, are known as Felicola and<tei:lb/>Lorisicola. For reasons of utility, each genus is divided into two holophyletic subgenera. None of<tei:lb/>the genera or subgenera coincides with any previous generic concept, as such concepts relied<tei:lb/>heavily on head shape and abdominal spiracle number, both of which characters have proved to<tei:lb/>be subject to a considerable degree of homoplasy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In order to maintain the logic of phyletic sequencing, if the Felicola-Lorisicola clade is to be<tei:lb/>considered as comprising two genera, the rank of this clade and of the Trichodectes-Protelicola<tei:lb/>clade must be equal and formally recognised. Use of the tribal category permits this, and the<tei:lb/>family-group names Trichodectini and Felicolini are available (see full classification below). It<tei:lb/>must be stressed that these tribes are inserted to maintain the formal structure of the<tei:lb/>classification, and are not intended (or believed) to have any other significance.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Neotrichodectinae (Fig. 34)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The first dichotomy in this subfamily divides the clade into those species previously assigned to<tei:lb/>the genus Geomydoecus on one side, and species from Neotrichodectes, Lakshminarayanella<tei:lb/>and Trichodectes (sensu Werneck, 1948) on the other. The two branches will be discussed<tei:lb/>separately.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The genus Geomydoecus as previously recognised is fairly uniform in morphology, distribu-<tei:lb/>tion and host species, and may be identified readily. To divide this genus into others would<tei:lb/>inhibit rather than encourage discussion, and the genus is retained in its present form. The two<tei:lb/>subgenera as proposed by Price &amp; Emerson (1972) are also retained though, as indicated above,<tei:lb/>neither are holophyletic groups.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The other branch of the primary dichotomy comprises the 10 species previously assigned to<tei:lb/>the genus Neotrichodectes (considered a subgenus of Trichodectes by Hopkins, 1949 and Ledger,<tei:lb/>1980), the two species previously assigned to the genus Lakshminarayanella (formerly Ly-<tei:lb/>meon), and a single species formerly placed in Trichodectes by most authors (T. barbarae}. The<tei:lb/>clade is plainly close to the established concept of Neotrichodectes, and it is preferable that this<tei:lb/>name is applied to as much of the group as possible. The 10 species of Neotrichodectes auctt. do<tei:lb/>not form a holophyletic group, however, though morphologically they are quite uniform.<tei:lb/>Inclusion of T. barbarae is unlikely to create problems, but Lakshminarayanella (as Lymeon)<tei:lb/>has been placed by some authors in a subfamily of its own (Eichler, 1940, 1963), and considered<tei:lb/>close to the hyrax lice (Keler, 1944; Hopkins, 1949; Eichler, 1963). If Lakshminarayanella is<tei:lb/>synonymised with Neotrichodectes and given no formal recognition it is likely to be raised from<tei:lb/>synonomy by future workers because of its distinctive morphology, leaving Neotrichodectes<tei:lb/>paraphyletic. The course taken here is to recognise Lakshminarayanella as a subgenus of<tei:lb/>Neotrichodectes, which necessitates recognition of four other (holophyletic) subgenera, names<tei:lb/>already being available for two of these. Application of the principles of phyletic sequencing<tei:lb/>permits equal ranking of the subgenera within the genus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subfamilies (Fig. 40)</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Fig. 40 Cladogram of the genera and subgenera of Trichodectidae, with subfamily assignments.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>the principles of phyletic sequencing permitted the use of the subfamily category throughout<tei:lb/>(with the addition of the tribes mentioned above). The limits of the subfamilies were chosen for<tei:lb/>maximum utility, modified by the dictates 01 the sequencing convention. It would be surprising,<tei:lb/>given the high degree of homoplasy of structures in the Trichodectidae, 4f the subfamilies<tei:lb/>fulfilled the criterion 'distinctness' described above and were readily distinguishable. A key to</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>246 C. H. C. LYAL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>subfamilies is provided, however, largely to satisfy the requirements of the International Code of<tei:lb/>Zoological Nomenclature (Article 13) for a description to accompany any new name for,<tei:lb/>although names were available for most of the subfamilies, a single new name is required.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A complete classification of the Trichodectidae to generic level is set out below in phyletic<tei:lb/>sequence (as recommended by Wiley, 1979, 1981).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sequenced classification of the Trichodectidae</tei:p>

         <tei:p>TRICHODECTID MAMMAL LICE 247</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subgenus CONEPATICOLA subgen. n.<tei:lb/>Genus GEOMYDOECUSEwing, 1929<tei:lb/>Subgenus GEOMYDOECUSEv/ing, 1929 (paraphyletic)<tei:lb/>Subgenus THOMOMYDOECUS Price &amp; Emerson, 1972 (polyphyletic?)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Descriptions of genera and subgenera</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The generic and subgeneric descriptions below are arranged by subfamily in the order of the<tei:lb/>sequenced classification of the Trichodectidae (see above).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Descriptions are set out in the following order: paragraph one - head, both sexes, with details<tei:lb/>of sexually-dimorphic features of antennae, if present; paragraph two - thorax, both sexes,<tei:lb/>omitting mention of the anterior setae (on the post-temporal margin) which are present in all<tei:lb/>species; paragraph three - abdomen, both sexes, with details of sexually-dimorphic features of<tei:lb/>the setae, sclerites or shape, if present; fourth paragraph - female terminalia and genitalia; fifth<tei:lb/>paragraph - male subgenital plate, terminalia and genitalia. Descriptions are given of each<tei:lb/>genus as a whole, even where subgenera are present. The descriptions of subgenera (if any are<tei:lb/>present) follow that of the genus in which they are placed, and give only subgeneric characters,<tei:lb/>so that some of the paragraphs listed above may be omitted. Characters that vary between<tei:lb/>subgenera, if mentioned in the generic description, are indicated by an asterisk (**).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Each description is followed by an indication of the host group or groups parasitised, and by<tei:lb/>any pertinent comments on the taxonomy, morphology or biology of some or all of the included<tei:lb/>species. A check-list of all species included in each genus or subgenus is also given, the names<tei:lb/>being placed in alphabetical order. Following each species name in the check-lists is an<tei:lb/>indication of the number of specimens of each sex examined in the study.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Two species have not been placed, and are considered incertae sedis. Trichodectes baculus<tei:lb/>Schommer, 1913; type-host: Caprahircus Linnaeus. Trichodectes tigris Ponton, 1870; type-host:<tei:lb/>Felis tigris Linnaeus. These species are discussed by Werneck (1950).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The subfamilies, genera and subgenera are keyed (p. 335).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BOVICOLINAE Keler</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genus BOVICOLA Ewing<tei:lb/>The genus Bovicola comprises four subgenera.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Anterior of head with osculum absent or, if present, broad and shallow* ; pulvinus of normal<tei:lb/>length or short and not attaining anterior margin of head; dorsal preantennal sulcus present or absent*;<tei:lb/>clypeal marginal carina not or only slightly broadened medially, or broadened to variable degree into bar<tei:lb/>with posterior and anterior margins roughly parallel, bar either straight and at right angles to long axis of<tei:lb/>head or curved and parallel to anterior margin of head* ; anterolateral margin of head smoothly rounded;<tei:lb/>preantennal portion of head short, outline broadly rounded or trapezoid*. Temple margin smoothly<tei:lb/>convex or with posterior projection*, sometimes convexly produced posteriad*. Male scape expanded or<tei:lb/>not expanded* , with setal row apparently present or setae randomly scattered; flagellomeres fused in males<tei:lb/>and females; male flagellum with two basally-articulated 'teeth' and interior face not 'roughened'. Dorsum<tei:lb/>of head with more or less abundant setae , short , long or of moderate length * . Sitophore sclerite unmodified<tei:lb/>or with posterior arms extended*.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thorax with more or less abundant setae, short, long, or of moderate length, frequently longest on<tei:lb/>postero-lateral margin of pterothorax*.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdomen oval or elongate, frequently tapering posteriorly more in male than in female*. Abdominal<tei:lb/>spiracles present on segments HI- VIII. Abdominal setae variable*; anterior setae always present on<tei:lb/>pleura, sometimes on sterna and terga; postero-lateral setae absent. Abdominal pleural projections<tei:lb/>absent. Sclerites present at least on sterna III-VII (males) and III- VIII (females), terga II-VII (males) and<tei:lb/>III-IX (females) and pleura II- VIII; male terga with posterior sclerites present or absent*.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gonapophyses with marginal setae; ventral lobe present, though sometimes not pronounced*. Gona-<tei:lb/>pophyses meet ventral vulval margin acutely, not linked by sclerotised band. Ventral vulval margin not<tei:lb/>sclerotised, or sclerotised only medially; subgenital lobe absent, though small median membranous<tei:lb/>projection may be present (Fig. 42)*. Genital chamber sometimes with median antero-dorsal area lacking<tei:lb/>scales or spicules*.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>248</tei:p>
         <tei:p>C. H. C. LYAL</tei:p>

         <tei:p>HOSTS. Bovidae, Cervidae and Camelidae (Artiodactyla).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. Some species of Bovicola are parthenogenetic, males being rare or unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A summary of the varying taxonomic treatments of Bovicola, its subgenera and synonyms, is presentee<tei:lb/>in Table 3.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>

      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTID MAMMAL LICE 251</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subgenus BOVICOLA Ewing</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 3, 42, 45, 46, 48, 49, 51-54)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bovicola Ewing, 1929: 193. Type-species: Trichodectes caprae Gurlt, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bo vidoecus Bedford, 1929: 518. Type-species: Pediculus bovis Linnaeus, by original designation. [Synony-<tei:lb/>my by Bedford, 1932a: 356.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rhabdopedilon Keler, 1938a: 453. Type-species: Trichodectes longicornis Nitzsch, by original designation.<tei:lb/>[Synonymy by Werneck, 1950: 59.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Clypeal marginal carina not broadened medially, or more or less broadened into bar with<tei:lb/>posterior margin straight or matching curvature of osculum. Temple margin smoothly convex, lacking<tei:lb/>projection on postero-lateral angle, not convexly produced posteriad to great extent. Male scape not<tei:lb/>expanded or only slightly expanded. Dorsum of head with setae short or of moderate length, of greater<tei:lb/>abundance anteriorly than posteriorly. Sitophore sclerite unmodified.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thorax with lateral and dorsal setae long and of moderate length, sometimes abundant and numerous on<tei:lb/>disc of prothorax and pterothorax, otherwise less abundant and sparsely scattered on disc of pterothorax<tei:lb/>with only two setae present on disc of prothorax; setae present along lateral margins and posteriorly<tei:lb/>(dorsally) on prothorax and pterothorax; posterior setal row of prothorax marginal, with median gap<tei:lb/>present or absent; posterior setal row of pterothorax submarginal, with median gap absent, row<tei:lb/>incorporating two very long setae between postero-lateral and postero-median angles or, if setae generally<tei:lb/>abundant on thorax, postero-lateral setae of pterothorax longer than others.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdominal setae short, long or of medium length; setal bases, at least of setae of posterior setal row on<tei:lb/>sterna and terga, enlarged, clearly with doubled margins. Pregenital sclerites present on sterna and terga<tei:lb/>(where present) of all segments, except sometimes tergum I and (independently) tergum VIII of males;<tei:lb/>terga of males, at least of segments IV- VI, with both anterior and posterior sclerites.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gonapophyses with lobe rectangular, acute, rounded or not pronounced; marginal setae confined to<tei:lb/>lobe, long. Ventral vulval margin not sclerotised; convex, biconvex with median indentation, or convex<tei:lb/>with small median membranous projection (Fig. 42); margin smooth or spinose. Postgenital area lacking<tei:lb/>spinose patch. Genital chamber with antero-median dorsal area lacking spicules, scales or other decora-<tei:lb/>tion , either very narrow and strongly-defined or wide and ill-defined , or with very narrow longitudinal fold .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male subgenital plate variable; stqrnites VII and IX present, fused to s.g.p.r., sternite VIII absent or, if<tei:lb/>present, fused or not fused to s.g.p.r. (Figs 46, 48). Pseudostyli absent (Fig. 49) or, if present, setose and<tei:lb/>lobulate (Figs 46, 48). Basal apodeme very concave anteriorly, the sides of the concavity frequently being<tei:lb/>parallel, though sometimes obscure. Parameres with broad basal flange or block; sometimes very reduced.<tei:lb/>Basiparameral sclerites present and fused, or absent. Mesomeres, if fused apically, forming very narrow<tei:lb/>arch lacking median extension; otherwise mesomeres not fused, sometimes very reduced and obscure.<tei:lb/>Male genitalia depicted in Figs 51-54.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Bovidae and Cervidae (Artiodactyla).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. Some of the species in this subgenus are parthenogenetic.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SPECIES INCLUDED<tei:lb/>alpinus Keler, 1942 (5 cf , 3 $)<tei:lb/>bovis (Linnaeus, 1758) (7 cf, 137 9)<tei:lb/>caprae (Gurlt, 1843) (c.50 Cf , c.50 $)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>concavifrons (Hopkins, 1960) [Recalled from synonymy with longicornis (Nitzsch).] (2 cf , 98 9)<tei:lb/>jellisoni Emerson, 1962 (10 cf , 10 $)<tei:lb/>7/mbafus(Gervais, 1844) (c.SOcT, c.65 9)<tei:lb/>longicornis (Nitzsch, 1818) (44 $)<tei:lb/>oreamnidis (Hopkins, 1960) (holotype cf)<tei:lb/>ov/s(Schrank, 1781) (59 cf, 64 9)<tei:lb/>tarandi (Mjoberg, 1910) (2 $ , 7 nymphs)<tei:lb/>t/Wa/is(Piaget, 1880) (c.100 9)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subgenus HOLAKARTIKOS Keler gen. rev., stat. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 44, 47, 57)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holakartikos Keler, 1938a: 461. Type-species: Trichodectes pilosus Piaget (nee Giebel) [= Trichodectes<tei:lb/>crassipes Rudow], by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Anterior of head with osculum absent; pulvinus very short, not attaining anterior margin of</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>252 C. H. C. LYAL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>head; dorsal preantennal sulcus absent, though ventral preantennal sulcus sometimes present; clypeal<tei:lb/>marginal carina not always pronounced and not, or only slightly, broadened medially; preantennal portion<tei:lb/>of head very short, outline smoothly and shallowly rounded. Temple margin smoothly convex, lacking<tei:lb/>projection on postero-lateral angle, convexly produced posteriad. Male scape very slightly expanded, with<tei:lb/>setae randomly scattered. Dorsum of head with abundant setae of moderate length; temple with long<tei:lb/>postero-lateral marginal setae. Sitophore sclerite unmodified.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thorax with abundant setae, long and of moderate length, present on margins and disc of prothorax and<tei:lb/>pterothorax; setae longest on the rounded postero-lateral angles of prothorax and ptero thorax.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdomen with long setae of posterior setal row, and shorter anterior setae, present on sterna, terga and<tei:lb/>pleura (where present) of all segments (Fig. 47). Pre-genital sclerites sometimes very faint, present on<tei:lb/>sterna and terga (where present) of all segments except tergum I and sternum II; male terga lacking<tei:lb/>posterior sclerites.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gonapophyses with broadly rounded lobe smoothly continuous with ventral margin; marginal setae<tei:lb/>long, present all along ventral margin, including lobe. Ventral vulval margin not sclerotised; produced into<tei:lb/>three weakly-developed lobes. Postgenital pleural area with patch of short, spine-like setae. Genital<tei:lb/>chamber lacking dorsal non-ornamented area or fold.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male subgenital plate with s.g.p.r. not joining sternites VII and VIII, and sometimes failing to contact<tei:lb/>either or both; sternites sometimes very faintly sclerotised, obscure; s.g.p.r. with broad lateral flange on<tei:lb/>VIII and IX (Fig. 47). Pseudostyli absent. Male genital opening dorsal. Basal apodeme long, not concave<tei:lb/>anteriorly. Parameres long, slender, with basal block and flange. Basiparameral sclerites absent. Meso-<tei:lb/>meres fused apically, with median extension present (see comments below). Male genitalia depicted in Fig.<tei:lb/>57.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Bovidae (Artiodactyla).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. The only included species is not known to be parthenogenetic.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Werneck (1950) failed to recognise the median extension of the mesomeral arch, and considered it<tei:lb/>absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holakartikos was considered a synonym of Bovicola by Werneck (1950) and Emerson &amp; Price (1981); a<tei:lb/>more extensive history of the variations in status of this subgenus is presented in Table 3.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SPECIES INCLUDED<tei:lb/>crassipes(Rudow, 1866) (24 cf, 31 $)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subgenus LEPIKENTRONKeler gen. rev., stat. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 43, 55)<tei:lb/>Lepikentron Keler, 1938a: 452. Type-species: Trichodectes breviceps Rudow, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Anterior of head with osculum absent; pulvinus very short, not attaining anterior of margin<tei:lb/>of head; dorsal preantennal sulcus absent; clypeal marginal carina not pronounced, not broadened<tei:lb/>medially; preantennal portion of head shorter in male than female, outline broadly and smoothly rounded.<tei:lb/>Temple margin smoothly convex, lacking projection on postero-lateral angle, not convexly produced<tei:lb/>posteriad to great extent. Male scape expanded, with setal row apparently present, though setae may be<tei:lb/>scattered randomly. Dorsum of head with setae of moderate length, slender; setae sparsely distributed,<tei:lb/>more abundant anteriorly than posteriorly. Sitophore sclerite unmodified.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thorax with lateral and dorsal setae slender, long and of moderate length; setae present postero-<tei:lb/>laterally and posteriorly on prothorax and along lateral margins and posteriorly (dorsally) on pterothorax;<tei:lb/>posterior setal row of prothorax submarginal, sparse, with large median gap; posterior setal row of<tei:lb/>pterothorax submarginal, with small median gap, setae shorter medially than laterally, with two long setae<tei:lb/>laterally; pair of setae, widely spaced, present on disc of prothorax dorsally; setae not present on disc of<tei:lb/>pterothorax.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdominal setae of moderate length, slender; anterior setae never present on sterna and terga.<tei:lb/>Pre-genital sclerites present on terga II-VII (males) and terga III-IX (females) and sterna III-VII (males)<tei:lb/>and III- VIII (females); male terga III-VII with both anterior and posterior sclerites, though the posterior<tei:lb/>elements may be very faintly sclerotised and difficult to see.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gonapophyses with small, pronounced lobe and broad tapering spur (Fig. 43); marginal setae confined<tei:lb/>to lobe. Genital chamber lacking median non-ornamented area or fold.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male subgenital plate with sternite VII fused to s.g.p.r. and sternites VIII and IX absent; s.g.p.r. broad.<tei:lb/>Pseudostyli absent. Male genital opening poste/o-dorsal. Basal apodeme slightly longer than parameres,</tei:p>

         <tei:p>HOSTS. Camelidae (Artiodactyla).</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Subgenus SPINIBOVICOLA subgen. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 12, 41, 50, 56)<tei:lb/>Type-species: Trichodectes hemitragi Cummings.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Anterior of head with osculum absent; pulvinus very short, but attaining anterior margin of<tei:lb/>head; dorsal preantennal sulcus absent; clypeal marginal carina broadened medially into straight bar with<tei:lb/>posterior margin slightly irregular; anterolateral margin of head smoothly rounded; preantennal portion<tei:lb/>short, with outline rounded, almost straight anteriorly. Male scape<tei:lb/>slightly expanded, with setae randomly scattered. Dorsum of head with abundant setae of moderate<tei:lb/>length. Sitophore sclerite with posterior arms extended (Fig. 12).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thorax with dorsal and lateral setae abundant, long or of moderate length, present marginally and on<tei:lb/>disc of prothorax and pterothorax; longest setae present postero-laterally on pterothorax.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdomen tapering more acutely in male than in female. Male genitalia depicted in Fig. 56.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Genus WERNECKIELLA Eichler gen. rev.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 61, 62)<tei:lb/>Werneckiella Eichler, 1940: 160. Type-species: Trichodectes equi Denny, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Anterior of head with osculum absent; pulvinus not attaining margin; dorsal preantennal<tei:lb/>sulcus present; clypeal marginal carina slightly broader medially than laterally, or not broadened;<tei:lb/>anterolateral margin of head smoothly convex; preantennal portion of head not long, outline broadly<tei:lb/>rounded, sometimes slightly flattened anteriorly. Temple margin convex or rectangular. Male scape<tei:lb/>expanded, with setae randomly scattered; flagellomeres fused in males and females; male flagellum with<tei:lb/>two basally-articulated 'teeth'; male flagellum not 'roughened' on interior face. Dorsum of head with<tei:lb/>abundant short setae. Sitophore sclerite unmodified.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thorax with lateral and dorsal setae short and of medium length; setae present along lateral margins and<tei:lb/>posteriorly (dorsally) on prothorax and pterothorax; posterior setal row on prothorax marginal, with<tei:lb/>median gap; posterior setal row on pterothorax marginal or submarginal, with no median gap; posterior<tei:lb/>setal row of pterothorax incorporating two very long setae with intervening shorter setae between<tei:lb/>postero-lateral and postero-median angles; prothorax with seta or setae on disc laterally (dorsally).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdomen elongate-oval. Abdominal spiracles present on segments III-VIII. Abdomen with setae short<tei:lb/>and of moderate length; anterior setae frequently present on sterna and terga, always present on pleura;<tei:lb/>postero-lateral setae absent. Abdominal pleural projections absent. Sclerites present on abdominal pleura<tei:lb/>II- VII and sterna and terga of at least abdominal segments II- VII; male terga with single sclerites only.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gonapophyses broad, truncate, with median faces almost parallel to one another; marginal setae of<tei:lb/>moderate length; ventral lobe absent. Gonapophyses meet ventral vulval margin acutely, not linked by<tei:lb/>sclerotised band. Ventral vulval margin not sclerotised, very short, straight; subgenital lobe absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male subgenital plate with sternite VII present and fused to s.g.p.r., sternites VIII and IX absent;<tei:lb/>s.g.p.r. sinuate and broadest on sternum VIII (Fig. 61). Pseudostyli present, small, simple setose lobes.<tei:lb/>Male genital opening postero-dorsal. Parameres long, straight or flared and twisted medially, sometimes<tei:lb/>fused basally. Basiparameral sclerites absent. Mesomeres fused or almost fused into pentagonal mesomer-<tei:lb/>al arch with median extension absent; mesomeres broadest basally (external to b.a.l.s.) and more or less<tei:lb/>broad distally; mesomeres projecting basally between b.a.l.s. to contact parameres. Male genitalia<tei:lb/>depicted in Fig. 62.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Equidae (Perissodactyla) and Bovidae (Artiodactyla).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. Some species are parthenogenetic, the males being unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Werneckiella was considered a subgenus of Damalinia by Hopkins (1949) and a synonym of Bovicola by<tei:lb/>Werneck (1950); it is here raised from synonomy with Bovicola. A more extensive history of the variations<tei:lb/>in status of this genus is presented in Table 3. The genus was revised by Moreby (1978).</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Genus DAMALINIA Mjoberg<tei:lb/>The genus Damalinia comprises three subgenera.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Anterior of head with osculum present, narrow or broad, deep or shallow, or osculum<tei:lb/>absent, in which case head as described below for D. (T.) conectens*; dorsal preantennal sulcus present or<tei:lb/>absent*; clypeal marginal carina more or less broadened medially and of variable form*; anterolateral<tei:lb/>margin of head straight, slightly concave, slightly sinuate or convex; preantennal portion of head of<tei:lb/>variable length, outline triangular, trapezoid, rectangular or rounded*.          <tei:p>Gonapophyses variable; ventral margin without rounded lobe, but sometimes with hook-shaped<tei:lb/>projection*; marginal setae present. Gonapophyses meet ventral vulval margin acutely, not joined by<tei:lb/>sclerotised band. Ventral vulval margin sclerotised or not sclerotised; subgenital lobe present or absent*.<tei:lb/>Dorsal margin of vulva and post-vulval area with or without pointed scales*. Common oviduct, at<tei:lb/>branching point, with or without collar (see subgenus Cervicola)*.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male subgenital plate variable, sternites VII and VIII always being present and fused to s.g.p.r. , sternite<tei:lb/>IX sometimes modified. Pseudostyli absent or, if present, of variable form*. Posterior margins of tergum</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTID MAMMAL LICE</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Subgenus DAMALINIA Mjoberg</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 11, 68, 71-76)<tei:lb/>Damalinia Mjoberg, 1910: 69. Type-species: Trichodectes crenelatus Piaget, by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Anterior of head with osculum present, narrow or broad, deep or shallow; dorsal preanten-<tei:lb/>nal sulcus present; clypeal marginal carina broadened medially either into more or less developed simple</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTID MAMMAL LICE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>261</tei:p>
         <tei:p>81</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 81-86 Damalinia species, cf genitalia. 81, D. (Tricholipeurus) victoriae. 82, D. (T.) indica. 83, D.<tei:lb/>(T.) aepycerus. 84, D. (Cervicola) hopkinsi. 85, D. (C.) meyeri. 86, D. (C.) reduncae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>bar with posterior margin straight or concave, or into more or less broad U-shaped sclerite, or into broad,<tei:lb/>heavily-sclerotised margin of deep osculum; anterolateral margin of head convex or slightly sinuate, in the<tei:lb/>latter case slightly concave at junction of margin and clypeof rental sulcus and convex anteriorly;<tei:lb/>preantennal portion longer or shorter than posterior portion, outline triangular, trapezoid or rounded,<tei:lb/>sometimes with slight protuberances on either side of osculum. Temple margin smoothly convex, slightly<tei:lb/>produced posteriad, sometimes with postero-lateral angle developed laterally, or with small posterior<tei:lb/>rounded projection. Male scape with setae randomly scattered; male flagellum with two basally-articulated<tei:lb/>'teeth'. Dorsum of head with setae more or less abundant.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>262 C. H. C. LYAL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pterothorax with posterior setal row sometimes irregular or 'doubled'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdomen oval or elongate, sometimes very narrowly elongate. Abdominal setae present anteriorly on<tei:lb/>all pleura, occasionally on terga and sterna, but only laterally and as irregularity or 'doubling' of posterior<tei:lb/>setal row. Pleurum II with sclerite extending broadly or narrowly onto sternum II and sometimes tergum<tei:lb/>II, frequently 'crowding' sternite or tergite II (Fig. 68); pleurites not reduced in size or absent; tergum I<tei:lb/>lacking sclerite; male terga V and VI (at least) with both anterior and posterior sclerites.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gonapophyses variable, sometimes hook-shaped, though lacking distal spur, more frequently obtuse,<tei:lb/>sometimes with ventral (median) margin concave or convex; ventral margin with setae long or of moderate<tei:lb/>length, abundant, setae sometimes also present on anterior margin. Ventral vulval margin not sclerotised,<tei:lb/>sometimes short, straight or convex; subgenital lobe absent, though posterior margin of sternum VII<tei:lb/>sometimes developed into two spikes (Fig. 73). Dorsal margin of vulva and postvulval area usually without<tei:lb/>pointed scales. Common oviduct without 'collar'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male subgenital plate with sternites VII, VIII and IX fused to s.g.p.r. , sternite IX and postgenital sclerite<tei:lb/>sometimes fused; s.g.p.r. more heavily sclerotised than sternites (Fig. 68). Pseudostyli absent or, if<tei:lb/>present, long and broad, parallel-sided or with basal constriction (Figs 68, 71), or long and narrow (Fig.<tei:lb/>72). Posterior margin of tergum IX not greatly expanded. Parameres more or less broad, sometimes fused<tei:lb/>together. Basiparameral sclerites absent. Mesomeres unfused apically, sometimes fused to b.a.l.s. in<tei:lb/>characteristic manner (Fig. 75) or to parameres, basally or in entirety, in the latter case apparently absent.<tei:lb/>Endophallus lacking spicular patch (cf. subgenus Tricholipeurus). Male genitalia depicted in Figs 7476.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Bovidae (Artiodactyla).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. Emerson &amp; Price (1982) distinguish their new species orientalis (described in Bovicold) from<tei:lb/>the very similar species thompsoni Bedford on the following grounds: The female of B. orientalis is smaller<tei:lb/>than that of B. thompsoni and the lateral margins of the forehead are even [sic] so slightly indented for B.<tei:lb/>orientalis and always even for B. thompsoni; the median plates on tergites II- VIII are of different shapes<tei:lb/>for the two species; the chaetotaxy of terminal abdominal segments is different, with each gonapophysis<tei:lb/>having at least 20 median and anterior setae for B. thompsoni [orientalis having, according to the preceding<tei:lb/>description, 12-17 setae]; and the posterior margin of the temple of B. thompsoni has small projections that<tei:lb/>are not present for B. orientalis. The male of B. thompsoni is unknown.' Five male and seven female<tei:lb/>paratypes of B. orientalis were examined in this study, together with a further eight males and eight females<tei:lb/>from the same host (Capricornis crispus swinhoei) not examined by Emerson &amp; Price when they prepared<tei:lb/>their description of orientalis, and three females of thompsoni, including the holotype. Treating the<tei:lb/>supposed distinguishing characters in order, the three specimens of thompsoni are larger than any of the<tei:lb/>females from C. c. swinhoei; whilst none of the specimens of thompsoni has an indentation on the forehead<tei:lb/>(at the junction of the clypeo-frontal sulcus with the margin), not all of the specimens from Capricornis c.<tei:lb/>swinhoei have either; the shapes of abdominal tergites II- VIII are not significantly different in the two<tei:lb/>species; the chaetotaxy of the terminal abdominal segments is not different, and no specimen of thompsoni<tei:lb/>has more than 17 setae on the median and anterior margins of the gonapophyses; the small projections of<tei:lb/>the posterior temple margins are present in all specimens of orientalis. It seems, therefore, that the<tei:lb/>differences between the two species are twofold: host (orientalis being described from Capricornis crispus<tei:lb/>swinhoei and thompsoni being known only from Capricornis sumatrensis sumartrensis) , and size. The<tei:lb/>biological significance of the latter character is not clear, and the two species may be found to differ in other<tei:lb/>characters not so far discovered. Until a larger sample can be examined, collected from more localities, no<tei:lb/>taxonomic action is taken to reduce the rank or synonymise orientalis, though on the basis of the<tei:lb/>information so far available the species probably should not stand.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SPECIES INCLUDED</tei:p>

         <tei:p>TRICHODECTID MAMMAL LICE 263</tei:p>
         <tei:p>semitheileri Emerson &amp; Price, 1971 (holotype cf , allotype $)</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Subgenus CERVICOLA Keler gen. rev., stat. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 66, 67, 70, 77, 78, 84-86)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cervicola Keler, 1934: 263. [Nomen nudum.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cervicola Keler, 1938a: 460. Type-species: Trichodectes tibialis Keler (nee Piaget) [= Trichodectes meyeri<tei:lb/>Taschenberg], by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Anterior of head with osculum present, narrow or broad, deep or shallow; dorsal preanten-<tei:lb/>nal sulcus present; clypeal marginal carina broadened medially, either into simple bar with posterior<tei:lb/>margin straight or convex but occasionally with median posterior projection, or into longer posteriorly-<tei:lb/>developed sclerite with posterolateral angles more or less convex and more or less pronounced median<tei:lb/>posterior projection; anterolateral margin of head straight or slightly sinuate, in the latter case slightly<tei:lb/>concave at junction of margin and clypeof rental sulcus and convex anteriorly; preantennal portion of head<tei:lb/>as long as or shorter than postantennal portion, outline triangular, trapezoid or rounded. Temple margin<tei:lb/>smoothly convex, slightly produced posteriad. Male scape with setae randomly scattered; male flagellum<tei:lb/>with two basally-articulated 'teeth'. Dorsum of head with setae more or less abundant, sometimes less so<tei:lb/>posteriorly than anteriorly.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pterothorax with posterior setal row single.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdomen oval or elongate. Abdominal setae present anteriorly on all pleura except, occasionally,<tei:lb/>pleurum II, but may be very short, fine and difficult to see; anterior setae never on sterna and terga.<tei:lb/>Pleurum II never with sclerite extending onto sternum II; pleurites not reduced in size or absent; male terga<tei:lb/>V and VI (at least) with both anterior and posterior sclerites.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gonapophyses hook-shaped, apex of curved portion acute or rounded, sometimes with distal (dorsal)<tei:lb/>spur (Figs 66, 67). Gonapophyses with setae long or of moderate length on posterior margin and sometimes<tei:lb/>on apex of 'hook', smaller setae sometimes present on anterior margin of 'hook'. Ventral vulval margin not<tei:lb/>sclerotised. Subgenital lobe absent. Dorsal margin of vulva and post-vulval area with pointed scales.<tei:lb/>Common oviduct at branching-point with folded and more or less apparent 'collar', sometimes partially<tei:lb/>sclerotised and refracting light when viewed in phase-contrast or bright field transmitted light.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male subgenital plate with sternites VII, VIII and IX fused to s.g.p.r. , though sternite IX sometimes not<tei:lb/>complete, s.g.p.r. sometimes not attaining posterior margin of segment IX, perisetal gaps sometimes<tei:lb/>absent; s.g.p.r. more heavily sclerotised than sternites. Pseudostyli absent or, if present, apically pointed<tei:lb/>and more or less broad (Fig. 78) or apically rounded and very narrow (Fig. 77). Posterior margins of male<tei:lb/>tergum IX not greatly expanded. Parameres broad or narrow, larger or smaller than mesomeres, may be<tei:lb/>reduced to small discs, in which case mesomeres absent; parameres fused or unfused; apices sometimes<tei:lb/>widely divergent. Basiparameral sclerites present or absent. Mesomeres absent or, if present, not fused<tei:lb/>apically, nor fused to parameres or b.a.l.s. Endophallus lacking spicular patch (cf. subgenus Tricho-<tei:lb/>lipeurus).^ Male genitalia depicted in Figs 84-86.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Bovidae and Cervidae (Artiodactyla).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. Cervicola was treated as a synonym of Damalinia by Werneck (1950), and of both Damalinia<tei:lb/>and Bovicola by Hopkins &amp; Clay (1952, pp. 102 and 67 respectively). The history of the variations in status<tei:lb/>of Cervicola is presented in Table 3.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SPECIES INCLUDED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>annectens Hopkins, 1943 comb. rev. from Tricholipeurus (21 cf , 25 $)<tei:lb/>forficula (Piaget, 1880) (5 cf , 8 $)<tei:lb/>hendrickxi Hopkins, 1947 (4 cf , 6 $)<tei:lb/>hopkinsi Bedford, 1936 (15 cf , 28 $)<tei:lb/>lerouxi (Bedford, 1930) comb. n. from Tricholipeurus (9 $)<tei:lb/>maa/ Emerson &amp; Price, 1973 (holotype cf , allotype $)<tei:lb/>martinaglia (Bedford, 1936) (34 cf , 27 $)<tei:lb/>meyeri meyeri (Taschenberg, 1882) (5 cf , 54 $)<tei:lb/>meyeri hydropotis (Dobroruka, 1975) comb. n. from Cervicola<tei:lb/>meyeri sika (Dobroruka, 1975) comb. n. from Cervicola<tei:lb/>muntiacus (Seguy, 1948) (12 cf , 12 $)<tei:lb/>natalensis Emerson, 1964 (2 cf , 2 $)</tei:p>
