      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>264 C. H. C. LYAL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>reduncae (Bedford, 1929) stat. n., comb. n. from Tricholipeurus [Raised from subspecies of D.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>trabeculae.} (2% &lt;3, 29%)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>trabeculae (Bedford, 1929) comb. n. from Tricholipeurus (10 cf , 10 $)<tei:lb/>Uganda? (Werneck, 1950) stat. n., comb. n. from Tricholipeurus [Raised from subspecies of D.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>trabeculae.] (14 cf , 13 $)<tei:lb/>Unless otherwise stated, all species were previously considered as placed in Damalinia s. str.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subgenus TRICHOLIPEURUS Bedford stat. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 4, 7, 8, 13,65,79-83)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tricholipeurus Bedford, 1929: 514. Type-species: Tricholipeurus aepycerus Bedford, by original designa-<tei:lb/>tion.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Anterior of head variable, one of two types.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(a) Osculum absent; pulvinus short, not attaining anterior margin of head; dorsal preantennal sulcus<tei:lb/>absent; clypeal marginal carina insignificant, not, or only slightly, broadened medially; anterolateral<tei:lb/>margin of head straight posteriorly, convex anteriorly; preantennal portion of head as long as postantennal<tei:lb/>portion, outline rounded anteriorly (D. (T.) conectens only).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(b) Osculum present, rarely deep; dorsal preantennal sulcus present; clypeal marginal carina broadened<tei:lb/>medially either into simple bar with posterior margin straight or convex, or into longer posteriorly-<tei:lb/>developed U- or W-shaped sclerite, with posterolateral angles more or less acutely convex, and frequently<tei:lb/>with more or less pronounced median posterior projection; anterolateral margin straight, slightly sinuate,<tei:lb/>or slightly concave; preantennal portion of head longer or shorter than postantennal portion but not short,<tei:lb/>outline trapezoid or rectangular. Temple margin smoothly convex, more or less convexly produced<tei:lb/>posteriorly. Male scape with setal row frequently present, comprising four or five setae, though setae<tei:lb/>sometimes more or less randomly scattered; male flagellum with two or three basally- articulated 'teeth'.<tei:lb/>Dorsum of head with setae sometimes sparse.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pro thorax with median gap of posterior setal row sometimes almost the width of the posterior margin.<tei:lb/>Pterothorax with posterior setal row single.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdomen usually very elongate, narrow. Abdominal setae present anteriorly on all pleura except,<tei:lb/>occasionally, pleurum II, but may be very short, fine and difficult to see; anterior setae never on sterna and<tei:lb/>rarely on terga. Pleurum II never with sclerite extending onto sternum II; pleural sclerites frequently<tei:lb/>reduced to small anterior plate or absent; tergum I sometimes lacking sclerite; male terga lacking posterior<tei:lb/>sclerites, or with both anterior and posterior sclerites present on at least segments V and VI (though may be<tei:lb/>present on any segments up to II- VIII).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gonapophyses variable, sometimes hook-shaped with distal spur and marginal setae on posterior<tei:lb/>(dorsal) margin of 'hook', or long with ventral margin convex, straight or sinuate (though not with lobe),<tei:lb/>apically pointed or rounded; marginal setae of moderate length. Ventral vulval margin sometimes<tei:lb/>sclerotised; subgenital lobe present, variable, not marginally serrate, ventrally smooth or scaled. Dorsal<tei:lb/>margin of vulva and post-vulval area without pointed scales. Common oviduct without 'collar'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male subgenital plate with sternites VII, VIII and IX fused to s.g.p.r.; perisetal gaps sometimes large,<tei:lb/>occasionally absent; s.g.p.r. heavily sclerotised and sternites sometimes very lightly scerlotised; s.g.p.r.<tei:lb/>sometimes curved or sinuate (Fig. 80). Pseudostyli absent or, if present, variable, short and rounded or<tei:lb/>apically angular, posteriorly or medially directed, narrow or broad, sometimes fused to form single caudal<tei:lb/>projection. Posterior margins of male tergum IX frequently greatly expanded (Fig. 79). Lateral struts of<tei:lb/>basal apodeme sometimes with anteposterior spur (Fig. 83). Parameres unfused or, if fused, plate apically<tei:lb/>pointed or bifurcate. Basiparameral sclerites present or absent. Mesomeres unfused apically or, if fused,<tei:lb/>symmetric or asymmetric, median extension absent or present; mesomeral arch frequently recurved<tei:lb/>abruptly at base to contact parameres, sometimes extended between b.a.l.s.; mesomeres not fused to<tei:lb/>parameres or b.a.l.s. Endophallus with patch of regularly-arranged and numerous spicules sometimes very<tei:lb/>apparent. Male genitalia depicted in Figs 81-83.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Bovidae and Cervidae (Artiodactyla).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. Damalinia (T.) longiceps is included following the statement of Clay &amp; Hopkins (1955) that it<tei:lb/>resembles D. (T.) spinifer Hopkins 'most closely among known species'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tricholipeurus has been treated as a genus, synonym (Hopkins, 1943) and subgenus (Hopkins, 1949) of<tei:lb/>Damalinia; the history of the variations in status of Tricholipeurus is presented in Table 3.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>moschatus (Emerson &amp; Price, 1971) comb. n. from Tricholipeurus (holotype cf , disassociated cf head)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>pakenhami (Werneck, 1947) comb. n. from Tricholipeurus (21 cf , 20 $)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>parallels (Osborn, 1896) comb. n. from Tricholipeurus (50 cf , 106 $)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>parkeri (Hopkins, 1941) comb. n. from Tricholipeurus (10 cf , 10 $)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>spinifer Hopkins, 1943 comb. rev. from Tricholipeurus (17 cf , 16 $)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>victoriae Hopkins, 1943 comb. rev. from Tricholipeurus (33 Cf , 35 $)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>EUTRICHOPHILINAE Keler</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genus EUTRICHOPHILUS Mjoberg</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 87-93)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eutrichophilus Mjoberg, 1910: 71. Type-species: Eutrichophilus cercolabes Mjoberg, by subsequent<tei:lb/>designation (Harrison, 1916a: 21).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Anterior of head with osculum present or absent, but pulvinus always attaining margin;<tei:lb/>dorsal preantennal sulcus absent; clypeal marginal carina with median expansion absent or slight, or<tei:lb/>present as broad or narrow parallel-sided bar with transverse margins convex, straight, or concave;<tei:lb/>anterolateral margin of head straight or convex; preantennal portion of head long or short; outline<tei:lb/>triangular, rounded or broadly trapezoid. Temple margin convex or with posterolateral angle apparent;<tei:lb/>temples greatly expanded posteriad (Fig. 87). Male scape expanded, with longitudinal setal row present<tei:lb/>and comprising two setae; male flagellomeres fused; female flagellomeres fused or flagellum comprising<tei:lb/>two flagellomeres; male flagellum very long, with two basally-articulated 'teeth'. Dorsum of head with<tei:lb/>setae short or long, sometimes longer anteriorly than posteriorly. Sitophore sclerite unmodified.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thorax with dorsal setae short or of moderate length marginally or submarginally on posterior of<tei:lb/>prothorax and pterothorax, absent from disc of both; one or two long setae on posterolateral margins of<tei:lb/>pterothorax.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdomen oval and elongate. Abdominal spiracles present on segments III- VIII. Abdominal setae short<tei:lb/>or of moderate length, with tufts of long setae on at least pleurum VIII, sometimes also pleurum VII<tei:lb/>(males) or IX (females) (Fig. 88); anterior setae present on all pleura but absent from sterna and terga;<tei:lb/>postero-lateral setae present. Abdominal pleura lacking projections dorsally or ventrally. Sclerites present<tei:lb/>on sterna, terga and pleura (where present) of all pre-genital abdominal segments except, sometimes,<tei:lb/>tergum I, which may be very small; male terga, at least of abdominal segments V and VI, with anterior and<tei:lb/>posterior sclerites.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gonapophyses frequently large, broadly triangular or rounded, ventral margin lacking lobe but with<tei:lb/>more or less dense marginal setae which are long or of moderate length. Gonapophyses meet ventral vulval<tei:lb/>margin acutely, not linked by sclerotised band. Ventral vulval margin not sclerotised; smoothly convex,<tei:lb/>with or without median indentation or setose projection; subgenital lobe absent. Female terminalia<tei:lb/>depicted in Fig. 90.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male subgenital plate with sternites VII and VIII present and fused to s.g.p.r. , IX absent or, if present,<tei:lb/>fused to s.g.p.r. (Fig. 88). Pseudostyli absent. Male genital opening dorsal, male segment IX posterior.<tei:lb/>Parameres long or short, narrow or broad; with basiparameral sclerite or flange sometimes present and<tei:lb/>fused medially, thus linking parameres, but otherwise unfused. Mesomeres present, fused apically to form<tei:lb/>arch with no median extension; arch smoothly rounded, or with lateral desclerotisations, in which case<tei:lb/>median portion is straight and at right angles to lateral portions, very poorly sclerotised and thin, or absent.<tei:lb/>Male genitalia depicted in Figs 89, 91, 92.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>

         <tei:p>268</tei:p>
         <tei:p>C. H. C. LYAL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 94 Cebidicola armatus, 9 terminalia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>,/</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 95 Cebidicola armatus, cf abdomen.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>TRICHODECTID MAMMAL LICE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>98</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 96-99 Cebidicola species. 96, C. semistriatus , $ head, dorsal. 97, C. armatus, 9 head, dorsal. 98, C.<tei:lb/>armatus, cf genitalia. 99, C. extrarius, C? genitalia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Anterior of head with osculum present, deep; dorsal preantennal sulcus present or absent;<tei:lb/>clypeal marginal carina broadened medially into dorsal, posteriorly convex, sclerite; anterolateral margin<tei:lb/>straight, slightly convex, concave or sinuate anteriorly, more or less abruptly concave at junction with<tei:lb/>clypeof rental sulcus, with or without anterior sclerotised projection on either side of osculum (Figs 96, 97);<tei:lb/>preantennal outline broadly triangular. Temple margin convex or slightly acute and angular posterolateral-<tei:lb/>ly, with eyes more or less prominent (Figs 96, 97). Male scape expanded, with setal row present and<tei:lb/>comprising two or more setae; male flagellomeres fused, with two basally-articulated 'teeth'; female<tei:lb/>flagellomeres fused or unfused. Dorsum of head with setae short or of moderate length, sparse. Sitophore<tei:lb/>sclerite unmodified.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tarsal claws lacking ventral spines or teeth. Postcoxale absent or present, not greatly developed.<tei:lb/>Thoracic setae present dorsally only along posterior and posterolateral margins of pterothorax; setae short<tei:lb/>medially, longer laterally. Atrium of thoracic spiracle tubular or conical.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdomen oval, sometimes tapering posteriorly more in male than female. Abdominal spiracles present<tei:lb/>on segments III- VIII. Abdominal setae short or of moderate length, longest on pleura VI- VIII; anterior<tei:lb/>setae sometimes present on pleura and laterally on sterna and terga; postero-lateral setae present,<tei:lb/>sometimes numbering more than one per site. Pleural projection present ventrally on abdominal pleurum<tei:lb/>IV, large, sclerotised. Sclerites present on all abdominal pleura, on at least abdominal terga II to VIII and<tei:lb/>at least abdominal sterna V to VII; male terga, at least on segments V-VII, with anterior and posterior<tei:lb/>sclerites (Fig. 95).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gonapophyses broad, especially medially, though lobe absent; marginal setae long, densely crowded.<tei:lb/>Gonapophyses meet ventral vulval margin acutely, not linked by sclerotised band. Ventral vulval margin<tei:lb/>not sclerotised; sometimes expanded, otherwise smoothly convex (Fig. 94); bilobed median spinose<tei:lb/>projection may be present, but subgenital lobe absent. Median longitudinal sclerite sometimes present on<tei:lb/>female sternum VIII (Fig. 94).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male subgenital plate with sternite VII fused to s.g.p.r. , VIII fused or not fused to s.g.p.r. , and IX absent</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>270 C. H. C. LYAL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>or, if present, not fused to s.g.p.r. Pseudostyli absent or, if present, small, slender, incurved (Fig. 95). Male<tei:lb/>genital opening postero-dorsal or dorsal. Parameres fused or unfused; basiparameral sclerites present,<tei:lb/>fused. Mesomeres present, fused or unfused and, if fused, median extension absent; mesomeral arch<tei:lb/>produced basally between b.a.l.s. to contact parameres, which do not meet b.a.l.s. Male genitalia depicted<tei:lb/>in Figs 98, 99.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Genus PROCA VICOLA Bedford<tei:lb/>The genus Procavicola comprises two subgenera.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Anterior of head with osculum present, semicircular; dorsal preantennal sulcus present<tei:lb/>clypeal marginal carina broadened medially into dorsal, posteriorly convex, sclerite (Fig. 106); conus<tei:lb/>large, as long as female scape; anterolateral margin of head straight or convex anteriorly, more or less<tei:lb/>abruptly concave at junction with clypeofrontal sulcus; preantennal outline broadly triangular. Temple<tei:lb/>margin smoothly convex, sometimes produced posteriad, or with postero-lateral angle developed into<tei:lb/>posteriorly-projecting triangular or rounded process*. Male scape expanded, with setal row represente(<tei:lb/>by two setae only; male flagellomeres fused, with two basally-articulated 'teeth'; female flagellomeres<tei:lb/>unfused and closely associated, fused to two closely associated annulations, or completely fused*. Dorsum<tei:lb/>of head with setae short, sparse; anterior margin of head with setae longer than on disc. Sitophore sclerite<tei:lb/>unmodified.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tarsal claws lacking ventral spines or teeth. Postcoxale of metathoracic leg absent or present; if present<tei:lb/>may be well developed, but not to the same degree as described for Procaviphilus (Meganarionoides) am<tei:lb/>not fused to abdominal pleurite II. Thoracic setae present dorsally only along posterior and latero<tei:lb/>posterior margins of prothorax and pterothorax; setae short, except for laterally on pterothorax, where o<tei:lb/>moderate length.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdomen oval, more or less elongate (Figs 103, 105). Abdominal spiracles present on segments<tei:lb/>III- VIII, all approximately the same size. Abdominal setae short or of moderate length; anterior setae<tei:lb/>present on pleura only; postero-lateral setae present, sometimes numbering more than one per site*<tei:lb/>Pleural projections present dorsally and ventrally on abdominal pleurum IV, sclerotised. Sclerites presen<tei:lb/>on sterna, terga and pleura of all abdominal segments except, occasionally, tergum I* ; male terga, at leas<tei:lb/>of segments IV- VI, with anterior and posterior sclerites; second abdominal sternum with broad<tei:lb/>heavily-sclerotised apophysis underlying sternite, articulating with median extensions of abdomina<tei:lb/>pleurite II (Figs 103, 105).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gonapophyses broad, lacking lobe; marginal setae lacking tubercles, occasionally on small conica<tei:lb/>protuberances (Figs 101, 102). Gonapophyses meet ventral vulval margin acutely, not linked by sclerotisec<tei:lb/>band. Ventral vulval margin not sclerotised; expanded, sometimes W-shaped medially (Fig. 100),<tei:lb/>sometimes broadened posteriorly (Fig. 101), sometimes contracted, shorter than length of gonapophyses<tei:lb/>(Fig. 102)*.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male subgenital plate with sternites VII and VIII present and fused to s.g.p.r., sternite IX absent or, if<tei:lb/>present, fused to s.g.p.r. and perisetal gaps small*; s.g.p.r. not always attaining posterior margin of<tei:lb/>segment IX*. Pseudostyli absent (Figs 103-105). Male genital opening postero-dorsal. Male genitalia very<tei:lb/>variable* ; parameres not fused, basiparameral sclerites present or absent* , mesomeres fused or unfused*.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Procaviidae (Hyracoidea).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subgenus PROCA VICOLA Bedford</tei:p>

         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Temple margin smoothly convex, sometimes projecting posteriorly, but never with posterior<tei:lb/>membranous or lightly-sclerotised process.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Postero-lateral setae present, single at each site. Sclerites present on sterna, terga and pleura of all<tei:lb/>abdominal segments except segment I, where tergal sclerite absent.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Subgenus CONDYLOCEPHALUS Werneck</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 101-103, 107, 108)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Condylocephalus Werneck, 1941: 497 [as subgenus of Procavicola Bedford]. Type-species: Procavicola<tei:lb/>(Condylocephalus) bedfordi Werneck, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Temple margin convex, with posteriorly-projecting membranous or lightly-sclerotised<tei:lb/>process, more apparent in male than female, triangular or as small rounded bump (linfieldi females).<tei:lb/>Female flagellomeres unfused, but closely associated.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdomen with postero-lateral setae present, frequently doubled, trebled or numerous at each site.<tei:lb/>Sclerites present on sterna, terga and pleura of all abdominal segments.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventral vulval margin expanded, sometimes broadened posteriorly and broader than length of gona-<tei:lb/>pophyses (Fig; 101), otherwise narrower, width less than length of gonapophyses (Fig. 102).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male subgenital plate with sternites VII, VIII and IX present and fused to s.g.p.r., with perisetal gaps<tei:lb/>small (Fig. 103). Parameres unfused, curved, with anterolateral projections, not asymmetric. Basipar-<tei:lb/>ameral sclerites present, fused or unfused. Mesomeres fused apically; mesomeral arch with median<tei:lb/>extension and lateral double flexion (Figs 107, 108). Endophallus ornamented with large, hook-like<tei:lb/>sclerites (Fig. 107).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Procaviidae (Hyracoidea).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. Though Condylocephalus has been treated by most authors as a subgenus of Procavicola,<tei:lb/>Eichler (1963) considered it to have full generic status.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SPECIES INCLUDED<tei:lb/>bedfordi Werneck, 1941 (2 cf , 1 $)<tei:lb/>dissimilis Werneck, 1941 (64 cf , 58 $)<tei:lb/>hopkinsi Werneck, 1941 (24 cT, 29 $)<tei:lb/>JbMlfieW(Hill, 1922) (77 cT, 65 $)<tei:lb/>univirgatus (Neumann, 1913) (33 cf , 32 $)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genus PROCAVIPHILUS Bedford<tei:lb/>The genus Procaviphilus comprises two subgenera.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Surface of head, thorax and abdomen frequently covered with clearly- visible scales or<tei:lb/>sclerotised nodules.<tei:lb/>Anterior of head variable, one of two types: 'procaviphilus' or 'procavicola'*.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(a) 'procaviphilus' type. Osculum absent or, if present, slightly concave only; dorsal preantennal sulcus<tei:lb/>absent; clypeal marginal carina broadened medially into straight or slightly curved bar (Fig. 112); conus<tei:lb/>small, not as long as female scape; anterolateral margin of head straight or convex anteriorly, no abrupt<tei:lb/>concavity at junction with clypeofrontal sulcus; preantennal outline trapezoid (Fig. 112).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(b) 'procavicola' type. Osculum present, semicircular; dorsal preantennal sulcus present or absent; clypeal<tei:lb/>marginal carina broadened medially into dorsal, posteriorly convex, sclerite (Fig. 106); conus large, as long<tei:lb/>as female scape; anterolateral margin of head convex anteriorly, more or less abruptly concave at junction<tei:lb/>with clypeofrontal sulcus; preantennal outline broadly triangular.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Temple margin smoothly convex, more or less projecting posteriorly. Male scape expanded, with setal<tei:lb/>row represented by two setae only; male flagellomeres fused, with two basally-articulated 'teeth'; female<tei:lb/>flagellomeres unfused , though sometimes very closely associated . Dorsum of head with setae short , sparse .<tei:lb/>Sitophore sclerite unmodified.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tarsal claws lacking ventral spines or teeth. Postcoxale of leg III absent or, if present, frequently<tei:lb/>enlarged, heavily sclerotised, displaced posteriad to occupy abdominal sternum II, and fused to sclerite of<tei:lb/>abdominal pleurum II, in which case gap between postcoxales sometimes obscured by sternite II*.<tei:lb/>Thoracic setae present dorsally only along posterior and lateroposterior margins of prothorax and<tei:lb/>pterothorax; setae short, except for laterally on pterothorax, where of moderate length.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdomen oval-elongate. Abdominal spiracles present on segments III to VIII, though sometimes very<tei:lb/>small and possibly non-functional on VIII*. Abdominal setae short or of moderate length; anterior setae<tei:lb/>present on pleura only, sparse; postero-lateral seta present. Pleural projections present ventrally and<tei:lb/>dorsally on abdominal pleurum IV, sclerotised. Sclerites, frequently faint, present on sterna, terga and<tei:lb/>pleura of all abdominal segments except I; male terga, especially tergum VI, frequently with anterior and<tei:lb/>posterior sclerites.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gonapophyses with setae non-tuberculate and, frequently, tuberculate; setal tubercles, if present,</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>

         <tei:p>HOSTS. Procaviidae (Hyracoidea) and Cercopithecidae (Primates).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subgenus PROCAVIPHILUS Bedford</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 112, 117, 118)<tei:lb/>Procaviphilus Bedford, 1932: 725. Type-species: Procaviphilus ferrisi Bedford, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Anterior of head of 'procaviphilus' type.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Postcoxale absent or, if present, not greatly developed and not fused to abdominal pleurite II.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdominal spiracles all the same size.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gonapophyses with setal tubercles present but not fused; gonapophyses not apically truncate. Ventral<tei:lb/>vulval margin expanded, sometimes W-shaped medially, not broadened posteriorly.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male genitalia with basal apodeme short, attaining abdominal segment VII or VI, lacking median<tei:lb/>constriction; mesomeral arch with lateral desclerotisations.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Procaviidae (Hyracoidea).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SPECIES INCLUDED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>duWus Werneck, 1941 (10 cf , 10 $)<tei:lb/>ferrisi ferrisi Bedford, 1932 (12 cf , 5 $)<tei:lb/>ferrisi granuloides Bedford, 1939 (26 C? , 19 9)<tei:lb/>ferrisi Wndei Werneck, 1946 (3 cf , 4 $)<tei:lb/>granulates (Ferris, 1930) (13 cf , 17 $)<tei:lb/>Aarrisi Werneck, 1946 (15 cf , 19 $)<tei:lb/>robertsi (Bedford, 1928) (16 cf , 18 $)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subgenus MEGANARIONOIDESEichler</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 110, 111, 113-116, 119-122)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Meganarionoides Eichler, 1940: 159. Type-species: Trichodectes colobi Kellogg, by original designation.<tei:lb/>Acondylocephalus Werneck, 1941: 478 [as subgenus of Procavicola Bedford]. Type-species: Trichodectes<tei:lb/>congoensis Ferris, by original designation. [Synonymy by Werneck, 1946: 85.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Anterior of head of 'procaviphilus' type or, more frequently, of 'procavicola' type.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Postcoxale of leg III enlarged as described in description of Procaviphilus s.l., and fused to abdominal<tei:lb/>pleurite II, at least in female.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gonapophyses with setal tubercles absent (in which case gonapophyses characteristically broad and<tei:lb/>vulval margin produced posteriad as in Fig. 113), or present basally, marginally and submarginally, and<tei:lb/>fused characteristically to form basal process (Fig. Ill); gonapophyses more or less truncate. Ventral<tei:lb/>vulval margin expanded, as described for Procaviphilus s. str. or, more frequently, broadened posteriorly,<tei:lb/>sometimes produced posteriad (Fig. 113) or with median lobulate process (Fig. 110).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male genitalia with basal apodeme attaining abdominal segment VII or VI or, more frequently, long,<tei:lb/>attaining segment III or II, with median constriction (Figs 116, 119); mesomeral arch with or without<tei:lb/>lateral desclerotisation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Procaviidae (Hyracoidea) and Cercopithecidae (Primates).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. There has been some disagreement in the literature over the correct host of one species in this<tei:lb/>subgenus. Most species included in P. (Meganarionoides) are parasites of Procaviidae, as are all other<tei:lb/>species in the subfamily Dasyonyginae (other than the three species of Cebidicola, which are included in<tei:lb/>the subfamily for the first time in this study). One species, however, P. (M.) colobi (Kellogg, 1910), was<tei:lb/>described from the monkey Colobus guereza caudatus Thomas. Keler (1938a) included this species with<tei:lb/>the others described from Primates in his genus Meganarion (an objective synonym of Cebidicola},<tei:lb/>although realising that the species were not truly congeneric. Eichler (1940) described the new genus<tei:lb/>Meganarionoides for colobi, and placed it with Cebidicola and Lorisicola in the new subfamily Cebidicoli-<tei:lb/>nae. Werneck (1946) recognised the identity of colobi with the hyrax lice, and synonymised Meganar-<tei:lb/>ionoides with Procavicola (Acondylocephalus) Werneck, 1941, the subgenus thus taking the name<tei:lb/>Procavicola (Meganarionoides). Werneck (1946) also suggested that Colobus was not the true host of P.<tei:lb/>colobi, but that the louse was probably a parasite of Dendrohydrax validus subsp. He suggested that the<tei:lb/>host record of the type-specimens was erroneous and due to mislabelling (the collection having included</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTID MAMMAL LICE 279</tei:p>
         <tei:p>both Colobus and Dendrohyrax), and that a second record was due to contamination (other hyrax-lice<tei:lb/>having been associated with the specimens of colobi). Hopkins (1949) reported having examined 25 skins<tei:lb/>of Colobus polykomos, which he identified as the 'supposed host', without having found any Trichodecti-<tei:lb/>dae, and agreed with Werneck (1946) that Dendrohyrax validus subsp. was the correct host. Hopkins &amp;<tei:lb/>Clay (1952) also identified D. validus subsp. as the host, the record from 'Colobus caudatus' being termed<tei:lb/>an 'error'. Eichler (1963) agreed, and removed Meganarionoides from the Cebidicolinae and placed it in<tei:lb/>the Dasyonygidae with Procavicola (Fig. 38). Emerson &amp; Price (1981) include P. colobi, without<tei:lb/>comment, as a parasite of Dendrohyrax validus validus, although the association with the nominate<tei:lb/>subspecies of this animal has not appeared elsewhere in the literature. Kuhn &amp; Ludwig (1964), however,<tei:lb/>reported a specimen of Colobus guereza with 'hundreds of eggs and adult and larval Procavicola on it, all<tei:lb/>clasping the hairs tightly; most of them on the back and on the throat', and were able to state that the<tei:lb/>monkey had not been in contact with a Dendrohyrax or any other Procaviidae after its death. They<tei:lb/>concluded There is no doubt . . . that Colobus guereza is a natural host of Procavicola (Meganarionoides)<tei:lb/>colobi.' In view of the fact that there are now three records of the species from Colobus guereza and none<tei:lb/>from any member of the Procaviidae, this conclusion seems fully justified.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Meganarionoides was, as described above, treated as a subgenus of Procavicola by Werneck (1946). In<tei:lb/>this he has been followed by most authors, although Eichler (1963) considered it to be a full genus. Before<tei:lb/>the present study Meganarionoides had not been placed as a subgenus of Procaviphilus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SPECIES INCLUDED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>a/rica/ius( Werneck, 1941) comb. n. from Procavicola (5 cf , 5 $)<tei:lb/>angolensis (Bedford, 1936) comb. n. from Procavicola (8 cf , 11 9)<tei:lb/>colobi (Kellogg, 1910) comb. n. from Procavicola (1 d", 1 $)<tei:lb/>congoensis (Ferris, 1930) comb. n. from Procavicola (22 cf , 25 $)<tei:lb/>jordani (Bedford, 1936) comb. n. from Procavicola (2 cf , 2 $)<tei:lb/>muesebecki (Emerson &amp; Price, 1969) comb. n. from Procavicola (10 cf , 10 $)<tei:lb/>/it'i/niann/neuma/in/(Stobbe, 1913) comb. n. from Procavicola (2 cf , 1 $)<tei:lb/>neumanni baculatus (Ferris, 1930) comb. n. from Procavicola (13 cf , 14 $)<tei:lb/>sclerotis sclerotis Bedford, 1932 [treated as Procaviphilus s. str. by previous authors] (10 cf , 17 $)<tei:lb/>sclerotis major Maltbaek, 1937 [treated as Procaviphilus s. str. by previous authors]<tei:lb/>scutifer (Werneck, 1941) comb. n. from Procavicola (14 cf , 19 $)<tei:lb/>serraticus (Hill, 1922) [treated as Procaviphilus s. str. by previous authors] (50 cf , 70 $)<tei:lb/>tendeiroi (Emerson, 1965) comb. n. from Procavicola (3 Cf , 2 $)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genus DASYONYX Bedford<tei:lb/>The genus Dasyonyx. comprises two subgenera.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Anterior of head with osculum present, variable in degree of excavation* ; dorsal preantennal<tei:lb/>sulcus absent; clypeal marginal carina broadened medially, with posterior curvature of broadened portion<tei:lb/>similar to curvature of osculum* (Fig. 123); conus not large; anterolateral margin of head straight, convex<tei:lb/>or concave, though not very concave at junction with clypeofrontal suture; preantennal portion of head<tei:lb/>short or long, outline broadly triangular, trapezoidal or rounded*. Temple margin shallowly convex,<tei:lb/>sometimes with small rounded projection postero-laterally*. Male scape expanded, with setal row present;<tei:lb/>male flagellomeres fused, with two basally-articulated 'teeth'; female flagellomeres unfused. Dorsum of<tei:lb/>head with setae of moderate length. Sitophore sclerite with posterior arms extended (cf. Fig. 12), though<tei:lb/>sclerite difficult to see.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tarsal claws with ventral spines or teeth (Figs 14, 15)*. Post-coxale of metathoracic leg absent or, if<tei:lb/>present* enlarged, though not as described for Procaviphilus (Meganarionoides) and not fused to<tei:lb/>abdominal pleurite II. Thorax with dorsal setae present only posteriorly on prothoracic margin and<tei:lb/>posteriorly and posterolaterally on pterothoracic margin; setae short anteriorly, longer posteriorly with the<tei:lb/>longest setae on the posterolateral margins of the pterothorax; setae generally sparse.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdomen broadly oval, with male segment IX not projecting greatly (Fig. 129). Abdominal spiracles<tei:lb/>present on segments III to VIII, all approximately the same size, frequently inconspicuous. Abdominal<tei:lb/>setae of moderate length; anterior setae present on pleura only; postero-lateral setae present. Pleural<tei:lb/>projections present dorsally and ventrally on abdominal pleurum IV, sclerotised. Sclerites present on<tei:lb/>sterna, terga and pleura (where present) of all abdominal segments except I; male terga, at least of<tei:lb/>abdominal segment VI, with anterior and posterior sclerites.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gonapophyses with sparse marginal setae and variably-developed lobe ventrally, the lobe bearing two<tei:lb/>apical or subapical setae and frequently being serrate along dorsal (posterior) margin (Fig. 126).</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Genus EURYTRICHODECTES Stobbe</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 9, 16, 136-138)<tei:lb/>Eurytrichodectes Stobbe, 1913o: 111. Type-species: Eurytrichodectes paradoxus Stobbe, by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Anterior of head with osculum absent or, if present, very shallowly concave; dorsal<tei:lb/>preantennal sulcus absent; clypeal marginal carina slender, not greatly developed medially or, if de-<tei:lb/>veloped, in the form of a median posteriorly-directed narrow-based triangle; anterolateral margin of head<tei:lb/>slightly sinuate; preantennal portion of head very short, outline broadly triangular or trapezoid. Temple<tei:lb/>margin produced posteriorly into broad triangular spike, almost as long as prothorax or, if shorter,<tei:lb/>attaining front of pronotum (Fig. 138). Male scape expanded, with longitudinal setal row comprising only<tei:lb/>two setae; male flagellomeres fused, though semicircular sclerite at apex may be vestige of terminal'<tei:lb/>flagellomere; two basally-fused 'teeth' present on male flagellum; female flagellomeres unfused; membra-<tei:lb/>nous projection present on female pedicel (Fig. 138). Dorsum of head with setae short, sparse. Sitophore<tei:lb/>sclerite with posterior arms extended (cf. Fig. 12), though sclerite difficult to see.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tarsal claws ridged ventrally, lacking teeth or spines (Fig. 16). Postcoxale of metathoracic leg absent.<tei:lb/>Thorax with dorsal setae present on posterior margin of prothorax and on posterior margin of pterothorax;<tei:lb/>setae short, sparse.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdomen broad and oval, sometimes with male terminal segments tapering and projecting slightly.<tei:lb/>Abdominal spiracles present on segments III to VIII, all approximately of the same size. Abdominal setae<tei:lb/>short on sterna IV to IX, terga and pleura, some tergal setae very short; sterna II and III with stout, conical<tei:lb/>setae (Fig. 136); anterior setae present, sparse on pleura; setal row on terga and sterna may be irregular;<tei:lb/>postero-lateral setae present. Pleural projections present dorsally and ventrally on abdominal pleurum IV,<tei:lb/>sclerotised, very long, reaching or almost reaching posterior margin of pleurum V. Sclerites present on<tei:lb/>sterna, terga and pleura (where present) of all abdominal segments except, sometimes, tergum I; male<tei:lb/>terga, at least of abdominal segments II to VI, with anterior and posterior sclerites.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gonapophyses with ventral marginal setae present, each with a small, conical tubercle; ventral lobe<tei:lb/>absent. Gonapophyses meet ventral vulval margin smoothly, not linked by sclerotised band. Ventral vulval<tei:lb/>margin not sclerotised; medially expanded and trapezoid; subgenital lobe absent.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>TRICHODECTINAE Kellogg</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genus PROTELICOLA Bedford gen. rev.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 139, 140)<tei:lb/>Protelicola Bedford, 1932a: 355. Type-species: Protelicola intermedius Bedford, by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Anterior of head with osculum present; clypeal marginal carina broadened just laterally to<tei:lb/>osculum, tapering medially and interrupted by dorsal preantennal sulcus; anterolateral margin of head<tei:lb/>straight or convex; preantennal outline of head triangular or rounded. Temple margin convex. Male scape<tei:lb/>slightly expanded, with longitudinal setal row present and comprising three or four setae; flagellomeres<tei:lb/>fused in males and females; male flagellum with two basally-articulated 'teeth'. Dorsal setae of head short<tei:lb/>or of moderate length, longest and most abundant anteriorly. Sitophore sclerite unmodified.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thorax with setae long or of moderate length laterally and dorsally, with setae on postero-lateral angles<tei:lb/>of pterothorax shorter, more spine-like. Prothorax with setae present sparsely on lateral and posterior<tei:lb/>margins; median gap present, wide; single seta present antero-laterally on disc. Pterothorax with setae<tei:lb/>present postero-laterally and submarginally posteriorly; median gap present, wide; no setae present on<tei:lb/>disc.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdomen rounded, similar in shape in males and females. Abdominal spiracles present on segments<tei:lb/>III- VIII. Abdominal setae of moderate length; anterior setae present on pleura only; postero-lateral setae<tei:lb/>absent. Abdominal pleura lacking projections. Abdominal segments with tergal sclerites absent except<tei:lb/>tergite IX in female; pleural sclerites present on pleura II and III; sternites IV- VII present in male and<tei:lb/>V-VII present in female, very slender and difficult to see in both sexes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gonapophyses with basal setae and rectangular lobe on ventral margin, lobe formed from more or less<tei:lb/>fused setal tubercles. Gonapophyses meet ventral vulval margin smoothly, not linked by sclerotised band.<tei:lb/>Ventral vulval margin not sclerotised. Subgenital lobe present, not marginally serrate, but sometimes with<tei:lb/>apical papillae. Female genital chamber with small lapped scales on walls, dorsal wall with median<tei:lb/>longitudinal anterior 'slit' where scales are absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male subgenital plate comprising very slender sternite VII and s.g.p.r. only, s.g.p.r. not reaching<tei:lb/>posterior of sternum IX. Male genital opening dorsal or postero-dorsal. Pseudostyli absent. Basal<tei:lb/>apodeme with b.a.l.s. widely divergent anteriorly. Parameres long, slender, fused basally, projecting<tei:lb/>anteriorly between b.a.l.s. (but see second paragraph of 'comments' below). Basiparameral sclerites</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTID MAMMAL LICE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>287</tei:p>
         <tei:p>139</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 139, 140 Protelicola species, C? genitalia. 139, P. hyaenae. 140, undescribed species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>absent. Mesomeres fused apically to form arch, with median projection present, broad (see second and<tei:lb/>third paragraphs of 'comments' below). Male genitalia depicted in Fig. 139.<tei:lb/>Alimentary canal with numerous small spines in crop.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Hyaenidae and Protelidae (Carnivora).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. Protelicola was treated as a subgenus and a junior synonym of Felicola by Hopkins (1949) and<tei:lb/>Werneck (1948) respectively; its most recent placement (Emerson &amp; Price, 1981) was as a synonym of<tei:lb/>Felicola. A more detailed history of the variations in status of Protelicola is presented in Table 5.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the British Museum (Natural History) collection there is a slide bearing 1 nymphal, 3 female and 2<tei:lb/>male (one of which is teneral) lice from Proteles cristatus termes. Hopkins has identified the lice as<tei:lb/>Protelicola intermedius. The females are indistinguishable from females of P. intermedius s. str., but the<tei:lb/>male genitalia are very distinct, with the parameres completely fused to form a broad plate, the mesomeral<tei:lb/>arch wide, and the b.a.l.s. with a small postero-lateral projection contacting the mesomeres (Fig. 140). In<tei:lb/>all other respects the males resemble P. intermedius s. str. It seems that the males represent a new species,<tei:lb/>differing from Protelicola intermedius by the structure of the genitalia, but the identity of the females is<tei:lb/>doubtful. In view of the limited number of specimens available, the species is not formally described.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bedford (19320) described P. intermedius from Proteles cristatus, the first louse known from a hyaena.<tei:lb/>Hopkins (1960) described P. intermedius hyaenae (in Felicola) from Hyaena brunnea, distinguishing it<tei:lb/>from the nominate subspecies by the size, the outline of the preantennal portion of the head, and the male</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>288 C. H. C. LYAL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>genitalia. Ledger (1980) raised P. i. hyaenae to specific rank although Emerson &amp; Price (1981) retained its<tei:lb/>subspecific status. Hopkins (1960) indicated three features of the male genitalia in which the two taxa<tei:lb/>differ: the greater anterior divergence of the b.a.l.s. in P. i. intermedius , the shape of the parameres (which<tei:lb/>he presumed to be completely fused in P. i. intermedius, and are only basally fused in P. i. hyaenae), and<tei:lb/>the absence of the mesomeral arch extension in P. i. intermedius. The type-series of P. i. intermedius has<tei:lb/>not been seen in the present study, but a series of specimens from Proteles cristatus has been examined;<tei:lb/>these specimens agree with Bedford's and Hopkins' descriptions of P. i. intermedius in all but details of the<tei:lb/>male genitalia. The male genitalia of this series were found to be very similar to those of P. hyaenae, with<tei:lb/>the b.a.l.s. variably divergent anteriorly, the parameres fused only basally and the mesomeral arch with a<tei:lb/>median broad extension (although this is very thinly sclerotised and difficult to see in both taxa). The male<tei:lb/>genitalia of P. hyaenae are depicted in Fig. 139. The two species may be distinguished by the smaller size<tei:lb/>and shorter preantennal region of P. hyaenae (see photographs in Hopkins, 1960).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SPECIES INCLUDED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>hyaenae (Hopkins, 1960) stat. rev., comb. n. from Felicola (holotype cf , allotype $)<tei:lb/>intermedius Bedford, 1932 comb. rev. from Felicola (19 cf, 48 9)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genus LUTRIDIA Keler</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 141-145)<tei:lb/>Lutridia Keler, 1938a: 433. Type-species: Trichodectes exilis Giebel, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Anterior of head with osculum absent; dorsal preantennal sulcus absent; clypeal marginal<tei:lb/>carina broadened medially to form dorsal sclerite with three posteriorly-directed projections (Fig. 142);<tei:lb/>preantennal portion of head short, outline smoothly rounded. Temple margin convex or rectangular. Male<tei:lb/>scape not expanded, longitudinal setal row comprising two setae positioned distally on segment; flagello-<tei:lb/>meres fused in males and females; male flagellum lacking 'teeth'. Dorsum of head with setae short or of<tei:lb/>moderate length, sparse. Sitophore sclerite unmodified.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thorax with dorsal setae long or of moderate length, limited to posterior and postero-lateral margins of<tei:lb/>prothorax and pterothorax.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdomen oval or slightly elongate-oval, with male segment IX projecting slightly posteriorly (Fig. 141).<tei:lb/>Abdominal spiracles present on segments III- VIII. Abdominal setae as follows: pleurum II with setae<tei:lb/>sparse, stout and short, anterior setae and p.s.r. present; pleurum III with setae short and of moderate<tei:lb/>length, stout, very sparse (exilis) or with p.s.r. present (matschiei); pleura IV- VII or VIII lacking setae,<tei:lb/>those on VIII, if present, very small and posteriorly positioned; sternal setae short and stout or longer<tei:lb/>(about two-thirds length of segment); sternum II with median gap of posterior setal row small or absent;<tei:lb/>sterna III-IV and VII- VIII (matschiei) or III- VIII (exilis) with setae very sparse, setae absent from sterna<tei:lb/>V-VI of L. matschiei; terga I-IV (males) or I-III (females) with median setal group including one or two<tei:lb/>setae as long as segment, other terga with median group absent or comprising shorter setae; terga with<tei:lb/>lateral seta or setae generally present, of moderate length on terga II-III, shorter on more posterior<tei:lb/>segments (these setae may represent either lateral setal group or postero-lateral seta); anterior setae<tei:lb/>present only on pleurum II. Abdominal pleura lacking projections. Sclerites absent from abdominal<tei:lb/>pleura, present on terga IV- VIII (males) or terga IV-IX (females) and sterna III- VIII (males) or sterna<tei:lb/>IV- VIII (females); sclerites frequently very faint, may not be seen; male terga lacking posterior sclerites.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gonapophyses with non-tuberculate setae on ventral margin; ventral lobe not present. Gonapophyses<tei:lb/>meet ventral vulval margin smoothly, linked by sclerotised band. Ventral vulval margin sclerotised, with<tei:lb/>chord at 90 degrees to long axis of abdomen, submarginal non-tuberculate setae present. Subgenital lobe<tei:lb/>present, small, rectangular, sometimes serrate along posterior margin (Fig. 143).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male subgenital plate comprising s.g.p.r. only or with s.g.p.r. linked by broad sternite VIII (and possibly<tei:lb/>VII); in either case s.g.p.r. not attaining segment IX. Pseudostyli absent. Male genital opening dorsal.<tei:lb/>Basal apodeme slender, long, attaining at least abdominal segment III. Parameres long, slender, basally<tei:lb/>fused; basal fused portion may be partially detached from rest of parameres; parameres sometimes fused to<tei:lb/>b.a.l.s. Mesomeres absent. Male genitalia depicted in Figs 144, 145.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Lutrinae (Carnivora: Mustelidae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. Lutridia has been treated as a synonym and a subgenus of Trichodectes (Hopkins, 1942 and<tei:lb/>Hopkins, 1949 respectively), though the most recent treatment (Emerson &amp; Price, 1981) considered<tei:lb/>Lutridia as, a full genus. The history of the variations in status of Lutridia is presented in Table 4.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>(Figs 146, 147)<tei:lb/>Type-species: Trichodectes lutrae Werneck.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Anterior of head with osculum absent, though pulvinus attaining margin; dorsal preantennal<tei:lb/>sulcus absent; clypeal marginal carina slightly broadened medially at junction with pulvinus; preantennal<tei:lb/>outline broadly and smoothly rounded.       <tei:div>
         <tei:p>290 C. H. C. LYAL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>al setal row present, comprising four setae; flagellomeres fused in males and females; male flagellum<tei:lb/>lacking 'teeth'. Dorsum of head with setae short or of moderate length, sparse; temple margin with two or<tei:lb/>three longer setae. Sitophore sclerite unmodified.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Prothorax with two setae of medium length on posterior margin; pterothorax with one or two short,<tei:lb/>spine-like setae anterolaterally and six to ten long setae dorsally on posterior margin.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdomen oval, with male segment IX projecting posteriorly. Abdominal spiracles present on segments<tei:lb/>III-VIII. Abdominal setae as follows: pleurum III with short, stout setae anteriorly and posteriorly; pleura<tei:lb/>III-VIII lacking setae; terga I- VI (males) or I-IV (females) with central seta of median groups as long as<tei:lb/>segment, setae otherwise short; terga VII-VIII (males) or V-IX (females) with short setae, sparse; sterna<tei:lb/>with stout, short setae, sparse; anterior setae present only on pleurum II; postero-lateral setae absent.<tei:lb/>Abdominal pleura lacking projections. Sclerites absent from abdominal pleura and sterna, but present,<tei:lb/>slender, on at least terga III- VII (males) or V-IX (females), though may be very faint and not seen; male<tei:lb/>terga lacking posterior sclerites.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gonapophyses with small ventral lobes formed from fused setal tubercles. Gonapophyses meet ventral<tei:lb/>vulval margin smoothly, linked by sclerotised band. Ventral vulval margin sclerotised, with chord at 90<tei:lb/>degrees to long axis of abdomen; submarginal non-tuberculate setae present. Subgenital lobe present,<tei:lb/>large, with lateral spine-like projections and associated setae present basally (Fig. 146).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male subgenital plate represented by sternite VIII with lateral arms extending anteriad. Pseudostyli<tei:lb/>absent. Male genital opening dorsal. Basal apodeme attaining abdominal segment III, not slender.<tei:lb/>Parameres broad, scoop-shaped, not fused together, but fused to b.a.l.s. Mesomeres absent. Male<tei:lb/>genitalia depicted in Fig. 147.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Lutrinae (Carnivora: Mustelidae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SPECIES INCLUDED<tei:lb/>lutrae (Werneck, 1937) comb. n. from Lutridia (1 cf , 1 $)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genus WERNECKODECTES Conci gen. rev.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 148)<tei:lb/>Werneckodectes Conci, 1946: 59. Type-species: TrichodectesferrisfWerneck, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Osculum absent, though pulvinus attains anterior margin of head; dorsal preantennal sulcus<tei:lb/>present; clypeal marginal carina broadened slightly medially; preantennal portion of head short, outline</tei:p>

      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTID MAMMAL LICE 291</tei:p>
         <tei:p>smoothly and broadly rounded. Temple margin convex. Male scape expanded; flagellomeres fused in<tei:lb/>males and females; male flagellum with two basally-articulated 'teeth' and basal projection. Dorsum of<tei:lb/>head with setae of moderate length.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thorax with dorsal setae longest postero-laterally on pterothorax and along posterior margin on<tei:lb/>pterothorax; shorter setae present submarginally along posterior of pterothorax and on postero-lateral<tei:lb/>angles of prothorax, where there is a small setal patch; disc and posterior margin of pronotum each with<tei:lb/>pair of small setae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdomen oval, tapering posteriorly rather more in male than female. Abdominal spiracles present on<tei:lb/>segments III- VIII. Abdominal setae numerous, anterior setae being present on sterna, terga and possibly<tei:lb/>pleura of all segments; anterior setae smaller than setae of posterior setal rows on each segment;<tei:lb/>postero-lateral setae, if present, obscured by large number of other setae. Sclerites present on all abdominal pleura, on terga V-IX (males) or terga VII-IX<tei:lb/>(females) and on sterna III-VI (males only - sclerites absent on female sterna); male terga without<tei:lb/>posterior tergites, but anterior tergites, where present, with median longitudinal division.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gonapophyses with non-tuberculate setae on ventral margin; ventral lobe present, small; setae on lobe<tei:lb/>stout, short, whilst setae distal to lobe longer, more slender. Gonapophyses meet ventral vulval margin<tei:lb/>smoothly, linked by broad sclerotised band. Subgenital lobe present,<tei:lb/>broad, with lateral rounded projections and associated setae present basally.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male subgenital plate with sternite VII fused to s.g.p.r., sternites VIII and IX absent; s.g.p.r. with<tei:lb/>sinuate margins. Pseudostyli absent. Male genital opening dorsal. Parameres not as long as basal apodeme,<tei:lb/>not fused together. Basiparameral sclerites absent. Mesomeres not apically fused, abutting parameres and<tei:lb/>b.a.l.s. basally. Male genitalia depicted in Fig. 148.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Ursidae (Carnivora).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. Werneckodectes has been treated as a synonym and a subgenus of Trichodectes (by Hopkins,<tei:lb/>1942 and Hopkins, 1949 respectively) ; its most recent placement was as a synonym of Trichodectes. A more<tei:lb/>comprehensive history of the variations in status of Werneckodectes is given in Table 4.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SPECIES INCLUDED<tei:lb/>ferrisi(Werneck, 1944) comb. rev. from Trichodectes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genus TRICHODECTES Nitzsch<tei:lb/>The genus Trichodectes comprises three subgenera.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Anterior of head with osculum present or absent* , but always with pulvinus attaining margin;<tei:lb/>dorsal preantennal sulcus present or absent; clypeal marginal carina broadened to variable extent medially<tei:lb/>to form simple bar with posterior margin straight or concave, or carina broadened into dorsal sclerite which<tei:lb/>is heavily-sclerotised laterally (dorsal to margin of clypeus and pulvinus) and lightly or very lightly-<tei:lb/>sclerotised medially (posterior to the osculum) , more or less convex posteriorly or U-shaped with median<tei:lb/>posterior process* ; antero-lateral margin of head straight, convex or sinuate* ; preantennal portion of head<tei:lb/>long or short*, outline broadly rounded, broadly triangular, trapezoid or only slightly produced anteriad<tei:lb/>between coni*. Temple margin convex, rectangular or produced laterally*. Male scape expanded or not<tei:lb/>expanded* ; longitudinal setal row present, comprising at least four setae; flagellomeres fused in males and<tei:lb/>females; male flagellum with one, two or four basally-articulated 'teeth' or 'teeth' absent*. Dorsum of head<tei:lb/>with setae short, of moderate length or long, longest setae generally present along posterior temple<tei:lb/>margin; setae sometimes sparse. Sitophore sclerite unmodified.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thorax with prothoracic dorsal setae sparse, short or of moderate length* posteriorly and postero-<tei:lb/>laterally, absent from disc; pterothorax with setae on postero-lateral angles short and spine-like or of<tei:lb/>moderate length, dorsal setae otherwise present on posterior margin only, long or short, numerous, sparse<tei:lb/>or absent*.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdomen oval, male segment IX sometimes slightly projecting posteriad, but usually positioned<tei:lb/>dorsally on the abdomen (Figs 156, 158, 160, 164, 165). Abdominal spiracles present on segments HI-IV,<tei:lb/>III-V, III- VII or III- VIII*; spiracle on segment VIII, if present, sometimes much smaller than those on<tei:lb/>segments III- VII*. Abdomen with at least some tergal and sternal setae as long as segment, or setae very<tei:lb/>short, sparse and absent from pleura V and VI*; terga with lateral and median groups of setae frequently<tei:lb/>distinct; tergal setae numerous, or median group reduced to a single seta or absent*; male terga II and III<tei:lb/>sometimes with median group comprising exceptionally long, stout setae (Fig. 161)*; anterior setae</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Subgenus TRICHODECTES Nitzsch<tei:lb/>(Figs 10, 149-152, 158, 159, 162, 163, 169-171)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trichodectes Nitzsch, 1818: 294. Type-species: 'Trichodectes canis DeGeer (syn. T. latus N.)', by</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Grisonia Keler, 1938a: 464. [No type-species designated] [Homonym of Grisonia Gray, 1843: 68].<tei:lb/>Galictobius Keler, 1938fc: 228. [Replacement name for Grisonia Keler.] Type-species: Trichodectes</tei:p>
         <tei:p>galictidis Werneck, by original designation. [Synonymy by Hopkins, 1942: 444.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Male scape expanded; male flagellum with two or four basally-articulated 'teeth'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdominal spiracles present on segments III- VIII, spiracle on segment VIII not smaller than those on<tei:lb/>anterior segments. Abdomen with at least some tergal and sternal setae as long as segment, or setae very<tei:lb/>short, sparse and absent from pleura V and VI (kuntzi and emersoni); male terga II and III sometimes with</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>300 C. H. C. LYAL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>median group comprising exceptionally long, stout setae (undescribed sister-species to T. galictidis), tergal<tei:lb/>setae never with median group reduced to single seta or absent (except sometimes on tergum I).<tei:lb/>Abdominal pleura lacking projections. Abdominal sternal sclerites absent, or present on sterna V-VIII<tei:lb/>only; abdominal tergal sclerites present or, more usually, absent; if tergites present on male, then not with<tei:lb/>anterior and posterior sclerites on each segment.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female genital chamber with ventral wall frequently obscure, dorsal wall bearing sclerotised nodules,<tei:lb/>sometimes fused together.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male subgenital plate absent, represented by s.g.p.r. only, or by enlarged sternite VIII only. Parameres<tei:lb/>fused to form plate or unfused; symmetric or asymmetric; not fused to b.a.l.s. Faintly-sclerotised<tei:lb/>tongue-like sclerite of uncertain homology sometimes present dorsally between parameres if mesomeres<tei:lb/>absent (Fig. 169). Mesomeres absent or, if present, fused or unfused. Male genitalia depicted in Figs<tei:lb/>169-171.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Canidae, Mustelidae, Ursidae and Viverridae (Carnivora).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. Trichodectes Nitzsch, 1818 was placed on the Official List of Generic Names in Zoology, with<tei:lb/>the type-species Trichodectes canis DeGeer, by Opinion 627 of the International Commission of Zoologic-<tei:lb/>al Nomenclature (1962, Bulletin of Zoological Nomenclature 19: 91).</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Subgenus PARATRICHODECTESsubgen. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 6, 154, 160, 161, 166-168)<tei:lb/>Type-species: Trichodectes ovalis Bedford.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Anterior of head with osculum present; clypeal marginal carina broadened medially into<tei:lb/>dorsal sclerite which is heavily-sclerotised laterally and lightly-sclerotised medially, more or less convex<tei:lb/>posteriorly or U-shaped with median posterior process; antero-lateral margin of head convex or sinuate;<tei:lb/>preantennal portion of head not long, outline rounded or subtriangular. Temple margin convex or<tei:lb/>rectangular. Male scape not greatly expanded; male flagellum with two basally-articulated 'teeth'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thorax with prothoracic dorsal setae sparse, of moderate length posteriorly and postero-laterally,<tei:lb/>absent from disc; pterothorax with setae on postero-lateral angle long dorsally, short and spine-like<tei:lb/>ventrally; dorsal posterior pterothoracic setae submarginal, long, comprising two pairs with wide median</tei:p>
         <tei:p>gap.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdominal spiracles present on segments III- VII. Abdomen with at least some tergal and sternal setae<tei:lb/>as long as segment; setae present on all pleura; tergal setae numerous, median group not reduced to a single<tei:lb/>seta or absent except sometimes on tergum I or on posterior terga of males only , if male terga II and III with<tei:lb/>median setal group comprising exceptionally long, stout setae; postero-lateral setae presumed absent,<tei:lb/>though may be present as the most lateral seta of lateral group, which is frequently situated more<tei:lb/>posteriorly than other setae. Abdominal sterna and terga with or without sclerites; male terga, if sclerites<tei:lb/>present, with anterior sclerites only.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female genital chamber with dorsal wall not bearing sclerotised nodules.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male subgenital plate unsclerotised. Parameres separate or thinly fused to each other; symmetric or<tei:lb/>asymmetric; not fused to b.a.l.s. Tongue-like sclerite not present. Mesomeres absent. Male genitalia<tei:lb/>depicted in Figs 166-168.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Mustelinae (Carnivora: Mustelidae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SPECIES INCLUDED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ovalis Bedford, 1928 comb. rev. from Stachiella (15 cf , 12 $)<tei:lb/>ugandensis Bedford, 1936 comb. rev. from Stachiella (44 cf , 47 $)<tei:lb/>zor/tfaeStobbe, 1913, comb. rev. from Stachiella (17 cf , 26 $)</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>TRICHODECTID MAMMAL LICE 301</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subgenus STACHIELLA Keler stat. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 153, 155-157, 164, 165, 172-174)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Stachiella Keler, 1938a: 428. Type-species: Trichodectes pusillus Nitzsch [= Pediculus mustelae Schrank],</tei:p>
         <tei:p>by original designation.<tei:lb/>Potusdia Conci, 1942: 141. Type-species: Trichodectes potus Werneck, by original designation. [Synony-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>mised with Trichodectes by Werneck, 1948: 110; syn. n. of Stachiella.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Clypeal marginal carina broadened medially into dorsal sclerite which is heavily-sclerotised<tei:lb/>laterally and lightly or very lightly-sclerotised medially, more or less convex posteriorly or U-shaped with<tei:lb/>median posterior process; antero-lateral margin of head smoothly convex; preantennal portion of head<tei:lb/>long or short, outline broadly rounded, sometimes only slightly produced anteriad between coni. Male<tei:lb/>scape not, or only slightly, expanded; male flagellum with one or two basally-articulated 'teeth' or 'teeth'<tei:lb/>absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thorax with prothoracic dorsal setae sparse, of moderate length posteriorly and postero-laterally,<tei:lb/>absent from disc; ptero thorax with setae on postero-lateral angles short and spine-like or of moderate<tei:lb/>length, dorsal posterior setae submarginal, long, comprising one or more pairs with wide median gap, or<tei:lb/>absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdominal spiracles present on segments III-IV, III-V, or III-VIII; spiracle on segment VIII, if<tei:lb/>present, sometimes much smaller than those on segments III-VII. Abdomen with at least some tergal and<tei:lb/>sternal setae as long as segment; setae present on all pleura; terga with median setal group of male reduced<tei:lb/>to a single seta on most segments, lateral group small; female tergal setae of similar arrangement or with<tei:lb/>median group absent (see discussion on p. 221 above); male terga II and III never with median group<tei:lb/>comprising exceptionally long, stout setae; postero-lateral setae presumed absent, though perhaps present<tei:lb/>as the most lateral seta of lateral setal group, which is frequently situated more posteriorly than other setae<tei:lb/>of the group. Abdominal pleura lacking projections. Abdominal sterna variably sclerotised, with sternites,<tei:lb/>if present, most commonly on posterior segments; abdominal terga with sclerites present on segments<tei:lb/>III-VIII or III-IX, sometimes on I and II; male terga frequently with both anterior and posterior sclerites,<tei:lb/>though posterior sclerites may be faintly-sclerotised or absent; abdominal pleurum II frequently sclero-<tei:lb/>tised, otherwise pleura unsclerotised.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gonapophyses with separate or closely-associated tuberculate setae and single apical non-tuberculate<tei:lb/>seta on ventral margin. Gonapophyses meet ventral vulval margin smoothly, linked by sclerotised band.<tei:lb/>Ventral vulval margin sclerotised. Female genital chamber with dorsal wall not bearing sclerotised<tei:lb/>nodules.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male subgenital plate absent, or with sternites VII, VIII and IX present and fused to s.g.p.r., or of this<tei:lb/>form but with sternite VIII divided medially. Parameres separate or thinly fused to one another;<tei:lb/>symmetric, asymmetric or asymmetrically deflected; fused or not fused to b.a.l.s. Tongue-like sclerite not<tei:lb/>present. Mesomeres absent, present, small and unfused, or present and fused. Male genitalia depicted in<tei:lb/>Figs 172-174.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Mustelidae: Mustelinae and Procyonidae (Carnivora).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. Stachiella has been considered a synonym and a subgenus of Trichodectes (Hopkins, 1942 and<tei:lb/>Hopkins, 1949 respectively), although its most recent treatment (Emerson &amp; Price, 1981) was as a valid<tei:lb/>genus. Potusdia has also been considered as a valid genus, subgenus of Trichodectes and synonym of<tei:lb/>Trichodectes but has not, before this study, been considered a synonym of Stachiella. A more comprehen-<tei:lb/>sive history of the variations in status of Stachiella and Potusdia is given in Table 4.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SPECIES INCLUDED</tei:p>

         <tei:p>?)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>erminiae (Hopkins, 1941) comb. n. from Stachiella (92 d" , 100 $)<tei:lb/>fallax Werneck, 1948 [treated by Werneck (1948) and all subsequent authors as Trichodectes s. str.]</tei:p>

         <tei:p>302 C. H. C. LYAL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>potus Werneck, 1934 [treated by Werneck (1948) and Emerson &amp; Price (1981) as Trichodectes s. str.]</tei:p>

         <tei:p>refiisusrefususBurmeister, 1838 comb. rev. from Stachiella (1 cf , 1 $)<tei:lb/>retusus martis ( Werneck, 1948) comb. n. from Stachiella (1 cf)<tei:lb/>retusussalfii (Conci, 1940) comb. n. from Stachiella</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genus FELICOLA Ewing<tei:lb/>The genus Felicola comprises two subgenera.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Anterior of head with osculum present or absent; dorsal preantennal sulcus present or<tei:lb/>absent; clypeal marginal carina, if osculum absent, with very slight median broadening, or, if osculum<tei:lb/>present," carina broadened medially into dorsal sclerite which is heavily-sclerotised laterally (dorsal to<tei:lb/>margin of clypeus and pulvinus) and very lightly-sclerotised medially (posterior to osculum); anterolateral<tei:lb/>margin of head straight, slightly sinuate or convex; preantennal portion of head long or short, outline<tei:lb/>triangular or broadly rounded*. Temple margin rectangular or convex. Male scape variably expanded or<tei:lb/>not expanded* , with longitudinal setal row present and comprising at least three setae; flagellomeres fused<tei:lb/>in males and females; male flagellum with one or three basally-articulated 'teeth', or variable number of<tei:lb/>'teeth' fused to flagellum, or 'teeth' absent*. Dorsum of head with setae short, of moderate length or long,<tei:lb/>but in any case frequently longer than abdominal tergal setae; setae sparse, though most numerous<tei:lb/>anteriorly and along lateral margins. Sitophore sclerite unmodified.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thorax with dorsal setae long or of moderate length though frequently short and spine-like on<tei:lb/>postero-lateral angles of pterothorax, not present on disc of prothorax or pterothorax.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdomen oval or elongate, frequently terminating in more or less acute projection of segment IX in the<tei:lb/>male (Figs 179, 181, 183-189). Abdominal spiracles absent, or present on segment III, segments III-IV, or<tei:lb/>segments III-V*. Abdominal setae short, of moderate length, or occasionally long and fine* (Figs 182, 186,<tei:lb/>188); male tergum II frequently with 2-6 very long setae medially (Figs 179, 180, 187, 189); abdominal<tei:lb/>pleurum III frequently with posterior setal row comprising stout, conical setae (Figs 181, 182, 188);<tei:lb/>anterior setae, if present, only on pleurum II; postero-lateral setae present or absent. Abdominal pleurum<tei:lb/>III with projections absent, or, if present, dorsal or ventral, sclerotised or unsclerotised; abdominal<tei:lb/>pleurum IV with projections absent or, if present, dorsal and occasionally ventral, sclerotised or<tei:lb/>unsclerotised. Abdominal sclerotisation variable; sternal, tergal and pleural sclerites, if present, generally<tei:lb/>on anterior segments, becoming less clear on posterior segments; male terga sometimes with anterior and<tei:lb/>posterior sclerites, at least on tergum VI*.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gonapophyses with non-tuberculate setae and rounded or rectangular lobe present on ventral margin;<tei:lb/>apical spur present or absent* . Gonapophyses meet ventral vulval margin acutely, not linked by sclerotised<tei:lb/>band. Ventral vulval margin not sclerotised; straight or concave, with chord less than 90 degrees to long<tei:lb/>axis of abdomen; subgenital lobe present, apically single or bifurcate, with margins serrate, at least<tei:lb/>posteriorly (Fig. 175) (see comment below).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male subgenital plate not present, though sternite VIII sometimes with postero-lateral projections<tei:lb/>probably homologous with lateral rods of subgenital plate (Fig. 181). Pseudostyli absent. Male genital<tei:lb/>opening postero-dorsal or dorsal; segment IX frequently produced posteriad. Parameres generally long<tei:lb/>and slender (Figs 191, 192, 197, 201), occasionally broader (Fig. 198); frequently fused completely or,<tei:lb/>more usually, basally only. Basiparameral sclerites absent. Mesomeres present or absent; if present,<tei:lb/>unfused (Fig. 200) or, if fused, median extension absent*. Male genitalia depicted in Figs 190-206.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Herpestidae, Viverridae, Felidae and Canidae (Carnivora).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. Emerson &amp; Price (1980) distinguish the females of their new species Suricatoecus occidentals<tei:lb/>(transferred to Felicola in this study) from other species in the 'helogale Group' (equivalent to the<tei:lb/>congoensis-occidentalis clade) by the presumed absence of the subgenital lobe in occidentalis . Examina-<tei:lb/>tion of the type-series of this species, however, reveals that the subgenital lobe, although very fine, is<tei:lb/>present in all the females. A second species of this clade, close to F. helogaloidis, has been taken from skins<tei:lb/>of Crossarchus obscurus (the host of F. occidentalis) and specimens are in the collection of the British<tei:lb/>Museum (Natural History).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subgenus FELICOLA Ewing<tei:lb/>(Figs 5, 175, 179-185, 190-193, 196-198, 202-204)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FelicolaEwing, l.vi.1929: 121, 122, 192. Type-species: Trichodectes subrostratus Burmeister [attributed to<tei:lb/>Nitzsch], by original designation.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Subgenus SURICATOECUS Bedford stat. n.<tei:lb/>(Figs 176-178, 186-189, 194, 195, 200, 201, 205, 206)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Suricatoecus Bedford, 1932a: 354. Type-species: Trichodectes cooleyi Bedford, by monotypy.<tei:lb/>EichlerellaCond, 1942: 140. Type-species: Trichodectes vulpis Denny, by original designation. [Synonymy<tei:lb/>by Werneck, 1948: 172.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Preantennal portion of head with outline narrowly triangular or broadly rounded. Male<tei:lb/>scape not, or very slightly, expanded; male flagellum with 'teeth' absent or, if present, numbering one or<tei:lb/>three and basally articulated.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdominal spiracles absent, or present on segment III or segments III-V. Abdominal setae very short,<tei:lb/>of moderate length, or long and fine. Tergal and sternal sclerites generally present on abdomen, though<tei:lb/>less clear on posterior segments; male terga never with posterior sclerites.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gonapophyses with rounded or rectangular lobe on ventral margin; spur present.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Everted portion of endophallus never sclerotised.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Canidae and Herpestidae (Carnivora).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. Suricatoecus has been treated not only as a genus, but also as a synonym and a subgenus of<tei:lb/>Felicola (Bedford, 1936 and Hopkins, 1949 respectively); a more complete history of the variations in<tei:lb/>status of Suricatoecus and of Eichlerella is provided in Table 5. Eichler (1963) included the manuscript<tei:lb/>name Felicomorpha in his catalogue, without providing any further details, the name therefore being a<tei:lb/>nomen nudum. In an earlier, unpublished work, Eichler had attributed this name to Keler m.s. , and noted<tei:lb/>the type-species, which is a junior synonym of T. vulpis Denny. Felicomorpha is, however, not an available<tei:lb/>name.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Genus LORISICOLA Bedford<tei:lb/>The genus Lorisicola comprises two subgenera.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Anterior of head with osculum present or absent*; dorsal preantennal sulcus present or<tei:lb/>absent; clypeal marginal carina broadened medially, median sclerite variable*; anterolateral margin of</tei:p>

         <tei:p>C. H. C. LYAL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 218 Lorisicola (Paradoxuroecus) juccii, C? abdomen.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subgenus PAlMDOXl/tfOECI/S Conci gen. rev., stat. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 208, 209, 215-218, 221-226)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paradoxuroecus Conci, 1942: 141. Type-species: Paradoxuroecus juccii Conci, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Parafelicola Werneck, 1948: 226. Type-species: Trichodectes acuticeps Neumann, by original designation.<tei:lb/>Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Neofelicola Werneck, 1948: 235. Type-species: Neofelicola aspidorhynchus Werneck, by original designa-<tei:lb/>tion. Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Anterior of head with osculum present, in which case clypeal marginal carina broadened<tei:lb/>slightly to either side of osculum and very lightly sclerotised posterior to osculum, or osculum absent, in<tei:lb/>which case clypeal marginal carina broadened medially to form posteriorly-convex or straight heavily<tei:lb/>sclerotised bar (Fig. 209); outline of preantennal portion of head more or less broadly rounded or<tei:lb/>triangular, sometimes, if osculum absent, convexly produced anteriorly (Fig. 209). Temple margin convex<tei:lb/>or rectangular. Male scape expanded or only slightly expanded, with longitudinal setal row comprising at<tei:lb/>least three setae; male flagellum with two basally-articulated 'teeth', only rarely on projection.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thorax with dorsal setae short.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abdominal spiracles absent, or present on segments III- VI. Postero-lateral setae present or absent, but<tei:lb/>never numbering more than one per site if present. Males with posterior tergal sclerites absent, or anterior<tei:lb/>and posterior sclerites present on at least terga IV- VII.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gonapophyses with lobe present, rounded or rectangular; apical spur present. Subgenital lobe bilobate,<tei:lb/>with scales modified into short spines in some cases, though spines may be sparse (Fig. 208).</tei:p>
