         <tei:p>2 a MOV h</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The British and some other European Eriococcidae<tei:lb/>(Homoptera: Coccoidea)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>D. J. Williams</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Commonwealth Institute of Entomology, c/o British Museum (Natural History), Cromwell<tei:lb/>Road, London SW7 5BD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Contents</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synopsis 347</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction 347</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acknowledgements and depositories 348</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Morphology 348</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Biology and economic importance 350</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriococcidae Cockerell 351</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to genera of British Eriococcidae 352</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cryptococcus Douglas 352</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriococcus Targioni Tozzetti 356</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Kuwanina Cockerell 384</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Noteococcus Hoy 384</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ovaticoccus Kloet 384</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pseudochermes Nitsche 385</tei:p>
         <tei:p>References 389</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Index 393</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synopsis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eleven of the 12 indigenous British Eriococcidae, Cryptococcus fagisuga Lindinger, Eriococcus devonien-<tei:lb/>sis (Green), E. glyceriae Green, E. greeni Newstead, E. inermis Green, E. insignis Newstead, E. munroi<tei:lb/>(Boratynski), E. placidus Green, E. pseudinsignis Green, E. spurius (Modeer) and Pseudochermes fraxini<tei:lb/>(Kaltenbach), are redescribed; the twelfth species, E. cantium, is described as new. Four introduced<tei:lb/>species, E. lagerstroemiae Kuwana, Kuwanina parva (Maskell), Noteococcus hoheriae (Maskell) and<tei:lb/>Ovaticoccus agavium (Douglas), are discussed. Coccus buxi Fonscolombe, the type-species of Eriococcus<tei:lb/>Targioni Tozzetti, is redescribed, as are Coccus spurius Modeer, Acanthococcus aceris Signoret and<tei:lb/>Rhizococcus gnidii Signoret, the type-species of Gossyparia Signoret, Acanthococcus Signoret and<tei:lb/>Rhizococcus Signoret respectively.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In agreement with some earlier works ? these three genera remain synonyms of Eriococcus but Greenisca<tei:lb/>Borchsenius and Kaweckia Koteja &amp; Zak-Ogaza are newly synonymised with Eriococcus. R. gnidii is<tei:lb/>newly synonymised with E. thy mi (Schrank). An unnamed species of Eriococcus near E. buxi, occurring in<tei:lb/>the U.S.S.R. and Turkey, is also discussed and lectotypes of the British species are designated, where<tei:lb/>appropriate. There are sections also on morphology, biology and economic importance.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The family Eriococcidae has been formerly associated with the Pseudococcidae, or mealybugs,<tei:lb/>but the two are now considered to be distinct, and Afifi (1968) has given good characters to<tei:lb/>separate the adult males of both families. Ferris (1957a, 1957ft) discussed numerous genera,<tei:lb/>based on the female, that might be included in the Eriococcidae, and defined the family, mainly<tei:lb/>on negative characters or without certain characters normally found in other families of scale<tei:lb/>insects. Many genera that have been included in the family have never been studied critically and<tei:lb/>their affinities may lie elsewhere.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In order to establish the true relationships and possible phylogeny of the Eriococcidae, Dr J.<tei:lb/>M. Cox, British Museum (Natural History), and the present writer are currently studying the<tei:lb/>group on a world basis, and it is hoped to publish on these aspects later. In the meantime this</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bull. Br. Mus. Nat. Hist. (Ent . ) 51 (4) : 347-393 Issued 28 November 1985</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>348 D. J. WILLIAMS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>paper has been written to facilitate identification of the British species currently assigned to the<tei:lb/>family, and to discuss some European genera, the type-species of which are not British although<tei:lb/>such genera have been recorded from Britain.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Williams (1984) discussed briefly the distribution of the family and commented on its possible<tei:lb/>origins in Gondwanaland. It is poorly represented in the tropics and much speciation has taken<tei:lb/>place in the more temperate areas. The North American fauna was described by Ferris (1955)<tei:lb/>(under the name Dactylopiidae) and by Miller &amp; McKenzie (1967). Much of the Palaearctic<tei:lb/>fauna has been discussed in recent years by Borchsenius (1949), Danzig (1962, 1980), Dziedicka<tei:lb/>&amp; Koteja (1971) and Tereznikova (1981). Some interesting species from South America have<tei:lb/>been described by Miller &amp; Gonzalez (1975) and a thorough study of the 75 New Zealand species<tei:lb/>was made by Hoy (1962). The British species were listed by Boratynski &amp; Williams (1964). Of<tei:lb/>the 481 species included by Hoy (1963) in his catalogue of world species, almost 150 are known<tei:lb/>from Australia. It is doubtful, however, if more than one or two Australian species can be<tei:lb/>identified from the present literature and, because the Australian Region probably includes<tei:lb/>some of the most interesting and bizarre species, it is clear that a definition of the family and its<tei:lb/>limits can only be made after the Australian species have been studied adequately. Species from<tei:lb/>the Oriental Region, although at present rather few, are virtually unrecognisable from the<tei:lb/>literature and need revising.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acknowledgements and depositories</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The writer is much indebted to Dr A. Kaltenbach, Naturhistorisches Museum, Vienna, who has<tei:lb/>kindly supplied for study specimens from V. Signoret's collection mentioned in the text. Mrs D.<tei:lb/>Matile-Ferrero, Museum National d'Histoire Naturelle, Paris, has sent for study valuable<tei:lb/>material of Rhizococcus gnidii and Eriococcus thy mi collected in France, for which the writer<tei:lb/>extends his sincere thanks. Dr J. M. Cox, British Museum (Natural History), has given much<tei:lb/>help in discussions during the preparation of the manuscript.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Most of the material studied is deposited in the British Museum (Natural History) (BMNH)<tei:lb/>but other depositories of original material mentioned are the Imperial Agricultural Experiment<tei:lb/>Station, Tokyo (IAES) and the New Zealand Arthropod Collection, Auckland (NZAC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Morphology</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Many of the characters of the North American species were discussed by Ferris (1955) and by<tei:lb/>Miller &amp; McKenzie (1967), resulting in definitions of the family for this area. The morphology<tei:lb/>has also been discussed by Danzig (1980) and Hoy (1962) and a study of the labium was made by<tei:lb/>Koteja (19740). Present studies of the British and other genera have revealed characters that<tei:lb/>have not normally been used to separate species or genera and these characters are discussed<tei:lb/>briefly here.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There is no generally accepted common name for the family but the names 'felted scale<tei:lb/>insects' or 'felted coccids' have gained some acceptance and the former name could easily be<tei:lb/>used. The name refers to the ovisac produced by most species from the dorsum and the ventral<tei:lb/>margins. This ovisac, secreted from ducts, has a felted texture and completely covers the top of<tei:lb/>the insect except for a hole at the posterior end, allowing first instars to escape. The felted sac<tei:lb/>combines with mealy secretion on the venter, but on the dorsum rods of wax that seem to be<tei:lb/>produced from the dorsal setae are also present. Many slide preparations show these rods<tei:lb/>attached to the enlarged setae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Body shape and segmentation. The shape of the body varies from globular to broadly-oval and<tei:lb/>elongate, and although species may be found on leaves, stems and roots, the elongate species are<tei:lb/>usually found on grasses. In many species the body is strongly nodulose and when this takes up<tei:lb/>stain, it often masks minute characters. Numbering of the segments follows that given by Miller<tei:lb/>(1984) for Eriococcidae and by Williams (19850) for Pseudococcidae. In this system the vulva is<tei:lb/>situated between the 7th and 8th abdominal segments, so that the first abdominal segment on the<tei:lb/>venter is represented by areas lateral to the 3rd coxae and the 2nd abdominal segment is</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE BRITISH AND SOME OTHER EUROPEAN ERIOCOCCIDAE 349</tei:p>
         <tei:p>complete after the metathorax. On the dorsum the 1st abdominal segment is complete, but<tei:lb/>because the segment containing the anal lobes is probably complex, it is here regarded as the 8th<tei:lb/>or anal lobe segment.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Anal area. In many genera of Eriococcidae the posterior end of the body is produced into two<tei:lb/>prominent anal lobes, each usually sclerotised and often conical with a long apical seta. Dorsally<tei:lb/>there are frequently enlarged setae, varying in number, but in most species there are two such<tei:lb/>setae on the inner edge and one on the outer edge, although this may be reduced to a much<tei:lb/>smaller seta. Ventrally there are flagellate setae, often numbering 1-3, and near the inner corner<tei:lb/>of each lobe there is a seta that Hoy (1962) named the suranal seta. This is usually slender but in<tei:lb/>some genera it is flat or spatulate. In all the species discussed here the suranal setae are slender.<tei:lb/>Sometimes the inner edges of the lobes are so strongly nodulose and sclerotised that they appear<tei:lb/>to be toothed or serrate. When there are no definite anal lobes present the suranal setae are<tei:lb/>represented by a pair just anterior to the anal ring on the venter. Species with anal lobes often<tei:lb/>have a small dorsal lobe or plate projecting between the base of the lobes. It varies from being<tei:lb/>only a slight prominence to triangular, well developed and nodulose. In some species it is heavily<tei:lb/>sclerotised in the form of a definite plate, as in Eriococcus phyllanthi Ferris, and this led Ferris<tei:lb/>(19576) to refer to it as a cauda. It is not certain whether this plate is homologous with the cauda<tei:lb/>of the Aphidoidea and it is here called a dorsal plate no matter what the extent of its<tei:lb/>development is. The anal ring, in species with well-developed anal lobes, is normally situated<tei:lb/>vertically to the body between the dorsal plate and the apical margin of the venter between the<tei:lb/>suranal setae. When prepared on microscope slides it often becomes distorted or is pushed<tei:lb/>inwards, lying neither on the dorsum nor venter. Although the shape varies considerably, and<tei:lb/>this is mentioned in the text when appropriate, a normal anal ring usually has 8 setae and a single<tei:lb/>row of pores, except laterally, where there are a few pores forming a double row.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Antennae. These vary from being normal with 6 or 7 segments, to small stubs with 1 or 2<tei:lb/>segments. A normal antenna appears to taper, with the terminal segment usually one of the<tei:lb/>shortest and not wider than the previous segments.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Frontal lobes and frontal tubercles. Often just antero-medially to each basal antennal segment<tei:lb/>there is a lobe-like structure that varies in size and length. They are much more pronounced in<tei:lb/>distorted specimens when they can be observed to stick out from the surface. Normally they are<tei:lb/>membranous but sometimes, as in Eriococcus buxi and its relative herein described, they tend to<tei:lb/>be sclerotised. Their function is unknown. Signoret (1875) mentioned these lobes when<tei:lb/>describing Acanthococcus aceris. Boratynski described them as eversible membranous tubercles<tei:lb/>in A. munroi but there is no evidence that they are eversible. They were mentioned also by<tei:lb/>Dziedicka &amp; Koteja (1971) when describing Rhizococcus palustris. These structures seem to<tei:lb/>have been ignored in most other works but Dr J. M. Cox and the present writer have observed<tei:lb/>them in numerous species from all the zoogeographical regions. In at least one species from<tei:lb/>Australia these lobes extend around and posterior to the basal antennal segment; for this reason<tei:lb/>a more appropriate term would be frontal lobes and this term is used throughout this work.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Frontal tubercles are minute raised spots situated antero-medially to each antennal base.<tei:lb/>They are difficult to see but once their normal position is located their presence or absence can<tei:lb/>be noted. Again, their function is unknown but they seem to be homologous with the 'conical<tei:lb/>disc pores' mentioned by Ben-Dov et al. (1975) in Protopulvinaria mangiferae (Green), and to<tei:lb/>the 'preantennal spots' discussed by Ben-Dov (1979) in species of Kilifia. The species in these<tei:lb/>genera belong to the family Coccidae and the presence of these tubercles may be much more<tei:lb/>common throughout the group. They are certainly present in many species of Eriococcidae and<tei:lb/>may have some taxonomic significance. In all species studied so far, frontal lobes and frontal<tei:lb/>tubercles never occur together and one may have been derived from the other. Pseudochermes<tei:lb/>fraxini, herein described, possesses frontal tubercles in all instars and this may be normal, but<tei:lb/>some species have neither frontal lobes nor frontal tubercles.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Legs. Unlike species of Pseudococcidae, most of which have the tibia longer than the tarsus, the<tei:lb/>tarsus in the Eriococcidae is often longer than the tibia. Also the trochanter pores in the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>350 D. J. WILLIAMS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriococcidae form a line from the anterior lateral corner to about half-way along the posterior<tei:lb/>edge, more or less dividing the trochanter into two equal parts. In the Pseudococcidae the<tei:lb/>trochanter pores are situated towards the distal end.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Labium. The basal segment often has 2 pairs of setae but in some genera these are reduced to a<tei:lb/>single pair. In Cryptococcusfagisuga, herein described, they are absent except in the first instar<tei:lb/>when a single pair is present.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Setae. On the dorsum and ventral edges, there are often enlarged setae that are spine-like,<tei:lb/>conical, pointed, blunt or truncate, but sometimes they are cylindrical, lanceolate or even<tei:lb/>bulbous. Sometimes they are interspersed by quite slender setae. In some species, enlarged<tei:lb/>setae are confined to the anal lobes or they are absent entirely, but usually the dorsal setae,<tei:lb/>which may be minute, show some signs of being stiff and not flagellate. When the dorsal setae<tei:lb/>tend to be small and slender in the adult, there are usually thicker setae in at least the first instar.<tei:lb/>On the median part of the venter, what are here referred to as normal setae are flagellate setae<tei:lb/>found in many groups of the Coccoidea. Laterally there are often other setae which, although<tei:lb/>slender, are nevertheless stiff.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Macroducts. These have been discussed by Ferris (1955), Miller &amp; McKenzie (1967), Miller<tei:lb/>(1984) and by many other workers. They normally have the inner end reflexed in the form of a<tei:lb/>cup and, although found in some other families, they represent one of the most important<tei:lb/>characters of the Eriococcidae, although sometimes they are absent entirely.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Microducts. The significance of these minute ducts has been little understood but their structure<tei:lb/>may indicate affinities and evolutionary paths. They have been discussed in some detail by Goux<tei:lb/>(1948). Normally the inner end is bulbous, and the term ampulla is here adopted for it. It usually<tei:lb/>bears a minute filament arising from the inner end. Between the ampulla and the external orifice<tei:lb/>there is a tube varying from filamentous and slender to short and bulbous at the inner end, and<tei:lb/>situated internally just next to the orifice there is a structure often wing-nut-shaped in profile but<tei:lb/>which is here called a collar. Sometimes the orifice is bifid, as shown already by Miller &amp;<tei:lb/>Gonzalez (1975) in Eriococcus araucariae Maskell. The bifid orifice is external and may be seen<tei:lb/>on microducts at the edge of the body where the bifid part protrudes from the surface of the<tei:lb/>integument. They are not internal as shown by Hoy (1962) for E. araucariae. It is still not clear<tei:lb/>whether the shape and type of the microduct has generic significance. Cryptococcus fagisuga<tei:lb/>herein described possess microducts in the form of a double tube.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Enlarged ducts. These are illustrated here in E. buxi and E. sp. near buxi. They are usually larger<tei:lb/>than the macroducts but differ in having a flat or slightly rounded inner end, instead of being<tei:lb/>reflexed into a cup. Because Eriococcus possesses these ducts, Borchsenius (1949) separated this<tei:lb/>genus from all others. The significance of these special ducts is still not clear because Miller &amp;<tei:lb/>Gonzalez (1975) discussed them in Exallococcus laureliae Miller &amp; Gonzalez. Furthermore,<tei:lb/>some Australian species currently assigned to Eriococcus also have them.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pores. Although the disc pores are usually quinquelocular, there are often pores with up to 9<tei:lb/>loculi. They are usually on the ventral surface but when present on the dorsum they have<tei:lb/>sometimes been given generic significance. Cruciform pores are usually oval with a central slit in<tei:lb/>the form of a cross. When present they are usually found on the venter but their presence on the<tei:lb/>dorsum has been given generic importance by Koteja &amp; Zag-Ogaza (1981) when describing<tei:lb/>Kaweckia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Biology and economic importance</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Little work has been done on the biology of the British Eriococcidae, but Newstead (1903) has<tei:lb/>given useful field notes on some species. Gullan (1984) included the specialised gall-forming<tei:lb/>genus Apiomorpha in the family and has given important information on gall formation.<tei:lb/>Normally British species are univoltine but Patel (1971), discussing Eriococcus coriaceus<tei:lb/>Maskell from South Australia, has stated that it has five generations a year there.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE BRITISH AND SOME OTHER EUROPEAN ERIOCOCCIDAE 351</tei:p>
         <tei:p>British species are oviparous but whether this is true for all Eriococcidae is not clear from the<tei:lb/>literature. So far as is known, there are always three instars in the female and five in the male<tei:lb/>when present. Koteja (1983) has discussed an additional moult in Acanthococcus greeni<tei:lb/>(Newstead) after the adult female had formed, but this was probably caused by parasitism. In<tei:lb/>Pseudococcidae there are normally four female instars.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The ovisac in the indigenous British species is felted but, apart from the gall-forming species,<tei:lb/>it is not clear how the covering of many is formed. In Ovaticoccus agavium it is described by<tei:lb/>Boratynski (1958) as loosely felted. The ovisac of Eriococcus spurius in mature^ adults is present<tei:lb/>only around the margins, but this is because there are no macroducts in the median areas. The<tei:lb/>insect is, therefore, easily recognisable and is specific to elms.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Most of the British species feed on grasses but it is not known if they cause damage.<tei:lb/>Eriococcus devoniensis is always found on Erica tetralix in Britain, causing the stems to turn a<tei:lb/>complete circle enclosing the insect and ovisac in the bend. Large areas of the plant can be killed<tei:lb/>and this led Warburton (1937) to recommend burning to destroy the insect. Pseudochermes<tei:lb/>fraxini is found in enormous numbers in the crevices of bark of ash trees and often causes<tei:lb/>concern, but so far there are no records of mortality of trees. By far the most important insect is<tei:lb/>Cryptococcusfagisuga, found in the crevices of bark of beech trees. It is particularly prevalent in<tei:lb/>older trees (Wainhouse, 1980, states that trees around 25 years of age are particularly<tei:lb/>susceptible) and the species is probably found throughout Britain wherever beech is grown.<tei:lb/>Parker (1975) has stated that beech planted in southern England 1951-60 will be susceptible<tei:lb/>during the 1980s. The insect is probably the only parthenogenetic species of Eriococcidae in<tei:lb/>Britain and is often present in'enormous numbers producing what has been termed fluffy white<tei:lb/>wool, so that trunks appear to be completely white. Despite the large numbers, the insects<tei:lb/>themselves apparently do not cause damage. But, associated with the insect is an ascomycete<tei:lb/>fungus, Nectria sp., known as 'beech bark disease', a name coined by Ehrlich (1934) in a<tei:lb/>comprehensive account of the disease and insect in Canada and U.S.A. The fungus causes<tei:lb/>considerable damage resulting in mortality of the tree, and is dependent on the insect for<tei:lb/>providing an entry wound at the point of feeding. Parker (1975) showed that Nectria infected the<tei:lb/>bark only following wounding, but as Lonsdale (1980) has shown, heavy infestations of the<tei:lb/>insect induce a lowering of resistance to fungal invasion within bark tissue.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the Old World the insect is distributed throughout Europe, with incursions into Turkey and<tei:lb/>Iran. Covassi (1975) stated that Sicily is the southern limit, and the Commonwealth Institute of<tei:lb/>Entomology (1979) has produced a map showing the world distribution. Thomsen et al. (1949)<tei:lb/>gave a full and important account of the insect and fungus in Denmark. In Britain the insect has<tei:lb/>been made the subject of a Forestry Commission Leaflet (Hussey, 1956). Wainhouse (1979)<tei:lb/>showed that the larvae are dispersed passively by wind and a small percentage are carried above<tei:lb/>the canopy. Some trees are more susceptible than others (Wainhouse &amp; Howell, 1983) and,<tei:lb/>although there is possible intraspecific variation within populations of the beech scale, there is<tei:lb/>no evidence of adaptation of the scale to particular trees.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It was reported by Elliott (1933) that, in Suffolk, this species was devoured by a small beetle,<tei:lb/>Enicmus [now Lathridius] minutus (L.), but this was unlikely because the beetle is normally a<tei:lb/>fungus-feeder.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ERIOCOCCIDAE Cockerell</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acanthococcites Signoret, 1875: 16. Type-genus: Acanthococcus Signoret. [Placed on Official List of<tei:lb/>Family-Group Names in Zoology (Name Number 535) with an endorsement that it is not to be given<tei:lb/>priority over Eriococcini Cockerell, 1899 whenever both names are held to denote a single taxon<tei:lb/>(Melville, 1982: 96).]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acanthococcidae Signoret; Maskell, 1887: 47.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriococcini Cockerell, 18990: 389. Type-genus: Eriococcus Targioni Tozzetti. [Placed on Official List of<tei:lb/>Family-Group Names in Zoology (Name Number 534) with an endorsement that it is to be given<tei:lb/>precedence over Acanthococcidae Signoret, 1875 whenever both names are held to denote a single<tei:lb/>taxon (Melville, 1982: 96).]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriococcidae Cockerell; Brues &amp; Melander, 1932: 134.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>352 D. J. WILLIAMS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cryptococcidae Kosztarab, 1968ft: 12. Type-genus: Cryptococcus Douglas. [Synonymised with Eriococci-<tei:lb/>dae by Danzig, 1980: 58.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Until all genera are studied, including the peculiar gall-producing forms, it is impossible to<tei:lb/>define the family on a world basis. The following definition is based only on species that have<tei:lb/>been studied in some detail.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ADULT FEMALES. Body elongate, broadly oval or globular, usually membranous but often strongly<tei:lb/>nodulose. Segmentation usually distinct in the oval and elongate forms, obscure in the globular forms.<tei:lb/>Anal lobes often well developed, conical and sclerotised; when present usually with a dorsal plate between<tei:lb/>and with suranal setae at inner ventral bases. Anal ring often with 8 setae and pores, sometimes reduced,<tei:lb/>without pores. Antennae, when normal, with 6 or 7 segments, the apical segment usually narrower than<tei:lb/>preceding segments, sometimes segments reduced to one or two. Frontal lobes or frontal tubercles<tei:lb/>sometimes present. Legs present or absent; when absent sometimes third pair represented by minute flaps;<tei:lb/>when present and normal, tibia frequently longer than tarsus, trochanter pores in a line almost dividing<tei:lb/>trochanter into two equal parts. Labium usually with 1 or 2 pairs of setae on basal segment, rarely absent<tei:lb/>entirely. Dorsal setae often enlarged, conical, bulbous or cylindrical, if small, remaining spine-like or stiff.<tei:lb/>Disc pores, when present, usually quinquelocular, but sometimes with up to 9 loculi, frequently on venter<tei:lb/>and sometimes on dorsum. Macroducts normally present, at least on dorsum, sometimes absent.<tei:lb/>Microducts usually present. Cruciform pores often present on venter, rarely on dorsum.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to genera of British Eriococcidae<tei:lb/>Adult females</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Legs absent except for third pair replaced by small leg flaps</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Legs present</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Macroducts present on dorsum , CRYPTOCOCCUS Douglas (p. 352)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Macroducts absent on dorsum, replaced by large invaginated quinquelocular pores</tei:p>
         <tei:p>KUWANINA Cockerell(p. 384)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Anal lobes present, sclerotised 4</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Anal lobes absent 5</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4 Anal lobes with a series of about 12 enlarged setae on dorsum. Segmentation absent between</tei:p>
         <tei:p>trochanter and femur and between tibia and tarsus NOTEOCOCCUS Hoy (p. 384)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Anal lobes with at most 4 enlarged setae on dorsum. Segmentation distinct between trochanter<tei:lb/>and femur and between tibia and tarsus ERIOCOCCUS Targioni Tozzetti (p. 356)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5 Anal ring crescentic, containing pores and setae. Cruciform pores absent</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PSEUDOCHERMES Nitsche(p. 385)<tei:lb/>Anal ring not as above, without pores. Cruciform pores present OVATICOCCUS Kloet (p. 384)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CRYPTOCOCCUS Douglas</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cryptococcus Douglas, 1890: 155. Type-species: Coccus fagi Baerensprung [= Cryptococcus fagisuga<tei:lb/>Lindinger], by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The type-species is now known to occur on Fagus spp. throughout Europe and the eastern part of the<tei:lb/>U.S.A. C. aceris Borchsenius is known from Georgia and Azerbaizhan in U.S.S.R. and from Germany on<tei:lb/>Acer. Another species on Acer was described as C. williamsi Kosztarab from eastern U.S.A., and C.<tei:lb/>integricornis Danzig is known from the Primorsky region in the far east of U.S.S.R. on Tilia amurensis.<tei:lb/>Kosztarab (1968a) gave a key to the species known at the time.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>All four species are without legs in the adult female, but the hind pair are replaced by small flaps. In the<tei:lb/>type-species these are simple, each with at most a single seta, but in the other species the flaps are either<tei:lb/>reticulate or they possess minute pores. When viewed at the edge of the body these structures are flap-like<tei:lb/>and protrude . They are not plates on the surface of the body or pore plates , as has been suggested ; because<tei:lb/>they are always in the positions of the third legs and probably emit pheromones they are here referred to as<tei:lb/>leg flaps. C. integricornis possesses also spine-like remains of the first and second pairs of legs. All four<tei:lb/>species have 2-5 segmented antennae that are stub-like, and macroducts each with a cup-shaped inner end<tei:lb/>on the dorsum and at least the ventral margins. Microducts are present. In the type-species they are in the<tei:lb/>form of double tubes, the ampulla of each being expanded, with a filament between. The microducts of the<tei:lb/>other species need more critical study. Quinquelocular pores are present and the anal ring is simple, square<tei:lb/>or oval with 4-6 setae and a few pores. In C. fagisuga the basal segment of the labium is without setae but</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE BRITISH AND SOME OTHER EUROPEAN ERIOCOCCIDAE 353</tei:p>
         <tei:p>there is a single pair present in the first instar. Specimens of C. fagisuga, C. aceris and C. williamsi<tei:lb/>examined possess neither frontal lobes nor frontal tubercles.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hoy (1962) accepted C. nudatus Brittin in the genus. The species was described from New Zealand on<tei:lb/>Hoheria spp., but because it lacks macroducts it may belong to another genus, although it is very close.<tei:lb/>Kuwanina parva (Maskell), described from Japan and recorded from Britain on Prunus, has at one time<tei:lb/>been assigned to Cryptococcus, but the genus Kuwanina is here accepted as distinct because it lacks<tei:lb/>macroducts. These are replaced by large invaginated quinquelocular pores.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cryptococcus is represented by C. fagisuga only in Britain, where it is sometimes injurious to beech.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cryptococcus fagisuga Lindinger<tei:lb/>(Figs 1,2)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cocotf/ag/ Baerensprung, 1849: 174. Syntypes $, GERMANY: Berlin (probably lost). [Junior homonym of</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coccus /og/Sulzer, 1776.]<tei:lb/>Coccus fagi Walker, 1852: 1086. LECTOTYPE $, ENGLAND (BMNH), here designated [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[Junior homonym of Coccus fagi Sulzer, 1776.]<tei:lb/>Pseudococcus fagi (Baerensprung) Douglas, 1886: 152.<tei:lb/>Cryptococcus fagi (Baerensprung) Douglas, 1890: 155; Newstead, 1903: 215; Schmutterer, 1952: 417;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ferris, 1955: 83; Tereznikova, 1981: 46.<tei:lb/>Cryptococcus fagisuga Lindinger, 1936: 444; Borchsenius, 1949: 37; Hoy, 1963: 54; Danzig, 1964: 634.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[Replacement name for Coccus fagi Baerensprung.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult female (Fig. 1) in life, globular, bright to lemon yellow, completely covered in a white<tei:lb/>ovisac. On the slide, rotund, membranous, nodulose, largest about 0-6 /u,m in diameter, often wider than<tei:lb/>long, anal lobes not developed, their positions removed to ventral surface of body. Antennae reduced,<tei:lb/>with 1-2 segments. Legs absent but position of each third leg represented by a small flap often containing a<tei:lb/>single seta. Labium 48 /um long, often wider than long, shorter than clypeolabral shield, basal segment<tei:lb/>without setae. Spiracles often triangular, sclerotised. Anal ring at apex of venter, sclerotised, almost<tei:lb/>quadrate, with 4 short setae 12 /um long occupying corners, a few minute pores on posterior margin or<tei:lb/>morphologically anterior margin.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dorsal surface with small setae that are pointed and stiff, 5 /im long, in more or less single rows across the<tei:lb/>segments. Macroducts in single rows across the segments, each about 8 ^tm long, with the cup wider than a<tei:lb/>dorsal setal base. Microducts in moderate numbers, each about 6 /u,m long, in the form of a double tube<tei:lb/>tapering towards double orifice, each tube with inner end swollen into an ampulla with a filament between.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventral surface with setae about same size as dorsal setae except on anal lobe segment where the suranal<tei:lb/>setae, and one or two near margins, are larger and conical, about 10 /u,m long and usually a pair of slightly<tei:lb/>longer setae near anterolateral corners of anal ring, probably the anal lobe setae. Macroducts of two types.<tei:lb/>A large type, similar to those on dorsum, few, around margins and sometimes in submarginal areas of<tei:lb/>thorax and anterior abdominal segments. A small type, not much larger than a microduct, arranged singly<tei:lb/>in submedian areas of third to fifth abdominal segments and on metathorax anterior to leg-flaps, each duct<tei:lb/>with a shallow cup. Microducts, same as on dorsum, sparse, present in median areas as well as margins.<tei:lb/>Quinquelocular pores, about same diameter as the cup of a large macroduct, in more or less single rows on<tei:lb/>posterior abdominal segments, there being also one or two near each spiracular opening and one or two<tei:lb/>between clypeolabral shield and labium.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Second instar female (Fig. 2B) broadly oval, smaller than adult female. Antennae near margins,<tei:lb/>2-segmented, reduced. Legs absent but position of each third leg represented by a minute sclerotised point.<tei:lb/>Labium 36 /urn long, smaller than clypeolabral shield, basal segment without setae. Anal ring on venter at<tei:lb/>apex of abdomen , similar to that of adult but smaller. Dorsal surface with small pointed but stiff setae, each<tei:lb/>4 fjLm long, many not much longer than a setal base. Macroducts smaller than in adult female, present in<tei:lb/>single transverse rows on most segments. Microducts, as in adult, bitubular, represented by one or two<tei:lb/>only. Ventral surface with setae as on dorsum except for larger conical setae lateral to anal ring, a pair of<tei:lb/>which longer than others and probably apical setae. Suranal setae small. Macroducts same as on dorsum,<tei:lb/>occasionally on margins only. Microducts represented by one or two on margins only. Quinquelocular<tei:lb/>pores arranged singly next to spiracular openings only.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>First instar (Fig. 2A), oval, the smallest 300 [im long, 180 urn wide. Anal ring displaced to apex of venter,<tei:lb/>as in later instars but smaller. Antennae 65 /xm long, with 5 segments. Legs normal, hind trochanter +<tei:lb/>femur 40 /um long, hind tibia 16 /urn long, hind tarsus 16 ^tm long, claw slender, without a denticle, 16 /xm<tei:lb/>long. Labium 32 /um long, basal segment with a pair of minute setae. Dorsal surface with short pointed and<tei:lb/>stiff setae, 4-5 pm long, but some on head longer and flagellate. Macroducts absent. Microducts</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>354</tei:p>
         <tei:p>D. J. WILLIAMS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>D.J.W.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>\</tei:p>

         <tei:p>356 D. J. WILLIAMS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>represented at most by one or two varying in position. Quinquelocular disc pores sparse, rarely more than 2<tei:lb/>on any segment. Ventral surface with short setae similar to dorsal setae except for apical setae each 40 yxm<tei:lb/>long, larger conical setae lateral to anal lobes, and longer flagellate setae on head. Suranal setae small.<tei:lb/>Macroducts and microducts absent. Quinquelocular pores few in submarginal areas of abdomen and head<tei:lb/>and singly near spiracular openings. One or two pores medially to first and second coxa often trilocular, but<tei:lb/>this condition not constant. A minute indefinite scar present lateral to third coxae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED (all on Fagus sylvatica unless stated otherwise)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>England: Berkshire, Silwood Park, 5.V.1948, 17.iii.1950, 29.V.1959 (K. L. Boratynski), Cookham,<tei:lb/>4.iv.l973, ll.viii.1983 (D. J. Williams); Buckinghamshire, Burnham Beeches, 18.iii.1973, 1, 4, 15,<tei:lb/>23.iv.1973 (D. J. Williams); Cheshire, nr Chester, 1890 (R. Newstead), Ince, xi.1895 (R. Newstead);<tei:lb/>Hampshire, Bolderwood, 29.iii.1975 (J. H. Martin); Kent, Mailing, ix.1895 (E. E. Green), Bearsted,<tei:lb/>27.vii.1913 (E. E. Green), nr Canterbury, 19.V.1973 (L. M. Hanford); London, Buckingham Palace<tei:lb/>Gardens, S.x.1963 (K. L. Boratynski); Northumberland, Riding Mill, S.x.1950 (D. J. Williams); Shrop-<tei:lb/>shire, l.xi.1933 (E. E. Edwards); Suffolk, xi.1970; Surrey, Camberley, 25.V.1920, 10.iv.1930 (E. E.<tei:lb/>Green), Wisley, 4.vii.l954 (D. J. Williams); Yorkshire, Bingley, lO.x.1933 (G. Fox-Wilson), Hardcastle<tei:lb/>Crags, 22.viii.1961 (D. J. Williams). Scotland: Aberdeen, iv.1924 (G. D. Morison). Luxembourg:<tei:lb/>Beaufort, 29.vi.1961 (K. L. Boratynski). Hungary: Nagymilis Laszlotanya, 12.viii.1980 (F. Kozdr &amp; M.<tei:lb/>Kosztarab). U.S.A.: Vermont, on F. grandifolia, 8.V.1975.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISCUSSION. When discussing the homonymy of Coccus fagi, Lindinger (1936) referred to Roemer (1789)<tei:lb/>who gave an illustration. The first 32 plates of this work are a re-issue of those in Sulzer (1776) where on<tei:lb/>Plate XI, fig. 11 there is an illustration in colour of C. fagi. This seems to be Eulecanium tiliae (L.) as<tei:lb/>present understood.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>C. fagisuga is always parthenogenetic insofar as males have never been found.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although Walker made numerous slide preparations of aphids, there is no evidence that he made any<tei:lb/>slide preparations of the scale insects that he described. A batch of dry material mounted on a card labelled<tei:lb/>Coccus fagi in Walker's handwriting is present in BMNH. This is here regarded as Walker's original<tei:lb/>material and among 9 specimens prepared on separate microscope slides one has been selected as<tei:lb/>lectotype. The other 8 are labelled paralectotypes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ERIOCOCCUS Targioni Tozzetti</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriococcus Targioni Tozzetti, 1868: 726. Type-species: Coccus buxi Fonscolombe, by subsequent designa-<tei:lb/>tion (Signoret, 1872: 429) and by Opinion 1203 (Melville, 1982: 95).<tei:lb/>Gossyparia Signoret, 1875: 20. Type-species: Coccus ulmi Linnaeus sensu Linnaeus, 1766 [= Coccus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>spurius Modeer, 1778.], by original designation. [Synonymised by Ferris, 1955: 94.]<tei:lb/>Acanthococcus Signoret, 1875: 35. Type-species: Acanthococcus aceris Signoret, by monotypy and by</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Opinion 1203 (Melville, 1982: 95). [Synonymised by Ferris, 1955: 94.]<tei:lb/>Rhizococcus Signoret, 1875: 36. Type-species: Rhizococcus gnidii Signoret, by monotypy. [Synonymised</tei:p>
         <tei:p>by Ferris, 1955:94.]<tei:lb/>Greenisca Borchsenius, 1948: 502. Type-species: Eriococcus inermis Green, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Syn. n.<tei:lb/>Anophococcus Balachowsky, 1954: 61. Type-species: Eriococcus inermis Green, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[Synonymised with Acanthococcus Signoret by Danzig, 1980: 205.]<tei:lb/>Kaweckia Koteja &amp; Zak-Ogaza, 1981: 501. Type-species: Eriococcus glyceriae Green, by original</tei:p>
         <tei:p>designation. Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriococcus Targioni Tozzetti; Melville, 1982: 95. [Addition to Official List, Name Number 2153.]<tei:lb/>Acanthococcus Signoret; Melville, 1982: 95. [Addition to Official List, Name Number 2154.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although in time it may be necessary to recognise some of the genera Synonymised above, they are here<tei:lb/>regarded as components of Eriococcus pending further research on the family and until the characters of<tei:lb/>microducts, frontal lobes and tubercles can be assessed on a world basis. As Ferris (1955) has mentioned,<tei:lb/>division of the group seems undesirable (except for extreme forms) until comprehensive studies have been<tei:lb/>made, especially of the Australian fauna. Some reasons for the synonymy need explanation, however.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriococcus. This genus was separated by Borchsenius (1948, 1949) because the type-species possesses<tei:lb/>enlarged ducts. As already stated, some Australian species possess these ducts and their true significance is<tei:lb/>not yet known. The type-species also has well-developed frontal lobes, slender microducts with bifid orifice<tei:lb/>and only a single ventral seta on the anal lobes. Borchsenius based his interpretation of the type-species on<tei:lb/>Russian specimens which do not appear to be identical with specimens from the type-locality in France.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE BRITISH AND SOME OTHER EUROPEAN ERIOCOCCIDAE 357</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acanthococcus. The most important characters separating the type-species from Eriococcus are the<tei:lb/>absence of enlarged ducts and the presence of 2 ventral setae instead of one on the anal lobes and 2 pairs of<tei:lb/>setae on the basal segment of the labium instead of a single pair. Frontal lobes are well developed and the<tei:lb/>microducts are slender with bifid orifice. At present there seems to be no reason for recognising the genus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gossyparia. Based on the type-species, this is almost a replica of Acanthococcus but lacks dorsal<tei:lb/>macroducts in the median areas of the dorsum, regarded here as nothing more than a specific character.<tei:lb/>There are well-developed frontal lobes and the microducts are slender with bifid orifice.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rhizococcus. The genus was separated from Acanthococcus originally because, in the type-species, the<tei:lb/>antennae had 7 segments instead of 6 and because the body was presumed to be naked. It is now known that<tei:lb/>a normal ovisac is produced and the antennae may have either 6 or 7 segments. Other characters present<tei:lb/>are frontal tubercles instead of frontal lobes and slender microducts with bifid orifice. With our present<tei:lb/>knowledge the genus is not distinctive enough from Eriococcus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Greenisca. There are nomenclatural problems concerning the type-species. According to Danzig (1962)<tei:lb/>the species on which Borchsenius (1948) based Greenisca was not E. inermis Green but another species,<tei:lb/>which Danzig (1980) stated, was later described as Anophococcus gouxi Balachowsky; the type-species,<tei:lb/>therefore, of Greenisca should be A. gouxi Balachowsky, 1954 = E. inermis Green sensu Borchsenius<tei:lb/>1948. Article 70 of the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature states that 'if a zoologist considers<tei:lb/>that a type-species designated for a new genus has been misidentified, then that person should refer the<tei:lb/>case to the Commission to designate as the type-species whichever species will in its judgement best serve<tei:lb/>stability and uniformity of nomenclature . . .' Furthermore, the anal lobes of G. gouxi illustrated by<tei:lb/>Danzig (1980) have three enlarged setae but the same species illustrated by Balachowsky (1954) has the<tei:lb/>outer seta much reduced in size. E. inermis Green has a minute outer seta on the anal lobes, frontal<tei:lb/>tubercles and microducts without bifid orifice. Based on this type-species the genus Greenisca is here<tei:lb/>regarded as a component of Eriococcus. If Anophococcus gouxi is accepted as the type-species, a species<tei:lb/>with dorsal disc pores, there may be some justification for recognising the genus but until the significance of<tei:lb/>dorsal disc pores is better understood, the species is here regarded as belonging to Eriococcus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Kaweckia. The type-species has numerous cruciform pores and disc pores on the dorsum and the numbers<tei:lb/>of dorsal enlarged setae are restricted to the margins of the posterior abdominal segments. Other<tei:lb/>characters are frontal tubercles and microducts without a bifid orifice. At present there seems to be little<tei:lb/>justification for accepting this genus and it is here regarded as a component of Eriococcus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although the type-species of Eriococcus, Acanthococcus and Rhizococcus are not British species they<tei:lb/>are described here to help facilitate identification and to assess the characters. The following key is<tei:lb/>presented to separate the British indigenous and introduced species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to British species of Eriococcus</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Eriococcus aceris (Signoret)<tei:lb/>(Fig. 3)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acanthococcus aceris Signoret, 1875: 35; Borchsenius, 1949: 347; Danzig, 1964: 632; Tereznikova, 1981:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>15. Syntypes $ , SAVOIE and AUSTRIA: on Acer campestre (probably lost).<tei:lb/>Eriococcus aceris (Signoret) Cockerell, 1896: 323; Schmutterer, 1952: 406.<tei:lb/>Nidularia aceris (Signoret) Lindinger, 1933: 108.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult female on slide broadly oval, largest specimens 3-75 mm long, 2-2 mm wide. Surface of<tei:lb/>body strongly nodulose. Anal lobes protruding, about twice as long as wide, apically rounded, moderately<tei:lb/>sclerotised with inner margins conspicuously nodulose, each lobe with apical seta 200 ftm long, two inner<tei:lb/>dorsal enlarged setae and one outer enlarged seta situated towards mid-dorsum; ventral setae flagellate,<tei:lb/>one subapical, one at outer base and suranal seta longest but shorter than anal ring setae. Dorsal plate<tei:lb/>triangular, lightly sclerotised, strongly nodulose. Antennae 6- or 7-segmented, 250-330 /im long. Frontal<tei:lb/>lobes developed but smaller than basal antennal segment. Legs normal, well developed. Trochanter +<tei:lb/>femur 180-220 /xm long, tibia 110-140 /xm long, tarsus about 150 /im long, the tibia + tarsus always longer<tei:lb/>than trochanter + femur, claw 35 pm long, stout and curved with denticle near apex. Coxa without<tei:lb/>translucent pores but with spicules. Labium 160-170 pm long, shorter than clypeolabral shield, basal<tei:lb/>segment with 2 pairs of setae. Anal ring with 8 setae, each about 150 /im long.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dorsal surface with numerous enlarged setae of two main sizes, but all with more or less straight sides<tei:lb/>tapering gradually to a truncate tip, in profile curved and bluntly thorn-like. The largest setae 50 /u,m long<tei:lb/>on margins of posterior segments, the shortest, which are the most numerous, about 28 /im long.<tei:lb/>Macrotubular ducts of one size, 30 /xm long, tapering to orifice, the cup wider than base of a dorsal seta,<tei:lb/>evenly distributed. Microducts about 10 /im long, elongate, each with orifice bifid, evenly distributed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventral surface with normal flagellate setae in median areas, short, slender but stiff in lateral areas.<tei:lb/>Macrotubular ducts of three sizes. A large type similar to dorsal ducts on margins of abdomen. A smaller<tei:lb/>type about half width of large type, not numerous, in more or less single rows on abdominal segments and<tei:lb/>around submargins to head. A small type about half as wide again as the medium-sized ducts in small<tei:lb/>numbers across abdominal segments. Microducts absent. Disc pores predominantly quinquelocular but<tei:lb/>occasional pores present that have 6 or 7 loculi; in bands across the abdominal segments, around margins to<tei:lb/>head and on mid-venter. Cruciform pores present in a wide submarginal band from head to about fourth<tei:lb/>abdominal segment.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Austria: Weidling, on Acer campestre. Germany: Baden, on A. campestre, 24.V.1916 (H. Wtinn);<tei:lb/>Munich, on A. platanoides, 26.V.1951 (H. Schmutterer), Erlangen, 6.vi.l949 (H. Schmutterer). Switzer-<tei:lb/>land: Valais, on A campestre, 20.viii.1906.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISCUSSION. No original material has been traced. The specimens from Austria, one of the type-localities,<tei:lb/>are from the Naturhistorisches Museum, Vienna, identified by F. Low, and the specimens from Switzer-<tei:lb/>land are from the collection of P. Marchal. There seems to be no doubt about the identity of the species now<tei:lb/>recognised as such by many modern workers.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriococcus buxi (Fonscolombe)<tei:lb/>(Fig. 4)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coccus buxi Fonscolombe, 1834: 218. Syntypes $, FRANCE: Aix[-en-Provence] (probably lost).<tei:lb/>Eriococcus buxi (Fonscolombe) Targioni Tozzetti, 1868: 726; Fernald, 1903: 72.<tei:lb/>Nidularia buxi (Fonscolombe) Lindinger, 1933: 108.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE BRITISH AND SOME OTHER EUROPEAN ERIOCOCCIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>359</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 3 Eriococcus aceris Signoret. Germany, Erlangen.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>360</tei:p>
         <tei:p>D. J. WILLIAMS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 4 Eriococcus buxi (Fonscolombe). France, Orange, on Buxus sempervirens .</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE BRITISH AND SOME OTHER EUROPEAN ERIOCOCCIDAE 361</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult female broadly oval, largest specimens 1-9 mm long, 1-35 mm wide, not nodulose.<tei:lb/>Anal lobes about twice as long as wide, conical, each lobe with an apical seta 140 fjun long. Dorsally with an<tei:lb/>outer enlarged conical seta situated submarginally rather than on edge, and 2 inner enlarged setae.<tei:lb/>Ventrally with a single slender seta and a suranal seta shorter than anal ring setae. Dorsal plate only lightly<tei:lb/>sclerotised, rounded. Anal ring with 8 setae, each about 110 /u,m long. Antennae 160-175 /urn long, with 6<tei:lb/>segments. Frontal lobes well developed, about as long as width of basal antennal segment. Legs robust,<tei:lb/>hind trochanter + femur 170-190 pm long, hind tibia 80-90 /x,m long, hind tarsus 80-90 fim long, the tibia +<tei:lb/>tarsus either same length as trochanter + femur or slightly shorter, claw 25 /xm long, straight, with a minute<tei:lb/>denticle near apex. Hind coxa with a few small translucent pores. Labium 80 /um long, shorter than<tei:lb/>clypeolabral shield, basal segment with a single pair of setae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dorsal surface densely covered with enlarged setae, lanceolate, 32-52 /am long, pointed, the sides<tei:lb/>concave but curved in profile and thorn-like. Macroducts of one size, evenly distributed, each about 20 pm<tei:lb/>long, the cup about two-thirds width of diameter of setal base of a dorsal seta, the inner end of filament<tei:lb/>small and barely perceptible. Enlarged ducts present, each 35 /u-m long, the sides almost parallel, with inner<tei:lb/>end flat and rim of orifice sclerotised, but in profile thicker towards one side; present either singly or<tei:lb/>sometimes in pairs on head margin where there are 2-4 present at most. Microducts in a regular<tei:lb/>arrangement, each about 12 ^tm long, very slender, the sides parallel, with orifice widely bifid.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventral surface with normal slender setae in median areas. In submarginal areas the setae are shorter,<tei:lb/>stiff and blunt. Enlarged setae, same as on dorsum, around margins only. Macroducts of two sizes. A larger<tei:lb/>type, same as dorsal macroducts, numerous in a wide zone around margins and submargins, on thorax<tei:lb/>reaching to spiracles, and on head occupying area between clypeolabral shield and antennal bases. A<tei:lb/>narrower type on abdomen only, in transverse rows or bands across median areas of segments. Microducts,<tei:lb/>same as on dorsum, around margins only. Cruciform pores absent. Disc pores of quinquelocular type,<tei:lb/>numerous across abdominal segments almost to margins, occasional pores present in median areas of<tei:lb/>thorax and head and around spiracular openings.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED (all on Buxus sempervirens)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>France: 'south' (det. Signoret); Lyons, 20.vi.1932 (L. Goux); Orange, 15.iv.1978 (D. Matile-Ferrero &amp;<tei:lb/>D. J. Williams). Switzerland: Rolle, ix.1906 (P. Marchal), others labelled ex coll. P. Marchal.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISCUSSION. The most important characters are the dorsal setae 32-52 /im long, the dorsal macroducts<tei:lb/>about half width of setal base of dorsal seta, the enlarged ducts on head only and the lateral enlarged seta on<tei:lb/>anal lobes submarginal.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There seems to be no doubt about the identity of this species, even though the original material cannot be<tei:lb/>traced. The species was described from Aix-en-Provence and the specimens at hand collected in Orange,<tei:lb/>and from Lyons not far from the type-locality, are considered by French workers to be this species. A<tei:lb/>further specimen is available from material collected in the south of France and this was identified by V.<tei:lb/>Signoret as E. buxi.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriococcussp. near buxi (Fonscolombe)<tei:lb/>(Fig- 5)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Body of adult female on slide, broadly oval, membranous, not nodulose, largest specimens<tei:lb/>2-3 mm long, 1-3 mm wide. Anal lobes sclerotised, conical, pointed, about twice as long as wide at base,<tei:lb/>each lobe with an apical seta 180 ^tm long; dorsally with 1 outer enlarged seta on groove on edge and 2<tei:lb/>lateral enlarged setae; ventrally with 1 slender seta and a suranal seta shorter than anal ring setae. Dorsal<tei:lb/>plate projecting slightly, rounded. Anal ring with 8 setae, each about 185 /nm long. Antennae 150-210 /u,m<tei:lb/>long, 6-segmented. Frontal lobes lightly sclerotised at tip, elongate, sometimes twice as long as width of<tei:lb/>basal antennal segment. Legs well developed, hind trochanter + femur 160-190 pm long, hind tibia 80-95<tei:lb/>/Ltm long, hind tarsus 80-95 /xm long, the tibia + tarsus either same length as trochanter + femur, or slightly<tei:lb/>longer, claw straight, 25 /xm long, with a minute denticle, near apex. Hind coxa with a few translucent<tei:lb/>pores. Labium 80-95 /u,m long, shorter than clypeolabral shield, basal segment with 1 pair of setae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dorsal surface with numerous enlarged setae, evenly distributed, each seta broadly lanceolate, pointed,<tei:lb/>25-45 /xm long, curved in profile. Groups of these setae usually present submarginally on mid-head region,<tei:lb/>behind eyes, on prothorax, 1st and 7th abdominal segments, each group associated with a single enlarged<tei:lb/>duct or sometimes 2, each duct 40 /xm long with inner end flat and with sclerotised rim raised from<tei:lb/>surrounding integument. Other enlarged ducts sometimes present on submargins without the groups of<tei:lb/>setae, up to 17 marginal ducts present in some specimens and others present on midline, varying in number<tei:lb/>but there is usually one on meso thorax and another on 1st abdominal segment. Macroducts of one size,<tei:lb/>numerous, evenly distributed each duct about 25 /urn long, with a clear circular rim surrounding orifice, the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>362</tei:p>
         <tei:p>D. J. WILLIAMS</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Fig. 5 Eriococcus sp. near fcux/ (Fonscolombe). U.S.S.R. , Crimea, on Buxus sp.</tei:p>

      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE BRITISH AND SOME OTHER EUROPEAN ERIOCOCCIDAE 363</tei:p>
         <tei:p>cup about half width of setal base of a dorsal seta, the inner end of filament resembling a bunch of grapes.<tei:lb/>Microducts numerous, each about 12 pm long, slender, with parallel sides and with orifice widely bifid.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventral surface with normal slender setae in median areas and laterally towards margins. Enlarged setae<tei:lb/>same as on dorsum, around margins. Macroducts of two sizes. A large type, same size as dorsal ducts,<tei:lb/>present around margins and submargins, reaching to spiracles. A narrower type, not numerous in median<tei:lb/>areas of abdomen only, each duct with a distinct rim around orifice. Microducts on margins, same shape as<tei:lb/>on dorsum. Quinquelocular pores numerous on abdomen where they almost reach margins; others present<tei:lb/>in median areas of head and thorax and around spiracular openings, those next to first spiracle extending to<tei:lb/>margin. Cruciform pores absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>U.S.S.R.: Crimea, Massandra, on Buxus sp., 24.vii.1951 (T. Bustchik). Turkey: Gerede, on B.<tei:lb/>sempervirens , 13.vii.1970.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISCUSSION. The large number of submarginal enlarged ducts, many surrounded by groups of setae, and<tei:lb/>other ducts on the midline, easily distinguish this species from E. buxi. Specimens from Crimea have the<tei:lb/>dorsal setae 25-40 /xm long and noticeably shorter than those in E. buxi; in Turkish specimens, although<tei:lb/>28-45 /xm long, these setae are still shorter than in E. buxi. The position of the lateral enlarged seta on each<tei:lb/>anal lobe is always marginal, whereas in E. buxi this seta is displaced slightly to dorsum. Another main<tei:lb/>difference is the size of a dorsal macroduct, which in this species has the cup about half the width of a setal<tei:lb/>base, but in E. buxi it is about two-thirds the width. Furthermore, the dorsal ducts have a conspicuous rim<tei:lb/>around the orifice.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There is every indication that this species is new but for the moment it is left un-named pending further<tei:lb/>research by workers in U.S.S.R. It seems certain that it is the same as that described by Borchsenius (1949)<tei:lb/>and Tereznikova (1981) as E. buxi.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriococcus cantium sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 6)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult female, when prepared on microscope slides, elongate-oval with almost parallel sides,<tei:lb/>2-6 mm long and 1-00 mm wide, nodulose. Anal lobes about twice as long as wide, moderately sclerotised.<tei:lb/>Each lobe with an apical seta 300 /im long, dorsally with 1 inner and 3 outer enlarged setae and ventrally<tei:lb/>with 2 slender setae and a slender suranal seta shorter than anal ring setae. Dorsal plate not prominent,<tei:lb/>rounded, nodulose. Antennae 7-segmented, 300 j*m long. Frontal tubercle present, just anterior to basal<tei:lb/>antennal segment. Legs well developed, hind trochanter + femur 250 /u,m long, hind tibia 150 /im long,<tei:lb/>hind tarsus 160 /xm long, claw curved 40 /urn long, with a denticle near apex. Hind coxa with minute<tei:lb/>translucent pores on outer half and hind femur with a small group on mid-anterior margin. Labium 100 /xm<tei:lb/>long, slightly shorter than clypeolabral shield and basal segment with 2 pairs of setae. Anal ring with 8<tei:lb/>setae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dorsal surface with enlarged conical setae, pointed, 35-75 /im long, in bands across the segments. On<tei:lb/>7th segment medially a group of 4-5 present and on 6th segment a similar group present but this merging<tei:lb/>with lateral setae. Macroducts of one size, about 25 /xm long, the cup narrower than setal bases of largest<tei:lb/>setae, fairly evenly distributed across segments. Microducts not numerous, each about 4 ^tm long, with<tei:lb/>short collar, ampulla and swollen inner end to tube.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventral surface with normal slender setae in median areas. Enlarged setae, same as on dorsum, on<tei:lb/>margins of head, thorax and anterior abdominal segments, but submarginally a few setae that are more<tei:lb/>slender but stiff. Macroducts of two sizes; a larger type, same size as on dorsum, around margins and a<tei:lb/>narrower type in transverse rows on abdominal segments, and in median to submarginal areas of thorax<tei:lb/>and head. Microducts in small numbers on margins. Disc pores of quinquelocular type numerous across<tei:lb/>abdominal segments, in median areas of thorax and head and near spiracles. Cruciform pores present in<tei:lb/>small numbers in a narrow submarginal zone from about 5th abdominal segment forward to head.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, England: Kent, Bearsted, on Brachypodium sylvaticum (Poaceae), 30.vii.1925 (E. E.<tei:lb/>Green) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratype. England: 1 $ , same data as holotype (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISCUSSION. This species is close to E. greeni in having a similar distribution of enlarged dorsal setae. It<tei:lb/>differs, however, in possessing groups of 4-6 setae in the median areas of the seventh and sixth segments<tei:lb/>whereas in E. greeni these groups usually possess only 2 or at most 3 setae. The median group of setae on<tei:lb/>the sixth segment of E. cantium is not so differentiated and is almost continuous with the lateral setae.<tei:lb/>Furthermore there are three lateral setae on each anal lobe whereas in E. greeni there are only two.<tei:lb/>The name is the Latin word for the county of Kent, and is used as a noun in apposition.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>364</tei:p>
         <tei:p>D. J. WILLIAMS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 6 Eriococcus cantium sp. n. England, Kent, Bearsted, on Brachypodium sylvaticum.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE BRITISH AND SOME OTHER EUROPEAN ERIOCOCCIDAE 365</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriococcus devoniensis (Green) comb. rev.<tei:lb/>(Fig. 7)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rhizococcus devoniensis Green, 1896: 260. LECTOTYPE $&gt;, ENGLAND (BMNH), here designated</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[examined] .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriococcus devoniensis (Green) Cockerell, 1897: 589; Newstead, 1903: 201; Schmutterer, 1952: 413.<tei:lb/>Acanthococcus devoniensis (Green) Borchsenius, 1949: 337.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. A broadly oval species, attaining a length of 2-0 mm and a width of 1-3 mm, body nodulose.<tei:lb/>Anal lobes sclerotised, rather wide and pointed, triangular, about as wide as long at base in older<tei:lb/>specimens, but conical and rounded in young specimens. Each lobe with an apical seta 180 /u,m long and<tei:lb/>dorsally 2 inner submarginal enlarged setae and 1 outer marginal seta. Ventrally each lobe with 2 slender<tei:lb/>setae and a suranal seta shorter than anal ring setae. Dorsal plate poorly developed, rounded. Anal ring<tei:lb/>with 8 setae, each 100 /x,m long. Antennae 190-210 /im long, 7-segmented. Frontal lobes conspicuous and<tei:lb/>larger than a basal antennal segment. Legs well developed. Hind trochanter + femur 180-200 pm long,<tei:lb/>hind tibia 100-115 /um long, hind tarsus 110-120 /xm long, the tibia + tarsus longer than trochanter +<tei:lb/>femur, claw stout and curved, 30 /u,m long, with a denticle near apex. Hind coxa with a few noticeable<tei:lb/>translucent pores and hind femur with a few on anterior edge. Labium 130-150 /im long, usually slightly<tei:lb/>shorter than clypeolabral shield, basal segment with 2 pairs of setae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dorsal surface with an even distribution of enlarged setae of various sizes, 28-40 /im long, each truncate,<tei:lb/>the sides straight or only slightly concave, and tapering gradually. Macroducts of one size, about 20 /nm<tei:lb/>long, the cup about same size or smaller than diameter of setal base of largest setae, fairly numerous.<tei:lb/>Microducts each about 4 /u,m long, with ampulla, inner end of tube swollen, but without internal collar,<tei:lb/>opening to exterior with minute orifice, in moderate numbers over entire surface.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventral surface with normal slender setae in median areas and enlarged setae similar to those on dorsum,<tei:lb/>in a marginal zone, on thorax, reaching almost to spiracles. Macroducts of two sizes. A large type, same as<tei:lb/>those on dorsum, in a marginal zone, interspersed with the enlarged setae. A narrower type present across<tei:lb/>median areas of abdominal segments and in groups in median areas of thorax and head. Microducts few, on<tei:lb/>margins only. Disc pores predominantly quinquelocular, numerous on abdomen and present in median<tei:lb/>areas of thorax and around spiracles. Cruciform pores few, in submargins of head and thorax.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED (all on Erica tetralix unless stated otherwise)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>England: Devon, Budleigh Salterton, ix.1896 (lectotype), 20.ix.1896 (E. E. Green), Sherbrook,<tei:lb/>18.viii.1896; Surrey, Camberley, ll.iv.1922, vii.1914, ix.1914, xi.1929 (E. E. Green), 10.vi.1959 (D. J.<tei:lb/>Williams); Durham, Waldridge Fell, vi.1950, 16.viii.1960 (D. J. Williams); Yorkshire, Hawkesworth,<tei:lb/>12.viii.1960, Levisham, 27.viii.1959, Goathland, 25.viii.1959 (all D. J. Williams), Ickornshaw Moor,<tei:lb/>29.viii.1948 (A. Smith), Shipley Glen, 25.viii.1984 (N. B. Pungerl). Ireland: Kerry, Mt Mangerton, in<tei:lb/>sphagnum, viii.1943 (R. S. Bagnalf). Austria: Lunz, on E. cornea. Germany: Ratzeburg. Corsica:<tei:lb/>Vizzavone Forest, on E. arborea, l.xi.1930 (A. Balachowsky).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISCUSSION. Green's original slide contains three specimens, and the lectotype selected is clearly marked.<tei:lb/>The two other specimens are here designated paralectotypes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although Green described this insect originally on Erica cinerea he (Green, 1917) corrected the<tei:lb/>misidentification of the host-plant to E. tetralix and the insect seems to be restricted to this plant in Britain,<tei:lb/>even when other species of Erica are growing next to it. It distorts the stems at the point of feeding, so much<tei:lb/>so that stems may curl in a circle enclosing the insect in the middle as illustrated in colour by Newstead<tei:lb/>(1903). Specimens are at hand from Corsica collected on E. arborea and the record led Green (1931) to<tei:lb/>correct an early impression that E. tetralix was the only host-plant. There are unconfirmed records on E.<tei:lb/>cinerea and Calluna by Goux (1934) and on C. vulgaris by Balachowsky (1937).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Apart from the British records already listed, Harrison (1916a, 1916ft, 1918, 1948, 1949) has recorded it<tei:lb/>from Northumberland, Durham and Yorkshire, and from western Scotland including the Isle of Rhum and<tei:lb/>Benbecula, Ronay and Grimsay in the Outer Hebrides. Other records include those of Green (1917) from<tei:lb/>Cheshire and Green (1923) from Aberdeenshire, while Killington (1936) recorded it from Hampshire.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The species is found throughout Europe as far north as Sweden and may be present throughout the<tei:lb/>Palaearctic region wherever E. tetralix is found.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>366</tei:p>
         <tei:p>D. J. WILLIAMS</tei:p>

         <tei:p>THE BRITISH AND SOME OTHER EUROPEAN ERIOCOCCIDAE 367</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriococcus glyceriae Green comb. rev.<tei:lb/>(Fig. 8)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriococcus glyceriae Green, 1921: 146; Schmutterer, 1952: 410. LECTOTYPE $, ENGLAND (BMNH),</tei:p>
         <tei:p>here designated [examined].<tei:lb/>Nidularia glyceriae (Green) Lindinger, 1933: 116.<tei:lb/>Greenisca glyceriae (Green) Borchsenius, 1949: 368; Danzig, 1964: 634; Danzig, 1980: 228; Tereznikova,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1981: 52.<tei:lb/>Kaweckia glyceriae (Green) Koteja &amp; Zak-Ogaza, 1981: 506.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Body elongate-oval, largest specimens 3-4 mm long, 1-7 mm wide, membranous throughout,<tei:lb/>not nodulose. Anal lobes either membranous or faintly sclerotised, each lobe about as long as wide, with an<tei:lb/>apical seta 140 //,m long and dorsally 2 inner and 1 outer truncate setae and one ventral seta that is flagellate<tei:lb/>and situated towards outer margin. Suranal setae slender and flagellate, shorter than anal ring setae.<tei:lb/>Antennae 7-segmented, 220-230 tim long. Frontal tubercle present just anterior to each basal antennal<tei:lb/>segment. Legs well developed, hind trochanter + femur 180 /im long, hind tibia 110 /u,m long, hind tarsus<tei:lb/>110-120 /Am long, the tibia + tarsus always longer than trochanter + femur, claw 35 /AHI long, curved with<tei:lb/>minute denticle near apex. Hind coxa with proximal edge indistinct, translucent pores numerous, a few<tei:lb/>extending on to surrounding integument at base. Labium 85-100 /Am long, shorter than clypeolabral shield,<tei:lb/>basal segment with 2 pairs of setae. Spiracles heavily sclerotised, this sclerotisation completely surrounding<tei:lb/>atrium. Dorsal plate membranous in form of a narrow rounded lobe.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dorsal surface with enlarged setae on 5th and posterior segments only except for an occasional seta on<tei:lb/>4th segment, few, on margins, each seta with almost parallel sides, truncate, 15-25 /Am long. Other dorsal<tei:lb/>setae slender, often curved but stiff, with blunt tip 12-20 ttm long. Macroducts of two sizes, the largest<tei:lb/>about 16-20 tim long with the cup about same diameter as an enlarged setal base, in bands across the<tei:lb/>segments except on anal lobe segment where they are replaced by a narrower type. Microducts minute,<tei:lb/>about 6 /AHI long, with ampulla, swollen inner end to tube and an inner collar, few, across the posterior<tei:lb/>abdominal segments and around the margins to head. Disc pores, usually with 7 loculi, in more or less<tei:lb/>single rows at anterior edges of segments. Cruciform pores present in wide bands across median areas of<tei:lb/>second abdominal segment and forward to mesothorax; a few others present in lateral areas of these<tei:lb/>segments, on third abdominal segment and on prothorax.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventral surface with normal setae in median areas, replaced by shorter stiff setae, similar to those on<tei:lb/>dorsum, around margins of thorax and anterior abdominal segments. Macroducts, of the large type, similar<tei:lb/>to those on dorsum, on margins only. A narrower type in moderate numbers across abdominal segments, in<tei:lb/>median areas of thorax and head and reaching to submargins of thorax. Microducts as on dorsum, few, on<tei:lb/>margins. Cruciform pores restricted to a few only on margins of prothorax and head. Disc pores, usually<tei:lb/>with 7 loculi, but occasionally with more or fewer loculi at anterior and posterior edges of 5th and posterior<tei:lb/>segments, at anterior edges of anterior abdominal segments, in median area of thorax and in a zone around<tei:lb/>thoracic margins to head.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>England: Norfolk, Blakeney Point, on Glyceria maritima (now Puccinellia maritimd), vii.1920 (E. E.<tei:lb/>Green) (lectotype), ix.1920 (N. E. Brenchley). Hungary: Zicsiujfalu, on Agropyron sp., 8.ix.l981 (F.<tei:lb/>Kozar). U.S.S.R.: Odessa, on A. repens (A. Kiritshenko) .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISCUSSION. The lectotype is here designated from three specimens on the same slide and clearly indicated.<tei:lb/>The two other specimens are labelled paralectotypes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although this species has concentrations of cruciform pores on the mid-dorsum and rather heavily<tei:lb/>sclerotised spiracles, these characters are probably of specific significance only and the species seems to be<tei:lb/>congeneric with the type-species. Specimens available from eastern Europe tend to have the enlarged setae<tei:lb/>with slightly concave sides.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriococcus green/ Newstead comb. rev.<tei:lb/>(Fig. 9)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriococcus greeni Newstead, 1898: 96; Newstead, 1903: 200. LECTOTYPE $, ENGLAND (BMNH), here</tei:p>
         <tei:p>designated [examined] .<tei:lb/>Acanthococcus greeni (Newstead) Borchsenius, 1949: 340; Danzig, 1975: 71; 1980: 212; Tereznikova,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1981:27.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. An elongate-oval species, attaining a length of 3-0 mm and a width of 1-6 mm, body</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>368</tei:p>

         <tei:p>nodulose. Anal lobes about twice as long as wide, conical, tending to be pointed, moderately sclerotised.<tei:lb/>Each lobe with an apical seta 380 /xm long and dorsally with 1 outer and 2 inner enlarged setae and ventrally<tei:lb/>with 2 slender setae and a slender suranal seta much shorter than anal ring setae. Dorsal plate sclerotised,<tei:lb/>moderately developed, rounded but nodulose. Anal ring with 8 setae each about 140 /u,m long. Antennae<tei:lb/>280-300 /xm long, with 6 or 7 segments. Frontal tubercle present just anterior to basal segment. Legs well<tei:lb/>developed. Hind trochanter + femur 240-270 /xm long, hind tibia 150-170 /u,m long, hind tarsus 150-170<tei:lb/>/im long, tibia + tarsus always longer than trochanter + femur. Claw curved, 35 /u,m long, with a minute<tei:lb/>denticle near apex. Hind coxa with translucent pores on outer half and hind femur with a small group on<tei:lb/>mid-anterior edge. Labium 110-120 /am long, shorter than clypeolabral shield.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dorsal surface with pointed conical setae 30-70 jam long, the sizes in a haphazard arrangement but there<tei:lb/>are always some of the longest in the marginal groups. On the mid-dorsum of 7th abdominal segment, there<tei:lb/>is usually a group of 2 such setae, rarely 3, and a similar group is present on the mid-dorsum of 6th<tei:lb/>abdominal segment. Macroducts in a regular distribution, of one type, about 25 jum long, the cup smaller<tei:lb/>than diameter of setal base of largest setae , tapering gradually , the orifice usually surrounded by a pale oval<tei:lb/>area. Microducts about 4 jam long, each with ampulla, swollen inner end to tube and an internal collar,<tei:lb/>evenly distributed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventral surface with normal slender setae in median areas, marginally with a few enlarged setae similar<tei:lb/>to dorsal setae, submarginally with more slender but stiff setae. Macroducts of two sizes. A large type,<tei:lb/>same as on dorsum, in small numbers around margins. A narrower type in bands across abdominal<tei:lb/>segments, in median areas of thorax and head, extending in submargins almost to marginal macroducts.<tei:lb/>Microducts not numerous, in a marginal zone from anterior abdominal segments to head. Quinquelocular<tei:lb/>pores numerous on abdomen, in median areas of thorax and around spiracles. Cruciform pores few, in<tei:lb/>submarginal areas only of head, thorax and first few abdominal segments.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>England: Devon, Budleigh Salterton, on grass, 20. ix. 1896 (E. E. Green) (lectotype); Somerset,<tei:lb/>Minehead, on grass, ix.1920 (E. E. Green), Cheddar, vii.1926 (E. E. Green); Surrey, Camberley,<tei:lb/>31.viii.1914, ix.1914, 25. ix. 1934, Hog's Back, 21.vii.1922, on grass (all E. E. Green); Kent, Thurnham, on<tei:lb/>grass, 15. ix. 1926 (E. E. Green); Berkshire, Silwood Park, on Festuca sp., Deschampsia caespitosa,<tei:lb/>27.x. 1948, on grass 19.viii.1948 (all K. L. Boratynski);YorkshiTe, Hawkesworth, on grass, 20.viii.1961 (D.<tei:lb/>J. Williams). Scotland: E. Lothian, Gullane, on grass, viii.1925 (E. E. Green).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISCUSSION. The lectotype designated is the only original specimen seen. In all specimens there is always a<tei:lb/>group of 2 large setae on the mid-dorsum of the 7th abdominal segment or rarely with a small seta forming a<tei:lb/>group of 3. Furthermore, there is always a median group of setae on the 6th segment. These characters<tei:lb/>separate it from R. cantium herein described as new, a species that has a group of 4 on the mid-dorsum of<tei:lb/>the 7th segment and with the setae on the mid-dorsum of 6th segment not forming a distinct group.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Green (1923, 1926, 1928) recorded this species also from Sea View, Isle of Wight; Bearsted, Kent;<tei:lb/>Yately, Hampshire; and from Monument Hill in East Lothian (Haddington).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriococcus incrmis Green comb. rev.<tei:lb/>(Fig. 10)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriococcus inermis Green, 1915: 176. LECTOTYPE $ , ENGLAND (BMNH), here designated [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nidularia inermis (Green) Lindinger, 1933: 116.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Greenisca inermis (Green) Borchsenius, 1948: 502; 1949: 367.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Anophococcus inermis (Green) Balachowsky, 1954: 61.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rhizococcus inermis (Green) Danzig, 1962: 854; 1964: 634; Dziedicka &amp; Koteja, 1971: 576.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acanthococcus inermis (Green) Danzig, 1975: 64; 1980: 226.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Body of adult female not nodulose, elongate-oval, anterior end rounded, sides at times<tei:lb/>subparallel, largest specimens 2-5 mm long, 1-5 mm wide. Anal lobes about twice as long as wide, pointed.<tei:lb/>Each lobe with an apical seta 180 /urn long, dorsally with 2 inner enlarged conical setae, the anterior usually<tei:lb/>the larger, about 28 /u,m long, the posterior about 24 /im long, and a minute outer seta near base; ventrally<tei:lb/>with 2 slender setae and a suranal seta shorter than anal ring setae. Dorsal plate rounded, lightly<tei:lb/>sclerotised. Anal ring with 8 setae each 130 /urn long. Antennae 150-210 |u,m long, 6-segmented. Frontal<tei:lb/>tubercle present just anterior to basal antennal segment. Legs well developed, hind trochanter + femur<tei:lb/>140-170 fj.m long, hind tibia 90-110 /im long, hind tarsus 110-130 pm long, the tibia + tarsus conspicuously<tei:lb/>longer than trochanter + femur, claw curved, 30 /nm long, with a denticle near apex. Hind coxa with a few<tei:lb/>large translucent pores on outer half and hind femur sometimes with one or two on anterior edge. Labium<tei:lb/>95-110 fim long, shorter than clypeolabral shield, basal segment with 2 pairs of setae.</tei:p>
