         <tei:p>THE BRITISH AND SOME OTHER EUROPEAN ERIOCOCCIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>371</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 10 Eriococcus inermis Green. England, Surrey, Camberley, on grass.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>372 D. J. WILLIAMS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dorsal surface with minute bluntly pointed setae, most scarcely longer than diameter of setal base and<tei:lb/>some appreciably shorter, in moderate numbers across segments. Macroducts evenly distributed, each<tei:lb/>about 20 /um long with cup nearly twice diameter of a dorsal setal base. Microducts each about 4 /um long,<tei:lb/>with ampulla, tube with inner end swollen, and an internal collar, in moderate numbers over surface.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventral surface with slender setae in median areas and minute setae, similar to those on dorsum, around<tei:lb/>margins and submargins. Macroducts of two sizes. A larger type, the same as dorsal ducts, on margins only.<tei:lb/>A narrower type in median areas as far forward as head margins. Disc pores varying in size, numerous on<tei:lb/>abdomen where, on the posterior segments, many have 7 or occasionally more loculi but anteriorly on the<tei:lb/>abdomen, the median area of thorax and around the spiracles, they are quinquelocular. Cruciform pores<tei:lb/>present in a submedian zone from head to about 5th abdominal segment.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>England: Surrey; Camberley, on grass, ix.1914 (E. E. Green) (lectotype, paralectotypes), 15.iv.1922,<tei:lb/>l.x.1925, on Festuca ovina, ix.1929 (E. E. Green); Somerset, Cheddar, viii.1926 on F. ovina (E. E. Green);<tei:lb/>Berkshire, Silwood Park, on F. ovina, Deschampsia flexuosa 1948-1956 (various dates) (K. L. Bora-<tei:lb/>tynski); Yorkshire, Steeton Moor, 29.viii.1948 (A. Smith), Hawkesworth, on grass, 20.viii.1961 (D. J.<tei:lb/>Williams); Durham, Waldridge Fell, on grass, 17.vii.1960 (D. J. Williams).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISCUSSION. The original material comprises 12 specimens, six on each of two slides, one labelled 'type'<tei:lb/>and the other labelled 'co-type'. The lectotype has been selected from the slide labelled 'type' and is clearly<tei:lb/>marked, the remaining 11 specimens are labelled paralectotypes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The distribution at present also includes France, western U.S.S.R. and the far eastern area of U.S.S.R.<tei:lb/>It will probably be found throughout the Palaearctic Region.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriococcus ins/gn/s Newstead comb. rev.<tei:lb/>(Fig. 11)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriococcus insignis Newstead, 1891: 164; 1903: 198. LECTOTYPE $, ENGLAND (BMNH), here desig-<tei:lb/>nated [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nidularia insignis (Newstead) Lindinger, 1933: 116.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rhizococcus insignis (Newstead) Borchsenius, 1949: 357; Danzig, 1962: 841; 1964: 633; Dziedicka &amp;<tei:lb/>Koteja, 1971: 561.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acanthococcus insignis (Newstead) Danzig, 1975: 64; Tereznikova, 1981: 29.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Body of adult female elongate-oval, the sides often subparallel, nodulose, largest specimens<tei:lb/>2-9 mm long and 1-2 mm wide. Anal lobes conical, pointed, about twice as long as wide, moderately<tei:lb/>sclerotised. Each lobe with an apical seta 280-320 /um long, on the dorsum 1 outer and 2 inner enlarged<tei:lb/>setae, on the venter 2 slender setae and a suranal setae shorter than anal ring setae. Dorsal plate rounded,<tei:lb/>narrow, sometimes nodulose and lightly sclerotised. Anal ring with 8 setae, each 135 /um long. Antennae<tei:lb/>200-270 /um long with 7 segments. Legs well developed, hind trochanter + femur 200-250 /um long, hind<tei:lb/>tibia 120-160 /um long, hind tarsus 130-150 /um long, the tibia + tarsus always longer than trochanter +<tei:lb/>femur, claw curved, 35 /um long, with a denticle near apex. Hind coxa with conspicuous translucent pores<tei:lb/>on outer half. Labium 100 /um long, shorter than clypeolabral shield, basal segment with 2 pairs of setae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dorsal surface with a marginal row of enlarged setae 40-65 /um long, each with slightly concave sides. On<tei:lb/>segments 5-7 these setae are truncate, but anteriorly they are bluntly pointed and on head they extend to<tei:lb/>sub marginal area near midline. The setae on the 7th abdominal segment always number 4. Elsewhere on<tei:lb/>the dorsum there are small setae in moderate numbers, 6-8 /urn long. These vary in thickness on different<tei:lb/>specimens, even from the same batch, sometimes being quite slender but usually they are slightly conical<tei:lb/>and often they are thicker on the head and thorax. Despite these differences they vary little in length.<tei:lb/>Macroducts of one size, evenly distributed, about 25 /um long, cup narrower than a setal base of a marginal<tei:lb/>seta. Microducts in an even distribution, each about 4 /um long with ampulla, tube with swollen inner end,<tei:lb/>and an internal collar.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventral surface with normal slender setae in median areas, a few enlarged setae on head margin and stiff<tei:lb/>setae in a marginal zone from head to anterior abdominal segments, these setae usually larger than the<tei:lb/>small dorsal setae but smaller than dorsal marginal setae. Macroducts of two sizes. A larger type, same as<tei:lb/>on dorsum around margins, and a narrower type in median areas, extending laterally almost to marginal<tei:lb/>macroducts. Microducts few, around margins only. Disc pores usually with 7 loculi, fairly numerous across<tei:lb/>abdominal segments, but not reaching margins, also present in median areas of thorax and head and<tei:lb/>around spiracular openings. Cruciform pores in a narrow submarginal zone around entire body, not<tei:lb/>numerous.</tei:p>

      </tei:div>

         <tei:p>374 D. J. WILLIAMS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>England: Cheshire, Ince, on Agrostis sp., 1890 (lectotype, paralectotypes) ; Surrey, Camberley, 1914-<tei:lb/>1934 (various dates), on Hypericum sp., ix.1923, Wisley, ix.1915, Box Hill, 26. ix. 1921; Sussex, Arundel,<tei:lb/>ix.1914; Kent, Thuraham, 15. ix. 1926; Somerset, Cheddar, viii.1926, on Brachypodium sylvaticum,<tei:lb/>viii.1926, Minehead, ix.1920; Warwickshire, Morton Paddocks, 14.viii.1920 (R. Newstead); Devon,<tei:lb/>Budleigh Salterton, 10, 20.ix.1896; Yorkshire, Goathland, 25.viii.1959 (D. J. Williams). Scotland: E.<tei:lb/>Lothian, Gullane, vii.1925; Argyllshire, Skye, Uig, on grass, 8.ix.l973 (D. J. Williams). Channel Is:<tei:lb/>Guernsey, Houmet Homtolle, 9.ix.24; Herm, 13. ix. 1924, all on grasses (all E. E. Green).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISCUSSION. The lectotype has been selected and clearly marked, from four specimens on a single slide<tei:lb/>labelled 'Cotype $ $' by Newstead. The three other specimens are labelled paralectotypes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A discussion of the similarities between this species and E. pseudinsignis is given under the latter. At<tei:lb/>present E. insignis may be identified by the presence of 4 marginal setae on each side of the seventh<tei:lb/>abdominal segment instead of 3 in E. pseudinsignis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Literature records for Britain include those of Green (1915, 1925ft, 1926, 1928) for Camberley, the<tei:lb/>Channel Is, Wales (Breconshire) and Cheddar.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriococcus lagerstroemiae Kuwana comb. rev.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriococcus lagerstroemiae Kuwana, 1907: 182; Boratynski &amp; Williams, 1964: 91. Syntypes $, JAPAN:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ichijiku and Sarusuberi (IAES).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nidularia lagerstroemiae (Kuwana) Lindinger, 1933: 116.<tei:lb/>Acanthococcus lagerstroemiae (Kuwana) Borchsenius, 1960: 214.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This species was recorded from England by Green (1915) from specimens collected in a nursery garden at<tei:lb/>St. Albans on Lagerstroemia sp., growing in the open. It is not clear if the insects were destroyed at the<tei:lb/>time. The species has not been recorded from Britain since, but it has been found also in India and China.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>No authentic material has been studied for this work, although some specimens are at hand from Japan,<tei:lb/>Tokyo, on L. indica sent by Kuwana to Green. The species is in great need of further study.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Material shows that the species possesses frontal lobes, numerous slender microducts with bifid orifice,<tei:lb/>and a small group of setae on mid-dorsum of the anal lobe segment. It comes close to E. aceris but differs in<tei:lb/>having the marginal setae, especially those on the posterior segments, not appreciably longer than those on<tei:lb/>the mid-dorsum. In E. aceris the marginal setae are about twice the length of the mid-dorsal setae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriococcus munroi (Boratynski) comb. n.<tei:lb/>(Fig. 12)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acanthococcus munroi Boratynski, 1962: 56; Danzig, 1975: 71; 1980: 218; Tereznikova, 1981: 32.<tei:lb/>Holotype $ , ENGLAND (BMNH) [examined] .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Body of adult female nodulose, elongate-oval, widest at mesothorax, largest specimens 2-1<tei:lb/>mm long and 1-5 mm wide. Anal lobes about twice as long as wide, almost conical, sclerotised, each with<tei:lb/>apical setae up to 300 /u,m long. Dorsal surface of each lobe with 2 inner enlarged conical setae, the<tei:lb/>subapical longer than inner and with an outer enlarged seta, the longest, situated slightly on dorsum<tei:lb/>towards base. Dorsal plate sclerotised, narrow and rounded, the posterior edge with 'teeth' because of the<tei:lb/>nodulosity. Anal ring with 8 setae each about 125 /urn long. Antennae usually 7-segmented, 250-300 /im<tei:lb/>long. Frontal lobes present just anterior to basal segment. Legs normal, well developed, hind trochanter +<tei:lb/>femur 220-230 /urn long, hind tibia 130-150 /urn long, hind tarsus 140-150 jiim long, the tibia + tarsus always<tei:lb/>longer than trochanter + femur, claw curved, 30 /urn long with denticle near apex. Hind coxa with a few<tei:lb/>conspicuous translucent pores. Labium 120 /u,m long, shorter than clypeolabral shield, basal segment with 2<tei:lb/>pairs of setae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dorsal surface with enlarged setae, each conical with almost straight sides and with blunt tip, arranged in<tei:lb/>transverse bands across the segments but absent in the submarginal areas. These setae of various sizes,<tei:lb/>30-60 /um long but always with one or two of the large type present in any marginal group. On the median<tei:lb/>areas of 4th and 5th abdominal segments the conical setae tend to be shorter but the normal conical setae<tei:lb/>are replaced on the median areas of 6th and 7th abdominal segments by minute conical setae about 6 /u,m<tei:lb/>long and rarely longer than the diameter of a setal base, there being usually 4 across the middle of each<tei:lb/>segment. Macroducts of one size, each about 20 /urn long with almost straight sides and with cup narrower<tei:lb/>than a setal base of an enlarged seta, fairly numerous in wide bands across the segments. Microducts each<tei:lb/>about 4 fjim long with inner end of tube swollen, ampulla and a saucer-shaped inner collar, evenly<tei:lb/>distributed.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE BRITISH AND SOME OTHER EUROPEAN ERIOCOCCIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>375</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 12 Eriococcus munroi (Boratynski). England, Berkshire, Silwood Park, on Veronica chamaedrys.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>376 D. J. WILLIAMS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventral surface with normal slender setae in median areas and a few enlarged conical setae on margins<tei:lb/>and submargins. Macroducts of two sizes. A larger type, similar to dorsal ducts, around margins and a<tei:lb/>narrower duct in transverse rows on abdominal segments, in median and submarginal areas of thorax and<tei:lb/>head. Microducts few, around margins only. Cruciform pores not numerous, in submarginal areas of 6th<tei:lb/>abdominal segment and forward to head. Disc pores, usually quinquelocular, numerous in bands across<tei:lb/>abdominal segments but not reaching margins, present also in median areas of thorax and around the<tei:lb/>spiracles.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>England: Berkshire, Silwood Park, on Achillea millefolium (Asteraceae), 7.ix.l948 (holotype) and<tei:lb/>subsequent specimens collected on the same host plant, on Veronica chamaedrys (Scrophulariaceae),<tei:lb/>1948, 1949 (various dates), on Deschampsia caespitosa (Poaceae), 1949, Chrysanthemum leucanthemum,<tei:lb/>21. vi. 1949 and on 'thistle' (Asteraceae), 7.ix.l949 (all K. L. Boratynski); Surrey, Camberley, on grass,<tei:lb/>ix.!914(E. E. Green); Somerset, Cheddar, on Teucrium scorodoniae (Lamiaceae); Isle of Man, Port Erin,<tei:lb/>27.ix.1918.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISCUSSION. Boratynski (1962) has given an extended description and an account of the biology of this<tei:lb/>species. He has also discussed some specimens available labelled ex coll. Manchester Museum, without<tei:lb/>locality data. These have the enlarged setae wider, shorter and more rounded or almost truncate at the<tei:lb/>posterior end of body. The single specimen available on Teucrium scorodonia has the minute setae on the<tei:lb/>sixth segment replaced by enlarged setae, and the posterior marginal setae are conspicuously rounded. The<tei:lb/>extent of variation is still not clear. Since its description the species has been found throughout Europe and<tei:lb/>thefareastofU.S.S.R.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriococcusplacidus Green comb. rev.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 13)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriococcus placidus Green, 1915: 148. LECTOTYPE $, ENGLAND (BMNH), here designated [ex-<tei:lb/>amined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nidularia placida (Green) Lindinger, 1933: 116.<tei:lb/>Greenisca placida (Green) Rasina, 1955: 69; Danzig, 1964: 634.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Body of adult female elongate-oval, not nodulose, largest specimens 3-5 mm long, 1-7 mm<tei:lb/>wide. Anal lobes conical, pointed, about twice as long as wide, moderately sclerotised, each lobe with an<tei:lb/>apical seta 220-300 /um long, the dorsum with 2 inner enlarged conical setae, the anterior 36-50 /nm long,<tei:lb/>the posterior usually shorter, 32-40 /urn long, and an outer minute seta situated, in most specimens,<tei:lb/>towards centre. Ventral surface of lobe with 2 slender setae and a slender suranal seta. Dorsal plate<tei:lb/>moderately developed, lightly sclerotised, outer edge rounded, often nodulose. Anal ring with 8 setae each<tei:lb/>145 /im long. Antennae 280-300 /urn long, with 7 segments. Frontal tubercles present, minute, just anterior<tei:lb/>to each basal antennal segment. Labium 100-120 /urn long, shorter than clypeolabral shield, basal segment<tei:lb/>with 2 pairs of setae. Legs well developed, slender, hind trochanter + femur 230-240 /xm long, hind tibia<tei:lb/>140-150 /im long, hind tarsus 160-170 /xm long, claw slightly curved, slender, 40 /xm long, with a minute<tei:lb/>denticle near apex. Hind coxa with conspicuous translucent pores on outer half, hind femur with a small<tei:lb/>group at mid-anterior margin.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dorsal surface with two types of setae. Apart from the enlarged setae on anal lobes there are others<tei:lb/>present about 30 /xm long, on head margin in varying numbers but there are usually one or two present.<tei:lb/>Occasionally these are replaced by slender setae. Elsewhere the dorsum is beset with minute pointed setae<tei:lb/>scarcely more than 20 pm long, but often shorter, rarely more than twice as long as diameter of a setal base.<tei:lb/>Macroducts fairly evenly distributed, each about 25 /urn long, the cup about 2-3 times as wide as diameter<tei:lb/>of setal base of a small seta. Microducts in a regular arrangement, each about 6 /xm long, with ampulla, tube<tei:lb/>with inner end swollen, and inner collar. Quinquelocular pores present in single to double rows mainly at<tei:lb/>anterior and posterior edges of segments, each pore with wide sclerotised rim and about half width of a<tei:lb/>diameter of cup of macroduct.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventral surface with normal slender setae of various sizes. Short stiff setae present, often longer than<tei:lb/>small dorsal setae, on margins of head, thorax and anterior abdominal segments. Macroducts of two sizes.<tei:lb/>A larger type, same as on dorsum, around margins. A narrower type present in median to submarginal<tei:lb/>areas. Microducts apparently absent. Disc pores always smaller than dorsal pores, fairly numerous on<tei:lb/>abdomen, where on the posterior segments they have usually 7 loculi, but on the anterior abdominal<tei:lb/>segments, thorax and head they are quinquelocular. Cruciform pores not numerous, in a narrow<tei:lb/>submarginal zone from about 5th abdominal segment forward to head.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>THE BRITISH AND SOME OTHER EUROPEAN ERIOCOCCIDAE</tei:p>

         <tei:p>378 D. J. WILLIAMS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>England: Kent, Thurnham, on IFestuca sp., 8.ix.l920 (E. E. Green) (lectotype, paralectotypes), on<tei:lb/>Avena flavescens, Brachypodiwn sylvaticum, 13.vii.1921 (E. E. Green), Bearsted, on B. sylvaticum,<tei:lb/>30.vii.1925 (E. E. Green); Isle of Wight, on B. sylvaticum, 3.ix.l921 (E. E.          <tei:p>DISCUSSION. The original slide contains four specimens and the specimen selected as lectotype is clearly<tei:lb/>marked, the other three specimens are labelled paralectotypes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This species is easily recognisable by the dorsal quinquelocular pores that have wide rims and are always<tei:lb/>larger than the ventral disc pores.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Green (1923) recorded the species from the Isle of Wight and from Box Hill in Surrey.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriococcus pseudinsignis Green comb. rev.<tei:lb/>(Fig. 14)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriococcus pseudinsignis Green, 1921: 149; Schmutterer, 1952: 407. LECTOTYPE $, ENGLAND</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(BMNH), here designated [examined].<tei:lb/>Nidularia pseudinsignis (Green) Lindinger, 1933: 116.<tei:lb/>Rhizococcus pseudinsignis (Green) Borchsenius, 1949: 354; Danzig, 1962: 845; 1964: 633; Dziedicka &amp;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Koteja, 1971.<tei:lb/>Acanthococcus pseudinsignis (Green) Tereznikova, 1981: 35.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Slide-mounted specimens, elongate-oval, the largest 2-8 mm long and 1-4 mm wide,<tei:lb/>nodulose. Anal lobes conical, about twice as long as wide, sclerotised. Each lobe with an apical seta 280 ju,m<tei:lb/>long; dorsally 1 outer and 2 inner enlarged setae and ventrally 2 slender setae and a suranal seta shorter<tei:lb/>than anal ring setae. Dorsal plate lightly sclerotised, narrow, rounded and slightly nodulose. Anal ring with<tei:lb/>8 setae each about 140 /im long. Antennae 250-300 /AHI long with 7 segments. Frontal tubercle present just<tei:lb/>anterior to basal segment. Legs well developed, slender, hind trochanter -I- femur 230-260 /urn long, hind<tei:lb/>tibia 130-150 /im long, hind tarsus 150-160 /im long, claw 35 /u,m long, curved, with a small denticle near<tei:lb/>apex. Coxa with a few translucent pores on outer half. Labium 100-120 pm long, shorter than clypeolabral<tei:lb/>shield, basal segment with 2 pairs of setae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dorsal surface with a single row of enlarged marginal setae, 28-60 /u,m long, those on head extending to<tei:lb/>submarginal areas. Each seta almost conical but inner edges sometimes slightly concave or convex. On the<tei:lb/>posterior abdominal segments these setae are bluntly pointed, tending to be truncate, but anteriorly they<tei:lb/>are more sharply pointed. Margins of 7th abdominal segment always with 3 setae varying little in length.<tei:lb/>Elsewhere on the dorsum the setae on the head and thorax are conical, often curved, sometimes only<tei:lb/>slightly smaller than the enlarged setae on head, but usually 12-15 /am long. On the posterior abdominal<tei:lb/>segments the setae become shorter and more slender, 6-8 /xm long. Macroducts of one size in moderate<tei:lb/>numbers, fairly evenly distributed, about 25 /im long, the cup only a little narrower than diameter of a setal<tei:lb/>base of marginal seta. Microducts not numerous, about 4 /urn long, with inner end of tube swollen, ampulla<tei:lb/>and internal collar.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventral setae normal in median areas but laterally towards margins they are conical and thick but not so<tei:lb/>large as dorsal marginal setae. Macroducts of two sizes. A larger type, similar to dorsal ducts, around<tei:lb/>margins only. A narrower type in bands across abdominal segments in median areas of head and thorax,<tei:lb/>extending to submargins. Microducts around margins only. Cruciform pores in a narrow submarginal zone<tei:lb/>and in area between clypeolabral shield and antennae. Disc pores, usually with 7 loculi, numerous on<tei:lb/>abdominal segments but not reaching margins, present also in median areas of thorax and around spiracles.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>England: Kent, Thurnham, on Festuca sp., 9.ix.l920 (E. E. Green) (lectotype, paralectotypes); Surrey,<tei:lb/>Hog's Back, on Brachypodium sylvaticum, 21.vii.1922 (E. E. Green); Isle of Wight, Seaview, on B.<tei:lb/>sylvaticum, 3.ix.l921, Alum Bay, on grass, vii.1927 (E. E. Green); Berkshire, onAchillea millefolium,<tei:lb/>Veronica chamaedrys, Alopecurus pratensis, Agrostis sp., Holcus mollis, Deschampsia caespitosa, 1948<tei:lb/>(various dates) (K. Boratynski); Yorkshire, Ickornshaw Moor, x.1958 (A. Smith), Steeton Moor,<tei:lb/>29.viii.l948(A.Smith).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISCUSSION. Green's original slide contains three specimens, one of which is selected as lectotype and<tei:lb/>clearly marked, the other two are labelled paralectotypes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It is sometimes difficult to distinguish this species from R. insignis. At present the main differences are<tei:lb/>the 3 marginal setae on the 7th abdominal segment in R. pseudinsignis compared with 4 in R. insignis. The</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE BRITISH AND SOME OTHER EUROPEAN ERIOCOCCIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>379</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 14 Eriococcus pseudinsignis Green. England, Yorkshire, Ickornshaw Moor, on grass.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>380 D. J. WILLIAMS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>dorsal setae on the head and thorax of/?, pseudinsignis are quite robust and are much longer than the setae<tei:lb/>on the posterior abdominal setae, whereas all the dorsal setae in R. insignis are short and usually slender,<tei:lb/>although those on the head and thorax are often wider than the abdominal setae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>At present both species are here regarded as distinct but intermediates may be found to warrant further<tei:lb/>research.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriococcus spur/us (Modeer)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 15)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coccus ulmi Linnaeus, 1758: 455 (in part).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[Coccus ulmi Linnaeus sensu Linnaeus, 1766: 740. Misidentification.]<tei:lb/>Coccus spurius Modeer, 1778: 43. Syntypes 9, EUROPE (probably lost).<tei:lb/>[Gossyparia ulmi (Linnaeus) sensu Linnaeus, 1766; Signoret, 1875: 21; Schmutterer, 1952: 416. Misiden-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>tifications.]<tei:lb/>Gossyparia spuria (Modeer) Cockerell, 1899ft: 268; Fernald, 1903: 68; Borchsenius, 1949: 330; Danzig,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1964: 632; Tereznikova, 1981: 50.<tei:lb/>Nidularia spuria (Modeer) Lindinger, 1933: 108.<tei:lb/>Eriococcus spurius (Modeer) Ferris, 1955: 164.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult female, when prepared on slides, broadly oval, strongly nodulose, 3-0 mm long and 1-8<tei:lb/>mm wide. Anal lobes well developed, protruding, about twice as long as wide, rounded at apex,<tei:lb/>moderately sclerotised, strongly nodulose with sclerotised teeth, especially on inner margins. Each lobe<tei:lb/>with an apical seta 250 /-im long, dorsally with 2 inner and 1 outer enlarged setae, ventrally with 2 slender<tei:lb/>setae and a pointed suranal seta. Antennae 230-300 u,m long, with 7 segments. Frontal lobes present, just<tei:lb/>anterior to basal segment. Legs normal, well developed. Hind trochanter + femur 160-190 ^im long, hind<tei:lb/>tibia 100-110 /-im long, hind tarsus 130-150 //,m long, the tibia + tarsus always longer than trochanter +<tei:lb/>femur, claw 40 /*,m long, curved, with a denticle near apex. Hind coxa without translucent pores but with<tei:lb/>numerous spicules. Labium 150 /xm long, shorter than clypeolabral shield, basal segment with 2 pairs of<tei:lb/>setae. Dorsal plate well developed, triangular, lightly sclerotised and strongly nodulose. Anal ring with 8<tei:lb/>setae, each about 150 fim long.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dorsal surface with numerous setae, in a regular distribution except on the intersegmental areas of<tei:lb/>thorax where they are absent, but present on mid-line. Setae long and slender with almost straight sides,<tei:lb/>tapering gradually to a blunt point, the largest 60 /x,m long around posterior margins, the smallest about 25<tei:lb/>/Am long. Macrotubular ducts, each about 20 pm long, tapering slightly to orifice, cup wider than a setal<tei:lb/>base, present around margins and submargins, rarely extending to submedian areas, absent entirely on<tei:lb/>median area. Microtubular ducts slender, about 10 /x,m long, with the orifice widely bifid, in an even<tei:lb/>distribution over entire dorsum.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventral surface with normal slender setae in median areas, a few enlarged setae the same as on dorsum,<tei:lb/>around margins, and a few short setae that are slender and stiff on submargins. Macroducts of two main<tei:lb/>sizes. A large duct, same size as on dorsum, on margins, and a narrower duct in transverse rows on<tei:lb/>abdomen and in submedian areas of thorax and head. Microtubular ducts absent. Quinquelocular disc<tei:lb/>pores present across median areas of abdominal segments, on metathorax and near spiracles and in an area<tei:lb/>between antennae and clypeolabral shield. Cruciform pores in submedian zone between first spiracles and<tei:lb/>anterior abdominal segments.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>England: Surrey, Camberley, on Ulmus angustifolia, iv-vii.1916, 18. iv. 1922 (E. E. Green); Farnham, on<tei:lb/>U. angustifolia, x.1915 (C. J. F. Fryer); Woking, on Ulmus sp., vi.1918 (G. C. Gough). France: (ex coll. P.<tei:lb/>Marchal). Germany: Hanover, on U. procera (U. campestris)^vii.l893&gt;. Austria: 'Donau-Auen', on U.<tei:lb/>procera. Czechoslovakia: 'Bohemia', on Ulmus sp. (ex coll. K. Sulc). Turkey: Istanbul, on U. 'campestris<tei:lb/>var. pyramidalis.'</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In addition numerous specimens have been examined from U.S.A.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISCUSSION. Linnaeus (1758) cited Reaumur (1738) but unfortunately referred to two distinct species that<tei:lb/>Reaumur had figured and described. The first refers to pi. 5, figs 5, 6 and this is undoubtedly an armoured<tei:lb/>scale insect discussed on p. 78 as found on a branch of elm. This species is accepted at present as<tei:lb/>Lepidosaphes ulmi (L.). The second species referred to by Linnaeus is illustrated on pi. 7, figs 1-10 and<tei:lb/>discussed by Reaumur on p. 119 as found on a branch of elm. There is no doubt from Reaumur's<tei:lb/>illustrations that this is the species under discussion here. Linnaeus (1766) realising his mistake in 1758,<tei:lb/>listed C. ulmi but referred to Linnaeus (1761) where only the name is mentioned and to Geoffrey (1762) (a<tei:lb/>work not consistently binominal but nevertheless vital) who, apart from giving a short description, refers to</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE BRITISH AND SOME OTHER EUROPEAN ERIOCOCCIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>381</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 15 Eriococcus spurius (Modeer). England, Surrey, Camberley, on f//mi angustifolia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p/>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>382 D. J. WILLIAMS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>the second of Reaumur's species mentioned by Linnaeus (1758). Clearly the listing by Linnaeus (1766) is<tei:lb/>based on a misidentification of the species listed by Linnaeus (1758). All subsequent references to 'ulmi'<tei:lb/>the eriococcid, from Fabricius to the present day must refer to 'sensu Linnaeus, 1766'. Modeer (1778)<tei:lb/>described Coccus spurius and referred to the excellent illustrations of Reaumur (1738: pi. 7, figs 1-10).<tei:lb/>Modeer's name is accepted by all modern workers.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Records from England, listed above, were discussed by Green (1916, 1917) when there were outbreaks<tei:lb/>in Surrey. The insect has not been found since and it is not clear if it has become established but its external<tei:lb/>appearance is so distinctive that it should be easily recognised. Since it was introduced to the U.S.A.,<tei:lb/>probably in the last century, it has caused concern by its frequent large aggregations on elms. The species<tei:lb/>seems to be confined to the genus Ulmus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Macropterous and brachypterous males have been recorded and both forms have been described by Afifi<tei:lb/>(1968).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriococcus f/yim (Schrank) comb. rev.<tei:lb/>(Fig. 16)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coccus thymi Schrank, 1801: 146. Syntypes $ , GERMANY: Kehlheim (probably lost).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriococcus thymi (Schrank) Signoret, 1875: 32; Fernald, 1903: 79.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rhizococcus gnidii Signoret, 1875: 37; Fernald, 1903: 66. Syntypes $, FRANCE: Estrelle Mts, nr Cannes</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(probably lost). Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nidularia gnidii (Signoret) Lindinger, 1933: 116.<tei:lb/>Nidularia thymi (Schrank) Lindinger, 1957: 548.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Body of adult female broadly oval, nodulose, largest specimens 1-9 mm long, 1-35 mm wide.<tei:lb/>Anal lobes well developed, conical, about twice as long as wide at base, heavily sclerotised on venter,<tei:lb/>lightly sclerotised on dorsum. Each lobe with apical seta 280 /u,m long, dorsal surface with 3 enlarged setae,<tei:lb/>ventral surface with 2 slender seta and a suranal seta much shorter than anal ring setae. Dorsal plate<tei:lb/>membranous, rounded, narrow, margin irregular, nodulose. Anal ring with 8 setae each 120 /um long.<tei:lb/>Antennae 170-250 /urn long, with 6 or 7 segments, the 3rd segment often divided. Frontal tubercle present,<tei:lb/>seta-like, just anterior to each basal antennal segment. Legs well developed. Hind trochanter + femur<tei:lb/>140-190 /u,m long, hind tibia 70-100 /urn long, hind tarsus 110-130 /u,m long, claw 30 /urn long, stout, curved<tei:lb/>with a denticle near apex. Ratio of lengths of hind tibia -I- tarsus to hind trochanter + femur 1-18-1-30.<tei:lb/>Hind coxa with a few translucent pores. Labium 130-160 /um long, slightly shorter than clypeolabral shield,<tei:lb/>basal segment with 2 pairs of setae. Spiracles heavily sclerotised, the sclerotisation continuing around the<tei:lb/>atrium in varying degrees.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dorsal surface with enlarged setae of different sizes. The largest around margins 28-55 /u,m long, each<tei:lb/>seta blunt, with sides slightly concave but curved in profile, these setae tending to be longest on posterior<tei:lb/>abdominal segments. Remaining dorsal setae shorter, 12-28 /urn long on the head, thorax and anterior<tei:lb/>abdominal segments, sometimes approaching in length the shorter marginal setae, becoming short, 8 /u,m<tei:lb/>long on the 6th and 7th segments, each seta blunt and curved in profile. Macroducts of one size, each about<tei:lb/>25 /am long, the cup narrower than a setal base of an enlarged seta. Usually a single pair of smaller ducts on<tei:lb/>anal lobe segment. Microducts in moderate numbers, each about 8 /am long, with inner sclerotised<tei:lb/>ampulla, sclerotised tube and collar and with bifid orifice.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventral surface with normal flagellate setae in median areas. Enlarged setae, similar to dorsal setae on<tei:lb/>margins and submargins, varying in size but not as long as dorsal marginal setae. Slender but stiff setae also<tei:lb/>present in a submarginal zone. Macroducts of three sizes. A large type, similar to dorsal ducts, present<tei:lb/>around margins only. An intermediate type, only slightly narrower than the large type, in transverse rows<tei:lb/>on abdominal segments and in median areas of thorax and head. A small type sparse, present singly in<tei:lb/>submedian areas of most abdominal segments. Microducts few, in marginal and submarginal areas.<tei:lb/>Quinquelocular disc pores in transverse bands on abdominal segments but not reaching margins, in median<tei:lb/>areas of thorax and head and around spiracles. Cruciform pores few, in submarginal areas of anterior<tei:lb/>abdominal segments and thorax, and in median areas of thorax and head.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>France: Montpellier, on Thymus vulgaris (Lamiaceae) (det. as E. thymi by V. Signoret), Cannes, on<tei:lb/>Daphne gnidium (Thymelaeaceae) (det. as R. gnidii by V. Signoret), Var, Agay, on D. gnidium, 4.V.1908<tei:lb/>(P. Marchal), Bouc-Bel-Air, on T. vulgaris, v.1932 (L. Goux).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISCUSSION. Although there is no original material available, there seems to be no doubt that the<tei:lb/>specimens examined and identified by Signoret and others identified by Marchal and Goux represent the<tei:lb/>species described by Schrank on Thymus as C. thymi and on Daphne gnidium as R. gnidii. The characters</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE BRITISH AND SOME OTHER EUROPEAN ERIOCOCCIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>383</tei:p>
         <tei:p/>
         <tei:p>Fig. 16 Eriococcus thymi (Schrank). France, Montpellier, on Thymus vulgaris.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>384 D. J. WILLIAMS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>on some specimens of D. gnidium tend to be larger but the specimens themselves are larger and all<tei:lb/>represent the same species. In well-stained specimens the microducts clearly show the bifid orifice but this<tei:lb/>character is difficult to see in some specimens. The illustration is based on specimens from France on<tei:lb/>Thymus vulgaris, identified as E. thy mi by Signoret. Further collecting may show a much wider host-plant<tei:lb/>range.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A record by Hardy (1876) from Watch Law in the north of Northumberland, England, on the roots of<tei:lb/>Thymus serpyllum (probably T. drucei), has never been substantiated.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>KUWANINA Cockerell</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Kuwanina Cockerell, in Fernald, 1903: 121. Type-species: Sphaerococcus parvus Maskell, by original<tei:lb/>designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cockerell intimated that this genus differed from Antonina by the larva having 3 or 4 jointed antennae.<tei:lb/>Antonina belongs to the family Pseudococcidae but Kuwanina clearly belongs to the family Eriococcidae<tei:lb/>where it was accepted by Hoy (1963). Another species, K. hilli Laing, was shown by Williams (1985a) to be<tei:lb/>identical with Chaetococcus australis Froggatt, a mealybug in the family Pseudococcidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The type-species is in need of critical study, outside the scope of this work because the species is not<tei:lb/>native to Britain, having been found only once on imported cherry trees from Japan.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The genus, as represented by specimens at hand from Japan and Britain, seems to be related to<tei:lb/>Cryptococcus in lacking legs and having the third pair replaced by pore-bearing leg-flaps. It differs,<tei:lb/>however, in lacking macroducts. These are replaced by quite large invaginated quinquelocular pores on the<tei:lb/>dorsum and ventral margins. In addition there are smaller quinquelocular pores of two distinct sizes on the<tei:lb/>venter. Microducts are present.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Kosztarab (19686) placed Kuwanina in the Cryptococcidae and Koteja (1974ft), although agreeing that<tei:lb/>the genus was closely related to Cryptococcus, believed that the 'Kuwanina group' may form a distinct<tei:lb/>family. The genus is here regarded as a normal component of the Eriococcidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Kuwanina parva (Maskell)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sphaerococcus parvus Maskell, 1897: 244. Syn types $, JAPAN: on cherry (NZAC).<tei:lb/>Kuwanina parva (Maskell) Cockerell, in Fernald, 1903: 121; Hoy, 1963: 165.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>England: Hertfordshire, St Albans, on dwarf Prunus sp. , imported from Japan, 1914 (C. J. F. Fryer).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISCUSSION. Green stated that examples were found on gnarled branches in a nursery garden where they<tei:lb/>were able to thrive and exist. It is doubtful if the species now exists in Britain.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>NOTEOCOCCUS Hoy</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Noteococcus Hoy, 1962: 164. Type-species: Eriococcus hoheriae Maskell, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hoy erected this genus to accommodate E. hoheriae from New Zealand, a species with large sclerotised<tei:lb/>anal lobes, each with 12 small enlarged setae on the dorsum in addition to the normal pair on the inner<tei:lb/>margins, and with an irregular series of teeth on the venter. Furthermore, apart from the strongly nodulose<tei:lb/>posterior abdominal segments, there is a large rugose plate anterior to the anal lobes on the dorsum. The<tei:lb/>legs are much reduced with the trochanter + femur and the tibia + tarsus fused.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Noteococcus hoheriae (Maskell)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriococcus hoheriae Maskell, 1880: 298. Lectotype $, NEW ZEALAND: Lyttelton (NZAC), designated by</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Deitz &amp; Tocker (1980: 47).<tei:lb/>Noteococcus hoheriae (Maskell) Hoy, 1962: 164.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Specimens are at hand recorded by Green (1925a) from Cornwall, Isles of Stilly, Tresco, on Hoheria<tei:lb/>populnea, iii. 1924 (/. C. F. Fryer), living in the open. Williams (1985ft), reporting on scale insects collected<tei:lb/>at Tresco, stated that the species has not been found since, but in common with other exotic species that<tei:lb/>have been introduced to Tresco, on plant material, the insect may still occur there.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>OVATICOCCUS Kloet</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gymnococcus Douglas, 1888: 150. Type-species: Coccus agavium Douglas, by original designation (see</tei:p>
         <tei:p>below). [Homonym of Gymnococcus Zopf, 1887: 126.]<tei:lb/>Ovaticoccus Kloet, 1944: 86. [Replacement name for Gymnococcus Douglas.]</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE BRITISH AND SOME OTHER EUROPEAN ERIOCOCCIDAE 385</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This genus has been revised by Miller &amp; McKenzie (1967) who included nine North American species, but<tei:lb/>at least two others described from elsewhere have been listed by Boratynski (1958) and accepted by Hoy<tei:lb/>(1963). In a description of the genus, Miller &amp; McKenzie (1967) stated that the anal lobes are absent and<tei:lb/>that the anal ring is without pores, usually in the form of a modified circle with usually 3 pairs of setae.<tei:lb/>Enlarged dorsal setae are present in some species, as are macroducts, microducts and cruciform pores.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The type-species has been redescribed and illustrated by Boratynski (1958) and by Miller &amp; McKenzie<tei:lb/>(1967). An examination of numerous specimens shows that well-developed frontal tubercles are present.<tei:lb/>The genus is closely related to Pseudochermes but differs in possessing an anal ring without pores and in<tei:lb/>possessing cruciform pores.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although O. agavium is not a native British species, it is included here because it was described from the<tei:lb/>Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew (under glass) in 1888 on Agave, and Boratynski (1958) has indicated that he<tei:lb/>had no trouble finding it again in 1956 and 1957. This species is easily separated from Pseudochermes fraxini<tei:lb/>by the presence of numerous enlarged setae in addition to slender lanceolate setae on the dorsum.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Douglas (1888) proposed Gymnococcus conditionally when describing C. agavium and according to the<tei:lb/>International Code of Zoological Nomenclature the name is available from that date.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ovaticoccus agavium (Douglas)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coccus agavium Douglas, 1888: 150. Syntypes 9, ENGLAND: Kew (probably lost, but see below).<tei:lb/>Gymnococcus agavium (Douglas) Cockerell, 1893: 1049; Newstead, 1903: 204; Fernald, 1903: 79;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Borchsenius, 1949: 370; Tereznikova, 1981: 57.<tei:lb/>Ripersia agavium (Douglas) Newstead, 1897: 12.<tei:lb/>Ovaticoccus agavium (Douglas) Kloet, 1944: 86; Boratynski, 1958: 175; Danzig, 1964: 634; Miller &amp;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>McKenzie, 1967: 509.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>England: Surrey, Royal Botanic Gardens (under glass), ii.1888, on leaves of Agave sp. (original<tei:lb/>material), 1956, 1957 (various dates) on A. decipiens, A. francescini, A. parryi (K. L. Boratynski), on A.<tei:lb/>francescini, 26. v. 1964 (5. A. Afifi).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISCUSSION. Boratynski (1958) has indicated that he designated a lectotype from a slide containing<tei:lb/>type-material and that this is in the British Museum (Natural History). This slide is not present in the<tei:lb/>collections and it is doubtful if Boratynski could have done so. There are numerous unmounted specimens<tei:lb/>from Douglas' collection on cards numbered 1052 and 1056. These numbers agree with the information in<tei:lb/>his collection data books and three of these specimens were prepared on a slide by F. Laing. Douglas also<tei:lb/>sent specimens to Newstead who labelled four slides Type lot ex coll. J. W. Douglas'. None of these slides<tei:lb/>represents the original specimens used by Douglas in his description, although they are authentic enough.<tei:lb/>There is no doubt about the identity of the species.<tei:lb/>Afifi (1968) has described and illustrated the alate male.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PSEUDOCHERMES Nitsche</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pseudochermes Nitsche, in Judeich &amp; Nitsche, 1895: 1249. Type-species: Chermes ? fraxini Kaltenbach, by</tei:p>
         <tei:p>original designation.<tei:lb/>Apterococcus Newstead, 1898: 97 [as subgenus of Ripersia Signoret]. Type-species: Eriococcus fraxini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Newstead, by original designation [cited as Ripersia fraxini]. [Synonymised by Cockerell, 18996: 264</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(see below).]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This genus is now widely recognised, even though for many years most workers accepted the synonymy, by<tei:lb/>Cockerell (18996), with Fonscolombia Lichtenstein. Cockerell synonymised both Pseudochermes and<tei:lb/>Apterococcus with Fonscolombia but Fonscolombia is now regarded as an unrecognisable genus in the<tei:lb/>Pseudococcidae, even so the synonymy of Apterococcus with Pseudochermes still stands. Pseudochermes<tei:lb/>has remained monotypic.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult female oval to almost circular, posterior end rounded without recognisable anal lobes<tei:lb/>but with normal apical setae. Anal ring crescentic with 6 setae and pores. Suranal setae normal. Antennae<tei:lb/>6-segmented. Frontal tubercles present. Legs normal, claw with denticle. Labium short, basal segment<tei:lb/>with a single pair of setae. Dorsal setae short, narrow but spine-like. Macroducts present, each with inner<tei:lb/>end cupped, on dorsum and venter. Microducts slender, elongate, with simple orifice. Disc pores<tei:lb/>quinquelocular, on dorsum and venter. Cruciform pores absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>First and second instars with normal legs. Antennae 6-segmented, basal segment with a pair of setae.<tei:lb/>Frontal tubercles present. Anal ring as in adult female but smaller.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>386 D. J. WILLIAMS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISCUSSION. The genus has affinities with Ovaticoccus but differs in possessing an anal ring containing a<tei:lb/>crescentic plate with 6 setae and pores. In Ovaticoccus the anal ring is always without pores. Furthermore<tei:lb/>cruciform pores are present in Ovaticoccus, usually in large numbers, but are absent completely in<tei:lb/>Pseudochermes .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Koteja (1974a) allied this genus to Cryptococcus and included both in the family Cryptococcidae. There<tei:lb/>seems to be no reason for accepting this action.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pseudochermes fraxini (Kaltenbach)<tei:lb/>(Figs 17, 18)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Chermes (?) fraxini Kaltenbach, 1860: 259; 1974: 433. Syntypes &lt;j&gt;, GERMANY (probably lost).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriococcus fraxini Newstead, 1891: 165. LECTOTYPE $, ENGLAND (BMNH), here designated [ex-<tei:lb/>amined]. [Synonymised by Judeich &amp; Nitsche, 1895: 1249.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ripersia fraxini (Newstead) Newstead, 1892: 147.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coccus fraxini (Kaltenbach) Judeich &amp; Nitsche, 1895: 1247.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pseudochermes fraxini (Kaltenbach) Judeich &amp; Nitsche, 1895: 1249; Borchsenius, 1949: 365; Danzig, 1964:<tei:lb/>634; Tereznikova, 1981: 59.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fonscolombia fraxini (Kaltenbach) Cockerell, 1899ft: 264; Fernald, 1903: 114; Schmutterer, 1952: 418.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ripersia (Apterococcus) fraxini (Newstead) Newstead, 1898: 97.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Apterococcus fraxini (Newstead) Newstead, 1903: 210.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Young adult female (Fig. 17) on microscope slide oval, 1-15 mm long, 0-9 mm wide, but<tei:lb/>mature adult female sometimes almost circular, membranous, posterior end rounded, anal lobes not<tei:lb/>developed but position of each lobe with an apical seta 60 /urn long. Anal ring in form of crescentic<tei:lb/>sclerotised plate 30 pm wide, with a few pores and 6 setae, each about 30 ju,m long, blunt and stiff, situated<tei:lb/>on ventral surface even in young adult females. Suranal setae present just anterior to anal ring, shorter than<tei:lb/>anal ring setae. Antennae 100-110 /im long, with 6 segments. Frontal tubercles present just anterior to<tei:lb/>basal antennal segment. Legs small but well developed. Hind trochanter + femur 70-75 /itn long, hind tibia<tei:lb/>3540 /u,m long, hind tarsus 30-35 /-im long, claw 16 /n,m long, curved, with a denticle near apex. Ratio of<tei:lb/>lengths of hind tibia + tarsus to hind trochanter + femur 0-90-1-05. Hind coxa noticeably larger than<tei:lb/>anterior coxae, with a few large translucent pores. Labium 50-60 /-im long, much smaller than clypeolabral<tei:lb/>shield; basal segment with a single pair of minute setae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dorsal surface with narrow conical setae on 7th and anal lobe segments, each about 20 /xm long and<tei:lb/>usually shorter than anal ring setae. Anteriorly the setae are shorter and more slender, but stiff, 8 /AHI long.<tei:lb/>Macroducts fairly numerous, in an even distribution, each about 20 /im long, tapering to narrow orifice, the<tei:lb/>cup wider than a setal base of largest setae. Microducts present, not numerous, tending to be in rows across<tei:lb/>the segments, each duct filiform, about 4 /im long with a small sclerotised ampulla. Quinquelocular disc<tei:lb/>pores present in more or less single rows at posterior edges of segments.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventral surface with slender setae only slightly longer than dorsal setae, except on head where they are<tei:lb/>much longer. Macroducts of two sizes. A larger type, same as on dorsum, around margins only except on<tei:lb/>thorax near spiracles where they also occupy the submarginal areas. A narrower duct each with sclerotised<tei:lb/>cup and filiform tube, tapering to a minute orifice, sparse, on abdominal segments only. Microducts, same<tei:lb/>as on dorsum, few, on margins. Quinquelocular disc pores not numerous on head and thorax but more<tei:lb/>numerous on abdomen.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Second instar female (Fig. 18B), oval, similar in shape to young adult female but smaller. Anal lobes<tei:lb/>only slightly produced, each with an apical seta 40 fjun long, and suranal setae minute. Anal ring 20 /^m<tei:lb/>wide, crescentic, as in adult female situated at apex on venter, with 6 setae. Antennae 6-segmented, 75 /Am<tei:lb/>long. Frontal tubercles present. Legs similar in shape to those of adult female but all coxae approximately<tei:lb/>same size. Hind trochanter + femur 48 /nm long, hind tibia 25 /mi long, hind tarsus 25 /urn long, claw 12 /AHI<tei:lb/>long. Labium 45 /xm long, basal segment with a single pair of setae. Dorsal surface with thick truncate<tei:lb/>setae, 12 /4m long, on posterior segments, these longer than anal ring setae. Anteriorly the setae become<tei:lb/>shorter and more slender, but remain stiff. Macroducts in more or less single rows across the segments,<tei:lb/>each duct similar in shape to those of adult female but the cup narrower. Microducts as in adult, not<tei:lb/>numerous. Quinquelocular pores smaller than in adult, in single rows at posterior edges of segments.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ventral surface with slender setae, usually shorter than on dorsum except for a few long setae on head.<tei:lb/>Macroducts of one size as on dorsum, on head and thoracic margins and extending almost to spiracles.<tei:lb/>Microducts few on margins only. Quinquelocular disc pores not numerous, in single rows on abdominal<tei:lb/>segments and present on head and thorax but absent in median area of thorax.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>First instar (Fig. 18A) oval, 300 /urn long, 180 /tm wide, abdomen tapering. Anal lobes poorly developed,<tei:lb/>each with an apical seta 35 /im long. Anal ring as in second instar and adult female but 16 /xm wide, with 6</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE BRITISH AND SOME OTHER EUROPEAN ERIOCOCCIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>387</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 17 Pseudochermesfraxini (Kaltenbach). Berkshire, Cookham, on Fraxinus excelsior.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>388</tei:p>
         <tei:p>D. J. WILLIAMS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>V</tei:p>
         <tei:p>i-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>\<tei:lb/>1-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>t</tei:p>
         <tei:p>V</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B</tei:p>
         <tei:p>D.J.W.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 18 Pseudochermes fraxini (Kaltenbach). (A) First instar. (B) Second instar female.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE BRITISH AND SOME OTHER EUROPEAN ERIOCOCCIDAE 389</tei:p>
         <tei:p>setae. Antennae 65 ^tm long, with 6 segments. Frontal tubercles present. Legs normal, hind trochanter +<tei:lb/>femur 35 /xm long, hind tibia 35 /u,m long, hind tarsus 20 /ion long. Claw curved, 10 /urn long, with a minute<tei:lb/>[denticle near apex. Labium 30 /urn long, basal segment with a pair of setae. Dorsal surface with short<tei:lb/>truncate setae, tending to be cylindrical, tapering only slightly, those on abdomen the largest and thickest,<tei:lb/>about 8 fjLm long, becoming shorter anteriorly to head where they are 5 fjun long, all setae thicker than anal<tei:lb/>[ring setae. Microducts sparse, as in later instars. Ventral surface with slender setae, shorter than dorsal<tei:lb/>setae except for a few long setae on head. Ventral ducts absent. Quinquelocular pores smaller than in later<tei:lb/>instars, represented usually by a pair on each of 4th to 7th segments and singly next to openings of spiracles.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED (all on Fraxinus excelsior unless stated otherwise)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>England: Berkshire, Silwood Park, F. excelsior and Populus tremula (Salicaceae), 29. vi. 1966 (K. L.<tei:lb/>\Boratynski), Cookham, 5.viii.l972, 8.ix.l972, ll.iii.1973, ll.viii.1983 (D. J. Williams); Cheshire, Ince,<tei:lb/>[viii.1890 (R. Newstead) (lectotype, paralectotypes), Chester, 1895, ll.xi.1895 (R. Newstead); Devon,<tei:lb/>Sidmouth, 26.vi.1963; Gloucestershire, Cheltenham, viii.1973 (D. J. Williams); Hampshire, Bentley,<tei:lb/>Il8.iv.1969 (C. I. Carter), Exbury, viii.1974; Kent, Bearsted, vii.1913 (E. E. Green); Leicestershire,<tei:lb/>[Loughborough, 8.xi.l938 (A. Roebuck); London, Buckingham Palace Gardens, 11.x. 1963 (K. L. Bora-<tei:lb/>tynski); Northumberland, Riding Mill, S.x.1950 (D. J. Williams); Oxfordshire, Goring, 25.ii.1914 (E. E.<tei:lb/>Green); Somerset, Bath, Ashrey Gullywood, 24.ii.1978; Surrey, Frimley, 23.V.1921 (E. E. Green),<tei:lb/>Wisley, on Syringa sp., 1958, 6.vii.l983 (D. J. Williams), Woking, 1914, vii.1915 (E. E. Green); Yorkshire,<tei:lb/>Adel, 2.vii.l963 (D. J. Williams). Wales (N.): 1976. Belgium: intercepted in England, 31.U967 (5. H.<tei:lb/>Blore). Hungary: Galgamocsa, 26.iv.1981 (Nagy).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISCUSSION. Newstead's single original slide of Eriococcus fraxini contains nine whole specimens and a few<tei:lb/>| pieces. The lectotype selected is clearly marked and the remaining eight whole specimens are labelled<tei:lb/>paralectotypes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Afifi (1968) has described and illustrated the adult male of this species. It is always minute, wingless and<tei:lb/>degenerate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Apart from incursions into Iran, this species is European where its favourite host-plant is Fraxinus<tei:lb/>\excelsior, but it is known on other species of Fraxinus. It is often found in enormous numbers in the crevices<tei:lb/>of the bark. The record on Syringa is not surprising because this genus and Fraxinus both belong to the<tei:lb/>I family Oleaceae. Furthermore, Syringa has been mentioned from Germany by Lindinger (1938) who also<tei:lb/>(listed Sorbus sp. S. aucuparia (as Pirus aucuparia) was previously listed by Lindinger (1912). The record on<tei:lb/>Populus tremula is based on specimens collected at the same time as others on F. excelsior. There seems to<tei:lb/>be every reason that the insects were feeding on Populus and that P. fraxini may yet be found on other<tei:lb/>(host-plants.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The species is probably widespread in Britain on ash. Harrison (1944) recorded it from Inverarish in the<tei:lb/>(Isle of Raasay, Scotland.</tei:p>

         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History)<tei:lb/>Australian Mealybugs</tei:p>
         <tei:p>D. J. Williams</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mealybugs, or Pseudococcoidea, represent one of about 20 families currently recognized as<tei:lb/>scale insects of the superfamily Coccoidea, and are responsible for a significant proportion of<tei:lb/>insect-related crop damage in Australia. Although they have natural predators, a lack of<tei:lb/>authoritative systematic literature on the group has made identification a haphazard business,<tei:lb/>and selection of the appropriate natural enemy difficult. Biological methods of controlling<tei:lb/>these pests, therefore, have not been as fully exploited as they might have been.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This work should help this situation by providing an authoritative identification guide and<tei:lb/>comprehensive review of current knowledge on the biology of the 196 species of Mealybugs<tei:lb/>covered. It will fill the existing gap on the classification of these insects, and in enabling<tei:lb/>entomologists and agriculturalists to correctly identify and classify specimens, will promote the<tei:lb/>use of biological control.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1985 viii + 43 Ipp, 177 line illustrations 0565009532 40</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>

         <tei:p>By M. G. Fitton</tei:p>

         <tei:p>(Ichneumonidae)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>By I. D. Gauld</tei:p>
